Restaurants, tasting rooms, pubs, and other public-facing businesses may choose to reopenâ€”but may do so with physical distancing restrictions, shortened hours, and capacity limits. BrowserTitle: Top Wineries & Tasting Rooms in Willamette Valley's Oregon Wine Country
HeaderText: Wine Tasting & Tours in the Willamette Valley
ContentText:
With more than 550 of Oregon’s wineries calling the Willamette Valley home, it’s easy to find one to suit your taste. Whether you’re in the mood for Pinot noir or Pinot gris, experiencing the ambiance of a hip, metropolitan winery or admiring the legacy of a small town vineyard pioneer, you’ll find it in the Willamette Valley. 

"
MetaDescription: A tour of the Oregon Wine Country is sure to satisfy your inner  sommelier. Try our Willamette Valley Winery Map explorer and find the perfect varietal

BrowserTitle: Oregon Wine Country: Wineries & Wine Tasting in the Willamette Valley
HeaderText: Discover the Wines of the Willamette Valley
ContentText:
Situated only a few miles from the hustle and bustle of Portland, the Willamette Valley seems like a world away – back roads beckon visitors to explore the lush rolling hills, historic communities and farmer’s markets that showcase the region’s local produce. With a temperate climate and rich soils, the Willamette Valley is the perfect growing environment for Pinot noir, Pinot gris and Chardonnay grapes. Utilizing the valley’s rich natural resources, the Willamette Valley is host to internationally acclaimed wineries whose winemakers set themselves apart through collaboration, sustainability leadership and passionate winemaking.

When you spend time winding your way through Oregon's Wine Country you quickly realize it's easy to get a bit sidetracked by all there is to see and do in the Willamette Valley. Discover restaurants, breweries, places to stay and more in our visitors guide. Use our map explorer and wine pages to find go-to destinations and build your own customized trip.

If it is a memorable day trip you are looking for
PageType: there are enough fields of flowers
ParentPage: hot springs
Status: and scenic waterfalls to fill a month of Sunday drives. Rarely is there a weekend without a rodeo
IssuuCode: or a craft brew fest. And there are plenty of hotels
AccountCatIDForListings:
and farm stays.

If you are researching wineries in a specific area view our wine resources page for additional information from our winery partners. 

Once you get to the Willamette Valley
SortOrder:
the hard part isn’t finding something to do. It’s finding a reason to tell your friends back home that you aren’t leaving.

"

BrowserTitle: Get inspired for your next vacation to Oregon Wine Country in the Willamette Valley
HeaderText: Stories to Inspire Your Next Vacation
ContentText:
When you visit Oregon Wine Country, you’re stepping into one of the most storied regions in all of America. Tales of the fertile Willamette Valley—a green patch of paradise where anything and everything would grow-- lured thousands of dreamers across the Oregon Trail to the promised land at the end of journey.

Today, pioneers trek here for different reasons: the unmatched flavors of Oregon Pinot noir; the booming local food culture that results in farm-to-table dininglike no other; the forests and rivers and meadows that beckon with adventure.

Take a moment to explore some of our favorite Oregon Wine Country stories
PageType:
and get inspired to create a story of your own.

"

BrowserTitle: Willamette Valley Events: Experience Oregon Wine Country's Bounty
MetaDescription: Willamette Valley is full of events and festivals year round. Unique opportunities to immerse yourself in wine, brews and bounty of Oregon Wine Country. From the Oregon Truffle Festival, to the Wooden shoe Tulip Festival to the Oregon Country Fair. Discover the valley with our Event Calendar.

ContentText:
The Oregon Scenic Bikeways Program is celebrating 10 years of beautiful bike routes
“It’s been a fantastic first 10 years for the program,” said Lisa Sumption, director, Oregon Parks and Recreation Department (OPRD). “We are proud of the work we’ve done and look forward to collaborating with our partners to promote more routes that inspire people to experience Oregon’s natural and cultural beauty by bicycle.”
â€¨Sumption is among the guest speakers for the event; remarks will begin at noon.â€¨The Scenic Bikeways Program launched in 2009 and is a partnership between OPRD, Oregon Department of Transportation, Travel Oregon and Cycle Oregon. It is the first and only program of its kind in the United States.
â€¨Since 2009, OPRD has designated 17 Scenic Bikeways throughout Oregon, covering 1,253 miles.


Scenic Bikeways are nominated by local communities and designated based on scenic quality, road conditions and general riding enjoyment. Route difficulties vary—some are beginner friendly while others will challenge veteran riders—and each passes a through a distinct Oregon landscape.

â€¨Over the last decade, Scenic Bikeways have proven to be a boon for local communities: a study published by Travel Oregon found that in 2014, Scenic Bikeway cyclists spent $6.9 million on accommodations and food services and $5.3 million on retail, supporting over 150 local community jobs with earnings of approximately $3.4 million.


Download the Oregon Scenic Bikeways guide here.


Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeways

Covered Bridges Scenic Bikeway
Difficulty: Mild | Length: 36 Miles

Willamette Valley

The Covered Bridges Scenic Bikeway is a family-friendly ride from a historic downtown through six historic covered bridges to a picturesque lake.

Best season: Year-round


Safety Tips
Please be aware that the Bikeway information here is advisory only. You assume all risks as far as the quality and accuracy of the information; in other words
PageType: you’re agreeing to use it at your own risk. Scenic Bikeway routes include roads with car and truck traffic
PageLevel: and are for cyclists that are comfortable riding in some amount of traffic. Cyclists must obey the rules of the road. For car-free riding
PageSectionID:
check out the Banks-Vernonia State Trail on the Tualatin Valley Bikeway and the Row River Trail section of the Covered Bridges Bikeway.

A must-know: In Oregon
ParentPage:
a bicycle is legally considered a vehicle (and the same laws apply). Riding with the direction of traffic is the law; it’s also the best way to be seen by motorists.

To demonstrate the best riding etiquette and promote good relations with motorists
Status: please ride single-file. Riding side-by-side is legal
InsertCode:
but only if doing so does not impede traffic. Be aware that many rural roads are used daily for commerce; there’s a good chance you’ll encounter large trucks carrying oversized loads.

Never forget about drivers’ blind spots — especially when the vehicle is turning right. If you’re going straight at an intersection with stopped vehicles
IssuuCode: pull in behind the first stopped vehicle in the lane and wait your turn to go
HideFromNav:
as if you were a motorist.

All bicycle riders in Oregon under 16 must wear a helmet.

For more information on riding safely and legally in Oregon
DisplayListings:
visit the Oregon Department of Transportation.

BrowserTitle: Willamette Valley Visitor Association: Official Tourism Information
ContentText:
The Willamette Valley Visitors Association’s (WVVA) mission is to build awareness for the Willamette Valley as a premier year-round travel destination through marketing, sales and destination development. Also, serve as the regional destination marketing organization for the Willamette Valley while driving visitor expenditures and economic impact to all parts of the region.that supports travel and tourism in Oregon’s Willamette Valley. Comprised of six visitors associations, the Willamette Valley Visitors Association works to maintain the Willamette Valley as Oregon’s premier wine destination, while highlighting the culture and natural resources of the region.

Located in the Travel Salem Visitors Center located at: 

388 State St. Ste 100 Salem, OR 97301

Monday-Friday, 9:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m.
Closed on Saturday, Sunday, and major holidays

BrowserTitle: Mid-Project Grant Report
ContentText:
The Mid-Project report is designed to give us an idea of your efforts to date. Please review your grant agreement for the complete description of your approved grant project and make sure your report addresses all of the components. You must have all your supporting documents ready to attach on the next page. Documents include: 

  • Transaction Report and Budget Update
  • Print collateral for review 
  • Other Project Documents 

Please direct questions to Tori Middelstadt, tori@oregonwinecountry.org or call 503.881.4442.

BrowserTitle: Wildlife in Oregon - See Elk and other fauna this summer in Mt. Hood
HeaderText: Elk at Rosse Posse in Mollalla
ContentText:
Rosse Posse Acres in Molalla is a unique attraction along the Molalla County Farm Loop in Oregon’s Mt. Hood Territory. More than a petting zoo, this ranch is a 52-acre working elk farm renowned for giving people the chance to see these massive animals face-to-face, not to mention beautiful views of the surrounding countryside and Mt. Hood.

Established in 2005, Rosse Posse Acres has 70 head of elk on the property, including both bulls and cows. Other animals include pygmy goats and miniature donkeys, chickens, and the ever popular \Tucker\" the wallaby.

Guided tours of the ranch are both fun and informative. They start with an educational talk at the barn that highlights the differences between antlers and horns. The expert
PageType:
or \"elkspert\" also shows off elk ivory teeth while they pass around examples of cow and bull teeth as well as various examples of antlers.

After the talk
PageLevel: guests head out to the handling facility
PageSectionID: known as \"Elkatraz\" before getting some face time with the massive animals. One of the handlers calls the elk over by shouting \"candy\" which is actually whole grain oats. Make sure you have your camera handy
ParentPage: as this is a great photo opportunity. You’ll have the chance to not only come away with some amazing pictures
Status:
but see the beautiful creatures and their behavior closer than most anyone else you know.

After getting some quality time with the elk
InsertCode: you’ll get the chance to play with the animals in the petting zoo. Once you’ve had your fill in the petting zoo
IssuuCode:
head on over to the gift shop for some great elk-related items to commemorate your trip.

Tours are scheduled by appointments
HideFromNav: which can be made by calling (503) 829-7107 or emailing. They cost only $5 per person and are perfect activities for families or even large family reunions
DisplayListings:
making Rosse Posse Acres a perfect addition to the Willamette Valley’s 7 Food and Farm Wonders.

(Photo provided by: Rosse Posse Acres)

"

BrowserTitle: Grant Program FAQs
ContentText:
To ensure you are equipped to submit a grant application we have compiled a list of frequently asked questions. Please contact us with any additional questions, so we can answer them and add them to this page as a resource for others.

Q: How do I apply for a Willamette Valley Visitors Association grant?

A: The online application is available from October 21, 2019 - December 5, 2019 at 5pm. You must have access to the internet and be able to upload files in order to complete the application. The next WVVA Grant application will open in Fall/Winter 2020 if funds are available.

Q: Once I start the application, will I be able to save my work and return at another time?

A: No. The form is designed to be completed in one sitting. We have provided all the form questions ahead of time so you can prepare your answers and copy and paste into the form if desired. Don’t forget to have your budget spreadsheet prepared. You will attach the the required supporting documents to this form. A checklist of required documents has been provided in the grant guidelines.

Q: Can I view the application questions before I access the actual application?  A: Yes. We encourage you to download the application questions before you begin the application so you can have everything ready to go. Enlisting a proof-reader to review your answers before you complete the application is also highly recommended. Download the application questions here and Required Budget Template.

Q: Does wine need to be featured in my grant project?

A: No
PageType: wine does not need to be a feature in a grant project. The Wine+ messaging refers to how the Willamette Valley Visitors Association markets the region. We recognize that wine is the iconic feature most non-oregonians relate to the valley. However
PageLevel: we message with the ‘plus’ message that the Willamette Valley also has outdoor activities
ParentPage: farms etc. to experience. Your business needs to fall into at least one of the plus pillars of outdoors
HideFromNav:
culture (or wine).

Q: Can in-kind donations reduce the amount of my cash match?

A: No
DisplayListings: the 10% cash match to your ask amount is required. However
AccountCatIDForListings:
in-kind donations may lower the amount you need to ask for which can lower your cash requirement.

Q: Who should I contact if I have additional questions? 

A: Reach out to Tori Middelstadt
SortOrder:
WVVA Development & Industry Relations Manager 503.881.4442 or tori@oregonwinecountry.org.

"
CreationDate: Find answers to most common Willamette Valley Visitors Association Competitive Grant program questions here. FAQs and answers for our grant program.

Willamette Valley Fact Sheet

Our valley follows the Willamette River north to south for more than 150 miles from the Mt. Hood Territory east of Portland to just south of Eugene. It is a quilt of cities and towns that offer unique experiences for everyone
Status: from rural enclaves that pop up between expanses of farms and fields
InsertCode: to serene college towns with historic inns and classic main streets
IssuuCode: to cities alive with culture and heritage
HideFromNav:
including the state capital of Salem.

  • The Willamette Valley is 150 miles long and up to 60 miles wide making it Oregon’s largest AVA
  • Planted Area: 19
AccountCatIDForListings:
800 ha)
  • Predominant Soils: Marine sedimentary
PageLogo: Riesling
FeatureBlockTitle1:
Pinot blanc
  • The Willamette Valley has the largest concentration of wineries and vineyards in Oregon and includes six appellations within its borders: Chehalem Mountains
PartnerTitle:
Ribbon Ridge and Yamhill-Carlton.

BrowserTitle: Plan your next vacation in Oregon's Canby, Molalla and Willsonville area of Mt. Hood
ContentText:
Any time of the year, everywhere you look - Oregon's Mt. Hood Territory never ceases to amaze. Rich in history, food straight from the farm and endless recreational possibilities, each day offers a new experience, whether you're outdoors or indoors.

The region’s diverse lodging will cater to your every need
PageType:
with everything from independent hotels to intimate B&Bs.

While Oregon’s Mt. Hood Territory is full of nature experiences
PageLevel:
you won’t want to miss its regional cuisine featuring local specialties. Find out more about the adventures awaiting you at popular recreation sites and activities and arts and culture locations.

Don't forget to stop at local wineries just waiting to serve you.

BrowserTitle: McMinnville, Newberg and Dundee Oregon
ContentText:
Made up of a collection of small towns that dot the verdant rolling hills, Oregon's Yamhill Valley is brimming with opportunities to experience the good life. You'll find world-class wineries boasting the finest Pinot Noir in the U.S., but Pinot gris, Pinot blanc, Chardonnay, Riesling and Gewürztraminer are equally at home here.    

Whether you stop off in McMinnville
ParentPage: or Dayton you're sure to find delicious restaurants
Status: a sea of award-winning wineries and adventures like helicopter or equestrian wine tours
InsertCode: and hot air balloon rides. Bring the family to the Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum to explore the universe and ride a waterslide out of an airplane. No matter how old you are
IssuuCode:
Yamhill Valley has unique experiences and adventures waiting for you.

"
SEOPaidSearch: Yamhill County and the communities of Dundee, McMinville, Carlton and Dayton are known for having some of Oregon's most popular wineries. Known for Pinot Noir, chardonnay and Pinot Gris wines are found throughout.

Indoor entertainment venues are currently permitted to operate at 50% capacity. Any visit should be planned with caution and respect for our communities.

BrowserTitle: Make Salem your next vacation destination
ContentText: Pack your suitcase – but leave your suit behind. Salem may be the legislative heart of Oregon, but you won’t need a suit and tie to experience the many award-winning wineries
PageLevel:
cultural treasures and outdoor adventures you’ll find here.

Named a Heritage All-Star Community in 2013
PageSectionID: Salem offers an eclectic mix of old and new. When you visit the Salem area
ParentPage: you’ll find exquisite natural wonders and outdoor attractions. You can walk behind a waterfall
Status: hike through an old growth forest
InsertCode:
or cycle past vineyards and orchards.

Salem boasts a dynamic food and beverage scene. Dozens of boutique wineries abound in the area
IssuuCode: along with a growing craft beer and hard cider scene. Enjoy delicious
HideFromNav: locally sourced cuisine at an area restaurant
DisplayListings: pick up fresh produce at a farmer’s market
AccountCatIDForListings:
or grab gourmet products from one of the community’s many artisan food producers.

When you’re ready to settle down for the night
SortOrder: Salem offers a wide array of lodging options - from modern hotels to charming bed and breakfasts
FeatureChildPages:
offering an assortment of amenities.

BrowserTitle: Get your shopping fix in Northern Oregon
HeaderText: Shopping Trails in Oregon's Willamette Valley
ContentText:
Use these suggestions as multi-day or single-day shopping, sipping and supping inspirations. Oregon Wine Country’s locally-owned boutiques, gourmet food shops, and artisans markets are full of one-of-a-kind treasures.
 
In addition to shopping, you’ll find inspiration for places to stay, spa experiences, and memorable Oregon Wine Country restaurants.
 
Start with the South Willamette Shopping Trail and explore the quirky college towns of Corvallis and Eugene.

"

BrowserTitle: Shops, stores and boutiques in near Portland, Or
ContentText:
Shop


Fanciful

Tollen Farm serves up uncommon treasures for your own home and garden
PageType:
including items ranging from French Milled Soap to eclectic garden art to handcrafted jewelry. Farm owner Tonie Tollen finds unusual items during her off-season travels and brings them back to Tollen Farm for you.

Spurs Trading Company in Molalla ponies up items from cowgirl bling to boots that are at equally at home on the range or the ballroom. "Spurs" stocks enough stylish Western wear to outfit your own rodeo.

Union Block Marketplace in Newberg features more than 30 shops under one roof. Antique and eclectic articles that reflect the individual shop owners' palate making it possible to find something for everyone.

Fine

Lake View Village encourages you to indulge in Lake Oswego's upscale boutique shopping. A few top names that you'll find here include retailers CC MacKenzie
ParentPage: Meringue
HideFromNav:
Sur La Table and U.

Dapper Frog in Dundee is temptingly located next to the Ponzi Wine Bar. Dip into your flight of wine then hop over to the Dapper Frog
DisplayListings: where flights of fancy are given free reign. Whimsical dining ware
AccountCatIDForListings:
garden art and sculptures are all part and parcel of the art collectibles. An amusing and amazing shopping stop.

Stay

Fanciful

Rosse Posse Acres B&B is a working Elk Farm with 80+ head of elk
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
and B&B.

The 1905-era Hotel Oregon is as quirky as each of her sister McMenamin properties. Hotel Oregon offers four different room types for guests
DisplayArticles: with European-style rooms. Step right outside the door of Hotel Oregon to stroll Third Street
PageLogo:
with its numerous boutiques and bookstores.

Fine

Hilton Garden Inn Reconnect with family and friends and enjoy spacious guestrooms
FeatureBlockTitle1: free wifi and thoughtful amenities. Newly renovated
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
fitness center and complimentary covered parking. Favorite restaurants located nearby.

Black Walnut Inn & Vineyard is set amid vineyards
PartnerTitle: orchards and acres of forest. Newly constructed and reminiscent of a classic Tuscan villa
PartnerText: the inn is filled with modern art and furnished with eye-catching antiques
DisplayPartnerColumns:
old world details.

Put Your Feet Up

The Allison Inn & Spa pampers you with services designed to provide the ultimate in comfort and relaxation. With 15
YoutubeVideoID: wellness and a touch of indulgence
VideoTitle1: neither stress nor worry can survive this environment. For appointments at The Allison Spa
VideoTitle2:
please phone: 503-554-2524.

Wine

Fanciful

Quailhurst Vineyard Estate trots out distinctive wines that combine superior French winemaking traditions with the finest French wine grapes grown in mineral rich volcanic "Jory" soil. Nestled on 35 acre estate
MetaDescription:
this spectacular property offers the unique pairing of wine and horse dressage. Open by appointment.

Barrel Fence Cellars tasting room affords stunning views of the Willamette Valley to accompany sumptuous wine. Open Saturday and Sunday from Memorial Day through Thanksgiving weekend. Artifacts from the early days of the Oregon wine industry are also on display.

Fine

Oswego Hills Winery is situated on a historic farm
SEOTags:
nestled in the hills between Lake Oswego and West Linn. This family owned and operated vineyard and winery specialize in handcrafted premium quality wines.

Willakenzie Estate is open daily year-round. Their new tasting room befits a grand estate of this size
SeoNotes: but if you find you just can't live without a few more bottles of the award-winning pinot after you return home
SEOStatus:
shipping is also offered to an impressive number of states.

Dine

Fanciful

Dar Essalaam is tucked away in an unassuming shopping center in Oregon Horse Country. The family-owned eatery specializes in Moroccan Cuisine
ProposedHeaderText:
while the owners have created an ambience that showcases the rich decor of North Africa.

Harvest Fresh is perfect for lunch on the run. This little organic-centric deli is able to turn around a tasty sandwich
ProposedBrowserTitle:
homemade soup or a killer latte in just a few minutes.

Fine

Fivespice Pan-Asian restaurant features traditional dishes from Thailand
ContentType:
and Malaysia made with sustainable ingredients grown in the NW. Indoor and outdoor dining with fireplace and heaters for year-round on the deck dining.

Joel Palmer House fulfills the family's lifelong desire to combine great mushroom hunting with fine wine. The Joel Palmer House is on the National as well as Oregon Historic Register. Using many locally produced greens
AuthorUserID: a number of which come from their own culinary garden
PublishDate:
seasonal dishes take center stage in classic surroundings.

Photographs courtesy Oregon's Mt. Hood Territory
ExpirationDate:
Travel Yamhill Valley.

BrowserTitle: Experience Seasonal Bounty in the Yamhill Valley
HeaderText: Experience Seasonal Bounty in the Yamhill Valley
ContentText: Yamhill County is the perfect place to experience Oregon's farm to table excellence; no other county in Oregon boasts a greater concentration of agricultural bounty and culinary craftsmen. Now in its third year
PageType: Bounty of the County on Sept. 8 celebrates the trifecta of fervent farmers
PageSectionID:
and masterful chefs. 

Enjoy this spectacular feast on a warm summer evening in the picturesque Dundee Hills. In addition to a memorable meal
ParentPage: celebrants will be treated to fabulous live Oregonian musicians. To complete the evening's experience
Status: an old-fashioned country store (set up just for the evening) offers locally produced gourmet items for purchase. And don't miss the Wall of Wine
InsertCode:
where each participant can take home great wine at a great price. Be sure to examine the VIP tours that are happening in concert with Bounty of the County to fully immerse yourself! 

The event is held at Sokol Blosser Winery in Dayton. Purchase tickets at Yamhillenrichmentsociety.org

If a more active harvest celebration is what you have in mind
IssuuCode: visit Carlton for the Carlton Crush Harvest Festival: a grape-stomping competition
DisplayListings:
and watermelon-eating competition give you plenty of ways to immerse yourself in harvest-time fun.

The Carlton Crush is an entire day of harvest activities
AccountCatIDForListings: beginning at 10 a.m. on Saturday
SortOrder: Sept. 14 and running until 6 p.m. All events
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: are free and take place in downtown Carlton
DisplayArticles: a small town full of the best wine and food that Oregon has to offer. There will be live music
PageLogo: helicopter rides
FeatureBlockTitle2:
and games for kids.

For more information

BrowserTitle: Dig Deeper into Yamhill Valley's Food and Wine Culture
HeaderText: Dig Deeper into Yamhill Valley's Food and Wine Culture
ContentText: The Yamhill area has been called one of the \"foodiest\" places in the country
PageType: and every winter when grape harvest is complete
PageLevel:
the valley's chefs and winemakers let their passions run wild during \"Dig Our Valley.\" This annual wintertime exploration of all things food and wine invites visitors to dig deeper into the Yamhill Valley's culinary riches.

In January
PageSectionID: food is the focus: it’s \"Epicurean Excursion month\". Visitors to Yamhill during January can taste limited-time food and wine pairings focused on seasonal local ingredients. At The Joel Palmer House
ParentPage: the Dayton restaurant famous for its foraged wild mushrooms
Status:
chef Chris Czarnecki has created a three-course \"Mushroom Sunshine\" menu.

February is \"Oenophile’s Outings\" month
InsertCode: when wine-lovers are invited to relax in cozy tasting rooms and enjoy personal visits with winemakers. In March
IssuuCode: the focus is on active adventures that travelers of all ages can enjoy. The \"Family Forays\" this month include explorations of biking trails
AccountCatIDForListings: as winter draws to a close
SortOrder: the expeditions shift with the seasons. During \"Agriculture Adventures\" in April
FeatureChildPages:
visitors can learn from the Yamhill Valley’s numerous small and organic farmers about how the valley’s delicious specialty ingredients are grown.

To learn more about Dig Our Valley and take advantage of the special food and wine pairings
PageLogo: and lodging deals
FeatureBlockTitle2:
or e-mail info@travelyamhillvalley.org.


(photo provided by: Joel Palmer House)

"

BrowserTitle: Spend the day shopping near Corvallis, OR
ContentText:
Shop

Fanciful

Step out of the ordinary this holiday season as you bring your \"suits to the boots\" with shopping along any of Albany and Linn County's four Oregon Country Trails. Warm up with hand-knit sweaters and hats from Sylvan Skies Alpacas
PageType: escape to the country with a walk back in time to the Living Rock Museum and Gift Shop in Brownsville
PageLevel: where every item you see is made from rock
PageSectionID:
from sculptures to detailed paintings.

In the small town of Silverton
ParentPage: SHOP the Stone Buddha. With just a bit of imagination you will find yourself in the Far East amid exotic treasures such as screens and doors from China and Tibet
InsertCode: tea and tea ware from Korea and China
IssuuCode: heavenly vintage kimonos from Japan. Carvings and Dragon Kites from Indonesia
AccountCatIDForListings: hangings and door curtains from the Turkoman Empire and authentic altar cloths. Fortunately for you
SortOrder: all this is closer than a 16 hour flight to Asia
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
in the green hills of the Willamette Valley.

Fine

Emma Downtown Albany
DisplayArticles: The owners of Emma Downtown understand that everyone wants to be able to give unique gifts
PageLogo: no matter how much they have to spend. So
FeatureBlockTitle1: they work hard all year to find and provide great
FeatureBlockTitle2: one-of-a-kind gifts for any budget. Even better
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
they stand ready to listen to your shopper-needs and help you match your problem giftee with the perfect present. Their upscale fashions for home and apparel suit the discriminating buyer to a \"t.\"

Find holiday gifts at Danner and Soli
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
fine yarns at Teaselwick Wool and Pendleton wool blankets all located within the Willamette Heritage Center at the Mill. The Willamette Heritage Center at the Mill also has a unique collection of local history books and archival supplies.

Stay

Fanciful

If you like the sound of a rooster crowing at dawn
PartnerTitle: doves cooing outside your bedroom window
DisplayPartnerColumns: a warm hearth and a hearty breakfast
PartnerCityTitle: then The Brownsville House is the place for you. Located in a 1921 Bungalow on the edge of Brownsville
YoutubeVideoID:
this B&B can accommodate you or your small group.

Peggy's Alaskan Cabbage Patch B&B
VideoTitle1: an Alaskan themed B&B in Lebanon positions you for an afternoon of antiquing
VideoTitle2:
wine country touring or mural-scouting.

Silverton Inn and Suites has been re-created with charm and elegance rarely seen in contemporary properties. Each room is created with individuality
MetaDescription: defined with its own features to capture a specific aspect of Silverton's history. Have fun with the themes (do you feel more like the \"Farmer\" or the \"Grist Mill\" suite tonight?)
SEOTags:
and prepare to be thoroughly captivated by the little town of Silverton.

Fine

Phoenix Inn Albany Spa Suites caters to leisure travelers searching for a comfortable hotel at an affordable price. This all-suite hotel offers a complimentary full hot breakfast buffet
SEOStatus:
and fresh cookies served nightly.

Edelweiss Manor B&B is a quaint Four Square Farm House with a wrap around veranda with pillars. The setting provides a serene and peaceful ambience for anyone wishing to escape and relax. An on-site Day Spa completes your relaxation.

In downtown Salem
ProposedHeaderText: The Grand Hotel is within easy walking distance of unique shopping
ProposedBrowserTitle: the historic Elsinore Theater and Oregon State Capitol. Rates are inclusive of breakfast
ProposedMetaDescription: and amenities include an indoor pool and a spa tub as well as in-room refrigerators
SEOPaidSearch:
microwaves and premium cable channels.

Put Your Feet Up

A Touch of Class Vintage Day Spa rests on a beautiful
SEOPaidBanner: century estate acreage alongside Edelweiss Manor B&B. Visit the Tea Room and art classes
SEOPaidSocial: and then stroll the Victorian lawns and gardens with their gazebos
Excerpt:
and water falls. Escape the everyday world and receive the royal treatment.

Wine

Fanciful

Stay tuned for the much-anticipated Springbank Farms Blueberry Winery. For now
AuthorUserID: you can stop by the farm for U-pick or they pick during the blueberry season. Or stop by all year for frozen blueberries. But
ExpirationDate:
you can come by for delicious blueberry wine.

Visit Mama's Fine Italian Restaurant and Wine Shop in Lebanon. Wine tastings are often part of the Friday night fun at Mama's. They have an extensive wine store as well as a great Italian menu featuring gluten-free entrees.

Pudding River Wine Cellars Located in the heart of the east Willamette Valley
IncludeInWidgets: Pudding River Wine Cellars is a family operated vineyard and winery producing small-lot
DataFinds: boutique styled wines including Pinot Noir
AuditTransferPage:
and Riesling.

Fine

Springhill Cellars is situated on the banks of the Willamette river
AuditRefreshPage: near Historic Albany‚ downtown shopping district. The vineyards and winery look west to the McDonald Forest
AuditTransferNotes: which forms the beginning of the Coast Range. The tasting room is open weekends from 1-5 p.m. from the first weekend in May through November
AuditNavChange:
as well as by appointment.

Honeywood Established in 1934
column58: Honeywood is the oldest producing winery in Oregon. One of the Honeywood's lines
column60: \" is especially popular among those with 4-legged friends. A portion of the profit from every bottle of Dog Gone Wine sold goes to support a local dog non-profit organization. The Honeywood tasting room offers a gourmet shop and free tastings
column61:
seven days a week.

Dine

Fanciful

Eat up the Albany Nosh Tour
column62: a trolley led exploration of unique Albany restaurants. Get your calendar out to make note of Shedd Cafe Monthly Dinner Event. This family-style treat sometimes includes Dinner In the Orchard at nearby Horsecreek Farm
column63:
where the phrase \"farm to table\" really comes to life.

Silver Grille At this contemporary bistro
column64: feel free to order wayward dishes such as the Naughty Librarian salad with poached pears and sherry vinaigrette
column65: or the chicken breast Funghi with local chanterelles. For dessert
column66:
the house-made bread pudding with cinnamon and caramel bourbon sauce is not-to-be-missed.

Fine

Dinner with the Wine Makers at Marks Ridge Winery
column67: a special time with Jay and Jan Westly
column68: where you can explore the winery
column70:
and dine with a gorgeous view. By appointment.

Wild Pear restaurant This fun and artful restaurant in historic downtown Salem is always bustling with activity and the wonderful aromas of local food cooked up with flair.

Photographs courtesy of Albany Visitors Association & Ron Cooper.

BrowserTitle: Erratic Rock, Wine Country's Historical Bookmark
HeaderText: Erratic Rock, Wine Country's Historical Bookmark
ContentText: Whether you are a history buff
PageLevel: a visit to Erratic Rock State Park provides a serene glimpse into the miracles of time and nature. This park's namesake
ParentPage: reminds us of the multiple floods
InsertCode: and volcanic eruptions that have shaped Yamhill Valley's landscape
HideFromNav:
economy and agriculture.

Erratic Rock State Park is a hidden Wine Country destination located between McMinnville and Sheridan. Its paved roadside access path leads visitors up to its tenant's private hillside resting place. Once there
DisplayListings:
visitors are greeted by the 90-ton artifact - and a breathtaking view of the majestic Oregon Coast Range and surrounding valley.

What makes this rock \"Erratic\"? In geology
AccountCatIDForListings: this term describes a composition that is different from the surrounding geology. Why is it so unique? Approximately 15
FeatureChildPages: Erratic Rock floated from Canada to Oregon in a glacier during a cataclysmic Ice Age flood. The adventurous rock traveled across the North American continent
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
transported by waters similar to those credited with bringing the Yamhill Valley its diverse and varying soil types.

Erratic Rock now serves as our historical bookmark - marking a different place and time
DisplayArticles: a reminder of the events that shaped Oregon wine and terroir. Park visitors are welcomed to drink in the views
PageLogo:
soak in the surroundings and appreciate the events that created Oregon's fertile wine valley.

Directions from Portland: Take OR-99W to OR-18W/OR-233 S/SE Dayton Bypass. Turn right at SW Sauter Road
FeatureBlockTitle1:
and then right onto SW Oldsville Road. Turn left onto SW Dusty Drive.

Directions from Salem: Drive Highway 22 west and 99W north to Amity
FeatureBlockTitle2: then Highway 153 west for six miles to Highway 18. Turn right
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
then after little more than a mile turn left on Oldsville Road and follow the signs.

For more information: Go to oregonstateparks.org 
(photo provided by: Oregon State Parks )

"

BrowserTitle: Shopping, dining and fun near Eugene, Or
ContentText:
Shop

Mod Pod is the sort of shop you might hope to find at a grooving college town like Corvallis. From big \"Fat Boy\" super stuffed bean bag chairs to teensy robot and cupcake theme goodies
PageType: this is all about making shopping
ParentPage:
fun.

Ride your bike or walk along the riverbank on the multi-modal path that leads to the Locally Grown Corvallis Farmers' Market. Operating Wednesdays and Saturdays from mid-April through mid-November.

Marché Provisions Eugene’s specialty food store is filled with unique pastas
IssuuCode: cookbooks and wines. It also has espresso
AccountCatIDForListings:
pizza and an amazing salad bar with seasonal produce like heirloom tomatoes and fiddled ferns.

April through mid-November
SortOrder: enjoy all the goodness of the long-running outdoor Eugene Saturday Market. From the end of November through much of December
FeatureChildPages: take the fun indoors for the Eugene Holiday Market. Top-notch crafters sell everything from beeswax candles to hand-forged andirons to glass-blown ornaments
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
and wrap it with a tie-dyed ribbon. Enjoy your shopping to the tunes of local talent ranging from Celtic Harp to Christmas Blues.

If you enjoy the finer things in life
DisplayArticles: be sure to stop in at Sibling Revelry
PageLogo: a downtown shop with an eclectic blend of women’s clothing
FeatureBlockTitle2: and whimsical gifts. Their jewelry includes hand-crafted work by Willamette Valley artists
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
with dozens of unique pieces to choose from.


Fifth Street Public Market Within these historic walls you'll find a colorful collection of locally-owned boutiques
PartnerTitle:
and artisan galleries. Take a break in the courtyard and listen to live music on the patio Thursdays – Saturdays during the summer and fall.

Stay

Brooklane Cottage is located in one of the quietest neighborhoods of Corvallis. Abutting wetlands on the south and east
PartnerText: hilly oak woodlands to the west and quick access to bike paths and city parks to the north
DisplayPartnerColumns: the Cottage provides an ideal starting point for explorations on foot or bike. Pretty as a tiny
YoutubeVideoID:
this 763 square foot guest cottage is a place inviting you to feel at home.

Tipi Village Retreat: Nestled along the banks of Mill Creek near Eugene
VideoTitle1:
this glamping (glamorous + camping) hub is perfectly positioned for a culinary adventure. Sleep in luxury tipis with cozy goose down comforters and decorated rugs.

Relish the beauty of the Willamette Valley with a stay at the Hanson Country Inn. Sitting high on a knoll on the southwest edge of Corvallis
VideoTitle2: the Hanson Country Inn is a magnificent five-acre estate with views in every direction. In addition to fresh breakfasts and comfortable guest rooms
MetaDescription: visitors can relax in the Inn’s library
SEOTags: which overlooks the estate gardens and is stocked with a wide selection of books
SeoNotes:
many of them dating back to the home’s early years in the 1920s.

Inn at the 5th: The Inn at the 5th brings luxury and elegance to the south Willamette Valley. All 69 suites of this boutique hotel are uniquely designed with locally inspired artwork. Dine on gourmet room-service via a butler door from Marché. The Inn’s luxury shuttle offers complimentary service within four miles of the city. Or
SEOStatus:
hire the shuttle to take you to local wineries.

Eugene's Pearl Day Spa The world is your oyster at The Pearl Day Spa
ProposedHeaderText: where a large and diverse menu of services are designed to lull you into an oasis of relaxation. Diverse styles of massage
ProposedMetaDescription:
luxurious sea salts and pure and natural essential oils renew you for another day of pursuing the perfect purchase.

From epic facials to mud treatments
SEOPaidSearch: Epic Day Spa maintains their innovative fusion of health
SEOPaidSocial:
science and nature for your peace of body and mind.

Wine

Harris Bridge Vineyard is one of Oregon's small
ContentType: husband and wife artisan-farmer teams. Open for special events (think house concerts and valentine afternoons)
CreationDate: as well as weekends May through November
Excerpt: Harris Bridge specializes in dessert wines. If you are wondering about the name - yes
PublishDate:
covered Harris Bridge is located on the winery property and provides a beautiful and short walk during wine tasting events!

Territorial Vineyards Offering up glorious Oregon wines in a renovated coffee warehouse. Live music mid-week helps make this a favorite for all who know that Eugene's Whiteaker neighborhood is the trendiest spot in town.

Visitors to Tyee Wine Cellars are welcome to enjoy wine tasting and browsing the rotating art that is always exhibited. During the dryer months
ExpirationDate: picnicking on the farm and vineyard is encouraged
IncludeInWidgets: as are hikes along the Beaver Pond Loop Nature Trail. The Barrel Room Tasting room in this Century Farm is open weekends April through December
DataFinds:
and by appointment at other times.

Oregon Wine LAB: This urban wine bar gratifies oenophiles and new wine drinkers alike with vintages from the area’s smaller winemakers in a tasting lounge. Aussie/vintner Mark Nicholl charms guests with his knowledge and William Rose Wine label.

Dine

Nearly Normals harks back to the roots of the very best earth-burger food. Don't be led astray by their boasts of Veggielicious Vegetarian cookery. These restaurateurs pair a sense of fun with mad culinary skills. Try out their Margarita Munchie Mondays or their fresh and innovative fare in their whimsical dining room.

Belly Taqueria: Belly Taqueria is consistently voted one of the best places for Mexican food in Eugene
TopPageview:
casual atmosphere with special tacos paired with margaritas and award-winning key lime pie.

del Alma Restaurant means literally \"of the soul.\" Located along the waterfront in downtown Corvallis
MicrositeID:
del Alma offers an elegant yet warm and inviting dining atmosphere with a view of the riverfront. The menu is inspired by the flavors and cuisines of Latin America with the offerings of the Northwest.

Rye: From the drink to the dish to the dessert
AuditTransferPage:
Rye masters every morsel of a meal. The pan-seared duck breast will melt in your mouth and tastes marvelous with a Willamette Valley pinot noir. Save room for dessert. The staff chocolatier crafts artisan chocolates and pairs them with whiskey.

Photographs courtesy Melinda Stewart
column84: Explore the South Willamette Valley Shopping Trail and find gifts and other fun, unique items at these locally owned small businesses.

BrowserTitle: Warm up with a nice brew this winter in Wilsonville, Or
HeaderText: Winter Brews and Chocolate Therapy in Mt. Hood
ContentText: As winter settles in Oregon’s Mt. Hood Territory
PageLevel: inviting places to enjoy delicious food
PageSectionID:
great beers and wine with good friends.

McMenamins Old Church and Pub in Wilsonville is a family-friendly restaurant
ParentPage: brewery and event venue set in what was once a church
InsertCode: warm atmosphere makes it a popular stop for travelers
IssuuCode: while a calendar filled with a wide array of events such as live music
HideFromNav: holiday parties and more keeps people coming back. A popular series is the \"Meet the Brewer\" beer tastings
DisplayListings:
where aficionados of craft beer can sample the latest creations and learn from the brew master himself about what it took to make such a special beer.

To satisfy your sweet tooth
AccountCatIDForListings: head east from Wilsonville to Canby to tryPuddin River Chocolates
SortOrder: one of Canby Area Farm Loop’s newest members. Known for decadent gourmet chocolates
FeatureChildPages: Puddin River also offers a generous selection of wines
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: a perfect pairing to warm your soul on a winter’s day. If you need a little food therapy
DisplayArticles: owner and Chief Chocolatier Teresa Sasse is also known for comfort food that’s like a hug for the soul. With dinner specials that include hearty soups
PageLogo: baked pasta dishes or artisan pizzas
FeatureBlockTitle1:
you are guaranteed to leave with a smile.

To feel the warmth of the holiday spirit
FeatureBlockTitle2: visit one of Mt. Hood Territory’s 42+ Christmas tree farms while sipping hot chocolate. Once you’ve made your selection
FeaturedActivityTitle1: let the inviting hospitality of one our lodging partners complete the perfect day as you enjoy the comfort and beauty of Mt. Hood Territory <a href=\"http://mthoodterritory.com/places-to-stay\" target=\"_blank\">hotels
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
B&B’s or vacation rentals.

To see everything The Territory has to offer winter travelers
PartnerTitle:
visit www.MtHoodTerritory.com


(photo provided by: McMenamins Old Church and Pub)

"

BrowserTitle: Sample Old-Fashioned Flavor in Yamhill Valley
HeaderText: Sample Old-Fashioned Flavor in Yamhill Valley
ContentText: For gourmands interested in beverages produced using old-fashioned
PageLevel:
the Yamhill Valley offers the ultimate farm-to-table experience: sipping artisan beverages while chatting with the friendly folks who grew what’s in the glass.

At Kookoolan Farms and World Meadery Chrissie Mannion Zaerpoor and Koorosh Zaerpoor produce everything from grass-fed meat to organic vegetables to pinot noir grapes
PageSectionID:
and you can see their fields and vines in person when you stop by the Yamhill farmstand. What makes Kookoolan an unforgettable foodie stop is their onsite mead tasting room.

Mead
ParentPage: the world’s oldest fermented beverage
Status: is growing rapidly in popularity; just as modern brewers reinvented beer with the craft beer revolution
InsertCode: mead-makers and fans of artisan beverages are now rediscovering this old-world beverage. Kookoolan’s meads are brewed onsite from honey produced just up the road
IssuuCode: with palate-pleasing results. Kookoolan’s \"Elegance\" Mead won silver at the world’s largest mead competition in 2014. The tasting room offers samples of \"Elegance\" and more than 150 other meads
HideFromNav:
both those produced onsite and others from around the world. Visitors can stop by and get a taste of the mead renaissance for themselves.

For foodies looking for a different kind of old-fashioned drink
DisplayListings: a visit to Champoeg Creamery outside St. Paul is like taking a step back in time. Visitors to Champoeg will find a handful of Jersey cows contentedly munching in pastures of green grass. Farmer Charlotte Smith personally milks her cows daily and sells the rich
AccountCatIDForListings: creamy beverage direct to her customers
SortOrder:
in addition to pasture-raised eggs and grass-fed meat.

Interested in a truly hands-on experience? Smith gives cheese-making classes onsite on her five-acre family farm. Visitors can sign up for classes and experience the creamery process from start to finish—from milking the cow to making the cheese to enjoying a farm-fresh luncheon.

To find more farm-to-table experiences in the bountiful Yamhill Valley
PageLogo: NULL

PageDesc: A Tasting Room With a View
NavButtonText: A Tasting Room With a View
BrowserTitle: Enjoy beautiful scenery and excellent wine in Central Oregon near Eugene
HeaderText: A Tasting Room With a View - Chehalem Hillsides Wine Trail
ContentText:
Yamhill Valley is widely regarded for its panoramic beauty. Rolling verdant hills, agricultural lands and picturesque vineyards make almost any stop a photo opportunity. Whether you want to drink in the view or just drink wine, this route features a host of breathtaking vistas.

Sip & Take it in

Anne Amie Vineyards: Pinot reigns supreme at Anne Amie Vineyards with Pinot noir
PageType:
Pinot gris and Pinot blanc forming the heart of its production. The vineyards are located on the steep hillsides of the Chehalem Mountains overlooking the rolling hills of the Yamhill-Carlton District. The tasting room highlights breathtaking views of the vineyard and the Coast Range.

Vista Hills Vineyards: Come for the wine and stay to explore the Treehouse Tasting Room
PageSectionID: 000-square-foot hideout nestled high among Douglas fir and White Oak treetops. Inside
ParentPage: you'll find an open floor plan that overlooks the lower level barrel room and cellar. From the deck
Status:
enjoy the stunning view that brought owners John and Nancy McClintock here 15 years ago.

Winderlea Vineyard: Winderlea is a luxury boutique winery specializing in the limited production of Pinot noir. Winderlea was founded in 2005 by Donna Morris and Bill Sweat as an outgrowth of their passion for great Pinot noir. The tasting room built in 2008 features ultra-modern architecture and outstanding views from the Dundee Hills where it sits.

Willakenzie Estate Winery: WillaKenzie Estate is located on rolling hillsides in the Chehalem Mountains. The winery was named after the WillaKenzie soil in which the vines are planted to convey the influence that the soil imparts on the wine's flavors and aromas. The patio outside the tasting room is graced by a breathtaking view of rolling agricultural hillsides.

Stay

Third Street Flats: This new style of accommodation offers travelers the privacy and independence of a hotel with the hospitality of a bed and breakfast. A European-inspired nightly apartment rental
InsertCode: Third Street Flats offers four unique apartments in the heart of downtown McMinnville
IssuuCode:
all of which feature the best of local products and 'green' materials.

Fox Farm Cottage: This charming one-story cottage located in Dundee features a full kitchen
HideFromNav: two comfortable bedrooms with feather beds and luxurious linens
DisplayListings:
and a dining room that seats six or more for your candlelight supper. Beautiful wood floors and classic country decor will make your stay comfortable and romantic.

Savor

Subterra - A Wine Cellar Restaurant: Subterra was conceived by Floridians Janet Bleck and her husband Martin to fulfill their dream of joining the vibrant and burgeoning Oregon foodie movement. Their restaurant is open for lunch and dinner
AccountCatIDForListings: Wednesday through Saturday
SortOrder: along with brunch on Sundays from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Additionally
FeatureChildPages: the wine bar offers small plates
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
hors díoeuvres and affordable wines by the glass.

For more information on this area
DisplayArticles:
contact Yamhill Valley Visitors Association at www.yamhillvalleywines.com or 503.883.7770.

Photo copyright Mike Haverkate.

for the 23rd annual Oregon Grape Stomp Championship.

farms and forests: Corvallis offers a variety of sensory experiences.

If you're the hands-on type

experience harvest in the South Willamette Valley this year.

feel the warmth of a cozy fireplace and taste the freshest fall produce.

which means it's time to get outside in Oregon's Mt. Hood Territory.

VideoTitle2: \"A garden is a friend you can visit any time.\" In the Mid-Willamette Valley
MetaDescription:
there's an abundance of friends to choose from.

    The same terroir that brings Oregon elegant Pinot noir abounds with natural beauty so accessible you can go from riding through verdant vineyards to epic mountain biking trails all in one day.

      This is the time of year to really see all of Oregon. As you plan your summer getaways
SEOTags: don't forget to discover the unique outdoor adventure awaiting you in the beautiful Willamette Valley. "

BrowserTitle: Salem Oregon Wine Trail | Wineries & Wine Tasting in Oregon
ContentText:
Blaze a trail through time as you explore the rich history of Oregon Wine in the Salem area and timeless treasures.  As you work your way through wine country, venture off in discovery of artisan cheeses, traditional hard cider and delectable chocolate-covered cherries. Make sure to document your trip like true historians with photos and journal notes. 


Wineries

  1. Honeywood Winery – The oldest producing winery in Oregon has created award-winning varietals − including their delicious fruit wines − for more than 75 years.
  2. Redhawk Winery – Enjoy a picnic lunch on an open field as you overlook a beautiful vineyard in the Willamette Valley.  The tasting room − featuring a fun and relaxed atmosphere − is open daily 11 a.m. –  5 p.m. year-round.
  3. Witness Tree Vineyard – This Oreong winery is named for an ancient oak tree that was used as a surveyor's landmark in 1854 during the Oregon Trail years. The varied microclimates at the vineyard facilitate earlier ripening of the fruit which produces exceptional wines.
  4. St. Innocent Winery – The wines are handcrafted to complement food and extend the pleasure of a meal. The tasting room
PageLevel:
is open 11 a.m – 4 p.m. Tuesday-Sunday (May 1 through October 31).
  • Wandering Aengus Ciderworks – The cidery creates outstanding hard ciders from uncommon apple varieties. The tasting room is open the last Friday of each month and by appointment.
  • Johan Vineyards – Owner Dag Johan Sundby
PageSectionID: the descendant of a long line of soil cultivators
ParentPage:
moved to  the Willamette Valley to make his mark on the ancient Pinot noir grape.
  • Cherry Hill – Take a scenic stroll through the vineyard or relax on the patio with a glass of delicious Pinot noir. The tasting room is open weekdays 11 a.m. – 4 p.m. (call first) and weekends 11 a.m. – 5 p.m.
  • Left Coast Cellars – Past the entrance gates – a piece of art depicting the natural grapevines seen beyond them –you'll experience handcrafted
InsertCode:
Pinot gris and Pinot noir.
  • Eola Hills Wine Cellars – The famous all you can eat Sunday Brunch comes with two tickets to experience this winery's award-winning varietals.
  • Firesteed Celllars – Visitors can experience elegant fine wines at the newly remodeled tasting room and retail shop.
  • Orchard Heights Winery – The owners of this winery also operate a chocolate factory in Hawaii specializing in gourmet confections using Macadamia nuts
IssuuCode:
pineapple and Kona coffee beans. Chocolate and wine together – fantastic!
  • Cubanisimo Vineyards – Dust off your dancing shoes and channel your inner moves at the monthly salsa lessons held at Cubanisimo. Celebrate the wine in Oregon - Cuban Style!

    • Historic Places

    1. Bush House Museum – Built in 1878 by Asahel Bush II
HideFromNav: this Italianate-style Victorian mansion and conservatory in Bush's Pasture Park features changing exhibits
DisplayListings:
original fine art and furnishings.
  • Historic Deepwood Estate – This 1894 Queen Anne Victorian house
AccountCatIDForListings: located on 4.5 acres of historic gardens and nature trails
SortOrder:
features exquisite stained glass and golden oak woodwork.
  • Oregon State Capitol – Marble adorns Oregon's Capitol
FeatureChildPages: built in 1938. Atop the dome sits the “Gold Pioneer.” Tours of the building are available
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
including the 121-step spiraling climb to the top of the building onto an observation deck offering astounding views of the city.
  • Spring Valley Presbyterian Church – Enjoy a picnic lunch at this 1859 Queen Anne Victorian church placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1974.
  • Applegate National Historic Trail in Dallas – The official starting and ending point of the Applegate Trail
DisplayArticles: an alternative route from the Oregon Trail into the Willamette Valley. Interpretative wayside located at the Dallas City Park
PageLogo: Polk County Museum
FeatureBlockTitle1:
and Guthrie Park.

Overnight

  1. The Grand Hotel in Salem – This full-service hotel features 193 oversized guest rooms and suites.  Each room has a work/living area
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
complimentary breakfast and more.
  • Century House B & B –  This charming B&B offers spacious guest rooms and specialty breakfasts to accommodate all preferences and is within walking distance to downtown Salem shops
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
restaurants and attractions.  
  • Best Western Dallas Inn & Suites – Take a break from history at this inn featuring 42 comfortable guest rooms and suites
PartnerCityTitle:
exercise facility and more.

Dining

  1. Jonathan's – An iconic downtown Salem restaurant since 1979
YoutubeVideoID: Jonathan's recently moved a few blocks to a new location in the historic Pacific building. The restaurant serves great traditional seafood dishes
VideoTitle1:
steaks and some of the best Cajun food this side of Louisiana.
  • Bentley's Grill – Enjoy fine dining in a relaxing atmosphere at Bentley's
VideoTitle2:
which features Northwest cuisine and a premier selection of Oregon wines.  The restaurant is located inside The Grand Hotel in Salem.
  • Willamette Valley Cheese Company – The home of Oregon's only Artisan Farmstead cow's milk cheese
MetaDescription: the Willamette Valley Cheese Company cheeses are hand-crafted the old-fashioned
SEOTags:
sustainable way. Experience award-winning cheeses in the new tasting room.
  • Cherry Country Orchard & Chocolate Factory – A must try is the signature dried
    cherries and chocolates which
SEOStatus:
doesn't contain anything other than a dried cherry in the center of the high-quality milk or dark chocolate.  Cherry Country was featured on the Food Network's “Road Tasted" with the Neelys.

 

 

For more information on this area
ProposedHeaderText:
contact Travel Salem at www.TravelSalem.com or 800-874-7012.

"
column64: Experience the history of Oregon's oldest vineyards. A tour and map of wine tasting in Oregon's Wine Country.

BrowserTitle: 404 - Page Not Found

Oops! This content is gone, but you can still visit our homepage to start exploring!

"
MetaDescription: This page is no longer active, head over to www.oregonwinecountry.org to keep exploring.

BrowserTitle: Interactive Willamette Valley Wine Country Map Explorer
MetaDescription: Use our interactive map explorer to discover things to do on your next Willamette Valley vacation. You will find Oregon wineries, restaurants, attractions and events. Save your favorites and build your own unique Oregon Wine Country trip.

BrowserTitle: Bike to the best vineyards, wineries and tasting rooms near Eugene, Or
HeaderText: Pedaling for Pinot - Eugene Wine Trail
ContentText:
Just outside of Eugene lies a wonderland of low traffic country roads perfect for all types of cyclists and road trippers, from the leisurely café explorer to the well-traveled rider looking for a new view. Whomever you are, don’t rush it. On this wine trail, travel through rolling valleys dotted with farms, orchards and vineyards, and over forested hillsides. Stop for stunning vistas and watch for kestrels or red-tailed hawks. Breathe in the moist forest air and discover the variety of unique wines at tasting rooms along the way.

Sip

Sweet Cheeks Winery: Named for the curvaceous hillsides that grace its view
PageType: this charming winery is tucked into the steep countryside of the Briggs Hill Valley. Picnicking on the sprawling patio is encouraged
ParentPage:
and relax to live music or the company of friends.

Silvan Ridge Winery: At one of the region’s oldest wineries
Status:
sip on a nice Syrah by the fireplace or a refreshing glass of award-winning Early Muscat Semi-Sparkling on the patio.

King Estate Winery: Internationally renowned for its Pinot gris
InsertCode: King Estate Winery offers sweeping views of the Lorane Valley
IssuuCode: an incredible restaurant featuring a mostly estate-grown seasonal menu and
DisplayListings:
generous pours.

Chateau Lorane Winery: A Northwest winery specializing in the rare and unusual varietals of Huxelrebe
AccountCatIDForListings: Marechal Foch
SortOrder:
and Baco Noir.

Saginaw Vineyard: Enjoy a picnic beneath a walnut tree while savoring a glass of wine in this bucolic setting. Try Saginaw’s surprising blackberry wine and award-winning blueberry wine.

Iris Vineyards: Located in the Lorane Valley
FeatureChildPages: Iris Vineyards is dedicated to producing high quality
DisplayArticles:
pinot gris and chardonnay.

Ride

Hamm Road Loop
Explore the scenic diversity of the southern reaches of the Willamette Valley on this cycling route. Follow the Coast Fork of the Willamette River through open farmland and sprawling orchards near Creswell and Cottage Grove
PageLogo:
then head into the forested foothills and watch for wildflowers on your way to the plentiful Lorane Valley. This 43-mile loop offers moderate climbs and descents with smooth riding conditions.

Wolf Creek Loop
Challenge yourself on this 50-mile cycling route through the moss-laden forests of the Coast Range foothills. Breathe in the moist air and listen to the chorus of frogs at lower elevations. This route caters to riders who prefer remote or wilderness environments
FeatureBlockTitle1: as there are no services and you’re more likely to see another cyclist than a car. Wolf Creek serpentines through the hills
FeaturedActivityTitle1: gradual climbs and descents with some shorter
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
steep sections. Riders should be cautious of their speed on some turns.

Savor

King Estate Restaurant: Restaurant and wine bar open daily
PartnerTitle:
with complimentary wine tasting and tours. Full lunch and dinner menu with dishes featuring estate and locally grown organic ingredients that pair wonderfully with King Estate wines.

Creswell Bakery: Farm to table at its finest and freshest in the charming town of Creswell. Chef Heidi Tunnell uses locally-sourced ingredients to transform house-made breads
PartnerText:
pastries and lunches. Oregon wines and beers are available by the glass or bottle during lunch hours. 

Sleep

Village Green Resort: Stop to rest your legs and stay for the 14 acres of beautiful
DisplayPartnerColumns:
themed gardens and walking paths. Finish the day on a private garden patio outside your deluxe room featuring a fireplace and cozy down comforters.

Check out some of the other great places to stay
PartnerCityTitle:
eat and play in Cottage Grove and Creswell.

For more information on this area
VideoTitle1:
Cascades & Coast – Travel Lane County at www.eugenecascadescoast.org or 800.547.5445.

"
column58: The Eugene Wine Trail has several award-winning wineries along quiet country roads perfect for a bike ride wine tasting adventure.

BrowserTitle: 50 years of Pinot in Yamhill Valley
HeaderText: Willamette Valley's oldest Pinot tradition lives on
ContentText:
This spot is part of our Places to Sip Between the Wonders Road Trip. To view the full itinerary, click here.

Jason Lett had what you might call an early start in the winemaking business. Growing up on The Eyrie Vineyards in Dundee as the son of David Lett — one of Oregon’s wine pioneers — Lett started helping out at age three. “It is my earliest memory of feeling useful. I don’t know how helpful I actually was
PageLevel:
” he said with a laugh.

That early training stuck. Though his path took him to college
PageSectionID: a career and other adventures — like starting his own winery —Lett eventually returned to The Eyrie
ParentPage:
where he carries on a family legacy of pushing boundaries in winemaking.

David and Diana Lett planted the Willamette Valley’s first Pinot noir vines in 1965
Status: convinced that Oregon had the right climate for excellent winemaking. Their hunch paid off in 1979 and 1980 when The Eyrie wines competed against French burgundies in Paris and Beaune — and won. “That was a watershed moment
InsertCode:
” Lett said.

The Eyrie’s accomplishment signaled the world that Oregon was ripe for wine production. Soon
IssuuCode: French wine makers were exploring the region and moving to the state to start their own ventures. “We have gotten some very good neighbors in the process
AccountCatIDForListings: was akin to having another sibling. Though he enjoyed working with this dad
SortOrder: the long hot days made college seem like a good idea. He pursued a degree in botany and started a career. In 1997
FeatureChildPages: he returned to The Eyrie to help with the harvest. “And I realized
PageLogo: The Eyrie was too small a kitchen for two cooks. He started his own winery—BlackCap — in 2002. In 2005
FeatureBlockTitle1: his father offered him his present job as winemaker and vineyard manager. “Dad stayed on as spiritual heart and technical consultant
FeatureBlockTitle2:
” Lett said. David Lett passed away in 2008.

Today The Eyrie Vineyards comprise 118 acres
FeaturedActivityTitle1: 60 of which are planted with grapes and 12 with hazelnut trees. The rest is pasture and forest. The company produces about 9
FeaturedActivityTitle2: 000 cases of wine annually. That’s more than half a million glasses
PartnerText: but is roughly half of the output for an average Willamette Valley winery. Staying small is intentional
DisplayPartnerColumns: Lett said. “It is important to us that there is a single guiding philosophy behind the wine
PartnerCityTitle:
and that is easier to achieve when there is one person overseeing the details.”

With vineyards in Dundee and a winery in McMinnville
YoutubeVideoID: The Eyrie’s production is now half Pinot gris (it produced America’s first) and half a mix of Pinot noir
VideoTitle1: Chardonnay and more obscure varieties like Pinot blanc
MetaDescription: Ottenel and Pinot meunier. Lett recently planted a new variety for Oregon — Trousseau
SEOTags: a red wine from the Jura region of France. “It is very refreshing and spicy
SeoNotes:
” he said.

Those with a taste for history (and Pinot) will be interested to know that The Eyrie is re-releasing library wines
SEOStatus:
including some of the 1975 South Block Reserve that first captured the world’s attention in France.

As for how Lett carries on The Eyrie legacy
ProposedBrowserTitle:
“I don’t think there is any one way to encapsulate that. The best way to experience it is by tasting our wines.”

See Oregon Wine Country through Jason Lett's eyes:

Find It:

The Eyrie Vineyards | 935 East 10th Ave. McMinnville OR 97128 | 503-472-6315 | http://www.eyrievineyards.com

"

BrowserTitle: Enjoy art and culture while wine tasting in Corvallis, Or
HeaderText: Art of the Valley - Corvallis Wine Trail
ContentText:
A small town with big city culture, Corvallis, Oregon has an abundance of arts and culture, and what better way to drink it all in than a tour of local art galleries and local wineries? Join us as we meander across Benton County from the heart of historic downtown Corvallis to the tiny town of Wren. Indulge your creative senses and your palate in the heart of the Willamette Valley. The route is approximately 30 miles round-trip and one hour driving time.

Wineries

  1. Tyee Winery – Located on a Century Farm just south of downtown Corvallis
PageType: Tyee Wine Cellars is a family owned and operated vineyard and winery. Once a dairy farm
PageLevel:
the vintage milking barn still stands today and serves as an art gallery adjoining the tasting room. 
  • The Wine Vault – Housed in an old bank in the small town of Philomath
ParentPage: the Wine Vault is Pheasant Court Winery's official tasting room
Status:
and the old bank vault is still there!
  • Belle Vallee – The only winery located within Corvallis city limits
InsertCode: Belle Vallee’s tasting room is located on Corvallis’ historic riverfront walk. Showcasing rotating exhibits by local photographers and unique maps
IssuuCode:
Belle Vallee also offers outdoor seating during the warmer months.
  • Enoteca Wine Bar – Featuring both local and imported wines
HideFromNav: as well as a wide variety of espresso drinks and even a few microbrews
DisplayListings:
this stop has something for everyone. Enjoy a variety of appetizers with your wine as you browse the works of local painters in this chic venue.
  • Harris Bridge Vineyard – Sip on dessert wines while enjoying a stroll to the historic covered bridge at Harris Bridge Vineyard. A perfect location for a picnic or a game of bocce ball
AccountCatIDForListings:
this winery is worth the drive.

Art

  1. The Arts Center - Located in the heart of downtown Corvallis on the edge of a rose-filled park
SortOrder: The Arts Center showcases local art from all around the state. Housed in an historic church
FeatureChildPages: The Arts Center is more than just a gallery; local artists offer classes and workshops year-round
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
and a fun gift shop is filled with local goods.
  • Dana Marie Art Gallery - This chic and small gallery has just opened showcasing the hand-painted wearable work of Corvallis-based artist Dana Marie.
  • Pegasus Gallery - Featuring a wide array of art modes including sculpture
PageLogo: this whimsical gallery is located in an historic warehouse in downtown Corvallis. Thirsty? The Oregon Trail Brewery adjoins the gallery
FeatureBlockTitle1:
so stop off for a pint of their delectable Ginseng Porter.
  • Corvallis Artisans Market - Every Saturday from mid-April to mid-October
FeatureBlockTitle2: enjoy perusing artisans’ wares along the historic riverfront at the Corvallis Artisans Market. Walking through a wide array of eclectic local art
FeaturedActivityTitle1: including a great selection of wearable art
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
you can listen to local music and sample food from the adjacent farmers market while you shop.
  • Gateway Gallery - Gateway Gallery was created in connection with a glass blowing studio called Sneak Peek Glass. It features the work of local artists in varying media
PartnerTitle:
with a gallery emphasis on art glass.
  • The Gallery at Tyee Winery - Tyee Winery houses a small gallery in a historic building on its century farm. With exhibits from artists representing a wide array of styles
PartnerText:
Tyee is always an interesting stop.

Stay

  1. Harrison House - Just blocks away from the historic Oregon State University campus
DisplayPartnerColumns: this Dutch Colonial gem is the perfect retreat for those who want to be in the middle of it all. If you are a foodie
PartnerCityTitle:
you will love the gourmet breakfasts!

Savor

  1. Cloud 9 - This hip atmospheric eatery is located on Corvallis' historic riverfront and showcases both local ingredients and local wines!

For more information on this area
YoutubeVideoID:
contact Corvallis Tourism at www.visitcorvallis.com or 800.334.8118.
