BrowserTitle: Wine Tasting in Oregon's Eastern Willamette Valley
HeaderText: East of Eden - Oregon Wine in Molalla, Canby & Silverton
ContentText: The Willamette Valley's East Valley Wine Growers invite you to join them to Vacation on ‘Wine Time.’ Heading south from the Portland area
PageType: we take you off-trail to find boutique wineries
PageLevel: bright gardens and great restaurants located in tiny wine towns. Overnight at the much-awaited Oregon Garden Resort
PageSectionID:
then use that as your base to explore the country roads and flower-filled fields in the Silver Falls and Salem area. The wine trail can easily be explored in the reverse direction. Drink deep! 

Wineries

  1. St. Josef’s Winery - 28836 S Barlow Rd
ParentPage: Canby - Known for their tremendously fun events as well as their seriously light-hearted approach to creating fine wines
Status:
everything from the half-timbered tasting room to the romantic wine cellar invites you to stay a little longer.
  • Alexeli Vineyards - 35803 Oregon 213
InsertCode: Molalla - Where else can you find breathtaking views of Mt. Hood
IssuuCode: Mt. Jefferson and Mt. St. Helens
HideFromNav:
all to be enjoyed with a splendid Riesling in hand?
  • Vitis Ridge - This small winery has a quaint barn-like facility for tasting their impressive array of varietals. On holiday weekends
DisplayListings:
expect live music and lively camaraderie.
  • Paradis Family Vineyard has earned both Salmon Safe and \"LIVE\" certification.
  • Silver Falls - The Silver Falls tasting room is open Saturday and Sunday 11am-5pm
AccountCatIDForListings:
April through December and by appointment.
  • Piluso Vineyard - Each varietal is hand-harvested in small lots
SortOrder:
then aged in French oak cooperage until the wine says it’s ready to bottle – usually in 10 – 12 months.  This boutique winery with a reputation for a mean Tempranillo.


Gardens/Flowers

Flower Farmer 2512 N. Holly
FeatureChildPages:
Canby - Train ride through acres of flowers to see the farm animals on this fully operational European-Style Farm. Pick up fresh fruit and veggies at the fruit stand. Select your fresh bouquet from the field. Summer Basil Festival

Swan Island Dahlia Farm 995 NW 22nd Ave
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
Canby - Open daily August and September. Immerse yourself in blooms and color. The nation’s largest dahlia grower offers over 40 acres of beauty. Annual Dahlia Festival the last weekend in August and Labor Day weekend.

Wooden Shoe Tulip Farm 33814 S Meridian Rd
DisplayArticles: Woodburn - Walk among a multi-colored tulip field
PageLogo: enjoy the gift shop
FeatureBlockTitle2: country store or buy fresh flower bouquets. Tulip Fest open March 28 through May 4
FeaturedActivityTitle2: it’s Pumpkin Fest with good old-fashioned harvest festival and pumpkin patch. Open Sept 27 –Nov 2
PartnerTitle:
10a-6p daily.

The Oregon Garden 879 W Main St
PartnerText: Silverton – an 80-acre botanical sanctuary featuring 20 specialty gardens. You'll discover waterfalls
SEOTags:
art and a Pet Friendly Garden. The Children's Garden is complete with an in-ground Hobbit house.

Barn Owl Nursery - 22999 Peters Rd
SeoNotes: Wilsonville - Find over 100 different types of lavender
SEOStatus: and get expert advice on growing and using lavender and herbs. Open Fri-Sun
ProposedBrowserTitle:
May–July 27 & Nov 1–Dec 14.


Overnight

Oregon Garden Resort – A 103-room garden theme hotel located adjacent to The Oregon Garden. Take advantage of innovative
ProposedMetaDescription: high-value packages such as \"Wine and Jazz Festival package\"
SEOPaidBanner:
and diverse \"Spa Escapes.\"

Prairie House Inn 524 E Main St
SEOPaidSocial: Molalla - Built in 1900 and lovingly restored to its original detail
ContentType:
this home was the first one in Molalla to have water and electricity. Each of the six bedrooms has been tastefully decorated to reflect Molalla’s colorful history

The Grand Hotel in Salem – formerly the Phoenix Grand Hotel. Features 193 over-sized guest rooms and suites.

Dining

Pudding River Chocolates and Ladybug Chocolates - The quaint town of Canby boasts two top notch chocolatiers located just doors from each other. Pudding River Chocolates also offers lunch
Excerpt:
weekly cocktails and baked desserts most days.

Picnic at St. Josef’s - Throughout April and much of May
AuthorUserID: Red Lips and Tulips means that St. Josef's grounds are open on a daily basis for picnicking and the tasting room is open for quaffing. During summer months
PublishDate:
enjoy your picnic pond-side while listening to live music during special weekend events.

Glockenspiel Restaurant– Swarms of tourists and locals gather right outside the Mt. Angel Glockenspiel at appointed house to watch the figures dance and listen to the resonance of the bells.

  1. Beginning April 15: It’s asparagus time in Mount Angel!
  2. Nothing heralds the fact that spring has arrived like asparagus. All throughout Germany it is celebrated at every meal. At the Glockenspiel we have a variety of special recipes featuring locally grown asparagus to delight you
ExpirationDate:
known as Spargelzeit. Güten Appetit!

Silver Grille – Features an ever-changing menu with culinary pieces made from seasonal
IncludeInWidgets: organic and locally produced products. Dinner is served Wednesday thru Sunday 5-9pm. I love this place
DataFinds: and not just because of the \"Naughty Librarian\" salad. The wine cabinet is phenomenal
TopLanding:
and the mood of the establishment is something every savvy diner dreams of.

Top photo by Frank Barnett Photography

"
column78: Wineries in Oregon's eastern Willamette Valley. Find wine tasting, flower farms and great places to stay and eat in Canby, Molalla, Mt. Angel and Silverton.

PageDesc: 7 Fabulous Farms of Oregon Wine Country
BrowserTitle: Enjoy these farm experiences in the Willamette Valley of Oregon
HeaderText: 7 Fabulous Farms of Oregon Wine Country
ContentText:
This story first appeared on TravelOregon.com. 

When you set out in search of Oregon Wine Country’s most perfect food
PageType: don’t bring your fine china. Try a pair of work boots instead. Because there’s one thing that the Willamette Valley’s chefs
PageSectionID:
and winemakers agree on: the best food and wine starts on a farm. Here’s how to take this trip through seven fabulous farms in Oregon Wine Country:

1. Start your journey in Albany with a walk through the wild loveliness of Midway Farms
ParentPage: a 100-percent organic farm whose owners are so serious about working in harmony with nature that they leave certain plots of land undisturbed to promote healthy insect habitat. Old-fashioned fruits like quince and gooseberry grow side-by-side with herbs
InsertCode:
and visitors are welcome to wander through it all. Bring your kids to a farm day camp in the summer or bring a friend to one of Midway’s seasonal wine and cheese tasting parties with live music.

2. Head north to Salem
IssuuCode: where the melt-in-your-mouth goodness of Cherry Country Orchard will make your tastebuds happy whether you’re searching for fresh fruits or delectable desserts. Located in the hills west of Salem
HideFromNav: the farmers at Cherry Country Orchard grow 37 acres of fresh cherries
DisplayListings: then make a good thing even better by dipping their bounty in chocolate. Visitors can sample fresh
AccountCatIDForListings:
dried and chocolate-coated cherries at the farm and candy factory.

3. Continue through the Willamette Valley’s green fields and rolling hills
SortOrder: northward to the farmland outside Molalla
FeatureChildPages: where you’ll find Rosse Posse Acres
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: a farm like nothing you’ve experienced before. Yes
PageLogo:
where the Ross family raises flavorful local elk meat that finds its way to fine kitchens all over Oregon. But it’s also a place where visitors can get up close and personal with majestic herds of elk in a way you won’t find anywhere else.

4. From Molalla
FeatureBlockTitle1: turn west toward the Willamette River. There
FeatureBlockTitle2: in the heart of Oregon Wine Country
FeaturedActivityTitle1: you’ll come upon Champoeg Creamery
FeaturedActivityTitle2: where a handful of contented Jersey cows graze on green pastures
PartnerTitle: and family farmers turn that goodness into fresh milk and cheese. Customers drive for miles to purchase Champoeg’s farm-fresh milk
PartnerText: and adults and children alike can sign up for classes and camps to experience hands-on farm tasks like milking the cows
DisplayPartnerColumns:
hunting for eggs and making cheese.

5. Do yourself a favor and come hungry when you visit Gathering Together Farm outside Corvallis. The Farmstand Restaurant at Gathering Together takes grown-on-site organic produce and turns it into mouthwatering brunches
VideoTitle1: and more. If you can’t stay for a full meal
VideoTitle2: grab a house-made pastry or loaf of bread and munch while you browse the selection of veggies
SEOTags:
jams and jellies. You’ll leave with a full belly and a happy heart.

6. If Gathering Together wasn’t proof enough that everything tastes better on a farm
SeoNotes: Agrarian Ales will win your heart (and your tastebuds) entirely. This family-owned chili pepper farm turned brewery produces farm-brewed beers that will knock your socks off. And while you’re barefoot
SEOStatus: you might as well play — Agrarian’s onsite pub and brewery features yard games
ProposedBrowserTitle:
and even hula hoops. Unleash your inner child and enjoy yourself while you sip craft beverages and farm-inspired dining just north of Eugene.

7. An honorable mention on any list of seven top farms in Oregon Wine Country goes to Willamette Valley Farmers’ Markets. Any day of the week in the Willamette Valley
ProposedMetaDescription: you can find local producers setting up tents in vacant fields and city parking lots
SEOPaidSearch: putting their best berries and prettiest peaches out where foodies can trek in to purchase their local food nirvana. Whether you’re searching for artisan cheese
ContentType: or one of the multitudes of other crops that we’ve perfected in the Willamette Valley
CreationDate:
there’s a farmers’ market not far away where you can find the mouthwatering morsel of your dreams. Straight from our farms to your table — because that’s how we do things in Oregon.

"
column71: Enjoy delicious food and amazing experiences a farms in Oregon's Willamette Valley. Visit Midway Farms in Albany, Cherry Country Orchard in Salem, Rosse Posse Acres in Molalla, Champoeg Creamery, Gathering Together Farm and Agrarian Ales.

BrowserTitle: Experience Oregon's wine scene
ContentText:
Here are a couple opportunities to get out and experience Oregon’s wine scene:


• Discover Laughlin Loop, a seven-mile route of eight award-winning Yamhill-Carlton wineries.

Transportation is supplied by complimentary Laughlin Loop shuttles, with stops at every winery on the tour. Participating are Beacon Hill, Fairsing Vineyard, Gran Moraine, Lenne Estate, Roots Wine Co., Saffron Fields Vineyard, Solena Estate and WillaKenzie Estate.
Tickets, in the form of a scavenger trail guide, are $45 each and are valid for Aug. 6 and 7. Feel free to split up your winery visits for the weekend. The scavenger trail guide includes complimentary wine tasting at each winery, complimentary shuttle service, $10 in food cart vouchers and a chance to win a wine country gift basket. You are not required to use the shuttle service.
If you don’t make it to all the wineries this weekend, don’t worry. Keep your Laughlin Loop scavenger trail guide and visit the wineries you missed through Labor Day.
Learn more
 
• Take a peek into the Eola-Amity Hills AVA by participating in EA Confidential
PageType:
to be held Aug. 20.

It’s a day of touring the Eola-Amity Hills appellation and learning about the vineyards
PageLevel: and the people who create the wines. The fun begins at 10 a.m. when you board luxury buses in Eugene or Portland and travel to Bethel Heights Vineyard for a gourmet lunch and hear the stories from winemakers and vineyard owners about how they began their careers in the wine industry. After lunch
PageSectionID: tour participants will board the bus and depart for Keeler Estate Vineyard
ParentPage:
where Nicholas Keeler of Tonnellerie Allary will discuss the role of barrels in winemaking. What’s the difference/benefits between new and old oak? You’ll find out. You’ll also get to sample wines from a selection of Eola-Amity Hills producers.
Next stop is Bjornson Vineyard
Status: where you will work alongside winemakers to learn when to pick for the upcoming harvest. Learn about this decision by walking the vineyard
InsertCode: trying fruit samples and then testing for ripeness and flavor in the lab. You’ll get to sample more wines here
IssuuCode:
and enjoy the view of the Cascades from the Bjornson Vineyard.
A quick ride north will bring the group to Brooks Winery for dinner prepared by Chef Bernard Malherbe of the Crooked House Bistro
HideFromNav: paired with a selection of rare and limited library wines. To cap off the day
DisplayListings:
each table will be hosted by winemakers and vineyard owners who will share special bottles from their cellars.
Guests board the bus and will either be shuttled back to their parked vehicle or shuttled back to Portland or Eugene at 9 p.m.
Tickets are $199 per person. For more information
AccountCatIDForListings:
email Lauren Fuhrman-Burch at the Eola-Amity Hills Winegrowers Association.
 
Information from Barb Randall

BrowserTitle: Willamette Valley River Country Trail
HeaderText: Willamette Valley River Country Wine Trails
ContentText: Get your feet wet with this newly formed Oregon Country Trail any week day or week end. Crossing the Willamette River at the Calapooia River
PageType:
the trail leads you through Historic Downtown Albany to visit unique restaurants and Albany's Historic Carousel and out to wineries.
Check-in at Edelweiss Manor B&B across the river. A scrumptious breakfast is part of your stay. Then
PageLevel:
put on your walking shoes and hit the trail (you'll need the car too).

Head on down to First St. for espresso at Brick & Mortar Cafe. The Historic Carousel and Museum is open now
PageSectionID: so meander on down First Avenue for a tour and a ride. Then waltz down to Montieth River Park
ParentPage:
where they have Mondays at Montieth and River Rhythms concerts in summer.

For lunch
Status: head back First Avenue to First Burger
InsertCode: for hand crafted burgers and fries. They make it all from scratch
IssuuCode: even the chili! Or hop in the car and get some pub food and homemade microbrews at Calapooia Brewery. Now it's time to explore the country. Cross the Willamette and head to Midway Farms for fresh produce
DisplayListings: and baked goods. A family member will be there with friendly conversation. Ask if you can visit with their famous cow
AccountCatIDForListings:
Heidi.


Springhill Cellars

Just up the hill from Midway Farms
SortOrder: Springhill Cellars is a family-owned winery producing award-winning Pinot Noir and Pinot Gris in a beautiful vineyard on Scenic Drive. They also occasionally make a crisp
FeatureChildPages: light and fruity Pinot Noir Rose'
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
which they call " Sagnee' "

Sybaris Bistro

Now
PageLogo:
the choices…

Consider Sybaris Bistro. Sybaris is dedicated to bringing the best of Oregon to your table
FeatureBlockTitle1: much of it from local farms
FeaturedActivityTitle2: and innovation. Sybaris offers a fresh menu every month
PartnerText:
and an extensive Northwest-centered wine list.
After dinner
DisplayPartnerColumns: see a play at the Albany Civic Theater or a movie at the Pix Historic Theatre
PartnerCityTitle: where wine is served after 7pm. Then Vault 244 for a nightcap
YoutubeVideoID:
and back to the B&B for a good night's sleep. You can do the Historic Albany Downtown walking tour of over 700 Historic Homes and buildings tomorrow!

If you can't wait to get back in the water check out the The North Santiam River
VideoTitle1: a 92-mile (148 km) tributary of the Santiam River in western Oregon in the Cascade Range on the eastern side of the Willamette Valley east of Salem. Blocked by Big Cliff Dam near Mill City
VideoTitle2: the lower North Santiam River supports spring chinook salmon and summer steelhead. In the reaches upstream of the dam
MetaDescription:
the river is managed mainly as a stocked-trout fishery. 




"
column60: Explore award-winning wineries of the Willamette Valley along the Willamette River.

PageDesc: The Best Wine Routes in Willamette Valley
BrowserTitle: Explore the wine trails of Oregon's Willamette Valley
ContentText:
With more than 500 wineries filling the hills and valleys of Oregon Wine Country, it can be hard to know where to start. Check out our Willamette Valley wine trails and you’ll find an inspiring path to follow. Each wine-tasting journey includes picturesque vineyards, tasty restaurants, and relaxing overnight accommodations.


Seven Places to Sip Between the Wonders

The Sip Between the Wonders Road Trip highlights seven of the region's craft beverage producers and includes wineries
PageLevel:
and a cidery. It's the perfect trip when one traveler loves vino and the other wants a craft beer.

 

 

 


 
East of Eden

The East of Eden wine trail takes you through the boutique wineries and stunning gardens of the eastern side of the Willamette Valley. It's a perfect trip for those who like the road less traveled.
 

 

 

 

 

 

Pedaling for Pinot

Cyclists or those who like scenic drives will enjoy the Pedaling for Pinot trail in the south Willamette Valley
PageSectionID: which takes you to wineries both large and small
ParentPage: located on beautiful country roads. The wineries of the south valley range from large and elegant to small and intimate
Status:
and all of them make amazing Pinot noir.
 

 

 

 

 

Vintage + Vineyards

Explore Oregon history while you taste your way along the Vintage and Vineyards Wine trail. You’ll discover historic places
IssuuCode: and sip delicious Oregon wines. Located in the heart of the Willamette Valley
HideFromNav:
it's a trip full of delicious surprises.

 

 

 

 

 

7 Beautiful Vineyard Views

Bring your cameras and experience stunning landscapes along with great wine on the Seven Beautiful Vineyard Views trip. You'll explore wineries from one end of the valley to another on this breathtaking trip.

"
SEOPaidBanner: Oregon's Willamette Valley is known for amazing wines. The best wine trails are the Seven Places to Sip Between Wonders, East of Eden, Pedaling for Pinot, Vintage and Vineyards and 7 Beautiful Vineyard Views.

BrowserTitle: Plan your Trip to Oregon's Wine Country
HeaderText: Plan your Trip to Oregon Wine Country
ParentPage: https://wvva.objects.liquidweb.services/photos/983-eugene_gallowcoveredbrid_taylorhiggins3-1600.webp 1600w

YoutubeVideoID: https://wvva.objects.liquidweb.services/photos/1052-applepicking_aofilms_3-800.jpg 800w\">

ContentType: you’ll find plenty to love about spring throughout Oregon Wine Country. Sip your way through our world-famous vineyards
CreationDate: find fun for children of all ages in the North Willamette Valley
Excerpt:
or enjoy the outdoor abundance of the South Willamette Valley. 

But no journey to the Willamette Valley is complete without experiencing the majesty of Oregon Wine Country. As you travel through the Willamette Valley
AuthorUserID:
take time to taste world-renowned Pinot noir and drink in the magnificent vineyard views. See below for seven wonderful Willamette Valley vineyards we recommend with views you can’t afford to miss.

Did you know that Oregon wines fly free?

When you travel to Oregon Wine Country it's easy to take a taste of Oregon home with you
PublishDate: thanks to the Oregon Wines Fly Free program offered by the Oregon Wine Board

Travel Oregon and Alaska Airlines. If you’re not an Alaska Airlines mileage plan member you can sign up today for free. 

Learn more about the program and View Participating Wineries

"
column75: In Oregon's Wine Country we pair our wines with a lot more than cheese. Hikes, cycling, spa days, waterfalls; in Oregon wine goes with everything!

ContentText: NULL

PageDesc: Discover the Hidden Jewels of Kings Valley
NavButtonText: Discover the Hidden Jewels of Kings Valley
HeaderText: Discover the Hidden Jewels of Kings Valley
ContentText:
After visiting our daughter at Oregon State University in Corvallis, I headed out of town with my husband to the surrounding Kings Valley countryside to explore the wineries, restaurants, a sustainable shoe factory and yes, distilleries, in the community of Philomath, population 4,760.

Although Oregon is home to over 700 wineries, Philomath, ironically, was a dry town until 1948. In fact, the neighboring town of Monmouth was the last West Coast town in the United States to repeal its dry status in 2002.  

Thankfully, any vestige of prohibition is long gone, so try this weekend itinerary to explore this burgeoning community with an entrepreneurial vibe.

Stay in a vineyard cabin: The one of kind 1930’s renovated cabin on Lumos Vineyard, was a former H Bar H Dude Ranch. During your stay stop by the “great big barn”  where you can taste Lumos Pinot Gris, Pinot Noir and Pinot Blanc. As an added bonus, the cabin is stocked with binoculars for bird watching.

Little Wren Cabin at the Lumos Winery Vineyard, VRBO listing #668393.


Day One: Wine
PageType:
Spirits and Authentic Thai Food


Getting there:  From Corvallis
PageLevel:
drive six miles Highway 20E to Philomath

Start your adventure at the wineries along Highway 223

Travel Tip: You can download a free digital map at the local Benton County winery association website
PageSectionID:
Heart of the Willamette

The first stop on Arlie Road is appropriately Airlie Winery
ParentPage: which is certified sustainable and Salmon Safe and one of only 41 wineries that are certified LIVE  – Low Input Viticulture and Enology. Arlie has been women owned and operated since 1986 and features dry Pinot blanc
HideFromNav:
and Oregon’s famed Pinot noir.

Next stop on Arlie Road is the family owned and operated Emerson Winery where you can enjoy estate grown Pinot noir and the Friday Summer Music Series.

After Emerson
DisplayListings: head south on Hwy 223 towards Philomath to the tasting room at Cardwell Hills
AccountCatIDForListings:
another Salmon-Safe winery to taste the multitude of award winning wines with names like “The Bard Chard” and “Old Vines Pinot Noir” which garnered a 91 point award from the famed James Suckling.

And then it’s time for Happy hour cocktails at Harris Bridge Vineyards
SortOrder:
which are accompanied by complimentary recipes and original poetry inspired by the location on every bottle.  


Harris Bridge Cocktail recipe:

A Dream Rooted:

  • 2 oz Reverie sweet vermouth
  • 1 oz gin
  • 1 bar spoon Benedictine
  • 1 splash ginger beer
  • Mix first 3 ingredients with ice
DisplayArticles:
• Add a twist of orange peel and serve!


    • Harris Bridge Vineyard winemakers Nathan and Amanda Sever make Pinot gris and Pinot noir vermouth
PageLogo: aperitifs
FeatureBlockTitle2: and brandy. The duo harvests their grapes around 23 brix
FeaturedActivityTitle1: earlier than traditional ice wines or other “late harvest” dessert wines
FeaturedActivityTitle2: which gives the wine finished wine acidity to balance the sweetness. Visit the winery for an experience beyond the bottle with a walk to the river and historic covered bridge
PartnerText:
and picnics under the oaks.


Time for Thai or Americana? Head to dinner at the Woodsman
DisplayPartnerColumns: a hidden gem in what was once a lumberjack town. Although the name
YoutubeVideoID: and type of food all seemed to contradict each other in this former logger bar
VideoTitle1:
when Nong Sisovahn bought the establishment she introduced a Thai menu to the standard American fare and made it all work. The result is a perfect blend of burgers and beer or pad thai and Pinot gris.


Tour Day 2: Handmade Shoes
MetaDescription:
and on the farm dining


Breakfast at the Dizzy Hen:  Open every day except Monday 7:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. the newly opened Dizzy Hen serves locally sourced cuisine for the crowds lined up on the sidewalk waiting patiently. After tasting the vegan hash and The Dizzy – poached eggs with ham
SEOTags: chard and bechamel sauce on biscuits for a very reasonable $10.50
SeoNotes: it’s definitely worth the wait! Afterwards
SEOStatus:
get some more homemade goodness next door at Nutcakes Donut Bakery.


Soft Star Shoes Founders Tim and Jeannie Oliver learned to sew soft leather shoes from a local artisan after they couldn’t  find healthy shoes for their daughter. Their first official shoemaking workshop was in a renovated school bus and thirty years later they are still in a repurposed building in downtown Philomath
ProposedHeaderText:
the former “Philo-O-Rink” roller skating rink. Watch “the elves” at work creating handmade shoes and don’t forget to take a turn on the indoor slide.

After your artisan tour
ProposedBrowserTitle: explore one of Oregon’s smallest productions facilities at Panache
SEOPaidSearch: only five minutes from downtown Philomath. Despite the wineries pint sized locale
CreationDate:
Tempranillo and Sangiovese.

Ten minutes from Panache is another urban nano winery
AuthorUserID: where owners Charlie and Marcia Gilson manage to create an impressive variety of wines
PublishDate:
including distinctive big reds and dessert wines harvested from grapes in Southern Oregon and Walla Walla Washington vineyards.

Ready for lunch yet? Head back to downtown Philomath to  Eats & Treats Cafe
ExpirationDate: a  gluten free eatery with a relaxed
IncludeInWidgets: friendly atmosphere. Try the BBQ pulled pork
TopLanding: turkey and ham smoked on site by owner Sandy McHenry. If you’re lucky enough
TopPageview: visit on Friday  when it’s Tri-tip Day. That’s when you will see Sandy
AuditTransferPage: fire up the “Big Rig” with oak wood and set to work on slow-cooking mouth-watering
AuditRefreshPage:
Santa Maria Style Tri-tip.

Feel like walking ? You won’t have to go far to visit the distilleries of Philomath. Visit Marcotte Distillery to taste one of Oregon’s first flavored small batch Moonshine producers. The Marcotte’s have created  twenty different amazing flavors ranging from fruit
AuditNavChange: including seasonal options. Enjoy two - ounce pours at the tasting bar of the popular Ella’s Silver Moon
column58:
Aimee Jo’s Strawberry Lemonade and Broc’s Buttery Coconut. And don’t pass by the mega or mini “Mooners Club” so you can have your ‘shine shipped to your doorstep!

One mile from Marcotte is the new Taproom at Nectar Creek Mead. 100 percent of the honey local brothers and owners Phillip and Nick Lorenz use for the carbonated
column59: refreshing brew is raw and sourced directly from sustainable beekeepers. Along with a sampler flight
column60: try a can of  the year round session mead flavors Sting ginger
column61:
Waggle Wildflower or Cluster Cranberry/Strawberry with a salmon sampler from the new bar menu.

And there’s still time and to walk downtown a few blocks east for happy hour at Spindrift Vineyards
column62:
which recently added a second Compton Family label.

One last meal to top off your day. Dine at Gathering Together Farm
column63:
where you can pick up produce at the farmstand and stay for dinner enjoying Pacific Northwest cuisine prepared directly from the on-site farm.


Additional Tour Options:

Coastal Range Hike and Beach-Bound: Mary’s Peak At 4
column64:
039 is the highest point in Oregon’s Coast Range. From Philomath drive 19 miles via 34W and you’re at Mary’s Peak Road with two options; drive to the top for a short hike to summit or park at the bottom and hike up for 5 mile round trip. Or enjoy a picnic downtown in Mary’s River Park and check out Philomath Rodeo & Frolic annual summer rodeo.

Catch Oregon trout

BrowserTitle: Bike the covered bridges of Linn County
HeaderText: Bike the covered bridges of Linn County
ContentText:
Drive, bike or walk through a collection of Oregon’s charming covered bridges.  Wander through the rural paths of Linn County, passing family farms, small towns and five covered bridges. Be sure to pack a lunch and stop at the park by Larwood Bridge for a little R&R. Bring your bathing suit and take a dip in the swimming hole – a local favorite - before heading back on the trail. If you work up an appetite during your trip, stop at Novak’s Hungarian Restaurant in Albany. The Novak family serves up some of the best food around in a comfortable, relaxing atmosphere.

Spend the night in one of many comfortable lodging facilities, like the Train House Inn, where you’ll learn a little about local history. The Victorian home was built to project the social standing of the original occupant Samuel S. Train, a local political figure, newspaper owner and editor. The beautiful home welcomes guests with cozy rooms, a pavilion, corner tower and wrap around porch, as well as some firsthand insight into days gone by.  Start your morning off right - with a cup of java from Boccherini’s Coffee and Tea House in Historic Downtown Albany. After breakfast, be sure to stop by the city’s many antique shops, offering hidden treasures dating back to when the region was first settled.

BrowserTitle: Food and Wine Trek in Yamhill Valley
HeaderText: Food and Wine Trek in Yamhill Valley
ContentText:
Yamhill County is wine country, where artisan vintners craft complex Pinots, and creative chefs use the region’s bounty as their palette for innovative menus. Start at the northern end of the valley, in Newberg, and make a private appointment to visit Chehalem Winery, one of Oregon’s best small premium wineries. Across the street is Rex Hill Vineyards, a retired nut-drying facility that now produces Pinot noir, Pinot gris, Chardonnay, Sauvignon blanc and Riesling. From Newberg, the rolling hills lead South to some of the region’s oldest and most innovative wine producers.

To sample vintages from across the state, visit one of the Willamette Valley’s founding culinary outposts, Nick’s Italian Café, which offers an extensive wine list, lunch and a five-course dinner. For fare that is uniquely Oregon, Dundee Bistro’s menu highlights wine country ingredients with dishes like Roasted Mushroom Pasta and Calrton Farms Pork Tenderloin.

Stay at A’Tuscan Estate in McMinnville and be surrounded by historic decor. Cooking classes are available upon request, but before you start, visit the McMinnville Farmers’ Market for fresh, locally grown fruits, vegetables and eggs, as well as gourmet cheeses, wine and fresh flowers from the region. Plan a getaway to Yamhill County, and you’ll leave with an appreciation for the dedication to artisan food and drink that region is famous for.

BrowserTitle: Freefall in Molalla
ContentText:
Get your blood pumping, feel the rush of the wind, and take in some incredible views of Mt. Hood, Mt. St. Helens, the Willamette Valley and beyond with Skydive Oregon.

After jumping from an airplane, it’s time to kick back, bite into a beer sausage and enjoy a pint on the porch of the Hoffman House Restaurant. This historic Victorian house also serves up stuffed mushrooms and mixed greens for those looking for something a little lighter after their soar in the clouds.

If you need to add more adventure to your day, head out to the Molalla River Recreation Corridor for recreational activities through the dense forests of this picturesque river canyon, including miles of hiking, biking and horseback riding trails and easy river access.

After an exciting and adrenaline-pumping day, relax at Rosse Posse Acres. A bed and breakfast that doubles as an elk farm, here you can get up close and personal with this majestic native Oregon species as they hone their fighting skills, grow large velvety antlers or welcome calves to the family.

BrowserTitle: Fun for the whole family on vacation in Oregon near Portland
ContentText:
MAKING MEMORIES ON A FAMILY-FRIENDLY BIKE TRIP IN LANE COUNTY

The Willamette Valley is home to some of the best family activities in the state. Make memories with your loved ones when you hop on a bike and explore winding roads and country trails on the Covered Bridges Scenic Bikeway. The Row River Trail portion of the bikeway starts in the charming small town of Cottage Grove
PageType: then takes you through three historic covered bridges. This section of the bikeway is paved and not shared with cars
PageLevel:
making it a safe and enjoyable experience for cyclists of all ages and ability levels.

Along the way families can discover Cottage Grove’s rich gold mining history at the Bohemia Gold Mining Museum
PageSectionID: which is at the start of the Scenic Bikeway. Run by modern day miners
ParentPage: the museum features artifacts
Status: photographs and old mining equipment. Or catch a play at the Cottage Theatre
InsertCode:
a community theatre that producers a year-round season of plays and musicals.

Let curiosity be your guide on a family-friendly bike trip along the Covered Bridges Scenic Bikeway.


EXPERIENCE ART AND HISTORY IN ALBANY

Discover Albany
IssuuCode:
a historical town full of new activities off the beaten path for everyone to enjoy. Visit the Historic Carousel and Museum where you can witness artistry in action. Friendly community volunteers are hard at work carving and hand-painting a menagerie of animals; kids are welcome to touch the animals and climb on some of the completed creatures.

Head back in time at The Monteith House
HideFromNav:
Oregon’s most authentically restored pioneer home. Also visit family-friendly Linn County Historical Museum and Thompson’s Mills State Park.


MORE FAMILY TRIPS

Country Living – Junction City
Take a journey on the Long Tom Country Trail
DisplayListings: a 40-mile (65-km) agricultural tour that includes stops at wineries
AccountCatIDForListings:
farms and the Kiger Mustang Ranch where kids can interact with animals.

Adventure with Rocky and Bullwinkle – Wilsonville
Have a great time while enjoying the 18-hole miniature golf course
DisplayArticles:
the arcade and the Kidopolis playland at the Family Fun Center & Bullwinkle’s Restaurant.

What’s Your 20? – Corvallis
Discover hidden gems of the city as you track your way around town on the Waymarking GPS Hunt. Take photos of your stops and bring them to the Corvallis Visitors Center to win a free prize!

The Plane! The Plane! – McMinnville
See the world’s largest plane
PageLogo: the Spruce Goose
FeatureBlockTitle1:
with a wingspan longer than a football field at the Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum.

Take Me Out to the Ballgame – Keizer
Catch a game with the family and cheer on the Salem-Keizer Volcanoes baseball team
FeatureBlockTitle2:
a Class A affiliate of the San Francisco Giants.

Enjoyable

which makes Salem an excellent family of voyagers vacation destination.

BrowserTitle: Feed your inner connoisseur in Eugene
HeaderText: Feed your inner connoisseur in Eugene
ContentText:
Eugene is a cultural potpourri, bringing together people of all backgrounds for a myriad of festivals and events. Everything from craft fairs and farmers markets exist in harmony with classical music festivals, inspirational museums, galleries, world-class ballets and more.

Eugene’s renowned Saturday Market brings tastes from around the world to the epicenter of the city. Marionberry pies and local hazelnuts are just a few of the delectable treats available to sample or take home. Fresh flowers, juicy fruits, crispy vegetables, crafts and live music await those wishing to experience local life. Families routinely make their way to the market for their weekly produce and a chance to connect with the community. Visitors can get to know the area with a new walking tour where they’ll make their way through downtown, visiting more than 30 locations of interest - including churches, art galleries, museums, cafes, shops and live music venues.

Take a step back in time and see Lane County as it once was at the Lane County Historical Society and Museum. With a mix of long-term exhibits, children's educational programs and a vast collection of historic photographs, the museum has plenty of memories to share. The Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art at the University of Oregon hosts art from around the world. The museum was recently remodeled and restored to hold collections from Asia, Russia and Europe, along with American regional pieces by artists of the Pacific Northwest.

Feel the music and savor the flavors at annual ethnic events like Fiesta Latina and the Japanese Obon & Taiko Drumming Festival. The Willamette Valley Folk Festival, held at Eugene’s open-air summer venue, the Cuthbert Amphitheater, gives a glimpse into the sights and sounds that shaped the history of our nation. The Hult Center for Performing Arts, located downtown near Eugene’s best restaurants and art galleries, hosts touring musicians, comedians and renowned artists as well as eight resident performing companies.

No matter how you choose to spend your time - dancing to live music at the annual Eugene Celebration, a festival that combines parades, music, art, film and more, or enjoying the talents of world-class musicians at the internationally acclaimed Oregon Bach Festival - there is always something to keep you entertained in Eugene. Keep in mind, it’s not all about Bach at the Bach Festival. Family events, educational programs and a wide range of music make up this event, held along the Willamette River.

For a special dinner made from local ingredients try the Oregon Electric Station, a national historic landmark featuring dining in antique railroad cars, or taste the scrumptious crepes and fondues at The Vintage, a literal vintage house located at 8th and Lincoln.

The Hilton Eugene and Valley River Inn are ideal lodging options for visitors wishing to be near the bustling downtown, while those who prefer to relax in one of the many peaceful surrounding neighborhoods would enjoy a stay in a historic home like The Campbell House or C’est La Vie.

BrowserTitle: Explore the culture and heritage of the Oregon Trail History near Salem, Or
HeaderText: Embrace the Traditions of Salem - Culture Seeker Experience
ContentText:
The Willamette Valley has been the cultural and political heart of Oregon since the Oregon Trail. Immerse yourself in Oregon lore in the state’s capital city, where cultural and historical experiences abound. Whether it’s enjoying modern art, museum hopping or learning about native heritage, choose from Salem’s many offerings.

Marvel at the magnificently restored 1926 Tudor Gothic movie palace, the Historic Elsinore Theatre
PageType: while enjoying artistic performances including concerts
PageLevel:
musicals and classic silent movies.

Appreciate a new point of view through historical and contemporary art at the Hallie Ford Museum of Art.

Go back in time at the historic Mission Mill Museum
PageSectionID:
where western Oregon’s settlement and early industry is highlighted by 1840s Mission-style houses and a 19th century woolen mill.

Absorb beautiful manicured gardens
ParentPage: nature trails
Status:
exquisite stained glass and golden oak woodwork at the Historic Deepwood Estate.

Stop by the Bush House Museum. The renovated historic building now houses two contemporary exhibition galleries courtesy of the Salem Art Association.

Meander through galleries
IssuuCode:
multi-cultural exhibits and events in Historic Downtown Salem.

Tour beautiful rolling hills in Salem’s countryside and indulge in some of the region’s finest vintages at Redhawk Winery.

Opportunities to enjoy music
DisplayListings:
dance and the visual arts abound in Salem.

Browse the Antique Powerland Museum featuring steam-powered equipment and antique farm machinery preserved by a diverse set of heritage clubs and museums.

Celebrate the award-winning Oktoberfest in the historic village of Mt. Angel with music
AccountCatIDForListings:
dance and food.

Walk or bike along the Willamette River and catch a glimpse of wildlife at the Champoeg State Heritage Area park.

Witness a real Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde Pow Wow for an unforgettable cultural experience.

MORE CULTURE TRIPS

Stroll Through First Friday Artwalk – Newberg
Explore the works of Yamhill Valley’s growing artist colony at First Friday Artwalk on the first Friday of each month from 5 – 9 p.m.

Walk On! – Corvallis
Make a customized self-guided walking tourand discover local history while viewing historic homes and buildings that provide a glimpse into the growth of this beautiful university town.

Honor the Brave and Proud – Wilsonville
Visit the Oregon Korean War Memorial and pay tribute to the 60
SortOrder:
000 Oregonians who fought and the 298 who gave their lives overseas from 1950-1953.

Go ‘Round Again – Albany
Be entertained as community volunteers carve a menagerie of animals to ride on a historic Gustave Dentzel carousel found at the Historic Carousel and Museum.

Get Crafty – Eugene Area
Take an adventure on a variety of self-guided tours of artists’ studios and galleries in the southern Willamette Valley with Oregon Crafted.

Feed you Inner Connoisseur in Eugene
Here’s another option for a captivating cultural experience. Oregon’s second largest city draws visual and performing artists from all over the world
FeatureChildPages:
which makes the Eugene area an ideal culture-seeking vacation destination.

Check out this inspired itinerary for experience arts
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
heritage and culture in Eugene.

Learn about opportunities to appreciate the arts in Eugene. Click to view.

BrowserTitle: The trip to Salem youï¿½ll remember for years
HeaderText: The trip to Salem youï¿½ll remember for years
ContentText: Balanced diets
PageType: river biology and the human body? Kids don’t need textbooks when they can immerse themselves in hands-on exhibits
PageLevel: like those at the A.C. Gilbert’s Discovery Village in Salem. Stop in at the Little Gem Candy Store on your way home for that favorite childhood sweet
PageSectionID:
or continue to reminisce by taking a turn on an Oregon-themed horse at the Salem River Front Carousel. This old-world style carousel is enjoyable for all ages; just close your eyes and become a kid again.

Visit the Wild West
ParentPage: run the river in a log canoe
Status: or take a walk down storybook lane - all to the sounds of fairy-tale music and children’s laughter at the Enchanted Forest. Children young and old can visit an authentic English village or haunted house before taking in a kaleidoscope of lights during the daily Fantasy Fountain’s Water-Light show. If that’s not enough to satisfy
IssuuCode: Oregon’s premier “family fun spot.” This park features two giant waterslides
AccountCatIDForListings: thrill rides
SortOrder: and a kiddie section. Great food
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
and live entertainment round out the experience.

Take a seat in the Governor’s chair at the Oregon State Capitol. Parents can photograph their future lawmakers as they help to draft legislation in the ceremonial office where bills are signed and press conferences are held. Guided tours will teach you about the history of Oregon
DisplayArticles: the Capitol building and the state’s legislative process. When the legislature is in session
PageLogo: visitors can sit in the Gallery above the House and Senate floors to watch proceedings in person. Before you leave
FeatureBlockTitle2: a symbol that sits atop the capitol
FeaturedActivityTitle1: honoring the sacrifices made by pioneers on the Oregon Trail. From here
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
you can see the city of Salem and catch a glimpse of the green fields of the valley beyond. Everyone who makes it to the top will receive a certificate of achievement signed by the Governor.

The historic Mission Mill Museum offers hands-on activities for kids to experience how life once was. Ever wonder what it was like to be a pioneer? Take part in traditional crafts and children’s games
PartnerTitle: or watch reenactments of Kalapuya Indian activities. With Mill Creek running through the grounds
PartnerText:
the museum is a tranquil park-like destination.

Hear a ball crack against the bat and enjoy a hotdog smothered in mustard at a Salem-Keizer Volcanoes baseball game. The club was named the “Best Class A Short Season Franchise” in the nation by Baseball America.

Enjoy a family dinner while taking in a movie at the Northern Lights Theater Pub. Early shows are open to all ages and the theater serves kid friendly food along with adult fare. From light comedies to PG-rated action flicks
DisplayPartnerColumns:
this theater has films the whole family can agree on.

Whether you’d like to stay within walking distance of the Capitol
YoutubeVideoID: or you’d prefer a unique bed and breakfast beside a scenic vineyard
VideoTitle1: the Salem area offers diverse lodgings that cater to every need and many that come complete with fireplaces
MetaDescription:
as well as restored historic homes and full breakfast fare.

BrowserTitle: Relax, Rest and Re-energize on your vacation to Northern Oregon Near Newberg
HeaderText: Kick Back and Relax in Yamhill - The Relaxer Experience
ContentText:
Crisp, fresh air. Emerald mountains and hills. Peaceful rivers and lakes. It all awaits you in the Willamette Valley. Relax and leave any worries behind in Yamhill County, where gorgeous scenery, fabulous wine and delicious food will captivate you.

Order your picnic lunch from Harvest Fresh Grocery & Deli in historic downtown McMinnville.

Browse Red Ridge Farms
PageType:
a family-owned specialty plant nursery and gift shop to find locally grown herbs and other treasures.

Pair your favorite wines with gourmet treats from Honest Chocolates designed to complement different varietals.

An enologist waxes poetic about having a picnic at Lange Winery in the Dundee Hills.

Stay at the romantic 1892 Queen Anne Victorian Mattey House Bed & Breakfast. Or roam around in the privacy of an entire home at the historic University House in Newberg.

Go green at the Lions Gate Inn Bed & Breakfast
PageLevel:
where environmentally friendly additions such as large solar panels and tank-less water heaters were added to enhance energy efficiency.

Pamper yourself at The Allison Inn & Spa
PageSectionID:
the first destination hotel and spa in Newberg – opening in August 2009.

Enjoy fine local cuisine from the renowned Joel Palmer House in Dayton
ParentPage:
the acclaimed Dundee Bistro in Dundee and the internationally known Painted Lady Restaurant in Newberg.

Take a stroll through Newberg’s historic district
Status: home to the First Friday Artwalk
InsertCode: and make sure to visit the Newberg Gallery
IssuuCode:
where you can browse seven different show rooms.

Winemaker Lynn Penner-Ash is a welcoming presence at Penner-Ash Wine Cellars near Newberg. (NEED PICTURE)

MORE RELAXING TRIPS

The Bridges of Lane County – Cottage Grove
See the largest collection of covered bridges west of the Mississippi on the 30-mile (48-km) Cottage Grove Covered Bridge Tour Route connecting seven covered bridges.

Pamper Your Soul – Molalla and Canby
Unwind with a complete spa experience at the J & S Center for Wellness and sample local wines at St. Josef’s Winery and Alexeli Vineyard & Winery.

Recharge Yourself – Corvallis
Treat yourself to a holistic spa experience at The Retreat Day Spa and Salon located a short distance from downtown.

Unique Antiquing – Aurora
Shop in Oregon’s first National Historic District
HideFromNav: with more than 25 antique and specialty shops
DisplayListings:
you’re sure to find something special.

Picturesque Tours Near Brownsville and Albany
Here’s another option for a revitalizing break. Located on the leeward slopes of the Oregon Coast Range among numerous river and streams feeding into the Willamette River
AccountCatIDForListings: the Linn county area is an excellent destination for a relaxing vacation. Drive on one of Oregon’s newest Scenic Byways
SortOrder: "Over the River and Through the Woods
FeatureChildPages:
" featuring beautiful sites along rolling rivers and friendly farm towns.

 And check out this itinerary for cycling through covered bridges near Albany.

Cyclists muse about taking a delightful
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
leisurely tour through Larwood Bridge. Click to view.

Learn about other vacation experiences >>

"

BrowserTitle: Find the flora and fauna around Corvallis
HeaderText: Find the flora and fauna around Corvallis
ContentText:
Amble along trails leading through forests of native plants and trees, all teeming with wildlife. In the heart of the Willamette Valley, McDonald Forest is home to birds, deer and the occasional bobcat. Nature enthusiasts can explore hiking and biking trails, happen upon deer grazing or catch the hoot of an owl echoing through the forest.

Aspiring botanists can explore Marys Peak, the highest point on the Oregon Coastal Range Mountains and home to multiple native species of moss, trees, plants and fungi. On a clear day, hikers can see both the Pacific Ocean and the Cascade Mountain Range. Multiple trails allow hikers to choose their difficulty level and campgrounds are available for overnight stays.

Bird lovers will appreciate the care that the William L. Finley National Wildlife Refuge has taken to provide a winter habitat for migrating Dusky Canada geese. Made up of 5,325 acres of protected land, visitors can watch these nomadic geese in winter months, and explore other native species that call the refuge home year-round.

After spending the day connecting with Corvallis’ natural environs, enjoy a meal made with fresh, local organic ingredients at Fireworks Restaurant. The Grilled Fish of the Day or Mediterranean Mezza Plate will quench your inner explorer before retiring for the evening. Visitors can stay at the Hanson Country Inn, a bed and breakfast on five acres of gardens and meadows, located just a few miles from town or one of our other very nice hotels!

BrowserTitle: Hike, Bike and enjoy nature in Oregon's Mt. Hood Area
HeaderText: Explorers Can Find It All in Oregonï¿½s Mt. Hood Territory
ContentText:
The Willamette Valley is home to pristine rivers, thriving forests and the nation’s richest farmland. Travelers looking for a trip in tune with nature will enjoy a wide array of experiences in Oregon’s Mt. Hood Territory.

Head out to the Molalla River Recreation Corridor for off-road adventure including miles of hiking
PageType:
biking and horseback riding trails and easy river access.

Pedal through beautiful rolling countryside with views of Mt. Hood towering in the background by following rides outlined in the Clackamas County Bike It! map.

Visit local farms and produce stands featuring refreshing country fare. The Flower Farmer
PageLevel:
Fir Point Farms and Swan Island Dahlias are favorites in the area.

Breathe in fresh mountain air at the Molalla River State Park
PageSectionID:
where you can spot native blue heron rookeries in their natural habitat.

Ride on the Canby Ferry
ParentPage:
one of the three ferries still in service on the Willamette River.

A local horseback rider is happy after a family ride through the Molalla River Corridor.

Learn about the rehabilitation of local wildlife and habitat by visiting the American Wildlife Foundation. Then take the family to Rosse Posse Acres – a working elk farm that includes a petting zoo with several animals and a bed & breakfast.

Enjoy a relaxing picnic and drink award-winning Pinot gris at St. Josef’s Winery's Jo-Lily Pond.

A mountain biker reconnects with nature in the Molalla River Corridor.

MORE NATURALIST TRIPS

Count Wildlife in the Baskett – Dallas
View a variety of birds
InsertCode:
reptiles and amphibians in their natural habitats at the Baskett Slough National Wildlife Refuge.

Experience the Living Rock Studio – Brownsville
Take your family to the Living Rock Studio made from locally found semi-precious rocks and crystals. After admiring the rocks
IssuuCode:
stop in for lunch at the Corner Café.

Wing It with Us – Veneta
Gather with birdwatchers and wine lovers for a fun-filled day of observing
HideFromNav:
tasting and learning at the annual Fern Ridge Wings and Wine Festival.

Fly Fishing in Wine Country – Dayton
Grab your fly rod and fish in the private four-acre Red Hills Lake connected to streams that stock the lake with trout for catch-and-release fishing.

Find the Flora and Fauna – Corvallis
Here’s another option for an amazing alfresco experience. Because a special effort has been made along the Willamette River to preserve and restore the ecosystems for all to enjoy
DisplayListings: the Corvallis area is an ideal nature vacation destination. Amble along trails leading through forests of native plants and trees
AccountCatIDForListings: all teeming with wildlife
SortOrder:
when you visit any number of the Benton County Natural Parks or the City of Corvallis Open Spaces.

And check out this idyllic itinerary for bird watching spots near Corvallis.

Birders enjoy the sights and sounds of the Finley National Wildlife Refuge. Click to view.


Learn about other vacation experiences >>

"

BrowserTitle: Foodie Finds near the Cherry City
HeaderText: Foodie Finds near the Cherry City
ContentText: Salem lies within Marion County
PageType: which is the largest producer of agriculture in Oregon
PageLevel: growing everything from tea leaves to turnips
PageSectionID: juicy berries to ripe cherries. Coined the Cherry City for its thriving cherry industry
ParentPage: Salem offers all kinds of delectable treats to tempt your taste buds
Status:
as well as the opportunity to see how many of them are grown or made.

Cherries & Chocolate
Salem’s cherry industry dates back to 1847
InsertCode: when pioneer nurseryman Henderson Lewelling brought 700 tiny trees over the Oregon Trail with him from Iowa. The industry continues to thrive
IssuuCode: and just west of the city lies Cherry Country Orchard & Chocolate Factory – a family-owned orchard and chocolate factory specializing in all-natural cherry products
HideFromNav:
including their signature product: dried cherries covered in rich milk or dark chocolate. Visitors are welcome to stop at the factory store for delicious samples and views of the lush cherry orchards.

Cheese
In addition to dozens of wine tasting rooms
DisplayListings: the Salem area is also home to one of the state’s few spots devoted entirely to cheese tasting. Willamette Valley Cheese Company was created by owner Rod Volbeda
AccountCatIDForListings: who spent more than a decade perfecting cheese recipes and nurturing his herd of jersey cows. The result is more than 30 varieties of buttery
SortOrder: handcrafted cheeses. Guests who visit the tasting room not only get to sample nearly all 30 varieties
FeatureChildPages:
but they also receive a tasting sheet for jotting down notes about their favorites.

Hazelnuts
There are more than 29
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: 000 acres of hazelnuts grown in Oregon and Pacific Hazelnut Candy Factory
PageLogo:
turns these delectable nuts into mouth-watering confections. Visitors can tour the factory to see how the candies are made and then sample them all in the gift shop.

Berry Pies & Other Delights
If pastries and pies filled with fresh
FeatureBlockTitle1: local fruit makes your mouth water
FeatureBlockTitle2: then you definitely don’t want to miss a visit to Willamette Valley Pie Company. Their farm store is located on the same property as the bakery and processing plant
FeaturedActivityTitle1: where guests can tour the facilities
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
watch the bakers in action and finish the experience with a slice of warm pie à la mode.

For more foodie finds near Salem
PartnerTitle:
go to www.TravelSalem.com.


(photo provided by: Cherry Country Orchard & Chocolate Factory)

"

BrowserTitle: Chase Waterfalls in Silver Falls State park
HeaderText: Chase Waterfalls in Silver Falls State park
ContentText: Situated in the foothills of Oregon’s Cascade Mountains is one of the state’s most spectacular natural wonders: Silver Falls State Park. The crown jewel of the Oregon State Park system
PageType: Silver Falls is Oregon’s largest state park (9
PageLevel: 000 acres) and home to one of America's most impressive waterfall hikes. The Trail of Ten Falls is a designated National Recreation Trail and lures photographers
PageSectionID: hikers and waterfall enthusiasts alike. There are exactly ten falls on this 8.7-mile loop (which can be reduced via two cutoff trails) and many have natural pathways that allow hikers to walk behind the falls for a breathtaking perspective. Silver Falls also offers opportunities for fishing
ParentPage: swimming
InsertCode: mountain biking and overnight camping. Campers can get cozy in an RV
HideFromNav:
rustic cabin or yurt – some of which are also pet-friendly.

Located approximately 15 miles from the Silver Falls is the historic town of Silverton - named one of America’s coolest small towns by Budget Travel Magazine in 2009. Enjoy a cocktail and casual fare at the Creekside Grill & Grotto Martini Bar or a fine dining experience at the award-winning Silver Grille Cafe. Silverton is also home to The Oregon Garden
DisplayListings:
a stunning 80-acre botanical garden. The Gordon House - the only house in Oregon designed by renowned architect Frank Lloyd Wright – also sits on the Garden grounds. Guided tours of both The Oregon Garden and the Gordon House are offered regularly.

Charming
AccountCatIDForListings: family-owned vineyards surround the area as well
SortOrder: including the aptly named Silver Falls Vineyard
FeatureChildPages: which offers a wide assortment of wines
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: including Port and dessert-style varieties. At nearby Pudding River Wine Cellars
PageLogo: boutique style wines at the farm’s cozy tasting room. Vitis Ridge is Silverton’s urban winery
FeatureBlockTitle1:
with its barrel and tasting room situated at the north end of town.

For more ideas and inspiration in planning your trip to the Salem area
FeatureBlockTitle2:
visit www.TravelSalem.com.


(photo provided by: Ron Cooper )

"

Join us for this free educational event for the tourism industry, designed to help travel-related organizations and businesses take advantage of the many opportunities and services offered by Travel Oregon and to learn about successful partnership opportunities around the state.

taste and eat.

NavButtonText: Celebrate Oregon Craft Beer Month in the Valley
BrowserTitle: Enjoy brews in the Willamette Valley during Oregon Craft Beer Month
HeaderText: Travel through BeerVana during Oregon Craft Beer Month
ContentText: Eugene
PageType:
Cascades & Coast 

Start your beer pilgrimage in Eugene
PageLevel: which has been affectionately dubbed “Brew-gene” for its abundance of breweries. Eugene’s brewery district is centralized in the historic Whiteaker neighborhood. Ninkasi Brewing started brewing in “the Whit” in 2007 and opened a tasting room in 2009. Eugene’s other major breweries
ParentPage: Oakshire & Falling Sky all have tasting rooms within walking distance from Ninkasi. Drive or bike out to Agrarian Ales
Status: located on a chili pepper farm ten miles north of Eugene in Coburg. They grow all their own hops and always have a chili pepper beer on tap. The tasting room is a farmstand that overlooks a cherry orchard
IssuuCode: hop vines and the verdant Willamette Valley. There are hula hoops
HideFromNav:
backyard games and even a yurt on the property; dogs and kids are always welcome.

Want to an easy way to hit the highlights of breweries in the Eugene area? Check out the Eugene Ale Trail.

Corvallis

Continue north through scenic countryside via Highway 99W to the friendly university town of Corvallis.  Sky High Brewing’s towering brewpub rises four stories above the surrounding downtown; enjoy a brew on their rooftop bar overlooking the Willamette River. Walk three blocks down the riverfront to Flat Tail Brewing
DisplayListings: named in honor the mascot of the local university
AccountCatIDForListings: the Oregon State Beavers. Two more blocks and you’ll find yourself at Block 15 Brewing
SortOrder: housed in a historic downtown building and with a wide variety of seasonal microwbrews on tap. Next door is  Les Caves Bier Taverne
FeatureChildPages: a pub modeled after the great dining pubs of Europe. On tap you can find beers ranging from local to international; their bottle list includes more than 120 fine bottled beers stored in a temperature and UV-light controlled bar. The Tap Room
DisplayArticles: will take you a little further south of town
PageLogo:
but the beers make it well worth the five minute drive. 

Albany

From Corvallis
FeatureBlockTitle1: take Highway 34 west into Linn County. Stop at the Eastgate Center
FeatureBlockTitle2: where you can visit three tasting rooms in one central location. 2 Towns Ciderhouse brews specialty hard ciders and was named one of Oregon’s five best ciders of 2014. Nectar Creek Honeywine brews mead crafted from local honey
FeaturedActivityTitle1: and Mazama Brewing specializes in Belgian-style beers. Continue to the historic town of Albany
FeaturedActivityTitle2: home of the state’s largest collection of historic buildings. Stop to view the almost complete Historic Carousel Carving Studio and Museum
PartnerTitle: where volunteers are hand-carving animals for a historic carousel. Walk down the riverfront path to Deluxe Brewing
PartnerText: Albany’s first “brewstillery;” both microbrews and fine spirits are created in their converted industrial building. Just blocks away is Calapooia Brewing Co.
DisplayPartnerColumns:
a cozy brewpub famous for their award-winning chili beer.

Salem

Just north of Albany
PartnerCityTitle: Oregon’s capital city has come into its own as a brewing center. Family-owned Gilgamesh Brewing occupies a renovated warehouse turned into a full-scale brewery and restaurant. Sip a microbrew in their outdoor seating alongside Pringle Creek. The latest brewery to come to Salem – Salem Ale Works - was opened in July 2013 by two college friends and former wildland fire fighters who founded their business on the motto “friends don’t let friends drink swill.” Let your inner child out at the Coin Jam
YoutubeVideoID: Salem’s first “barcade” featuring old-school video games
VideoTitle1: plus pub grub & local beers on tap. Take Highway 22 west to the farming town of Independence
VideoTitle2: where the Chatoe Rogue Hop Farm grows hops
SeoNotes:
which is then transformed into handcrafted beer and spirits by the fiercely independent Rogue Brewing Company. 

Yamhill Valley

Stop to sip local Pinot as you travel north though the vineyards of Yamhill Valley
SEOStatus: but don’t worry--wine isn’t the only thing local artisans have perfected. The foodie town of McMinnville is Grain Station BrewWorks
ProposedHeaderText: located in a renovated barn in McMinnville’s historic Granary District
ProposedMetaDescription: anchoring McMinnville’s brewing scene for more than 20 years. Stay in the historic McMenamin’s Hotel Oregon
SEOPaidSearch:
a quirky downtown hotel with hand-painted artwork in the rooms and a rooftop bar. Don't miss a stop at Wolves and People Farmhouse Brewery to enjoy their small production artisan-crafted brews in their historic barn or at picnic tables surrounded by hazelnut trees. Chehalem Valley Brewing Company offers food along with their hand-crafted ales in a pub setting.  Dundee’s Deception Brewing Company makes a selection of artisan beer with indoor and outdoor seating.

Oregon’s Mt Hood Territory

Take a trip back in time as you travel from the Yamhill Valley to Oregon’s Mt. Hood Territory. Stop and explore Champoeg State Heritage Area and get an ice cream cone at the Historic Butteville Store
SEOPaidBanner: dating from 1863 and considered the oldest continously operating store in Oregon. Ride the historic Canby Ferry
SEOPaidSocial: especially delightful in August and September when dahlias are in bloom
ContentType: and always popular with the biking crowd. Enjoy an incredible meal at Dar Essalam in Wilsonville
CreationDate: which serves up an evocative Moroccan atmosphere
Excerpt: paired with authentic cuisine from the region. Afterward stop by the Beer Station for a pint of your favorite Oregon microbrew. At the neighboring McMenamin’s Old Church and Pub in a renovated church
IncludeInWidgets: movie screenings and special events. Today
DataFinds:
the interior of the pub is filled with unusual artwork and colorful murals that hearken back to the Church’s long history.

 

"

BrowserTitle: Explore the best restaurants in the Willamette Valley
HeaderText: Culinary Adventures - Explore the bounty of the Willamette Valley
ContentText:
Foodie Fantasy

Take a food-inspired trip through Oregon Wine Country


Day One:

Start your trip at the north end of the Willamette Valley
PageType: in Oregon's Mt. Hood Territory. Take a tour of the Molalla Country Farm Loop to meet purveyors of local food
PageSectionID: native plants & flowers.  Gather your provisions for a picnic while you learn all about elk and come away with some ranch-made elk meat products from the picturesque Rosse Posse Acres Elk Ranch. As featured in Wine Spectator magazine
ParentPage: the AlexEli family is personally involved in each winemaking step from picking to pressing to pouring at AlexEli Vineyard & Winery. They are also the makers of the only kosher Pinot noir in Oregon. Walk down to their gazebo for a lakeside picnic of handcrafted
Status: small batch cheese from Goldin Artisan Goat Cheese
InsertCode:
some elk sausage and top it off with a slice of Marquam Meadows Fruit Company’s freshly made apple pie.

Continue your trek to the countryside and rural towns of Yamhill County. Drive along the scenic country roads and drop in for a leisurely wine tasting at Stoller Vineyards in Dayton or a cold pint at Grain Station Brew Works in McMinnville after touring the Evergreen Aviation Museum
IssuuCode: home of Howard Hughes’ Spruce Goose.  Dine at the internationally-inspired and historic Joel Palmer House
HideFromNav:
whose menu celebrates wild mushrooms in their ‘freestyle cuisine’ that pairs their international flavors with Oregon wines.

Day Two:

Continue to Salem
DisplayListings: where you'll find that Oregon's capital city has much to offer the foodie traveler
AccountCatIDForListings: with orchards
SortOrder: vineyards and artisan inspired cafes. The Grand Hotel is the perfect spot to base your explorations with so many culinary treats in the downtown area. Start your morning at The Governor's Cup for locally roasted coffee
FeatureChildPages: and for lunch hit The Wild Pear
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: which serves fresh seasonal fare. Pick up some cheese at Willamette Valley Cheese Co. or the E.Z. Orchards Farm Market for some local farm-fresh snacks on your way to Brooks Winery. Head back to Salem for a late dinner at Rafns
DisplayArticles:
where they serving a small seasonal menu paired with a carefully crafted wine list. 

Begin your day at Busick Court
PageLogo: where breakfast is served all day
FeatureBlockTitle1: before checking out the Willamette Valley Fruit Company. Seasonally fresh and frozen berries fill their famous fruit pies and baked goods. Pick some fruit or take a tour. Stop by the tasting room of 1859 Cider Co
FeatureBlockTitle2: which crafts outstanding fermented ciders from seven generations of farming in Salem
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
Oregon.

Day Three:

Known for its 700 historic buildings and remarkably well preserved downtown
FeaturedActivityTitle2: Albany sits in the heart of the lush Willamette Valley. Get an authentic European-style breakfast at the only Hungarian restaurant in Oregon
PartnerTitle: Novak’s.  Tour the Historic Carousel and Museum to witness or learn first-hand the time honored techniques used to create the carousel animals. Across the street from the carousel is Sybaris
PartnerText:
an eclectic Northwest bistro owned by a James Beard honored chef. Grab a pint at Calapooia Brewing to get a taste of why Oregon is a hotbed for great micro-brews.

Just across the Willamette River from Albany
DisplayPartnerColumns: pay a visit to <a href=\"http://www.visitcorvallis.com\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"Corvallis
PartnerCityTitle: Oregon\">Corvallis. You can’t get much closer to the source than dining at Gathering Together Farm
YoutubeVideoID: a certified organic vegetable and fruit producer. Their on-farm restaurant serves seasonally creative French and Italian fare blended with Northwest cuisine.  For wine-lovers
VideoTitle1: Tyee Wine Cellars is located on the Buchanan Family Century Farm with picnic areas and nature trails. For dinner
VideoTitle2: try the del Alma Restaurant & Bar in downtown Corvallis which combines the flavors of Latin America
MetaDescription: the Caribbean and Spain. Stay overnight at The Hansen Country Inn
SEOTags:
a beautiful bed & breakfast in a historic home on the edge of town.

Day Four

Continue your journey to Eugene
SeoNotes: where you'll find all kinds of craft beverages and unique restaurants.  Start with a fantastic breakfast at the Noisette Pastry Kitchen or a decadent pastry at Sweet Life Patisserie. The Whiteaker Neighborhood
ProposedHeaderText: is just west of downtown Eugene and home to wineries
ProposedBrowserTitle: breweries and a host of eclectic cafes
ProposedMetaDescription:
restaurants and food carts; whether your taste buds are looking for Willamette Valley Pinot noir at Oregon Wine LAB or an IPA at Coldfire Brewing. 

For those seeking fine dining paired with fine wine
SEOPaidBanner: the largest winery in the state. Their restaurant sources locally and uses organic produce grown on-site at their 1
SEOPaidSocial: 033-acre estate. Travel over the bridge to neighboring Springfield to enjoy George and Violets Steakhouse for a delicious steak dinner. Guests staying at upscale Inn at the 5th will enjoy the delicious seasonal meals at Marché
ContentType:
one of Eugene’s premiere restaurants located right next door.

"
column70: Willamette Valley restaurants feature farm to fork dining paired with our best Oregon wines. Best restaurants in Salem, Eugene, McMinnville & Newberg Oregon.

BrowserTitle: Bring your bike and enjoy Oregon
ContentText:
Eugene, Cascades & Coast

Begin your journey in Eugene
PageType: located at the southern end of the Willamette Valley just two hours south of Portland. You’ll find a collection of locally-owned shops
PageLevel: urban tasting rooms and restaurants. Cycle the extensive bike path system throughout the city
PageSectionID: or head to nearby Fern Ridge Reservoir for a fun day of boating and swimming. Discover the many vineyards that line Territorial Highway
ParentPage: then cozy up for the night at a hotel or bed and breakfast. The next morning
Status: begin your ride with serious carbo-loading at Off the Waffle
InsertCode: a local favorite featuring gourmet European-style waffles. Bike out to Armitage Park
IssuuCode:
where you head northward on the Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway.

Corvallis 

Enjoy a short hike at the historic Tyee Winery located on a certified Century Farm. It is noted for its sustainable practices and art gallery. While there
HideFromNav: savor a glass of their Pinot under the old apple tree
DisplayListings: from a seedling that made the journey across the Oregon Trail. If you feel like really getting away from it all
AccountCatIDForListings: Marys Peak is an ideal place for mountain biking or an overnight hike. With a campground situated on the highest peak on the Oregon Coast Range
SortOrder: it is an enjoyable place to hike and bike for miles and miles. If you are looking for a more laid back ride
FeatureChildPages: start at the Irish Bend Covered Bridge and follow the meandering road that leads you to Bald Hill. Gentle paved pathways circle the base of Bald Hill for a mellow ride
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: or take a trail ride all the way to the top
DisplayArticles:
where you’ll find a bench perfect for savoring views over the valley. 

Albany

Continue along the Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway
PageLogo: veer off the path to Historic Brownsville
FeatureBlockTitle1: where everything is within walking distance and the movie “Stand by Me” was filmed. After you’ve enjoyed a snack at Randy’s Main Street Coffee
FeatureBlockTitle2: continue on to historic downtown Albany
FeaturedActivityTitle1: including the upscale Sybaris Bistro
PartnerTitle: the Historic Carousel and Museum
DisplayPartnerColumns: and the Albany Antique Mall
PartnerCityTitle: all within a ten-block area. At the Carousel Museum
YoutubeVideoID: you’ll find volunteers hand-carving and hand-painting a 52-animal carousel which will eventually be located on the banks of the Willamette. Tours of the carousel are free and include a behind-the-scenes peek into the carving studio
VideoTitle1:
where you can watch artists at work. Cycle  past historic homes or take a paved riverfront path to the Calapooia Brewery (); enjoy a glass of their famous chili beer while you cool off on their covered patio.

Salem

Make a rejuvenating stop along your ride to catch a river breeze along the Willamette River as you detour through Salem (www.travelsalem.com)
VideoTitle2: Oregon’s Capital City. Salem is split by the mighty Willamette River next to lush forests
MetaDescription: fields and bird-filled wetlands. Stop at Salem’s Riverfront Park and watch an Osprey catch its next meal; or enjoy a ride on the hand-carved Carousel
SEOTags: or reinvent yourself at A.C. Gilbert’s Discovery Village
SeoNotes: Salem’s year-round children’s museum. You will want to take a stroll through Salem’s beautiful and historic downtown
SEOStatus: featuring sky bridge walkways and architectural delights that house specialty shops
ProposedHeaderText: galleries and restaurants. Historic downtown Salem offers a Wednesday Farmers Market
ProposedMetaDescription: and a Saturday Market (April through October). Both feature locally grown fruits and vegetables
SEOPaidBanner:
candy and an unending array of culinary pleasures. The weekly markets also offer a wide selection of fresh flowers and art from local artisans – it is truly a feast for all senses.

Yamhill Valley 

The sweet song of spring warblers will lure you to explore the Willamette Valley Birding Trail Yamhill Loop. Stop for a fresh
SEOPaidSocial: Northwest-inspired lunch at The Barlow Room in historic Dayton
ContentType: then head to Winter’s Hill Vineyard to explore trails specially designed for birdwatchers. Nest boxes for the Western Bluebird line the road up to the vineyard
CreationDate: and Acorn Woodpeckers are resident in nearby oaks. Sample a Reserve Pinot Noir or crisp Pinot Gris at the Winter’s Hill tasting room. Enjoy spectacular vineyard views as you cycle from Winter’s Hill along Hilltop Lane to Wine Country Farm
Excerpt:
a bed & breakfast located on a working farm that raises wine grapes and Arabian horses.

Oregon’s Mt Hood Territory 

Historic Champoeg State Park lies just south of Wilsonville in Oregon Horse Country and boasts ten miles of hiking and biking trails. The paved cycling trail winds through old growth hardwood forests
AuthorUserID: while the hiking-only trail curves along the banks of the Willamette. Champoeg State Park resides alongside the winding Willamette River Water Trail
PublishDate: so be on the lookout for canoeists and kayakers. A few miles further east will bring you to the height of your accomplishment when you and your two wheels pull into Skydive Oregon. Pull the ripcord on this adventure
ExpirationDate: then toast yourself and your mates at nearby AlexEli Vineyard. Feel free to let the award-winning bubbly go right to your head. End your great adventure with a ride into Oregon City
IncludeInWidgets: where you can put your bike on the train for free
DataFinds:
and ride the rails into downtown Portland or PDX for the flight home.

"
column83: Biking trails in the Willamette Valley in Corvallis, Eugene, Albany, Salem, the Yamhill Valley and in Oregon's Mt. Hood Territory.

BrowserTitle: Resources and Associations in Oregon's Willamette Valley Wine Country
ContentText:
There’s something to be said for a place that’s full of ingenuity and authenticity. From planting the first Oregon Pinot vine and trailblazing biodynamic wine to picking fresh organic berries off the bush, the Willamette Valley creates real experiences - and that makes all the difference.

In the heart of Oregon Wine Country
PageType: the Willamette Valley is rich in tradition and appreciation for great wine.  A majority of Oregon wineries continue to remain family-owned and eager to welcome visitors year-round.  Memorial Day and Thanksgiving weekends are especially popular
PageLevel:
because most wineries that are typically closed to the public open their doors for wine tasting and an exclusive look at their facilities.   

Willamette Valley winemakers are known for making some of the world’s best Pinot Noir as well as a diversity of other cool-climate varieties with a personal
PageSectionID: handcrafted approach. In addition to producing world-renowned wines
ParentPage: these wineries have set themselves apart through collaboration
Status:
sustainability leadership and passionate winemaking.
 




Willamette Valley AVAs

Chehalem Mountains Winegrowers
Dundee Hills Winegrowers Association 
Cascade Foothills Winegrowers
Eola-Amity Hills
Heart of Willamette Wineries
McMinnville
North Willamette Vintners

PageID:
South Willamette Wineries Association
Willamette Valley Wineries Association
Yamhill-Carlton


Additional Oregon AVAs
 
 
 

Oregon Wine Board
To see the breadth of the state and its appellations
PageDesc:
explore Oregon's viticultural areas via the Oregon Wine Board.

Oregon's regional grower and winery organization websites are helpful resources providing more details about the state’s wineries.
 


Did you know that Oregon wines fly free?
 
When you travel to Oregon Wine Country
NavButtonText: it's easy to take a taste of Oregon home with you
BrowserTitle: thanks to the Oregon Wines Fly Free program offered by the Oregon Wine Board
HeaderText:
Travel Oregon and Alaska Airlines.

What you need to know:

  • One free checked case per Alaska Airlines Mileage Plan member
  • Your checked case does not count toward your baggage allowance
  • Mix and match bottles or bring a whole case from your favorite Oregon winery
  • Free tastings do not apply on holiday weekends or during special winery events
  • Visit our FAQs page if you have more questions

If you’re not an Alaska Airlines mileage plan member you can sign up today for free. Then
ContentText:
find an Alaska Airlines flight from your city and start planning your dream trip to any of Oregon’s diverse wine regions.
Alaska Airlines Mileage Plan members will receive a free tasting at participating wineries
PageType: and can check one case of Oregon wine for free on all domestic flights from participating Oregon airports (Medford
ParentPage:
plus Walla Walla).

Learn More or View Participating Wineries.
