BrowserTitle: Wineries and Wine tasting through Oregon and the Willamette Valley

NavButtonText: Celebrate Harvest in Mt. Hood Territory
BrowserTitle: There is plenty to entice your taste buds in Oregon's Mt. Hood
HeaderText: Savor Food in the Fields in Mt. Hood Territory
ContentText: Growers in Oregon's Mt. Hood Territory are celebrating harvest in a big way this fall. Field & Vine Events
PageType: headed by chef-owner Pascal Chureau of Allium Bistro in West Linn
PageLevel: has partnered with Oregon Farm Loop for a farm dinner series in The Territory
PageSectionID: complete with the iconic center-field communal table with twinkling candles and glimmering wine glasses. Tour the farm
ParentPage:
wine in hand; then relax into seven courses celebrating locally farm-grown produce and wine. There are still several dinners available this year all the way into December.

Fun Festivals

Visit St. Josef's Sept 20-21 for the Pacific Northwest’s original Grapestomping Festival! Enjoy Bavarian music
InsertCode: and try your skills at grape stomping in a 10-foot oak barrel that holds the equivalent of 3
IssuuCode:
200 bottles of wine!

Harvest time also means Wooden Shoe's Pumpkin Fest is coming up Sept 27-Nov 2. Celebrate the harvest season with archery tag
AccountCatIDForListings: a paintball gallery
DisplayArticles: hay rides and the famed Iverson Potato Cannon. Plus
PageLogo:
kids 12 and over will love their Halloween Hauntings attraction.

 Farm-to-table cooking

And for an intimate harvest experience
FeatureBlockTitle1: try a new farm to table cooking class at The Kitchen at Middleground Farms
FeatureBlockTitle2: a new recreational cooking school located on a family hobby farm in Wilsonville. The Kitchen resides in a refashioned cattle barn
FeaturedActivityTitle1: equipped with a modern kitchen and state-of-the-art appliances. A vegetable garden provides stock for the kitchen
FeaturedActivityTitle2: as does the family’s 15 laying hens and small herd of Nubian dairy goats. Neighboring farms and local artisan producers provide much of the rest. Their primarily hands-on cooking classes are technique-driven as opposed to recipe-driven
PartnerTitle:
to help you:

  • Practice the proper use and care of knives.
  • Learn to gracefully prepare a four-course meal for friends
  • Discover different kinds of milk and learn to make cheese.
  • Discover new uses for unique summer vegetables available from the market or your CSA.

 

Make the memories last
PartnerText: and find your perfect lodging during your autumn wine country getaway. For more trip ideas

BrowserTitle: Visit Eugene for endless culinary and foodie vacations
HeaderText: Eugene, Cascades and Coast Culinary Adventures
ContentText:
Eugene anchors the south end of the Willamette Valley. From Oregon’s largest winery to boutique and urban tasting rooms, breweries and farm-to-table dining, the Eugene, Cascades & Coast region takes culinary getaways to tasty new heights. Located along the Willamette River and surrounded by vineyards, hop farms and verdant farmland, the area’s winemakers, brewers and chefs transform the culinary bounty found outside of their doors into divine culinary creations.

Every January, culinarians from around the world unite in Eugene for the Oregon Truffle Festival, inspiring Fodor’s Travel to name Eugene one of Five Trips for Truffle Lovers.

With real adventures, real close, the region is a paradise for the culinary and outdoor adventurer. Epic mountain bike trails, kayaking, birding, and hiking await! Pedal through wine country, under historic covered bridges and by lava fields on the area’s three Scenic Bikeways. Scale 200 foot tall Douglas firs into the canopy of an old growth forest at Pacific Tree Climbing Institute, or ride the raging rapids of the McKenzie River on a whitewater rafting adventure.
AccountCatIDForListings: NULL
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Visit Corvallis, Or in the Fall for a fabulous wine adventure
HeaderText: Corvallis: a fall feast for the senses
ContentText:
Plan a wine country getaway in Corvallis this fall and you’ll enjoy a feast for all your senses.

Delight in mild days followed by crisp clear nights
PageType: and sight-see amid fall foliage in full color with glorious shades of red
PageLevel: orange and yellow offset by amazing evergreens. You can taste the goodness at family farms
ParentPage:
and artisan wineries around the Corvallis area.

Taste the Bounty

You can truly appreciate the bounty of the Corvallis area by sampling produce at the Corvallis Farmers Market or visiting farms such as Davis Family Farms. Go for a hayride
InsertCode:
and grab some hot apple cider to bring home and enjoy. 

Corvallis’ downtown restaurants take great pride in preparing food with fresh
HideFromNav: and at the height of harvest come prepared to be wowed by amazing culinary creations. After a meal
DisplayListings:
stop at one of the region’s wineries for oustanding wines like the 2012 Estate Pinot Noir from Tyee Wine Cellars--it was just named the top wine in Oregon in a blind taste taste by Portland Monthly Magazine.

The vineyards are spectacular in the autumn months
AccountCatIDForListings:
as the preparations for harvest get underway. Stop to meet the winemakers and taste some of the sensational varietals the Willamette Valley is famous for.

See the Sights

Another don’t-miss experience on a fall visit to the Corvallis area is a tour through one of three covered bridges in Benton County. For a photographic treat
SortOrder: head for Harris Bridge Vineyard
FeatureChildPages: which boasts beautiful views of a historic covered bridge right next door to a vineyard. This vineyard/distillery specializes in complex dessert wines
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: liqueurs and aperitifs. Wander past beautiful Marys River
DisplayArticles:
old oak trees and of course the bridge.

Stay to explore

Once you have seen and tasted the Corvallis area
PageLogo: stay to explore the town and countryside. Choose to visit a cozy B&B like the Hanson Country Inn
FeatureBlockTitle1: or an upscale hotel such as the <a title=\"Holiday Inn Express on the River
FeatureBlockTitle2: Corvallis\" href=\"http://www.ihg.com/holidayinnexpress/hotels/us/en/corvallis/cvoor/hoteldetail\" target=\"_blank\">Holiday Inn Express on the River
FeaturedActivityTitle2: Corvallis\" href=\"http://hiltongardeninn3.hilton.com/en/hotels/oregon/hilton-garden-inn-corvallis-CVOCHGI/index.html\" target=\"_blank\">Hilton Garden Inn located just across the street from Oregon State University
PartnerTitle:
or the Comfort Inn & Suites conveniently located in the center of town.

For more getaway ideas in the Willamette Valley
PartnerText:
go to www.VisitCorvallis.com and plan your perfect autumn wine country vacation.

"

BrowserTitle: Freshwater diving in Albany, Or
HeaderText: Dive into Adventure at Clear Lake
ContentText: Geologists call it \the lake born of fire
PageType: \" but to the rest of the state’s hikers
ParentPage: it’s Clear Lake: one of Oregon’ most stunningly pristine mountain lakes. It’s perfect for kayaking
InsertCode: bring scuba diving gear and explore the submerged 3
HideFromNav: 000 years ago when a volcanic eruption blocked a mountain spring
DisplayListings: the newly-formed lake covered up surrounding forest land
AccountCatIDForListings:
and the coldness of its alpine waters has kept those ancient trees preserved in the depths of the lake. Freshwater divers consider it one of Oregon’s best scuba diving spots.

If you prefer to explore from the surface
SortOrder: rent a rowboat from the Clear Lake Resort on the lakeshore. To preserve the serenity of the lake
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: so let yourself bask in the serenity of your surroundings. Peer over the side and you’ll be able to see down to the lakebed
DisplayArticles: where the ancient lava flows and forests are still visible. Cast a line
PageLogo:
and you may be rewarded with a bite from a cutthroat trout.

You can grab a hearty burger and fries from the restaurant at Clear Lake Lodge
FeatureBlockTitle1: but make sure you save room for dessert—the lodge specializes in homemade fruit pies. If you’re there on a Saturday morning
FeatureBlockTitle2:
stop in for one of their famous homemade cinnamon rolls before they’re all gone.

Trails encircle the lake
FeaturedActivityTitle2: where Douglas firs tower above you and waterfalls rush down the hills. Mt. Washington’s stone spire and the peaks of the Three Sisters are visible on a clear day. After boating and hiking
PartnerTitle: you can choose from one of Clear Lake’s historic cabins with rustic accommodations
PartnerText: or a modern cabin with electricity
DisplayPartnerColumns: kitchen facilities and showers. Build a fire in Clear Lake’s historic stone fireplace
PartnerCityTitle: built by the Depression-era Civilian Conservation Corps
YoutubeVideoID:
and watch the starlight reflect off the lake water—there’s nothing like the serenity of a night in the Cascades.

For more mountain adventures in the Linn County area

BrowserTitle: Botanical Gardens to enjoy on your vacation to Central Oregon near Salem
ContentText: Someone once said, \A garden is a friend you can visit any time.\" In the Salem area
PageType: there’s no shortage of garden friends eager to welcome you with open arms. From rich roses to hardy hostas
PageLevel: many local growers not only showcase their plants for sale
PageSectionID:
but they have also created awe-inspiring display gardens that will delight visitors of all ages.

The Salem area is home to a number of beautiful botanical gardens. One you’ll definitely want to visit is the Dellbert Hunter Arboretum and Botanical Garden in Dallas
ParentPage: where you’ll find perennials
IssuuCode: wetland species and even dryland desert plants
HideFromNav:
thanks to the varied terrain contained within the Arboretum.

Sometimes referred to as Salem’s secret garden
DisplayListings: the Martha Springer Botanical Garden is located on the campus of Willamette University and offers a quiet place for contemplation and reflection. Opened in 1988 in honor of Professor Martha Springer
AccountCatIDForListings:
the 1-acre garden contains 12 smaller gardens stretched along the Mill Race stream that bisects the campus.

No botanical garden tour is complete without a trip to the area’s shining showpiece
FeatureChildPages: an 80-acre botanical wonderland located in Silverton
PageLogo:
water features and more. Well-behaved pets on leashes are even welcome to tour the gardens with you.

The Willamette Valley offers one of the finest climates in the world for growing roses
FeatureBlockTitle1: and you’ll find thousands of them displayed on five acres of themed gardens at Heirloom Roses in St. Paul. And if you love roses
FeatureBlockTitle2: but growing them seems to be a thorny subject
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
check out the farm's Saturday Rose Academy - an on-going series of monthly seminars designed to take the mystery out of growing roses.

Roses and other fair flowers can also be found at Historic Deepwood Gardens
FeaturedActivityTitle2: a 4.5-acre English-style garden surrounding Historic Deepwood Estate
PartnerTitle: created by landscape architects Elizabeth Lord and Edith Schryver in 1930. Deepwood Gardens feature covered arches and gazebos
DisplayPartnerColumns:
and a nature trail that weaves its way through the western border of the property.

From early May to mid June
PartnerCityTitle: the public is welcome at Adelman Peony Gardens
YoutubeVideoID:
where you'll encounter a kaleidoscope of color and 250 different peony varieties. The Gardens’ tree peony called Hephestos received the “Best of Show” award at the American Peony Society’s annual flower competition in 2012.

In business since 1925
VideoTitle1: Schreiner's Iris Gardens boasts 10 acres of display gardens open to the public
VideoTitle2: plus bulbs and cut flowers for sale. Bloom season at Schreiner’s begins mid May
MetaDescription:
so make a plan to bring a picnic lunch (picnic tables provided) and admire the beautiful blooms.

If you’re looking for hastas
SEOTags: be sure to visit Sebright Gardens in NE Salem
SeoNotes: where you can explore their large display garden and then select the perfect additions for your yard
ProposedHeaderText:
hardy ferns and other shade loving plants.

To see what else is blooming in the Salem area
ProposedBrowserTitle: go to the Official Salem Area Website

BrowserTitle: Deals and Specials for your next trip to Oregon Wine Country
ContentText: Everyone loves a bargain! Here are some special offers and deals from our partners around the Willamette Valley to make your Oregon Wine Country trip even more affordable.

BrowserTitle: The perfect trip for three days in Oregon wine country
ContentText:
Visiting Oregon Wine Country? Here's your guide to wining and dining your way through a long weekend in the Willamette Valley.

Day 1 (Mt. Hood Territory and Yamhill County)

Start the day with a coffee and breakfast at Gwynn's Coffee House in Canby. Afterwards
PageType: stop by one of the many U-Pick farms for your pick of blueberries
ParentPage: among other crops. At Morning Shade Farm you can pick blueberries
IssuuCode: Marionberries and Boysenberries. Fruit and veggies aren’t the only u-pick options in Mt. Hood Territory. Fill your vases with aromatic treasures like lavender and tulips from places like the Wooden Shoe Tulip Farm. If one farm isn't enough
HideFromNav: choose one of the many farm loops: Mollalla Farm Loop
AccountCatIDForListings:
and a portion of the Farmlandia Farm Loo

After you've pick to your hearts content
SortOrder: stop to sample local wine at a boutique winery like St. Josef’s Winery
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: or Beckham Estate. The winemaker behind Beckham Estates is also a talented potter; stop to browse the gallery adjacent to the tasting room
DisplayArticles:
and sip wine that's been stored in hand-crafted clay amphora.

Lunch
Take Hwy 99W to Yamhill County. Stop by a favorite of hometown winemakers
PageLogo: The Dundee Bistro. Like other area chefs
FeatureBlockTitle1:
Dundee Bistro's chef takes great pride in using locally grown organic ingredients that showcase the bounty of Willamette Valley’s farmers.

Afternoon Activities
As you enter the heart of Oregon’s wine country
FeatureBlockTitle2: you’ll find nearly 400 wineries ranging from large-producing estates to small
FeaturedActivityTitle1: boutique artisans such as WillaKenzie Estate. For a taste of multiple small-batch wines
PartnerTitle:
where you can sample hand-crafted wine made by independent winemakers. You can also stop by Erath Vineyards Winery to see one of the true pioneers of Oregon’s wine industry.  


Dinner
PartnerText: sans-serif;\"> Yamhill County has become the culinary hot spot of Oregon’s wine country – the perfect destination for any foodie. Enjoy innovative
DisplayPartnerColumns: seasonal dishes in a charming Victorian setting at The Painted Lady Restaurant. Nick’s Italian Café  in McMinnville is a legendary restaurant championed by winemakers and travelers alike. Enjoy Chef Nick Peirano’s handmade pasta and an extensive Oregon wine list.
PartnerCityTitle: sans-serif;'> Or visit the Joel Palmer House in Dayton
YoutubeVideoID: where Chef Chris creates culinary works of art based on sustainable
VideoTitle1:
regional ingredients – primarily wild mushrooms. 

Lodging
You don’t have to venture to the hills of Tuscany for an Italian retreat.  Centrally located in the Red Hills of Dundee
VideoTitle2:
the Black Walnut Inn is the perfect jumping off point for the area’s numerous world-class wineries and wide range of activities. Or try a little Glamping at The Vintages Trailer Resort.

Day 2 (Yamhill County
SEOTags:
and Eugene)

Breakfast
Enjoy a delicious breakfast your hotel
SeoNotes: or try the house-made granola at Community Plate
SEOStatus:
made with Oregon-grown hazelnuts and served with yogurt and honey. Then take 99W south to Corvallis. Saturday travelers will want to stop by the Downtown Waterfront to sample some of the region’s freshest local produce at the Farmers Market.  

Lunch

Enjoy the best of the Pacific Northwest’s fare at Big River Restaurant
ProposedHeaderText: or go Italian at American Dream Pizza. Or
ProposedBrowserTitle: get a taste of Asian fusion at Magenta. Here dishes are influenced by the many different foods of Southeast Asia and incorporate wild
ProposedMetaDescription:
bold flavors while remaining simple and tasty.

Afternoon Activities and Dinner
Continue south on Hwy 99 and arrive in Eugene
SEOPaidSearch: one of the Willamette Valley's southernmost cities. There's something for everyone here – from world-class arts
SEOPaidBanner: to outdoor adventure. Taste some of the valley's finest wine while enjoying spectacular views of the region at King Estate. This grand winery features 1
CreationDate: produce and flowers. After a tasting of Pinot gris
Excerpt:
savor an estate-grown meal in the restaurant.

Lodging    
The Inn at the 5th
AuthorUserID: is a boutique hotel that includes a relaxing day spa
PublishDate: fine dining and the historic Fifth Street Public Market
ExpirationDate:
full of artisan shops and eclectic restaurants. 

Day 3 (Eugene
DataFinds:
Salem area)

Breakfast
Begin your morning in Oregon's Emerald City with a hot cup of coffee or fresh juice and a visit to Sweet Life Patisserie
TopLanding: an artisan bakery serving specialty breads
MicrositeID: cookies and more using the Willamette Valley's freshest produce. Then depart Eugene by heading north on Interstate 5 towards
AuditTransferPage:
Albany. Take a Walking Tour of Albany’s four historic districts or drive through this friendly town as you immerse yourself in the past.

Lunch

For lunch
AuditTransferNotes:
an old-fashioned hamburger place with Northwest flair. Buns are made from scratch in-house daily and all meat and produce are sourced from local farmers.

Afternoon Activities

Depart Albany and head north on 1-5 and stop in for a visit to Willamette Valley Vineyards.  For over two decades they have been perfecting their craft
AuditNavChange: producing some of the best wines Oregon has to offer. Afterwards
column58: wrap up your tour of Oregon's Wine Country at Coria Estates to try a daily wine tasting
column59: or pick up a salsa lesson at Cubanisimo Vineyards.  End your day checking-in to the Oregon Garden Resort in Silverton
column60: where you will find a lush
column61:
flowing 80-acre botanical wonderland to explore while lodging in luxury. 

 

"
column88: This is the perfect three-day trip in the Willamette Valley. Tour wineries and enjoy farms and delicious food in Mt. Hood Territory and Yamhill County, Corvallis, Eugene Albany and Salem.

BrowserTitle: Wine Region of the Year 2016
ContentText: Each year
PageType: the editors of Wine Enthusiast honor individuals
PageLevel: companies and regions that have made outstanding achievements and contributions in the wine industry. Our humble valley earned their prestigious Wine Region of the Year award in 2016
PageSectionID: and the award was presented at the Wine Star Awards dinner in Miami on January 30
ParentPage: 2017. Fellow nominees include Provence
HideFromNav:
California.


“Wine lovers worldwide are traveling to Oregon to experience our valley first hand and find our winegrowers as welcoming as our valley is beautiful. The Willamette Valley is indeed a Star." 
-Jim Bernau
DisplayListings:
Founder of Willamette Valley Vineyards


While the number of wineries continues to grow
AccountCatIDForListings: Willamette Valley winemakers haven’t lost their personal
FeatureChildPages: or their desire to do things a little differently. Many winemakers in the Willamette Valley practice sustainable winegrowing techniques based on their respect for the land and desire to see future generations continue the winemaking tradition. Nearly half of all Willamette Valley vineyards are certified sustainable
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
making the valley the most sustainable wine region in the world. Learn a little bit about our winemaking history and plan your visit today.


"

BrowserTitle: West Cascades
ContentText: Enter the lush western slope of the Cascade Mountains and you are in an Eden of green with water at every turn. To the east you've got the every popular Pacific Coast Trail
PageType: and to the west you'll find Mt. Hood National Forest
PageSectionID:
not to mention historic covered bridges and hot springs that bubble up from deep within the earth.

Interested in a loop around the West Cascades Scenic Byway?  Just be sure to bring a fly rod
ParentPage: a mountain bike
Status:
and definitely a camera to enjoy any or all of these West Cascades offerings.


Biking and Hiking

If the bicycle is your travel mode of choice don’t miss the Aufderheide and Oakridge-West route - otherwise known as the mountain bike capital of the northwest. This seasonal route features smooth ribbon of pavement
InsertCode: a cathedral of trees above and the sound of a rushing river beside you — it doesn’t get much better than this road. You can ride the Aufderheide with equal pleasure from either direction (as a 130-mile round-trip it’s grueling); it’s a classic up- and-over
IssuuCode:
letting you work hard for the first half and enjoy the fruits of your labors for the rest. Along the way you’ll follow a fork of the Willamette River and pass Cougar Reservoir; consider a dip in the Terwilliger Hot Springs near the reservoir.

Just outside the mountain town of Oakridge offers world- class mountain biking trails
HideFromNav: great hiking routes and majestic water-falls. Known as the “Mountain Bike Capital of the Northwest
DisplayListings: ” Oakridge lures fat-tire enthusiasts every summer with Mountain Bike Oregon for two weekends of guided rides
AccountCatIDForListings:
demos and riverside camping.


Hot Springs & Covered Bridges

If you are traveling with kids
FeatureChildPages: family-friendly events along this corridor. Try the McKenzie River Chainsaw Art Festival and the Oregon Lavender Festival during the summer months
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
or enjoy the hot springs almost all year round.

Belknap Springs is a mineral springs spa that has operated for nearly 150 years. Farther west past McKenzie Bridge
DisplayArticles: the Belknap Covered Bridge spans 120 feet and is strong enough to support logging trucks
PageLogo:
and has a covered bridge at the site since 1890.

Farther up the road you'll find Breitenbush Hot Springs Retreat and Conference Center
FeatureBlockTitle1: a privately owned resort in the sylvan old growth forest setting. Open year-round
FeatureBlockTitle2: this unique resort offers hot springs
TopPageview: Find adventure and fun where the Cascade mountains meet the Willamette Valley. Mountain biking, hiking. Explore the Cascades Scenic Byway, Terwilliger Hotsprings and covered bridges.

BrowserTitle: Winter in the Willamette Valley
PageType: geneva; font-size: small;\">Winter in the Vineyard by Cindy Easterly
PageLevel: geneva;\">While temperatures may be a bit lower than most years in the Willamette Valley
PageSectionID: we're lucky to have relatively mild weather throughout the winter. Sure
ParentPage: it’s rainy (and maybe a bit snowy and icy) but with a little bit of gear and the right attitude
Status: you can enjoy the beauty and tranquility of the great outdoors followed by tasting room after tasting room of award-winning Pinot
IssuuCode: the Willamette Valley picked up the Wine Region of the Year award in 2016. So stop off to sip and buy a few bottles for friends and family. We can't wait to see what 2017 will bring.
HideFromNav: geneva;\">Your Willamette Valley winter adventure awaits. Whether you have a long weekend to spare
AccountCatIDForListings: don't miss any of our outdoor adventures
FeatureChildPages: or places to savor this season.

Travel Oregon

Want to make a weekend of it? Explore our interactive travel planner to find wineries

and make memories with a holiday trip to Oregon Wine Country.

BrowserTitle: Explore artistic wine tasting rooms in Yamhill Valley
HeaderText: Brighten your winter with wine + art
ContentText:
Spend Indoor Time Enjoying Yamhill Valley Art and Wine

Oregon is an “outdoorsy” state, but it just happens to have some cozy, inviting opportunities for indoor fun as well. For example, the Yamhill Valley features a unique collection of wineries that also feature art collections within their walls, providing visitors with a memorable two-for-one experience. 

  • Yamhill | In the quaint city of Yamhill, travelers can find Fairsing Vineyard and its new tasting room
PageType: which is a piece of art itself. Fashioned after structures from ancient Irish countrysides
PageLevel: the curved-beam ceiling of the Celtic-inspired space mirrors an accompanying labyrinth for a peaceful wine-sipping locale. (Contact Fairsing to schedule a winter wine tasting appointment). Also in Yamhill
PageSectionID:
Saffron Fields Vineyard owners Angela Summers and Sanjeev Lahoti have curated artworks featuring bright colors and varied textures for tasting room visitors to enjoy.
  • Newberg | Nearby Newberg is home to its own art-and-wine experiences. Trisaetum combines a vineyard and winery with a 1
ParentPage: 500-square-foot art gallery showcasing photographs and paintings by owner James Frey. Visitors can sample a flight of Trisaetum vintages while touring the artistic space. Meanwhile
Status: the Allison Inn and Spa comprises luxury accommodations
InsertCode: fine dining and hundreds of pieces of art created by local artists. In fact
IssuuCode: part of the collection is curated through ART Elements
HideFromNav:
a gallery with exhibits in Newberg and Dayton.
  • Throughout the valley | Additional interactions with art can be had throughout Yamhill Valley. In Sheridan
DisplayListings: check out Lawrence Gallery
AccountCatIDForListings: which highlights local artists
SortOrder: a large sculpture collection and even modern masters
FeatureChildPages: all in one location. Right next door is Fire’s Eye Gallery
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: a showcase for pottery and glass art that’s creatively functional or colorfully decorative. In McMinnville
DisplayArticles: Currents Gallery is a source of eclectic offerings from area jewelry
PageLogo:
fiber and metal artists as well as painters and carvers.

Explore the art-and-wine experiences Yamhill Valley has to offer during your next visit. For more information
FeatureBlockTitle1:
contact Travel Yamhill Valley.

Photos: Saffron Fields Vineyard by Andrea Johnson

 

"

BrowserTitle: Make Salem your Capital for Seasonal Indulgence
HeaderText: Make Salem your Capital for Seasonal Indulgence
ContentText: As fall morphs into winter in the Mid-Willamette Valley
PageType: it’s the perfect time to treat yourself to a little indulgence. From wines paired with decadent desserts to warm restaurants and comfort food
PageLevel:
Oregon’s capital city offers experiences you won’t want to miss this winter.


Jazz it Up

For the perfect winter evening
ParentPage: Salem’s first wine bar
Status: shop and bistro. This cozy downtown spot features wine by the taste
IssuuCode:
a small plates menu and live jazz every Friday night. Grand Vines also carries decadent handmade desserts and truffles by local chocolatier Extreme Chocolates – the perfect finish to your evening out.


Fire & Spice

Get cozy at The Campus
DisplayListings: bar and brewery located in Southeast Salem. Curl up in a comfy leather chair by the fireplace and enjoy a spicy seasonal ale. Or
AccountCatIDForListings: enjoy a meal at Bentley’s Grill
SortOrder: which features an extensive wine list
FeatureChildPages:
upscale comfort food and a giant hearth in the middle of the restaurant. Try the Cioppino (fresh seafood in a rich tomato broth); it’ll warm you from the inside out.

For a taste of all things Oregon
DisplayArticles: held January 24-25 at the Oregon State Fairgrounds & Expo Center. Enjoy samples from Oregon wineries
PageLogo: breweries
FeatureBlockTitle2:
plus food and live entertainment.


Shop ‘til You Drop

Indulge in a tax-free shopping spree at Woodburn Premium Outlets
FeaturedActivityTitle1: which features 110 stores and has become a premier shopping destination
FeaturedActivityTitle2: drawing visitors from around the globe. For one-of-a-kind finds
DisplayPartnerColumns: and antique stores found throughout historic downtown Salem. Stay the night in Salem’s luxurious Grand Hotel
YoutubeVideoID:
” and you’ll receive a $50 gift card to the Salem Center Mall.

For more ideas of things to do in the Salem area this winter
VideoTitle1:
go to www.TravelSalem.com.


(photo provided by: Travel Salem)

"

BrowserTitle: Hike The Table Rock Wilderness
ContentText: The Table Rock Wilderness encompasses over 5
PageType: 700 acres of pristine land comprised of one of the largest untouched forests along the Molalla River. No wonder it’s one of the Willamette Valley’s Seven Wonders
PageLevel:
but did you know it also holds many wonders itself?

Hikers enjoy Table Rock Wilderness’ 17 trails where you can escape into peaceful solitude amidst verdant forests and breathtaking vistas. The trails give you the opportunity to hike through towering Douglas and Noble firs. Keep an eye out for endangered Oregon sullivantia and Gorman's aster
PageSectionID: which serve as a reminder of what makes the wilderness so special. While watching for rare plants
ParentPage: you may also see deer and elk in winter months
Status:
as well as spotted owls which have been occasionally seen hiding in the old growth trees.

An easy yet rewarding hike is the Tablerock Trail to the summit of namesake Tablerock. There you will see reminders of the areas tumultuous past in the soaring basalt cliffs that remain from the volcanic activity that created this area. The views from this point are diverse and stunning
InsertCode: with Mt. Rainier can rising to the north
IssuuCode:
Bull of the Woods Wilderness visible off to the east and the fertile Willamette Valley opening up to the south.

As this is wilderness
HideFromNav: it’s best to get all the supplies you’ll need beforehand. Your closest town is Molalla
DisplayListings: where you can grab a bite to eat at Cindy’s Café and Catering. After a full day of exploring
AccountCatIDForListings: return to Molalla and refill at Arrowhead Golf Course’s Farmstead Restaurant and Pub and recharge at Prairie House Inn
FeatureChildPages:
beautifully-restored 1900 B&B.

The Tablerock Wilderness is just one of many wonders in the Willamette Valley
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: and a great addition to any nature lover’s Oregon travel itinerary. For more information
DisplayArticles:
visit www.MtHoodTerritory.com


(photo provided by: Bureau of Land Management)

"
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Say Cheese and Shake Your Hips in Salem
HeaderText: Say Cheese and Shake Your Hips in Salem
ContentText: Fall is a feast for the senses in the Willamette Valley: you can see the leaves turning colors
PageType:
feel the warmth of a cozy fireplace and taste the freshest fall produce. Head to the Salem area for exceptional harvest time experiences that will delight all of your senses.

Get your groove on at Cubanisimo Vineyards in West Salem
PageLevel:
where you can taste estate grown wines and learn to dance Cuban style! Vineyard owner Mauricio Collada brings his Cuban heritage to life at this lovely hillside vineyard where beginner Salsa dance lessons are offered the third Saturday of most months.

Play golf - hillbilly style. For a truly hands-on harvest experience
PageSectionID: head to family-owned Wavra Farms & Nursery
ParentPage: where you can pick your own pumpkin and other produce
Status: weave your way through a corn maze
IssuuCode:
and even try your hand at hillbilly golf a wacky lawn game played by throwing a bolo of two golf balls at a ladder-like stand. 

Say cheese. If the mention of artisan cheese makes your mouth water
HideFromNav: get to Willamette Valley Cheese Company's tasting room
DisplayListings: where you'll learn about the cheesemaking process and taste many different varieties. you'll even receive a handy form
AccountCatIDForListings:
where you can make notes about your favorites just like you would in a wine tasting room.

Scare yourself. Fall is a fine time to visit The Oregon Garden
FeatureChildPages: and you're in for a real treat if you go there in October to experience Scarecrows in Garden a month-long display featuring locally designed scarecrows. From whimsical to wild
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
you'll marvel at the creativity and artistry of each creation.

For more ways to experience the bounty of the harvest season in the Salem area
PageLogo: NULL

PageDesc: 15 Years in the Making - Albany's Historic Carousel Opens its Doors
NavButtonText: Albany's Historic Carousel Opens its Doors
BrowserTitle: 15 Years in the Making - Albany's Historic Carousel Opens its Doors
HeaderText: 15 Years in the Making - Albany's Historic Carousel Opens its Doors
ContentText:
Albany Oregon, situated in the heart of the Willamette Valley, will soon be known as the community where talented workers came together to volunteer their time and talents to create a destination unlike any other. For the long-awaited Albany Historic Carousel & Museum will open at last!

In a newly constructed building located in near the center of Albany's celebrated downtown district
PageType: the Albany Historic Carousel & Museum is a testament to dreaming big. From humble beginnings
PageLevel:
this story is one that should inspire communities across the globe.

A Dedicated Community Rebuilds History

The carousel project began 15 years ago with a vision and a donation from a local resident.  That simple act spiraled into a full-blown non-profit association that attracted volunteer artisans and sponsors from all around Oregon’s Willamette Valley.

The carving and painting workshop at the carousel became a beehive of community activity as “lions and tigers and bears” came to life under loving hands. Because of volunteer's tireless efforts the carousel will consist of 52 hand-carved animals ranging from a seven foot plus tall giraffe
ParentPage: cats
AccountCatIDForListings: tigers
SortOrder: and bears! The animals will be situated in three rows
FeatureChildPages:
where the outside row (large animals) will be “standers”

No matter your age
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
make plans to visit Albany and be among the very first to ride this amazing work of art. Everyone is welcome to the bright and spirited community where dreams really do come true.

What You Need to Know When You Go

  • Grand Opening: August 15
DisplayArticles: 2017 is the slated date for a ribbon cutting and door opening event for all to enter and enjoy. The carousel will be open seven days a week
PageLogo:
excluding major holidays.
  • Food: Concessions such as hot dogs
FeatureBlockTitle2: and soft drinks will be available. For a more substantial meal
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
there are several restaurants within walking distance to choose from.
  • Contact: For detailed history
DisplayPartnerColumns: visit the Albany Historic Carousel & Museum"

BrowserTitle: Warm Up Your Winter at Sybaris in Albany
HeaderText: Warm Up Your Winter at Sybaris in Albany
ContentText: There's nothing quite like a romantic dinner beside a roaring fire -- the subtle smell of smoke in the air
PageLevel: the warmth the fire brings on a cold winter evening. At the award-winning Sybaris Bistro in historic downtown Albany
PageSectionID:
the large fireplace is the centerpiece of the room -- a tall stack of wood always at the ready. Sybaris has the fire and a whole lot more to warm you up this winter. 

\"A lot of restaurants try to take you away from winter
ParentPage:
\" Sybaris owner/chef Matt Bennett said. \"We embrace it.\" 

Bennett is a Michigan native
Status:
so he knows all about cold winters. Bennett also knows to put an emphasis on locally sourced food any time of year. 

\"Here in the Willamette Valley we're lucky that our climate is mild enough our local farmers can grow all year
InsertCode:
\" Bennett said. 

Consistently named one of the best restaurants in the Mid-Valley by Travel Oregon and others
IssuuCode: the menu at Sybaris changes monthly to bring the best products from the farm to you at their peak. This time of year
HideFromNav: the menu includes root vegetables such as potatoes
DisplayListings:
parsnips and beets or dark green leafy options like kale or Swiss chard. 

Winter is a time for hearty food and the menu at Sybaris fits that theme. \"A couple of the main courses are likely to include red meat game
AccountCatIDForListings: such as elk or venison
SortOrder:
\" Bennett said. \"And duck fat. Lots of duck fat.\" 

The warmth doesn't end with the meal at Sybaris as they're known to serve the best hot drinks in the area. A Spanish Coffee or BFK by a roaring fire is the perfect ending to any dining experience this time of year. 

Sybaris is the place to eat
FeatureChildPages:
drink and stay warm by the fire this winter. 

(photo provided by: Jimmy Lee Johnson)

"
PageLogo: NULL

NavButtonText: Bike Bridges and Hike Foothills in Linn County
BrowserTitle: Bike Bridges and Hike Foothills in Linn County
HeaderText: Bike Bridges and Hike Foothills in Linn County
PageLevel: hike or drive through the valley this spring to catch a glimpse of picturesque agriculture
ParentPage: waterfalls and the charming communities that make up Linn County.
Status: sans-serif;\">Try touring the county’s eight<a title=\"Historic Covered Bridges of Linn County
InsertCode: OR\" href=\"http://www.covered-bridges.org/\"> Historic Covered Bridges that represent a microcosm of the state’s collection of historic bridge structures. Cycle along the country roads and through towns to find rich links to the county’s history and heritage. The bridges are close enough for cyclists to complete the loop in one day; set aside a half day if you’re traveling by car.
IssuuCode: sans-serif;\">Travel to the beautiful McDowell Creek Falls Loop trail
HideFromNav: an easy to moderate hiking trail tucked into the Cascade foothills in Willamette Valley. The loop has impressive waterfalls as well as a couple of smaller cascades. Hikers walk through lush green woodlands near the falls and experience an island of serenity in the surrounding clearings.
AccountCatIDForListings: make your way over to Marks Ridge Winery and sip in springtime views and wine
SortOrder: of course. Along with offering delicious wines
FeatureChildPages: Marks Ridge Winery owners graciously welcome visitors into their warm and inviting tasting room with 60 feet of windows providing tremendous views. A lookout patio and picnic area also offer guests a place to sit
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: sip and stay awhile.
DisplayArticles: sans-serif;\">Explore more of Linn County’s trails
PageLogo:
bike trails and back roads at www.trailstolinn.com/ and www.albanyvisitorsassociation.com/

"

BrowserTitle: Feast on the Farm in Benton County
HeaderText: Feast on the Farm in Benton County
ContentText: Seeking the freshest possible produce? It doesn’t get any fresher than eating a meal on the very farm where your food was grown. At Gathering Together Farms
PageType: just outside of Corvallis in Philomath Oregon
PageLevel:
enjoy expertly prepared local cuisine at a farmstand dining room.

Gathering Together is a certified organic farm growing a wide array of organic produce. They have been in business since 1987 and are a family-owned operation with a thriving community supported agriculture program
PageSectionID:
an on-site farm store and a seasonal restaurant all in one location.

The store not only carries tasty produce
ParentPage: they also have homemade pastries
AccountCatIDForListings:
all sourced from nearby organic farms. Their homemade potato doughnuts are made fresh every morning—stop by and fuel yourself for a day of exploration in the Willamette Valley.

Gathering Together’s Farmstand restaurant has menus inspired by the best French and Italian traditions and change frequently based on the abundance of produce and the creativity of their chef. An early summer meal might feature Oregon strawberry sorbet
SortOrder:
while late summer brings dishes like stuffed summer squash and caprese salad with fresh-picked basil and heirloom tomatoes.

Restaurant hours vary
FeatureChildPages: so it is best to check their website for hours of operation. Can’t make it to the farm? Gathering Together produce may also be found at the Corvallis Indoor Winter Market
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
the Corvallis Saturday Farmer’s market and the Corvallis Wednesday’s Farmer Market located in Corvallis’ beautiful Riverfront Park.

Visiting the farm is a must-have experience when visiting the lush
DisplayArticles:
abundant Willamette Valley.

(photo provided by: Gathering Together Farms )

"
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Explore Benton County's Wonders
ContentText: There are the seven wonders of the world
PageType:
the seven wonders of Oregon and now we have picked the seven wonders of Corvallis and Benton County.

Marys Peak Scenic Botanical Area is the highest point in the Oregon Coast Range. Situated at 4
ParentPage: bike
Status: camp or picnic there. Don’t forget to visit the scenic botanical area
InsertCode: featuring a lush meadow surrounded by stately noble fir trees. Wildflowers peak in late June and early July
IssuuCode:
and on a clear day you can see the ocean to the west and the Cascade Mountain Range to the east.

Alsea Falls is located 13 miles west of Monroe
HideFromNav: Oregon in Benton County. The south fork of the Alsea River flows through the Alsea Falls Recreation site
DisplayListings:
cascading down to form the falls. Wander through trails and enjoy beautiful surroundings that lead to picnic grounds and beyond.

Just to the south of Corvallis you’ll find the William L. Finley National Wildlife Refuge
AccountCatIDForListings: situated along foothills of the Coast Range. The refuge encompasses a diverse assortment of habitats and its primary goal is to provide a wintering habitat for geese
SortOrder: especially the dusky Canada goose. It’s a great place for bird watching
DisplayArticles:
photography and more.

Wonders of the man-made variety include Corvallis’ historic downtown with many buildings that date back to the 1800s. This includes the Benton County Courthouse
PageLogo:
an iconic building which is also the oldest courthouse in Oregon still used for its original purpose. Today other historic buildings house many locally-owned shops and restaurants. These unique buildings add to the overall charm and appeal of our downtown core.

Downtown is bordered by the beautiful Riverfront Commemorative Park
FeatureBlockTitle1:
and Benton County is home to three stately Covered Bridges. Benton County’s final wonder encompasses one of the things the Willamette Valley is most famous for- our local Heart of Willamette Wineries!

For more information
FeatureBlockTitle2:
please visit www.visitcorvallis.com 
(photo provided by: Lainey Dyer)

"

BrowserTitle: Cheer Up with Corvallis Wine and Cuisine
HeaderText: Cheer Up with Corvallis Wine and Cuisine
ContentText: Have wintertime blahs got you down? Well cheer up there is plenty of good food and wine to be found in Corvallis! Come celebrate the 6th Annual Corvallis Culinary Week this January. Featuring the very best our participating restaurants have to offer
PageLevel: 2014) to sample the delights offered by 101 Eat & Drink
ParentPage: Big River
IssuuCode:
Luc and Magenta. Each restaurant offers special small plates for only $10.00. For more information about this week long event please visit www.visitcorvallis.com

If wine is more to your liking then we have two events coming up that are sure to please. You can join the Heart of the Willamette Wineries Association 4th Annual Winery & Barrel Tour. On February 15th you can travel the scenic back roads of Oregon by guided tour bus and visit six local wineries. Each winery will serve three wine selections and includes a souvenir wine glass
HideFromNav:
bag of local snacks and a barrel sample- all paired with the winery’s favorite appetizers. For more information visit www.heartofwillamette.com.

March features \"In the Vineyard \" - a downtown wine walk presented by the Downtown Corvallis Association. Retailers throughout our charming downtown will host Oregon wineries
AccountCatIDForListings:
a meadery and distilleries with representatives from each on hand to discuss their beverages and answer your questions. Downtown businesses will offer delicious appetizers along with music and or artwork by local artisans. For more information about this event please visit www.downtowncorvallis.org. 

(photo provided by: Lainey Dyer)

"
PageLogo: Archive

BrowserTitle: Feast on the Finest in Benton County
HeaderText: Feast on the Finest in Benton County
ContentText:
Feast on the finest in Benton County

Wine
PageSectionID:
farms and forests: Corvallis offers a variety of sensory experiences.

At Gathering Together Farm
ParentPage: you can feast on the finest from Oregon wine country: locally-grown produce
IssuuCode: Afton Field Farm free range chicken
AccountCatIDForListings:
and gourmet cheeses. Experience their Harvest Dinner with Pheasant Court Winery on September 28th. 

Don't want to limit yourself to a single meal?

From now until September 22nd the Heart of Willamette Wineries are offering wine tour tickets for $20. If you visit all fifteen wineries by the 22nd you will be entered to win their grand prize drawing. 

Come taste some of the best pinots to be found!

If beer and spirits are more to your liking then check out the Mid Valley Sip Trip. Comprised of six breweries
FeatureChildPages: one cider house and one meadery
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: the area is known for its fragrant hops
PageLogo:
bittersweet apples and golden grains- all of the ingredients to make the most delectable libations around. You can download a passport to take to all ten locations at www.visitcorvallis.com.

If you would like to enjoy a more hands on experience feel free to stop in at Davis Family Farms or Midway Farms both located on Highway 20 just outside of town. Both offer U Pick and farm stands with the tastiest produce that you can bring home.

Finally
FeatureBlockTitle1: if you are in the mood to learn something new check out Starker Forest Tours. Each Wednesday until September 18th
FeatureBlockTitle2: Starker offers a guided tour of a working forest. you'll learn about Oregons Coast range geography
FeaturedActivityTitle1: geology and history. Discover the diversity a multi-use forest provides
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
from recreational opportunities to plant and animal habitats to forest products. Call Visit Corvallis at (541) 757-1544 for reservations. 

"

BrowserTitle: Agrarian Ales - A place to taste and play in Eugene
HeaderText: Agrarian Ales - A place to taste and play in Eugene
ContentText: Beer and food just taste better on a farm. Spend one evening at Agrarian Ales and you’ll see why. The brewery sits on a 25-acre family farm 13 miles north of Eugene in the Willamette Valley. Ben and Nate Tilley started Agrarian as a way to return to their roots. The brothers grew up on their parent’s chili pepper farm
PageType: which is on the same property as the brewery
PageLevel:
and wanted to share that love for the country and Oregon’s bounty with others.

A Place To Taste
Housed in a converted 1940’s dairy barn
PageSectionID: Agrarian’s tasting room is surrounded by hop vines and cherry orchards. As you sip your saison
ParentPage: Agrarian’s speciality
Status: you see the organic hop vines (ten different varieties) responsible for the liquid magic. A wood fired pizza oven turns vegetables
IssuuCode:
and meats from neighboring farms into a truly farm-to-table pairing.

A Place to Play
Many breweries serve outstanding craft beer and food. But Agrarian has something else. The rural setting means that there is plenty of space where you can have fun in the sun (and the rain too
HideFromNav: the heat lamps work like a charm). Hula hoops
AccountCatIDForListings: backyard games
SortOrder: and even a wooden play structure for the kiddos
FeatureChildPages: free you from the day’s responsibilities
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
allowing you to breathe the fresh countryside air and feel the grass between your toes.

The first pints are free to those who pedal to the brewery. A slight detour from the Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway
DisplayArticles:
Agrarian is along a popular cycling route.

At Agrarian
PageLogo: it’s about good beer and quality ingredients. But most importantly
FeatureBlockTitle1:
it’s about the community and experiencing the absolute best of Oregon’s hospitable bounty.

For more information
FeatureBlockTitle2:
go to http://www.eugenecascadescoast.org/

For summer deals on dining

BrowserTitle: Conquer the McKenzie River Trail - America's #1 Trail
HeaderText: Conquer the McKenzie River Trail - America's #1 Trail
ContentText: The Willamette Valley stretches to the crest of the Cascade Mountains. In the foothills of those mountains
PageType: you’ll find the renowned McKenzie River National Recreation Trail. An hour east of Eugene
ParentPage: follows the McKenzie River from its headwaters at Clear Lake to the town of McKenzie Bridge. As it continues west
Status: the pure and pristine McKenzie River pours into the south Willamette Valley
InsertCode:
providing an ideal water source for the area’s 17 wineries and more than a dozen craft breweries.

It won’t take you long to see why the MRT has been called the #1 Best Trail in America. The MRT brings 26.5 miles worth of adventure
IssuuCode: natural beauty and a topaz-blue pool that will knock your hiking
HideFromNav: running and mountain biking socks off. Venture over lava beds
DisplayListings: under 600-year-old Douglas fir forests to thundering Koosah and Sahalie Falls. Traverse handmade log bridges over streams and beds of billowing ferns from Trailbridge Reservoir to Tamolitch Pool
AccountCatIDForListings: the bluest water you’ve ever seen. This is where the mineral-rich McKenzie River emerges from a three-mile subterranean craw through basalt lava tubes
SortOrder:
the azure water so clear sometimes you can see more than 100 feet to the bottom.

While the Tamolitch tempts with its tantalizing beauty
FeatureChildPages: the water is very cold. Save your swimming cravings for the riverside hot springs at Belknap Hot Springs Resort. Surrounded by the Willamette National Forest
DisplayArticles:
cabins and tent camping. The secret garden is a must-see!

Share your tails from the trail over a buffalo burger and a glass of Pinot at nearby Takoda’s Restaurant.

Discover more of what the Eugene
PageLogo:
Cascades & Coast region has to offer at http://www.eugenecascadescoast.org/


(photo provided by: Jody Trendler)

"

BrowserTitle: Taste Truffles and Feast by the Fireside in Eugene
HeaderText: Taste Truffles and Feast by the Fireside in Eugene
ContentText:
Spend the crisp winter months discovering Eugene’s culinary scene. The South Willamette Valley foodie haven recently gained worldwide recognition for its abundance of Oregon black and Oregon white truffles.


Tantalizing Truffles

Eugene hosts the Oregon Truffle Festival every January. The event is so highly acclaimed that the city was named one of Fodor’s Top Five Trips for Truffle Lovers and Zagat’s Eight U.S. Cities Making Their Own Foreign Delicacies. January 24-26
PageLevel: marks the ninth year of the three-day feast. For the first time ever
PageSectionID:
the Oregon Truffle Festival is incorporating craft beer and spirits pairings.

Take advantage of a rare opportunity to sample and purchase black and white truffles at Sunday’s Oregon Truffle Festival Marketplace. Open to the public
ParentPage:
the Marketplace includes cooking demonstrations and Oregon wine pairings.


Fireside Farm-To-Table

Eugene’s robust food scene takes a toasty turn during the winter. Many local restaurants offer fireside dining. Sink your teeth into fresh burrata mozzarella and wild boar ribs paired with a 2010 J. Scott Pinot noir at Ox & Fin. Chef Mike Meyer creates masterpieces with the flavors of the season
InsertCode:
classic and fireplace-warmed setting.

Indulge in fireside farm-to-table dining at its finest at the Excelsior Inn Restaurant. Owner and Chef Maurizio Paparo grows his own organic ingredients at the five-acre Excelsior Farm in nearby Dexter. Insider tip: The Osso Buco alla Milanese with a 2009 Silvan Ridge Pinot noir is a match made in heaven.

Fireside dining isn’t just for the oenophiles. Hop over to The Bier Stein’s new tasting room for cozy comfort. Pick from 1
IssuuCode: 000 bottles and more than two dozen craft beers on-tap. With that many to choose from
HideFromNav: it’s no wonder that CraftBeer.com voted The Bier Stein the Best Beer Bar in the Pacific. Not to mention
DisplayListings:
their Bavarian soft pretzel and The Gouddhist panini may be the two best things that have ever happened to craft beer.

For more information on wining
AccountCatIDForListings: dining and brewery touring in Eugene

BrowserTitle: Learn to Harvest, Brew & Blend in Eugene
HeaderText: Learn to Harvest, Brew & Blend in Eugene
ContentText: If you're the hands-on type
PageType:
experience harvest in the South Willamette Valley this year. You can learn how to bring out the best in this year's bounty as you sip and taste your way through new tasting rooms and cooking classes in Eugene and Springfield.

Discover how a winemaker decides the perfect time to pick the grapes at the Oregon Wine Lab. Mark Nicholl of William Rose Wines brings his passion for Pinot to the people in this brand new endeavor brilliantly located in downtown Eugene.

A few blocks away you'll find the Whiteaker neighborhood
PageLevel:
the epicenter of all fermented things. Check out the three new brewery tasting rooms and save room for dinner. Between the pubs you'll find new restaurants brimming with fall-centered feasts.

Bring the brewing to your own backyard at a homebrew class or make your own bountiful masterpiece at a cooking lesson. Explore the ingredients and processes used to make craft beer at the Home Brew How-To September 5 at Willamalane in Springfield.

Savor the flavors of the Mediterranean from Main Street at the Delicious Tour de France cooking class at Sprout! in Springfield. Immerse yourself in new styles of cooking and techniques using local ingredients in this weekly lesson taught by dynamic teaching force
PageSectionID:
Chef Chris Crosthwaite.

Celebrate your new found culinary prowess with a trip to the wineries. The leaves turn vibrant yellows and oranges after September's harvest
ParentPage: blanketing the vineyards with a fiery glow. Sip by the fire at Pfeiffer Vineyards Fireside Pavilion
Status:
a spectacular new addition to this charming villa-style tasting experience. Tour the vineyard with owner Robin Pfeiffer and learn how to blend and create your own custom wine on the Vines to Wines: A Vineyard Management Tour and Wine Blending Clinic.

Experience
IssuuCode: sip and savor the bounty in Oregon's Eugene
AccountCatIDForListings:
craft beer and food lovers.

For more information
SortOrder:
go to EugeneCascadesCoast.org.

For fall deals on dining
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Visit Oregon year round for a great relaxing wine vacations
HeaderText: Featured Stories of the Willamette Valley

BrowserTitle: Put a spring in step with vacation destination Salem near Portland, Or
Summer activities and attractions to visit on your vacation to Eugene, OR
31 Days of Oregon Wine this May
HeaderText: 31 Days of Oregon Wine this May
ContentText: It's Oregon Wine Month
PageType:
which means you've got exactly 31 days to sip and savor the best of Oregon's world-class wine right here in your own backyard.

There's no shortage of parties or pours in Oregon this May. Right here in Oregon's Wine Country you'll find every kind of wine event– from paddle trips to wine walks
PageLevel: sipping seminars to ballet at the bar
PageSectionID: we've got it all! And because we know just how to party
ParentPage: we end the month of May with a three-day wine fest at nearly every winery in the Valley with Memorial Day weekend open houses
Status:
where practically every wine maker pops open the door and the cork for the summer season.

Get a taste of just a few events happening in your area this May!

 

 Albany:

  • Albany Wine Walk - May 5
  • Marks Ridge Winery “Mothers Day at the Winery” - May 14
  • Benton-Lane Winery Open House - May 28

Find other Albany area events in May

Corvallis:

  • Paddle for Pinot - May 13
  • Airlie's Mother Day Special - May 14th
  • Wine Sensory Two-Day Exclusive Course at OSU- *Moved to June 3-4th.* Save 10% on registration.
  • Heart Of Willamette Winery Associations Memorial Day Open House - May 27-29

Find other Corvallis area events in May

 

Eugene:

  • Ballet Fantastique Open Barre Event at the Oregon Wine Lab - May 3
  • Food Scene Eugene - May 5-6
  • Grapes of Half Marathon - May 21
  • Memorial Day Weekend on the Territorial Wine Trail - May 28-29

Find Memorial Day wine events in and around Eugene

Salem:

  • Arcane Cellars Big Red Release Party - May 7
  • Syttende Mai (Constitution Day) Celebration - May 20
  • Celebrate Memorial Day "Cuban Style" at Cubanisimo Vineyards - May 27-29
  • “Ribs & Red” - May 29

Find more Salem Area Events

Mt. Hood:

  • Cascade Foothills Winegrowers Oregon Wine Month kick off - May 6
  • Christopher Bridge 10 wine line-up - Tasting fee includes all wines and hearth-fresh wood-fire pizza.

2017

The 2nd annual “Taste Oregon” event in Seattle will feature 35 premium wineries from Oregon to be held in the SODO area of Seattle at a new venue called the Metropolist. There will be a private trade/industry tasting followed by a general public tasting with 35 wineries from an array of Oregon’s diverse AVAs.

Metropolist Event Space
2931 1st Ave. S – Seattle WA
1 to 5 pm
Advance $35/ Door $40

 

"

BrowserTitle: 7 Breathtaking Oregon Wineries in the Willamette Valley
ContentText:
Explore seven beautiful valley vineyards on this wine trip. 

Oregon Wine Country is known for producing some of the finest wines in the world. But not only do our vineyards grow great grapes—they also create some stunning views.
 
Any Willamette Valley vineyard you visit will be pretty, but we’ve picked seven with exceptionally gorgeous vistas to inspire your Oregon Wine Country vacation:

Sarver Winery: Specializing in small-lot production of fine Willamette Valley wines
PageType:
from a vineyard with unsurpassed views out over the valley.

Tyee Winery: Tyee makes certified organic wines with a vineyard located on a century-old family farm
PageLevel:
surrounded by heritage fruit trees and criss-crossed with nature trails.

Marks Ridge Winery: Marks Ridge is the highest-elevation winery in the Willamette Valley. Enjoy panoramic views from this boutique producer tucked into the foothills of the Cascades.

Willamette Valley Vineyards: The newly-remodeled tasting room at Willamette Valley Vineyards offers delicious food pairings to go along with the sweeping views and fine wines.

Cherry Hill Winery: In the Eola-Amity Hills west of Salem
PageSectionID: Cherry Hill produces premium Pinot Noir on a beautiful 150-acre estate with a vineyard
ParentPage: cherry orchard
Status:
and small lake.

Winter’s Hill Vineyard: Winter’s Hill sits in the storied Dundee Hills of Oregon and is a stop on the Willamette Valley Birding Trail.

St. Josef's Winery: St. Josef's is a large European old world styled winery and one of the first 25 in Oregon. Take in the unique architecture while enjoying one of their many varietals. 

 

"
AccountCatIDForListings: Active
ProposedBrowserTitle: Take this tour of Oregon Wine Country and discover what the beauty of the Willamette Valley is all about. You will treat your taste buds some of the valley's best wines from Pinot noir to the Chardonnay. You will see some of the best scenic views Willamette Valley Vineyards have to offer. It's an Oregon Winery Tour you won't want to miss.

BrowserTitle: Fall wine getaways in Salem, Oregon
HeaderText: Sip sublime in Salem this fall
ContentText:
The leaves are turning crimson and gold, the air is getting crisp and the grape harvest is nearly underway - which means now is the perfect time to plan an Oregon Wine Country getaway. Head to the Salem area to sip sublime wines at beautiful wineries with extra experiences to make your visit even more memorable. 

Taste and explore

Situated on the 45th parallel in the beautiful Eola-Amity Hills AVA, Left Coast Cellars offers opportunities to enjoy a wide variety of sustainably grown estate wines as well as explore the beautiful property. In fact
PageType: the term “wiking” (wine plus hiking) originated at Left Coast. Though formal
PageLevel: guided “wiking” tours are not currently offered
PageSectionID:
guests are encouraged to hike the property on their own. 

Located just west of Salem
ParentPage:
Eola Hills Wine Cellars also encourages visitors to get outdoors at its new Legacy Estate Vineyard and Tasting Room. The 160-acre property is open for hiking and offers beautiful views of the vineyards and surrounding countryside. 

Sample wine and cuisine

At Willamette Valley Vineyards in Turner
Status: you’ll not only enjoy elegant wines in a beautiful hillside setting
InsertCode: you can also take part in the winery’s new wine and food pairing experience.  Offered Thursdays through Sundays
HideFromNav:
multi-course meal matches seasonal small plates with limited-production wines and includes a Winery Ambassador who will lead you through the experience.

Dance your cares away

While Pinot noir and salsa dancing may seem like an odd couple
DisplayListings: they pair perfectly at Salem’s Cubanisimo Vineyards
AccountCatIDForListings: where you can enjoy a classic wine tasting and then dance the night away. This Cuban-inspired winery and tasting room offers salsa dance lessons most Saturday evening
SortOrder:
along with live Cuban music and tapas (Spanish appetizers) on select holiday weekends. 

Bring a four-legged friend

Airlie Winery
FeatureChildPages: known for making “serious whites and elegant reds since 1986” has the added benefit of being completely canine friendly. Guests are encouraged to pack a picnic lunch
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
bring their dogs and enjoy a glass of wine on the tasting deck or dock area that overlooks a large pond.

For more fall wine getaway ideas and unforgettable experiences near Salem
DisplayArticles:
go to www.TravelSalem.com.

 
"
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Fall foliage and wine tasting in Eugene, Oregon
HeaderText: Fantastic foliage and fine wine in Eugene
ContentText:
Yes, we tell you to come to Oregon Wine Country every season. But if you choose one time of year to come, make it fall. It’s worth it, especially in the south Willamette Valley’s 17 wineries. Summer’s long, sunny days linger into September and October, bringing crisp nights and painting the valley in a pallet of fall’s finest hues – the perfect recipe for culinary and outdoor adventures.

Autumn Colors, Covered Bridges

Start your fall wine tasting in the All-America of City Cottage Grove, the “Covered Bridge Capital of the West.” Cycle or drive to six covered bridges on the Covered Bridges Scenic Bikeway and the Cottage Grove Covered Bridge Tour Route. Both routes follow the Row River Trail
PageType: which becomes a feast for your eyes with pomegranate red vine maples
PageLevel: golden ash and cottonwoods.  While in Cottage Grove
PageSectionID: stop for a tasting at Saginaw Vineyard
ParentPage:
a small family-owned winery known for its fabulous wine and friendly tasting room nestled in a beautiful red barn. 

Scenic Drives
Status:
Vineyard Vistas

Follow Cottage Grove Lorane Road through a tunnel of autumn glory to Iris Vineyards. Iris reopened a vineyard-side tasting room this spring. Sip a glass of their 2008 Pinot Noir Reserve while you soak in the 360-degree view of the forested hills of the Lorane Valley and the pumpkin orange grapevines as they transform from September’s harvest. From Iris
InsertCode:
follow Territorial Highway as it leads you to even more award-winning wineries. 

Live Leaf Updates on the Oregon Fall Foliage Blog

Plan your fall wine tasting trip using the Oregon Fall Foliage Blog. We’ll post live leaf updates
HideFromNav: seasonal winery events and fall deals so that you know when the leaves are changing and where
DisplayListings:
plus special events to include in your visit. 

The autumn celebration comes to a fitting end on Thanksgiving weekend
AccountCatIDForListings: when our wineries bring in live music
SortOrder:
seasonal pairings and open special bottles.

 
"

NavButtonText: Art and Wine in Yamhill Valley
BrowserTitle: Sip wine and tour artist studios in Yamhill Valley Oregon
HeaderText: The artful way to explore Oregon Wine Country in autumn
ContentText:
An Oregon Wine Country experience goes beyond sipping excellent wine at tasting room bars. It involves unforgettable vineyard scenery, and winery owners shuffling in and out of the tasting room (and maybe stopping by to say hello). With more than 200 tasting rooms in the Willamette Valley, choosing your route can be daunting. Narrow your choices by combining your wine experience with local art, and take the self-guided Art Harvest Studio Tour. 

See the essence of Oregon Wine Country through the eyes of artists
PageType: engage in conversations and see artistic innovation
PageSectionID: Oregon artists will open their studios to the public for the first two weeks of October. This tour takes visitors into 36 Yamhill Valley artists’ studios in Newberg
ParentPage: Lafayette
HideFromNav:
Amity and Sheridan. 

While visiting the studios within these communities
DisplayListings:
don’t miss the chance to sample the signature wines of the region. All these wineries are within an easy walk or drive of studios on the Art Harvest Studio Tour:

McMinnville wineries

Near the 10 artist studios in McMinnville
AccountCatIDForListings: you can visit <a title=\"Eyrie Vineyards
FeatureChildPages: one of the oldest and most prestigious wineries in Oregon. Or stop by R. Stuart & Co.’s delightful downtown tasting room on Third Street in McMinnville—it’s a charming area that was recently named one of the best Main Streets in America by Parade Magazine. You can sample wine from several talented winemakers when you stop by at WineWorks Oregon
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
a tasting room located within a custom wine production facility.

Carlton wineries

The town of Carlton may be small in size
DisplayArticles: but it’s a don’t-miss stop for foodies and wine-lovers
PageLogo: beloved for the number of quality wineries and delicious eateries it packs into its downtown. When you visit the two artist studios in Carlton
FeatureBlockTitle1: you’ll find yourself just steps away from the Carlton Winemaker’s Studio
FeatureBlockTitle2:
a unique winemakers’ collective where you can taste from bottles that may not be available anywhere else. Another great tasting stop is Cana’s Feast Winery in Carlton. Visit their Mediterranean-inspired tasting room and sip from their Old World-style wines.

Newberg wineries

When you’re visiting the two studios near Newberg
FeaturedActivityTitle1: do yourself a favor and stop by Anam Cara Cellars on Main Street in Newberg. They feature estate wines from a single family-owned vineyard in the Chehalem mountains
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
and also showcase work by local artists in their tasting room.

Explore the charming downtowns
PartnerText: and the tasting rooms that inspire poets and painters alike. See art that reflects what Oregonians love about their wine country
DisplayPartnerColumns: and after a few tasting room stops
PartnerCityTitle: you’ll understand why wine is such a beloved part of Oregon culture. For more travel inspiration or help finding comfortable hotel or B&B in Oregon Wine Country
YoutubeVideoID:
visit www.TravelYamhillValley.org.

 
"

NavButtonText: Albany fall colors and fine wine
BrowserTitle: Visit Albany Oregon for artisan wine and beer plus autumn scenery
HeaderText: Artisan drinks and autumn scenery in Linn County
ContentText:
If you want to experience the bounty of Oregon, you’ll find it in Linn County this fall. Here you will delight in a recreational paradise, see magnificent fall colors and scenery, and enjoy the tastes and smells that perfume the air almost any time of the year. 

Situated in the heart of the fertile Mid-Willamette Valley, Linn County’s location allows chefs to work directly with growers to create the freshest farm-to-table meals. The wineries of the Willamette Valley are known for world-class, award-winning Pinot noir, but did you know Oregon Wine Country is also known for its distinctive breweries and distilleries? Take a trip through Linn County and enjoy all kinds of artisan drinks and inspiring scenery this fall.

Winery with a view

Marks Ridge Winery is located just north of Sweet Home in an area with a spectacular view. Winemakers Janet and Jay Westly purchased the hilltop property and restored the 30-year-old vineyard to health
PageType: as well as planting new vines that produce Pinot Noir
PageSectionID: and Gewurztraminer grapes. Along with their delicious wines
ParentPage: Marks Ridge frequently hosts art shows and
InsertCode:
live music on Friday nights.

Microbrews and music

Calapooia Brewing
IssuuCode: on the east side of downtown Albany
HideFromNav:
offers what are regarded by many as some of the best microbrews in the Willamette Valley and has received national attention for its products.  It hosts live musical performances each weekend and offers a wide variety of brews on tap.  

Riverside spirits & brews

Sinister Distilling and Deluxe Brewing make up Albany’s first “brewstillery.” A production brewery and a distillery
DisplayListings:
it is located along the Willamette River and is producing some of the finest lagers and whiskeys in Oregon. 

If you want to explore Linn County’s trails
AccountCatIDForListings: bike paths and back roads
SortOrder: check out Trails to Linn
FeatureChildPages: a comprehensive resource to all things Linn County. For personalized travel advice
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: information on places to stay in the mid-valley
DisplayArticles: and vacation itineraries to inspire your trip
PageLogo:
go to www.AlbanyVisitors.com  or call 541-928-0911. 

 
"

NavButtonText: Culinary Journey along the Scenic Bikeway
BrowserTitle: Take a culinary journey along the Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway
HeaderText: Farms to Feast: a foodie bike trip
ContentText:
Explore the Willamette Valley by bike with this cycling trip. Scroll down for trip mapping. Find cycling details here.

The Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway is famous for being the first official Scenic Bikeway in U.S.
PageType: but it's more than that. It's also your pathway to foodie heaven
PageLevel: taking you through the heart of Oregon Wine Country. As you cycle or drive the route
PageSectionID: you can feast at organic farmstands
ParentPage: sip craft beer at farm-based breweries
Status: and dine at James Beard-nominated restaurants.
IssuuCode: Eugene: Start your trip with a tasy meal in downtown Eugene. Marche offers classic farm-inspired cuisine from award-winning chef Stephanie Pearl Kimmel
HideFromNav:
all sourced from the farms surrounding the city.

Agrarian Ales
DisplayListings: Eugene: Visit a farm-based brewery where brothers Ben and Nate Tilley use herbs
AccountCatIDForListings: flowers and chili peppers grown on site in the beers
SortOrder: and serve wood-fired pizzas using their own crust
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
plus toppings from other local farms. 

Randy's Main Street Coffee
DisplayArticles: Brownsville: Stop and stretch your legs in historic Brownsville. Randy's is where the locals gather for coffee every morning
PageLogo: and it serves up pastries
FeatureBlockTitle1:
soup and sandwiches until 3 each afternoon. Try the fresh bread baked in-house every morning by Randy himself.

Gathering Together Farm
FeatureBlockTitle2:
Philomath. Detour slightly from the bikeway route for a totally-worth-it trip through Corvallis and out to Gathering Together Farms. Their on-site farm restaurant features an ever-changing menu based on what's growing in the fields. The daily fresh-baked doughnuts are divine.

Sybaris Bistro
FeaturedActivityTitle1: Albany. Chef/owner Matt Bennett is a two-time James Beard-nominee. His ever-changing menu varies with whatever is fresh and locally available
FeaturedActivityTitle2: including wild-foraged ingredients. A meal at Sybaris is always a unique experience; after Matt has featured a dish once
PartnerTitle:
he never repeats it.

Ankeny Vineyard
PartnerText: Salem. Munch on wood-fired pizza and chat with the winemaker here
DisplayPartnerColumns:
while petting the friendly winery dog and enjoying views out over the Ankeny National Wildlife Refuge.

EZ Orchards
PartnerCityTitle:
Salem. Taste Oregon's cider renaissance with a stop at EZ Orchards farm market. EZ Orchards grows their own apples and produces award-winnng hard cider in the French style (plus home-made doughnuts and fresh produce).

Arcane Cellars
YoutubeVideoID: Salem. Take the Wheatland Ferry across the Willamette River to Arcane Cellars. Enjoy a bocce court
MetaDescription:
private setting along the Willamette River.

The bikeway officially ends at Champoeg State Park. To cap off your journey
SEOTags:
head out for a celebration at the northern end of the Willamette Valley.

Villa Catalana Cellars
SeoNotes: Oregon City: Go wine tasting at the spectacular Villa Catalana Cellars
SEOStatus: a winery on the site of a rare plants nursery. Nestled amid beautiful gardens
ProposedHeaderText:
Villa Catalana resembles a Tuscan castle.

The Joel Palmer House
ProposedBrowserTitle: Dayton: Celebrate with a memorable meal at The Joel Palmer House
ProposedMetaDescription: famous for its extensive use of wild-foraged mushrooms and truffles

BrowserTitle: Sample the Willamette Valley's best restaurants
ContentText:
Sourced from TravelOregon.com

Explore the Willamette Valley's food scene with this restaurant trip. Scroll down for trip mapping.

The best way to end a day of wine tasting in the Willamette Valley is with a a delicious dinner. Valley chefs strive to source the freshest local produce
PageType:
meats and seafood to complement superb local vintages. Get a taste of the valley at these fine restaurants.

Albany

Sybaris Bistro calls itself \"an eclectic Northwest Bistro.\" Chef Matt Bennet has numerous James Beard Award nominations
PageLevel:
and his local resume extends to First Burger in downtown Albany.

Try: Vegetarian \"haggis\" with mashed turnips and potatoes and whiskey mustard cream.

Canby

For something sweet or savory
PageSectionID: check out <a title=\"Gourmet chocolates and wine at Puddin River Chocolates and Wine Bar in Canby
ParentPage: Oregon\" href=\"http://www.puddinriverchocolates.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Puddin River Chocolates & Wine Bar. In addition to hand-crafted chocolates (including more than 37 truffle flavors to choose from) and a range of desserts
Status: Puddin River features a substantial wine list
InsertCode:
a menu of hearty appetizers and a weekly dinner special.

Try: Amish-style home cooked meal
IssuuCode:
served Thursday through Saturday.

Corvallis:

Big River Restaurant and Bar gets grass-fed lamb from Junction City
DisplayListings: Angus beef from Canby and organic produce from Philomath. Clearly
AccountCatIDForListings:
fresh and local come with the territory.

Try: Troll-caught king samlon
SortOrder: Denison Farms delicata squash and new potato homefries with spinach
FeatureChildPages:
shallots and salsa verde.

Eugene

Urban steakhouse
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
Oregon\" href=\"http://oxandfin.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Ox & Fin serves Northwest cuisine with an Italian flair. The menu features seasonal and local ingredients sourced from a range of local purveyors. Chef Andrew Stone presides in the kitchen of the imaginative restaurant.

Try: Grilled Pears with honey
PageLogo: arugula
FeatureBlockTitle1:
pine nuts and grana padano.

Newberg

Aspiring to be \"refined
FeaturedActivityTitle1: \" The Painted Lady has been praised by Zagat
PartnerTitle:
among others. The delicious menu is matched by the beauty of the restored Victorian house.

Try: Slow roasted steelhead with wild mushrooms and prosciutto in a white wine cream sauce.

Salem

At the Wild Pear Restaurant
PartnerText: a passion for Northwest cuisine is detectable in every dish. The wide range of sandwiches
PartnerCityTitle:
pizzas and specials is sure to please.

Try: Pizza with pears
VideoTitle2:
chicken and mozzarella on a pesto-brushed crust.

 

 

"
column59: These are some of the best restaurants in Oregon's Willamette Valley. Discover amazing food at these restaurants in Albany, Canby, Corvallis Eugene, Newberg and Salem.

NavButtonText: Beyond Wine in the Willamette Valley
BrowserTitle: Taste craft brews, ciders and spirits in the Willamette Valley
HeaderText: Beyond Wine in the Willamette Valley
ContentText:
Sourced from TravelOregon.com

Explore the food & drink of Oregon Wine Country on this trip. Scroll down for trip mapping.

We're wild about wine in the Willamette Valley
PageType: but this fertile region has even more to offer than the 300-plus wineries within its boundaries. Beer
ParentPage:
farm-to-table cuisine and local harvest also flourish here. Why not take a trip beyond the wine in the WIllamette Valley?

Brews News: From the monks at Mount Angel Abbey
Status: known for their contemplative retreat and meditative Bach Festival
InsertCode: comes the newly opened Benedictine Brewery. Check their Facebook page for updates to their \"Taste and Believe\" enterprise. Corvallis' Mazama Brewing celebrated its first anniversary of brewing Belgian-style ales in May 2014. Visit the taproom for a taste of Hop Eruption
IssuuCode: Pyroclastic Porter and more. Deluxe Brewing Co and Sinister Distillery Co. bills itself as Albany's first brewstillery. On the beer side
HideFromNav: look for the Pre-Prohibition Pilsner as well as a dark and amber ale. Sinister's offerings include rum
DisplayListings: gin and whiskey. Eugene's Whiteaker neighborhood is home to several fabulous craft breweries: Ninkasi Brewing
AccountCatIDForListings: Oakshire Brewing
SortOrder:
Hop Valley Brewing Company and Falling Sky Brewing's Delicatessen.

From Bees and Trees: Corvallis' Nectar Creek Honey Wines offers three varieties of tasty mead: ginger
FeatureChildPages: raspberry and wildflower. The honey-based drinks are naturally gluten free. For more mead
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: check out Kookoolan World Meadery in Yamhill with more than 100 varieties from around the world. 2 Towns Ciderhouse in Corvallis presses Northwest apples into cider varieties franging from classic Bad Apple to Cherried Away
DisplayArticles: Made Marion and Rhubarbarian. Wandering Aengus Ciderworks in Salem selects heirloom apple varieties from Oregon to create varieties like Bloom
PageLogo:
Wanderlust and Wickson.

Farm to Table: From Field & Vine Events comes the Dinner in the Field series. Arriving by school bus
FeatureBlockTitle1: diners are treated to a tour of the host winery or farm followed by a six-course meal at communal tables set in the field. Albany localvores rejoiced with Cody Utzman
FeatureBlockTitle2: two-time winner of the Food Network's \"Chopped
FeaturedActivityTitle1: \" returned home and opened Frankie's with his sister
PartnerTitle: late last year. Named for their late father
PartnerText: Frankie's focuses on the freshest goods from local farmers
