PartnerCityTitle:
and fishermen.

Local Harvest: Find dozens of farmers markets in towns throughout the Willamette Valley
SEOTags: many of which run through the fall. Search for locations on the Oregon Farmers' Markets Association website. U-pick fresh fall fruit and vegetables around the valley at locations like Detering Orchards in Harrisburg
SeoNotes: Beilke Family Farm in Brooks and Lone Pine Farms in Junction City. Check out fall festivals like the Sublimity Harvest Festival
SEOStatus: Mount Angel Oktoberfest
ProposedHeaderText: Independence Hop & Heritage Festival
ProposedMetaDescription: Colonial Harvest Days in Pleasant Hill
SEOPaidSearch:
and the Mount Pisgah Arboretum Mushroom Festival in Eugene.

 

"
column67: Oregon's Willamette Valley is known for its many wineries. The Willamette Valley is also home to numerous breweries, farms producing all sorts of delicious food and award-winning farm to table dinners.

BrowserTitle: Trips for beer-lovers and foodies in Eugene, Oregon
HeaderText: Eugene trips for beer-lovers and foodies
ContentText:
There’s nothing like receiving a gift that you get to do something with. The joy then goes beyond the opening, extending to anticipation of what’s to come. Now imagine if that present also tempted your tastebuds and rekindled your adventurous spirit. 

We have a few ideas for how you can give just that gift: 

North American Truffle Dog Championship Tickets - $15

This is the perfect gift for both the animal lover and the foodie in your life. The first ever North American Truffle Dog Championship The Joriad™ will be held at the indoor Oregon Horse Center in Eugene on January 21
PageType: 2015. The Joriad™ is a rare opportunity to see trained truffle dogs hunt for truffle-scented targets. Cheer on teams as they go nose-to-ground in a one-of-a-kind competition. Finalists from Day 1 events advance to the next day of competition
PageSectionID:
which is closed to the public.

Oregon Truffle Festival Marketplace Tickets - $15; with wine tasting $20

Tickets to the Oregon Truffle Festival Marketplace on Sunday
ParentPage: January 25
Status: 2015 in Eugene are another great option. Few culinarians ever get to actually use native Oregon truffles in their own kitchen. These hard-to-find delicacies will be for sale at the Marketplace. Attendees will also get to taste truffles
InsertCode: artisan foods and watch a truffle dog demonstration. Pre-purchase the $15 tickets ($20 with wine tasting)
DisplayListings:
you’re done. Sidenote: We actually recommend purchasing TWO tickets so you get to go to the Marketplace too. 

Eugene Ale Trail Gift Package – $15 - $30

Do you know someone who loves craft beer? Well
AccountCatIDForListings: this gift is for them. Eugene Ale Trail gift packages include a gift certificate for a local brewery PLUS a branded mason jar
FeatureChildPages: a bag of Doug’s Nuts and a Eugene Ale Trail passport. Prices range from $15 - $30. The passport guides you to eleven of the area’s best breweries
DisplayArticles: whose tasting room is in a 1920s dairy barn on an organic hop farm
PageLogo: to Falling Sky Brewing
FeatureBlockTitle1: an urban gastropub that nails it with stellar food
FeatureBlockTitle2: beer and hand-crafted sodas. All Eugene Ale Trail gift packages are sold at the <a title=\"Eugene
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
Cascades & Coast Adventure Center. 

That’s just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to travel and culinary gift ideas from the Eugene
PartnerTitle:
Cascades & Coast region. Find even more on our Deals page.  

 

"

BrowserTitle: Wine and culinary adventures in Oregon's Mt. Hood Territory
HeaderText: Try cooking classes and wine trips in Mt. Hood Territory
ContentText:
We all know that one person who is difficult to shop for. They always have the newest item in their hands before anyone else can purchase it for them.  With the gift of travel, you can help them gain new experiences along the newest farm loop in Oregon’s Mt. Hood Territory.

The Farmlandia Farm Loop features a great selection of farms
PageType:
wineries and country events and other agricultural businesses. Some stops like Bob’s Red Mill and Fir Point Farms are long-time favorites perfect for foodies. The addition of some new businesses is making the loop an even more attractive travel option giving that special someone the chance to enjoy new experiences while also finding new favorite gift items. 

The Kitchen at Middle Ground Farm opened just recently and is joining the Farmlandia Loop lineup for 2015. Chef Jessica Hansen is fun
PageLevel: charismatic leader in the kitchen who walks her guests through the creation of a gourmet meal that incorporates only the freshest ingredients harvested from her family farm and other nearby growers. Paired with local wines
PageSectionID:
each course is an adventure in both culinary creation and enjoyment. The pride one feels after helping to make such a delicious meal is matched only by the enjoyment of eating it. 

Another new attraction along the loop is Our Table Grocery and Kitchen.  Offering a curated choice of produce
ParentPage: dairy
Status: meats as well as local beer and wine
InsertCode:
this store is quickly becoming the go-to spot for discerning home chefs and lovers of all things delicious. They also boast numerous choices for people with food sensitivities and will soon offer a selection of cooked foods including preserves and fully-cooked meals. 

Of course no trip is complete without wine tasting. While Terra Vine Wines has actually been a local favorite for some time
IssuuCode:
the family-owned winery just opened an on-site tasting room this past year that combines their excellent selection of small lot wines with sweeping views of the vineyard and surrounding Willamette Valley. Their namesake label features big reds from vineyards throughout the region while the La Famiglia label features wines crafted from estate-grown fruit. 

Chances are the recipient of your generous gift of travel will find some new favorites on their journey. If you’re truly lucky
HideFromNav:
they’ll invite you along for the experience. The more the merrier on the Farmlandia Farm Loop in Oregon’s Mt. Hood Territory. 

 

 

"
AccountCatIDForListings: NULL
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Sustainable brews at Block 15
ContentText:
This spot is part of our Places to Sip Between the Wonders Road Trip. To view the full itinerary, click here.

Block 15
PageType: the mid-Willamette Valley’s premiere brew pub
PageLevel: specializes in locally sourced pub food and premium from-the-source craft brews. Located in downtown Corvallis
PageSectionID:
they're leaders in the sustainable craft brew revolution that's taking the Northwest by storm.

Block 15 takes their footprint on this earth very seriously. They are participants in Pacific Power’s Blue Sky Program and NW Natural Gas Smart Energy Program.  They brew efficiently in order to reduce the use of water and recycling waste and by using organic and regional ingredients. For instance
ParentPage: they use a hot liquor tank that catches excess water during cooling and stores it for the next brew day. They use a clean in place systems to clean their tanks. In addition
Status: they purchase Bonneville Environmental Foundation Water Certificates. For every gallon of water they use in their brewery
InsertCode:
the amount is diverted back to rives in need through those certificates.

But most importantly they take pride in serving tasty craft beers and delicious food all in a warm welcoming casual environment. 

They have set a great example for other craft brew establishments that have opened since Block 15 came into town. For example
IssuuCode: Sky High Brewing does local deliveries to area restaurants using a bicycle built in Eugene and they are a bike friendly business. The folks at Sky High brew beer to celebrate life here in Corvallis. They feel lucky to live in the Willamette Valley and they know it. They brew on a 10 barrel JV Northwest system made in Canby
HideFromNav:
use Crosby Hop Farms hops from Woodburn and Wyeast yeast from Hood River. They also serve some excellent pub food that is locally sourced. 

Each year since 2011 the Corvallis Craft Brew Association comes together to hold two great events: the Corvallis Beer Picnic is scheduled for July 25
DisplayListings:
2015 and Corvallis Beer Week is on schedule for September 11th through September 19th 2015.

Find It:

Block 15 Brewing | 300 SW Jefferson Corvallis OR 97333 | Phone: 541-758-2077 | online: www.block15.com

"
AccountCatIDForListings: NULL
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Uncover new restaurants, wineries, and hikes in Salem, Oregon
HeaderText: New year, new adventures in Salem
ContentText:
The entrepreneurial spirit never ceases in Oregon, where people turn their passions for wine, beer, food and adventure into new and exciting experiences for residents and visitors alike. This year, plan a trip with your loved ones to the Salem area to see what’s new and noteworthy in Oregon’s capital city. 

Where to Shop

One of the most exciting changes in downtown Salem is the re-opening of the historic McGilchrist-Roth Building. Originally built in 1916, this beautifully renovated building now features three cool, new shops worth visiting: Gayle’s Italian Market
PageType: an authentic Italian market featuring a pizza oven
ParentPage: meats and more; Ricky’s Bubbles & Sweets
Status: an old-fashioned candy and gift store; and Archive
IssuuCode:
urban coffee shop by day and Prohibition-inspired bar at night. 

What to Eat

Salem’s culinary scene continues to grow with the addition of new eateries. In downtown
HideFromNav: Table Five08 unites the culinary talents of executive chef Jason Freeburg and chef de cuisine Alexander Baccarat - both graduates of New York’s prestigious Culinary Institute of America. The chic
AccountCatIDForListings: global flavors using fresh
SortOrder: local ingredients. A few miles outside of Salem in the small town of Sublimity is Panezanellie’s Breadstick Shoppe. Under new ownership this year
FeatureChildPages: this cozy café serves up some of the most to-die-for breadsticks
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
sticky buns and flatbread pizza in the Willamette Valley. 

Where to Taste

A few Salem area wineries have also expanded in order to enhance the visitor’s experience. One of the most notable new venues is Brooks Winery. The 12
DisplayArticles: 000-square-foot tasting room features stunning views of the vineyards and plenty of space to sip and relax with friends and family. Eola Hills Winery also opened a second tasting room this year. Their new Legacy Estate Vineyard features a rustic tasting room with a lovely view of the man-made pond
PageLogo:
plus 300 acres that are open to visitors for hiking and exploring. 

What to Do

In June
FeatureBlockTitle1: Salem officially became home to the Oregon WWII Memorial. Located on the grounds of the Oregon State Capitol
FeatureBlockTitle2: this $1.22 million recognizes the service and sacrifice of the 152
FeaturedActivityTitle1: 000 Oregonians who served during WW II. The names of the 3
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
771 Oregonians killed in action are also inscribed on a black granite wall.  

Outdoor enthusiasts will find new adventures in the area
PartnerTitle: too.  Approximately 30 miles east of Salem on the beautiful Santiam River sits the newly opened Bear Creek Campground – a 15-acre campground featuring 15 camp sites
DisplayPartnerColumns: designated swimming areas and hiking trails. At iconic Silver Falls State Park
PartnerCityTitle: families can enjoy the new “natural play” area   - the first of its kind to be constructed in an Oregon state park. This ¼-mile loop allows kids to hide out in a cougar's den
VideoTitle1:
weave a bird's nest and more. 

For more ideas about where to go and what to do in the Salem area

BrowserTitle: Perfect weekend getaway in Corvallis, Oregon
HeaderText: Plan a perfect Corvallis weekend in the new year
ContentText: Got the winter time blues? Then start thinking about the summer and consider Corvallis this year. Here are our ideas for a perfect weekend in
PageLevel:
Oregon.

Eat & Drink

Summer here is beautiful with average temperatures in the eighties and everything is green and verdant. Check out our fabulous Farmer’s Market every Wednesday and Saturday through the fall. Corvallis is surrounded by the best agricultural land in the West that makes for wonderful fresh produce
PageSectionID:
great cheeses and organic meats all here for enjoying. 

The best way to sample the flavors and sights of the Willamette Valley is on a Craft Brew Float Trip. This tasty trip features paddling the peaceful Willamette River with pull outs to sample some of the area’s finest craft brews while relaxing in the sunshine. End the day with a scrumptious meal at Block 15
ParentPage:
one of Corvallis’ best local brew pubs. Check out www.cascadiaexpeditions.com.

Relax by the river

Stay the night at the newly-renovated Holiday Inn Express on the River. As a guest you can enjoy the picturesque scenery of the Willamette River from the comfort of your own room or by strolling along the riverfront walking path. Walk down to Historic Downtown Corvallis where you will find locally owned shops and restaurants nearby. A hot complimentary breakfast is provided at the hotel as well. Visit www.hiexpress.com.

Taste & Travel

After a tasty breakfast take the Bridge Wine Tour. Mix in a little history while enjoying some tasty varietals at beautiful boutique wineries. Visit the Irish Bend Bridge then off to picturesque Cardwell Hills Cellars for the first tasting of the trip
Status: before moving on to two more wonderful wineries- Harris Bridge Vineyards and Tyee Wine Cellars with a picnic lunch along the way. Each winery offers different specialty wines-it’s not just about pinot noir anymore. What’s more
InsertCode:
you’ll have the pleasure of actually meeting the winemakers themselves.  This is trip is also offered by Cascadia Expeditions along with many other adventures. Explore their offerings an find the perfect adventure for you and your loved ones: www.cascadiaexpeditions.com.

 

 

 

 
"
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Hunt for hidden gems in Albany, Oregon
HeaderText: Explore hidden gems of art and history in Albany
ContentText:
Give the unique gift of an adventure this year. When you give the gift of travel, you can share hidden gems of culture and cuisine located in the Willamette Valley.  Here are a few unique adventures for you and your loved ones to experience this year.  

The Albany Historic Carousel 

The art-lovers on your gift list will love a trip to The Albany Historic Carousel and Museum. Open six days a week year-round
PageType:
the carousel project delights visitors while they witness a team of volunteer wood-carvers and artists at work creating a menagerie of carousel animals by hand. The 52 whimsical animals destined for placement on the carousel range from a 7-foot-tall giraffe to a mythical mer-horse. The museum also houses a collection of historic carousel animals and carousel memorabilia dating back to 1885. Admission is free; donations are welcomed.

 

Albany Antique Mall

Winter is a good time to come in out of the weather. Anyone who loves hunting for vintage and retro treasures will love a trip to the two story Albany Antique Mall
PageSectionID: 000 square feet of antiques and collectibles. Browsing the beautifully displayed items is like taking a step back in time. More than 100 booths offer fabulous possibilities
ParentPage: including antique furniture
AccountCatIDForListings: Fiestaware
DisplayArticles: the “Vintage Boutique” includes a fabulous selection of vintage clothing; a large variety of hats
PageLogo:
shoes and accessories; and a men’s section as well. 

Sybaris

Take your foodie friends to enjoy a one-of-a-kind meal at Sybaris
FeatureBlockTitle1: an eclectic Northwest Bistro in historic downtown Albany. Sybaris offers a fresh menu every month in a spacious
FeatureBlockTitle2: upscale atmosphere with an extensive Northwest-centered wine list and a full bar.  Chef Matt Bennett
FeaturedActivityTitle1: who has twice been nominated for Best Chef in the Northwest
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
is known for his Oregon-centric cuisine and expertise in foods native to the Willamette Valley. His collaborations with the Confederated Tribes of the Grand Ronde earned him an invitation to present the “Willamette Valley Native Tribute” at the James Beard House in New York City in 2011; it was the first time Native American foods were featured at the prestigious establishment. A meal at Sybaris is a memorable experience to enjoy with your loved ones. Call for reservations: 541-928-8157

Albany Historic Districts

The history-lovers on your list will love a trip to wander through Albany's four nationally registered historic districts. If you make a trip in December
PartnerTitle: you can see the magical effect of over 200 historic homes lit with white lights for the holidays. If you want to get a closer look at history
PartnerText: the Christmas Parlor Tour on Sunday
PartnerCityTitle: 2014 from 2-7 p.m. offers a chance to tour inside beautifully decorated historic homes
VideoTitle1:
and museums lit up with the sights and sounds of a Victorian holiday.  Entertainment will delight the sight-seers along the way and light refreshments will be served.  Rides in a horse-drawn wagon and vintage trolley rides are included in the ticket price.  Ticket Price:  Adults - $15.  Seniors and Children - $12. Call the Albany Visitors Association for more information.  541-928-0911.

 

"

BrowserTitle: Explore the Willamette Valley with video
ContentText:
Wine and Art

Wine and Food

Wine and Agriculture

"
MetaDescription: Watch videos from the Willamette Valley. Discover wine and art, wine and food pairings and agriculture in these videos.

BrowserTitle: Wine + Portuguese hospitality in Yamhill Valley
HeaderText: Wine + Portuguese hospitality in Yamhill Valley
ContentText:
This spot is part of our Places to Sip Between the Wonders Road Trip. To view the full itinerary, click here.

More than 20 years ago
PageType: Dave and Deolinda Coelho left a life of farming crops in California’s San Joaquin Valley to plant new roots – grapevines this time – in the gentle hills just outside of Amity. The couple’s first vintage
PageSectionID: was a testament to their family’s Portuguese heritage
ParentPage:
and that’s been their focus ever since.

The charming Coelho Winery building in downtown Amity is a literal phoenix from the ashes; the couple saw potential in the charred remains of a hardware store and capitalized on the exposed beams
Status: remnant wood and original doors. Today
InsertCode:
there is no cozier place to enjoy a flight of exceptional Oregon wines served with a shot of Portuguese Acolhimento (hospitality).

Of course
IssuuCode: the striking décor of the tasting room doesn’t detract from the state-of-the-art winemaking facilities housed in adjacent rooms. The temperature- and humidity-controlled barrel room and functional processing space are where winemaking magic happens
HideFromNav:
allowing the Coelhos to offer visitors their award-winning vintages every day of the week.

Still operated by members of the family
DisplayListings:
Coelho Winery continues to manage its acreage just south of town with sustainable practices that maximize the terroir of the Willamette Valley AVA while also being friendly to local fauna and flora. 

A gorgeous spring day is the perfect opportunity to settle into a comfortable tasting room chair near the window and sample Coelho pinot noir
AccountCatIDForListings:
pinot gris and traditional Portuguese blends. Bring some friends and stay a while – the family welcomes you.

Find it

Coelho Winery | 111 Fifth St. Amity

NavButtonText: Great beer and cozy vibes in Albany Oregon
BrowserTitle: A cozy craft beer haven in Albany
HeaderText: A cozy craft beer haven in Albany
ContentText:
This spot is part of our Places to Sip Between the Wonders Road Trip. To view the full itinerary, click here.

The Calapooia Brewing Company is a lively
PageType: but cozy brewpub in the historic town of Albany
PageLevel: famous for its award winning brews. The brewery sits on the northeastern corner of Hill Street and Water Avenue and is in an off-the-beaten-path corner of downtown Albany near the Willamette River.  The pub may be tucked away
PageSectionID: but  it’s easily accessible once you’re there
ParentPage:
and the friendly vibe – and excellent beer – draws visitors in.

The beer: After purchasing the original brewery that had first opened in 1993
Status: husband-and-wife team Mark Martin and Laura Bryngelson opened their new brewery business and named it after the Calapooia River
InsertCode: one of the two rivers that flows into Albany. The Calapooia has an award-winning lineup of seasonal and specialty beers;  the best-selling classic Northwest IPA is named RIPArian IPA.  It is massively hopped with Chinook
DisplayListings: and balanced with a malt finish.  Another popular brew is the Chili Beer
AccountCatIDForListings: a truly unique beer that is medium-bodied and amber; minimally hopped and generously flavored with fresh Anaheim
FeatureChildPages:
and Jalapeno peppers.

The food: Great food goes hand in hand with great beer. The chef at the Calapooia subscribes to the concept of sustainability
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
so only Oregon Natural Meat called  “Brew Beef” (which means it is Oregon beef that is fattened on spent brewery grain) is used.  The burgers are served on a steamed bakery bun with Beaver Brand sweet-hot mustard and other savory condiments and sides.

Brewery Tours:  You can taste the wonderful world of Oregon craft beer via a tour of the Calapooia Brewery. The Calapooia offers behind the scenes brewery tours with a chance to meet the brewers
DisplayArticles: who  make over 30 recipes a year and keeping up with the demand to supply beer for their own pub
PageLogo:
as well as taps and bottled beer available around the state.

Entertainment: Calapooia Brewery offers live music every week.  Many local bands like playing the “’Pooia” because of the warm and friendly atmosphere and audience.

Bike Friendly:  There’s nothing like stopping for a delicious cold drink to quench ones thirst after a hard day’s ride on the nearby Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway.  The Calapooia Brewery is one of Oregon’s network of certified bike-friendly businesses.

Find it:

Calapooia Brewing | 140 Hill Street NE Albany OR 97321 | Phone: 541-928-1941 | www.calapooiabrewing.com

 

"

NavButtonText: Sip artisan cider in Eugene Oregon
BrowserTitle: Reviving artisan cider traditions in Eugene
HeaderText: Reviving artisan cider traditions in Eugene
ContentText:
This spot is part of our Places to Sip Between the Wonders Road Trip. To view the full itinerary, click here.

Take a sip of small-batch ciders at WildCraft Cider Works’ reclaimed tasting room


As bottles of cider start to find themselves on more store shelves
PageType: it’s a pleasure to revisit unique craft efforts like <a title=\"WildCraft Cider Works\" href=\"Take%20a%20sip%20of%20small-batch%20ciders%20at%20WildCraft%20Cider%20Works’%20reclaimed%20tasting%20room.%20%20As%20bottles%20of%20cider%20start%20to%20find%20themselves%20on%20more%20store%20shelves
ParentPage: %20cherries
IssuuCode: %20you%20can%20feel%20the%20history%20surround%20you%20inside%20this%20tasting%20room%20as%20you%20sip%20away.%20They%20even%20recovered%20the%20original%202%20x%204%20ceiling%20beams%20that%20held%20the%20building%20together%20in%20its%20original%20design%20as%20a%20grocery%20warehouse.%20%20What%20else%20can%20you%20experience%20at%20WildCraft%20Cider%20Works?%20Think%20cider’s%20just%20made%20with%20apples?%20Try%20one%20of%20WildCraft’s%20seasonal%20flavors%20like%20blueberry%20or%20plum.%20See%20where%20the%20magic%20happens%20and%20visit%20the%20reclaimed%20rack%20and%20cloth%20hand%20press%20that%20squeezes%20juice%20year-round.%20Into%20beer%20too?%20Don’t%20forget%20to%20pick%20up%20one%20of%20Eugene’s%20Ale%20Trail%20passports%20while%20you’re%20there.%20Get%20stamps%20at%20eight%20beer%20destinations%20and%20earn%20a%20prize.%20Find%20it:%20%20Click%20here%20for%20details%20on where%20to%20find%20these%20fun%20Eugene-area%20trips.%20%20%20Find%20it:%20Wild%20Craft%20Cider%20Works%20390%20Lincoln%20Street%20Eugene%20OR%2097401%20Phone:%20541-735-3506%20Online:%20www.wildcraftciderworks.com\" target=\"_blank\">WildCraft Cider Works. Their whole fruit fermentation idea is more of a philosophy than a fermentation style: revitalizing old orchards. Hand picking the perfect apples
AccountCatIDForListings:
plums and other fruit in local Willamette Valley orchards that are up to 150 years old leads to rich flavors and delicious combinations that represent true local flavor.

The WildCraft tasting room is a treat unto itself
SortOrder: playing host to an array of refurbished and reclaimed assets lining its walls. From barstools made out of classic Ford Model-A axels to an old barn door that separates the fermentation area from the restaurant
FeatureChildPages:
you can feel the history surround you inside this tasting room as you sip away. They even recovered the original 2 x 4 ceiling beams that held the building together in its original design as a grocery warehouse.

 

What else can you experience at WildCraft Cider Works?

  • Think cider’s just made with apples? Try one of WildCraft’s seasonal flavors like blueberry or plum.
  • See where the magic happens and visit the reclaimed rack and cloth hand press that squeezes juice year-round.
  • Into beer too? Don’t forget to pick up one of Eugene’s Ale Trail passports while you’re there. Get stamps at eight beer destinations and earn a prize.

Find it:

 

Click here for details on where to find these fun Eugene-area trips.  

 

Find it:

Wild Craft Cider Works | 390 Lincoln St. Eugene OR 97401 | Ph: 541-735-3506 | www.wildcraftciderworks.com

 
"
PageLogo: NULL

NavButtonText: St. Josef's Winery in Mt. Hood Territory
BrowserTitle: Beautiful St. Josef's beckons in Mt. Hood Territory
HeaderText: Beautiful St. Josef's beckons in Mt. Hood Territory
ContentText:
This spot is part of our Places to Sip Between the Wonders Road Trip. To view the full itinerary, click here.

As you tour Oregon’s many scenic vineyards enroute between the 7 Wonders
PageType:
no trip is complete without a stopover at St. Josef’s Winery.

Owner and winemaker Josef Fleischmann is considered one of the pioneers of the state’s now well-known wine industry. He first planted his vines in 1978
PageLevel:
making his winery the first in Oregon’s Mt. Hood Territory and among the first in the state. His passion for the science and artistry behind winemaking and for helping others successfully start their own businesses helped solidify Oregon as a premier viticultural destination. 

The Willamette Valley’s climate is perfect for creating big
ParentPage: and St. Josef’s are no different. Done in the classic Burgundian style
Status:
this variety is known as the wine that put the Willamette Valley on the map. But one should be careful not to overlook the many other varietals crafted from the estate-grown vines and nearby vineyards in St. Josef’s lineup. The merlot has a fine fruit bouquet with a light finish and the mighty cabernet sauvignon is a complex wine with a deep body.

Not to be outdone
InsertCode: St. Josef’s selection of white wines have an outstanding reputation as well. The white Riesling is immensely popular with its floral bouquet and semi-sweet flavor
IssuuCode: while the pinot gris is a light
HideFromNav:
easy-to-drink wine that pairs well with many foods or is perfectly suited to enjoy alone. 

A number of other whites and even desert wines round out the lineup
DisplayListings: giving wine-lovers ample reason to return to this winery again and again to sample each of the offerings. Savvy travelers time their journeys to coincide with annual events such as the winemaker’s dinners in February
AccountCatIDForListings: summer music series
SortOrder:
grape stomp in September or harvest festival in October. More active souls can take part in their spring countryside half marathon or the bike ride and brisket event.

When these fun events are paired with the scenic views surrounding this picturesque winery and the award-winning wines
FeatureChildPages:
it is no wonder how this affable vintner and his family have become fixtures in Oregon’s wine scene. 

Find it:
St. Josefs Winery | 28836 S. Barlow Rd. Canby
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Discover Salem's craft brew scene at Gilgamesh
HeaderText: Discover Salem's craft brew scene at Gilgamesh
ContentText:
This spot is part of our Places to Sip Between the Wonders Road Trip. To view the full itinerary, click here.

While wineries continue to flourish in the Salem area
PageType: the local craft brewing industry has also made huge strides in recent years. One of the pioneers to spearhead the creation of a craft brew culture in Salem is Gilgamesh Brewing – known not only for creating award-winning beer
PageLevel: but also for opening one of the best new spots to sit back
PageSectionID:
sip and relax with friends and family. 

Gilgamesh Brewing was born in 2009 when Mike
ParentPage: Matt and Nick Radtke
InsertCode: started brewing beer commercially out of their home. They quickly outgrew their home-based operation
IssuuCode: which prompted the family to open “The Campus
DisplayListings:
bar and outdoor event venue which officially opened its doors in November 2012. 

 “We wanted to create a place where people felt comfortable hanging out
AccountCatIDForListings: ” says Nick Radtke. With that premise in mind
SortOrder: the restaurant features two cozy fireplaces (one inside and one outside)
FeatureChildPages: an open beam ceiling and lots of natural light. Quirky details – like lamps made from recycled metal kegs and mason jars – add a rustic feel. An outdoor patio and lawn area backs up against Pringle Creek
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
providing the ideal spot for dining and sipping al fresco. 

Craft beer enthusiasts will be delighted to learn that The Campus features at least 12 Gilgamesh beers on tap at any given time
DisplayArticles: plus local wines and hard cider. Menu items include hearty Northwest fare like scratch-made soups
PageLogo: fresh salads and gourmet burgers. Dishes feature seasonal
FeatureBlockTitle1:
local ingredients including fruit and produce sourced from nearby farms. 

On the brewery side
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
17-barrel system that is designed for maximum efficiency and uses 1/3 less water than the previous system. Tours of the brewing facility are offered regularly. 

As you’re making travel plans this spring
PartnerTitle: be sure to visit Gilgamesh Brewing’s The Campus  - an ideal spot to enjoy local craft beer
PartnerText:
Northwest cuisine and the beauty of the Mid-Willamette Valley.

Find it:

Gilgamesh Brewing | 2065 Madrona Ave. Salem OR 97302 | Phone: 503-584-1789 | www.gilgameshbrewing.com
"

PageDesc: 7 Places to Sip Between the Wonders
NavButtonText: Places to Sip Between the Wonders
BrowserTitle: Oregon's 8th Wonder - Oregon Wine Country & the Willamette Valley
HeaderText: 7 Places to Sip Wine Between the Wonders
ContentText: When you're trekking between Oregon's 7 Wonders this spring
PageType: fuel your wanderings with a taste of Oregon's legendary craft beverage scene. Whether it's a hand-crafted Pinot noir or a flavorful craft brew that you crave
PageLevel: the Willamette Valley is a powerhouse when it comes to artisan food and drink
PageSectionID:
and it's centrally located on your way from Wonder to Wonder.

Take this craft beverage road trip and sip your way between the Wonders--we guarantee your taste buds will thank you.



Day One

Sip: After you've explored the Columbia River Gorge and the slopes of Mt. Hood
ParentPage: head for the valley. Nestled near the small town of Canby in Oregon's Mt. Hood Territory is St. Josef's Winery. Walk through their rose garden
Status:
sit beside the lake and unwind with a classic Oregon Pinot noir or food-friendly Pinot gris. Feel the serenity begin to sink in--you've arrived in Oregon wine country.

Sip: No trip to Oregon is complete without a pilgrimage to the Yamhill Valley. It's the birthplace of Oregon Pinot noir--the spot where
IssuuCode: a brave soul name David Lett planted the first Pinot vines in the Willamette Valley. Today his son Jason carries on the family legacy at The Eyrie Vineyards. Stop
DisplayListings:
and look around. This is where it all began.

Stay: Not far from the Eyrie tasting room in McMinnville is Hotel Oregon
AccountCatIDForListings:
a funky renovated historic hotel. Stay in one of their quirky rooms and enjoy a drink in one of the four bars onsite.




Day Two

Sip: Take Highway 99W south through rolling green hills to the small town of Amity
SortOrder: where you'll find Coelho Winery
FeatureChildPages: a welcoming spot in a historic renovated building. Taste Pinot noir as well as wines made in the Portuguese tradition
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
an homage to the Coelho family's Portuguese heritage.

Sip: Next head to Salem
DisplayArticles: where you can educate your taste buds with a trip to The Campus
PageLogo: Gilgamesh Brewing's beer oasis in Salem. Oregon is know for craft beers bursting with flavor and personality
FeatureBlockTitle1:
and Gilgamesh is a perfect spot to start your beer exploration.

Stay:

PageID: The Grand Hotel in located in Salem's historic downtown area
BrowserTitle:
and coffee shops.




Day Three

Sip: In Albany
HeaderText: the Calapooia Brewing Co. offers a cozy haven for craft brews
ContentText: pub food
PageType: and live music on the weekends. Grab a seat on the covered atrium when the weather's nice. If you're there on a weekend
PageLevel:
the brunch menu is a must.

Sip: Next head west to Corvallis
PageSectionID: where Block 15 Brewing is leading a sustainable-brewing revolution. Locally-sourced food and beer ingredients are just the starting point for this brewpub
ParentPage: which makes sure that for every gallon of water they use to brew
Status:
a gallon of water is diverted back to rivers in need.

Stay: The Hanson Country Inn is a beautiful bed & breakfast located on a small estate just outside of town.

 


Day Four:

From Corvallis
InsertCode:
you can take a side trip west to view another of Oregon's 7 Wonders: The Oregon Coast--or you can continue the tasting journey south to Eugene.

Sip:

PageID: WildCraft Cider Works is reviving the centuries-old tradition of artisan cider-making. Working with local orchards (some of them dating back to the pioneer-era) the cider-makers at WildCraft hand-pick and sort their fruit to create truly unique hard ciders. Their downtown Eugene tasting room features 10 WildCraft ciders on tap
PageDesc: a tasting menu of imported ciders
NavButtonText:
and delicious local cuisine.

Stay: The Inn at the Fifth is a boutique hotel located just six blocks from WildCraft and only steps from the Fifth Street Market
BrowserTitle:
home to charming boutiques and world-class restaurants.

From Eugene
HeaderText: you have several choices to continue checking stops off your 7 Wonders bucket list. Head south to Crater Lake. Or east
ContentText: where you can explore Smith Rock
PageLevel: and the Wallowas. No matter where you go
PageSectionID: grab a bottle (or two) to take home
ParentPage:
and keep exploring.

 

"
AccountCatIDForListings: NULL
ProposedHeaderText: Oregon may be known for it's even wonders, but an 8th would be the amazing wineries of the fertile Willamette Valley. Sip wines at these scenic vineyards between visiting wonders.

PageDesc: Wine tasting, birding and whale watching road trip
BrowserTitle: Wine tasting, whale watching and birding
HeaderText: Wine tasting, whale watching and bird watching.
ContentText: Winter Oregon road trip - wine tasting
PageType:
birding and whale watching

 


Oregon is generally known for rain
PageSectionID: cloudy skies during the winter months. Our winter weather nurtures fertile Willamette Valley grapevines and the nearby coast of the Pacific Ocean gives sanctuary and food to migrating whale populations. It’s the perfect time to grab your binoculars
ParentPage:
camera and a raincoat to enjoy a road trip. Slow down this season and enjoy cozy wine country and the wave crashing views along the Oregon Coast.


Day 1: Portland to Corvallis – 84 miles/ 135km

Pick up a rental car at the Portland Airport and head 90-minutes south to the college town of Corvallis
Status:
home to the Oregon State University. Stroll the campus or visit downtown for boutique tax-free shopping. Grab a bite at local favorites like Block 15 Brewery known for its creative sour beers and traditional pacific northwest IPA or Taco Vino for their unique street tacos and build your own guacamole. 

If you would prefer
InsertCode: pick up a picnic lunch to-go from New Morning Bakery to enjoy it in the serene wetlands of the William Finley National Wildlife Refuge. Known for its winter birding
HideFromNav: hosts various walking trails where you can find flocks of geese
DisplayListings:
ducks and swans - you may even spot a bald eagle. 

After birding
AccountCatIDForListings: take the scenic route back to Corvallis and stop in Philomath. On weekends
SortOrder: enjoy a wine sampling from Spindrift Cellars or grab a glass of mead and dinner at Nectar Creek. Downtown Corvallis also hosts great dinner options walking distance from their newly built riverfront hotel
FeatureChildPages: Courtyard by Mariott Corvallis. Big River Restaurant and Bar brings the flavor of the Willamette Valley to your plate with local organic ingredient
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
and nearby Magenta offers eclectic Asian Fusion plates.

Find more things to do in the Corvallis area 



Day 2: Corvallis to Florence - 96 miles/ 155km

Breakfast choices in Corvallis can be quick and quirky
DisplayArticles: like a hand-dipped donut from <strong>Benny’s Donuts
PageLogo: or casual dining at a bustling breakfast favorite like Broken Yolk Cafe. For a locally roasted cup of coffee
FeatureBlockTitle1:
pick-up a cup for the road at Tried and True before leaving town.

Make your way toward the Oregon Coast via Highway 34
FeatureBlockTitle2: designated as Marys Peak to Pacific Scenic Byway. This 72-mile/116km tour takes you from the Willamette Valley along the twists and curves of the Alsea River Valley to the sandy and scenic central coast. As you head along the byway toward the coastal town of Waldport you can stop and get your first peek of the Pacific Ocean from the top of Mary's Peak Day Use Area. Mary's Peak is the highest mountain in the Coast Range with full 360-views from the Pacific Ocean to the Cascades. Rolling fog can coat the Coast Range valleys during winter sometimes obscuring the ocean view
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
but the light dusting of snow on the peak makes it a beautiful nature scene nonetheless. 

Travel Tip: Have some cash on hand
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
Marys Peak requires a $5 parking fee. 

Once you hit Hwy 101
PartnerText: home to over 40 miles of coastal dunes in the Siuslaw National Forest. The forest has plenty walking trails for wildlife viewing and birding
DisplayPartnerColumns:
or a rugged and adventure-filled dune buggy ride. 

Watch the sun set in Historic Old Town Florence from behind the Siuslaw River Bridge built in 1936. After the sun goes down
PartnerCityTitle: walk to dinner at one of the many great restaurants in old town: Waterfront Depot Restaurant an urbane riverside bistro offering an upscales twist on American fare. Bridgewater Fish House and Zebra Bar offer eclectic seafood plates
MetaDescription:
pasta and seafood. After dinner check-in at beachside Driftwood Shores Resort.

Find more things to do in the Florence area





Day 3: Florence to Yachats 25 miles/ 40km

Eat breakfast beachside at the hotel’s Surftide Restaurant. After breakfast
SEOTags:
take a few steps from the restaurant and hop on Driftwood Beach for a whale watching walk.

Next stop: the Sea Lion Caves. Take an elevator ride 200 feet (61 m) down into the cave as tall as a 12-story building and as wide as a football field. Barking sea lions lounge around inside the cave's natural amphitheater during the fall and winter months.

As you meander your way North
SeoNotes:
stop halfway to Yachats at the historic Heceta Head Lighthouse. Stop under the bridge over Cape Creek exactly where it meets the ocean and see hundreds of Western gulls bathing in the water. Bring your binoculars when you take a tour of the lighthouse and look for whales from 205ft (63 m) above the ocean. 

Another whaling view point on the way to Yachats is Cape Perpetua. At 800 feet in elevation
SEOStatus: the lookout provides a 70-mile view of the Oregon coast on a clear day. Additionally
ProposedHeaderText:
the unobstructed view out west over the Pacific allows visitors to see more than 35 miles out to sea. Cape Perpetua is also part of the Cape Perpetua Marine Reserve and Marine Protected Areas.

You can’t go wrong with dinner at the Drift Inn in Yachats. The menu is an eclectic mix of family favorites and original dishes focused on fresh ingredients from the Pacific Northwest. After dinner
ProposedBrowserTitle:
walk up the block for a nightcap at Yachats Brewing + Farmstore.

After dinner
ProposedMetaDescription: head to the Overleaf Lodge for a good nights rest. In the morning
SEOPaidSearch:
watch some of the best wave crashing on the Oregon Coast while drinking your morning coffee off your room’s private patio - don’t forget to keep an eye out for whale spouts!

Find more things to do in the Yachats area 



Day 4: Yachats to Lincoln City- 37 miles/ 60km

Whale and wave watch over breakfast at Yachats Ona Restaurant. After breakfast
SEOPaidBanner: stop at the Green Salmon to get a cup of coffee for the road toward Newport
ContentType: Yaquina Head Lighthouse. You can take a tour of the 130-year-old lighthouse guided by Bureau of Land Management staff before heading to Historic Nye Beach
CreationDate: a centrally located beach with easy parking
Excerpt: to take a stroll to watch for whales in the bay. Head back to enjoy boutique shopping at Nye Beach
AuthorUserID:
and warm up at the Chowder Bowl with a bowl of their famous clam chowder.

After lunch
PublishDate: travel north on Highway 101 to Depoe Bay
ExpirationDate: the whale watching capital of the Oregon Coast. Oregon State Parks and Recreation has a Whale Watching Center with staff available to answer any whale related questions. If you’re visiting December or January
IncludeInWidgets: you will likely see at least one of the nearly 20
DataFinds: 000 gray whales migrating south for winter. Spring whale watching
TopPageview:
showcases the gray whales returning as they travel back to Alaskan waters.

Depoe Bay has a great main street with local shops and boutiques right on Highway 101 with another overlook for whale watching. For dinner visit Tidal Raves where Chef Jon Hamlin
MicrositeID: a graduate from the Culinary Institute of America in New York
AuditTransferPage:
serves pacific northwest seafood with restaurant views over the ocean.

Continue north to Lincoln City to stay at the Inn at Spanish Head where you can enjoy an oceanfront view to whale and storm watch from the comfort of your room
AuditRefreshPage: or head down to enjoy a glass of wine at the oceanfront restaurant and bar
AuditTransferNotes:
Fathoms.

Find more things to do in the Lincoln City area




Day 5: Lincoln City to Amity - 57 miles/ 77km

Enjoy breakfast at local hot-spot
AuditNavChange: Wildflower Café. An old house turned restaurant specializing in made-to-order plates. After breakfast
column58: head to Siletz Bay Wildlife Refuge for a bird watching walk. Common bird sightings at this refuge include the Western sandpiper
column61:
and green-winged teal. 

After the refuge take your last stroll along the Pacific Ocean at the Roads End Beach before making your way back toward the Willamette Valley via Highway 18. 

On your drive you will travel through the Van Duzer Forest Scenic Corridor and the newly designated American Viticulture Association (AVA)
column62:
Van Duzer Corridor AVA. Visit Chateau Bianca to sample the distinctive wines known for their signature terroir of marine sediment with a top layer of basalt. Pinot noirs in this AVA are darker and richer due to grape skins that are thickened by cool pacific winds.

For another birding opportunity
column63: stop at Baskett Slough Wildlife Refuge near Dallas. Baskett Slough hosts over 200 species of birds for winter as nesting or migration stopovers. The diversity in habitat demonstrates an array of birds to see from shorebirds and waterbirds
column66: the gateway to the Eola-Amity AVA and a few short miles to McMinnville and the Evergreen Aviation Museum. In Amity
column67: pick up a sandwich or snack at Blue Raven Farmstand
column68:
then head down the road to Keeler Estate Vineyard for spectacular wine sourced from biodynamic and sustainable grape farming.

Have dinner at The Blue Goat on Amity’s Trade Street
column70: local and sustainably-farmed produce from the Willamette Valley. After dinner
column71:
walk down the block and check in at the Amity Flats to stay in a charmingly restored loft.

Find more things to do in the Yamhill area



Day 6: Amity to Eugene - 85 miles/ 136km

Travel tip
column72:
you can travel through Salem to get to Albany. Find more things to do in the Salem area

In the morning grab a waffle and espresso for breakfast at the Common Cup then make your way South toward historic downtown Albany
column73:
boasting more than 800 historic structures in a 100-block area. 

After exploring historic homes and buildings
column76: built in Albany in 1849. Across the street
column77: take a ride on a hand-carved animal at the Historic Carousel & Museum. Community volunteers hand-carve all the one-of-a-kind animals that adorn the carousel. Each animal takes over two years to complete and soon
column78: you can ride the orca whale
column80: Oregon’s longest running family-owned Hungarian restaurant
column81:
before making the 50-minute drive to Eugene.

Eugene
column82: known as TrackTownUSA and home to the University of Oregon. While on campus
column83: be sure to visit the National Medal winning Museum of Cultural and Natural History. After the museum
column84: stop in at the urban winery
column86:
to sample their private label William Rose Wines or other local artisan craft drinks.

Dinner choices in Eugene are nearly limitless. Keep it casual in The Whit with street tacos at Tacovore or exceptional sandwiches and beer at Falling Sky Delicatessen. To splurge on yourself
column87: go downtown and enjoy locally sourced menus from Marche
column88: Rye or Oregon Electric Station. Check in at the Hyatt Place
column89:
one of the newest hotels in the area. The SkyBar is a great place to unwind after a long day. 

Find more things to do in the Albany area



Day 7: Eugene to Airport

Grab a wood-fired breakfast at Hideaway Bakery and head to a the largest collection of native raptor birds in the Pacific Northwest at Cascades Raptor Center. At the center
column90: you’ll get to see staff working with rescued raptors. Raptor Center Staff will bring birds out of enclosures to educate and allow for a closer
column91:
unobstructed visit.

Travel Tip: At the Cascades Raptor Center you can book a private tour ahead of time or take a self guided tour though the property.

Find more things to do in the Eugene area 

If you have more time in the Eugene area
column92: do some wine tasting along the Territorial Wine Trail at Sweet Cheeks Winery
column95: the Willamette Valley’s largest body of water
column96: and an exceptional birding site. An important fly-way for migrating birds
column99: lookouts and viewing platforms. The Eugene Airport is 30 minutes from Cascades Raptor Center. Or
column100: if you are flying out of Portland
column101:
Portland International Airport is approximately 2 hours and 15 minutes away.

If you want to stay in the Portland area longer
column102: stay at the Best Western Wilsonville Inn. From Wilsonville
column104:
visit the quaint town of Aurora to taste at Pheasant Run Winery in the old Aurora State Bank. The bank building was built in 1905 as part of the Portland World’s Fair and moved to its current home after the exposition.

Find more things to do in the Wilsonville area. 

This itinerary was created in partnership between the Oregon Coast Visitors Association
column105:
the Willamette Valley Visitors Association and VisitUSA Parks. Andi Fischer of MissAdventures with Andi got to experience this trip first hand and you can read about her experience here.



"
column132: In addition to tasting wine, you can go whale watching and birding in Oregon's Willamette Valley.

PageDesc: The Great American Solar Eclipse Comes to Oregon Wine Country
NavButtonText: Celebrate the Total Solar Eclipse in Oregon
BrowserTitle: Best Place to view The Great American Solar Eclipse is Oregon Wine Country
HeaderText: Watch the 2017 Total Solar Eclipse in Oregon's Wine Country
ContentText: On August 21
PageType:
2017 the Willamette Valley will be in prime viewing path of the first total solar eclipse since 1979. In fact it touches Oregon first - the shadow of the Moon (umbra) does not touch any other landmass or island before Oregon.

It will take only two minutes for the shadow to race eastward toward its first date with a large population of folks who will be breathlessly awaiting its arrival. Salem
ParentPage: Corvallis
DisplayListings: will experience various lengths of totality based on their varying distances from the centerline. At the Oregon State Fairgrounds
AccountCatIDForListings:
we will be treated to one minute and 54.5 seconds of shadow at just after 10:17am.

Oregon will be one of the most popular states to view the eclipse. While the rest of the United States offers a longer duration of totality
SortOrder: sections of the eclipse path in Oregon offers the best weather prospects anywhere along the entire eclipse path. Plus
FeatureChildPages:
there will be plenty of parties and celebrations in store for your visit.

Total Solar Eclipse Facts and Figures:

  • How long will the total solar eclipse last (in totality)? Approximately 1 minute and 44 seconds
  • What time will is the eclipse? It depends on your position in the Willamette Valley
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
but a Valley average puts totality at approximately 10:15 a.m.
  • How long should I plan on viewing the eclipse? In total
DisplayArticles:
it is about a 2 ½ hour event
  • What is the safest way to view the total eclipse? Boy are we glad you asked. Complete totality is the only time it is safe to view the sun without optical protection. See below for specific viewing safety tips.

    •  

    Observing the Eclipse:

    The only safe way to look directly at the un-eclipsed or partially eclipsed sun is through special-purpose solar filters
PageLogo: such as “eclipse glasses”  or handheld solar viewers. Homemade filters or ordinary sunglasses
FeatureBlockTitle2:
are not safe for looking at the sun.

Eclipse glasses should be worn whenever even a part of the sun can be seen; only during totality when the moon has slid fully in front of the sun is it safe to take off one’s eclipse glasses. In fact
FeaturedActivityTitle1: observing those brief seconds of totality without eclipse glasses is encouraged because it’s possible during this time to see the outer atmosphere of the sun and its streamers
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
loops and plumes of gas. Check out these great eclipse-viewing safety tips from NASA.

A few things to remember:

  • Protect your vision; do not look directly at the Sun during the 2 1/2 hours. It is only safe to view the Sun during the 1:44 minutes of totality. 
  • Eye equipment: Proper eclipse glasses or filters must be used to observe the partial phase before or after totality. Stay tuned to find out where find glasses in the Willamette Valley
  • Binoculars can only be used during totality
  • Telescopes are for experts only
  • Cameras are not recommended. Again
PartnerTitle: probably for experts only. If you must capture this moment on camera make sure you time for the event and do not look into the viewfinder during the eclipse
PartnerText:
except when it is in totality.
  • Don’t use anything that is not designed for viewing a solar eclipse
  • Don’t use sunglasses
  • Bottom line: For many
DisplayPartnerColumns:
this is a once in a lifetime event. Just enjoy it and live in the moment. You don't want it to pass you by while you fiddle with your devices.

If you plan to view the solar eclipse in the Willamette Valley
PartnerCityTitle: pick up our Solar Eclipse safety glasses
YoutubeVideoID: available (while supplies last) this summer at Willamette Valley visitors centers
VideoTitle1:
and at participating hotels and campgrounds. 

             Photo Courtesy of Outdoor Project

Event Information:

Now you know how to view a Solar Eclipse
VideoTitle2: but where should you view this epic event? And where can you stay before and after? Many eclipse enthusiasts host parties in local community centers
SeoNotes:
parks or open fields. Even your own backyard is a good place to throw a party. It is always a good idea to choose a place that has access to shade and facilities. You may also want to check weather-related web sites for forecasts for your area - and don't forget your safety glasses!

If you prefer a party
SEOStatus: you're in luck. Viewing celebrations big and small will be happening in just about every corner of the Willamette Valley on August 21. In Salem don't miss the opportunity to view the event in the hustle and bustle of the Capitol Mall. In the Corvallis area take in the epic event after a refreshing goat-yoga session at Emerson vineyard. In Albany
ProposedHeaderText:
join the party in the path at the historic airport. Many vineyards throughout the Valley would be happy if you stopped by for a sip a or two of Pinot Noir while you are in the path.

Keep an eye on these listings and find the right party for your best 2017 solar eclipse experience.

  • Salem
  • Corvallis
  • Mt. Hood Territory
  • Albany
  • Eugene

Planning your own party? Email becca@oregonwinecountry.org. and submit your event.

NASA has a few tips and tricks for you.

Lodging

According to Travel Oregon
ProposedBrowserTitle: many hotels and campsites along the path of totality are already booked on the dates surrounding August 21
SEOPaidSearch: first-served campgrounds are set to be temporarily converted to reservation-only for the eclipse
SEOPaidBanner:
so additional campsites will be made available in the coming months. Check with the Willamette Valley visitor center near your event for available lodging options.

 

Transportation

Getting in and around the Willamette Valley may be a bit tricker than usual a few days before and after August 21 due to this epic event. Congestion and delays on I-5 are expected all throughout the Willamette Valley. Buses and trains via Amtrack may be a great alternative.

  • What to Expect
  • Different traffic patterns. Normal travel paths may change. Communities may close streets to through traffic or ban left turns or right turns to keep traffic moving
SEOPaidSocial: especially in areas near gatherings with many eclipse visitors. ODOT does not plan to close state highways
ContentType:
but some left turns may be restricted from or to highways.
  • Work zones. All construction and non-emergency maintenance in the path of totality will shut down Aug. 18-22.  Slow down and pay attention in all work zones
CreationDate:
active or not.
  • Fewer big trucks. All over-dimension loads are restricted everywhere in Oregon from noon Friday Aug. 18 to Tuesday Aug. 22. 
  • Truck scales will be closed. 
  • More signs with advice. Hundreds of extra roadside readerboards will warn you about road issues and reminding you to avoid distractions and be even more careful about fire danger. 
  • www.Tripcheck.com provides you the most current travel information available
AuthorUserID:
other travel data and more than 400 highway cameras. Check up on the traffic on your planned route before leaving home. 

 

Solar Eclipse Etiquette:

  • Please leave your music at home
  • No fireworks
IncludeInWidgets:
or lights of any kind to the viewing

                                                              

A few other things to remember:

  • The temperature will drop by a few degrees
  • Local wildlife may come out for viewing as well. This natural occurrance may throw off the circadian rhythm of local wildlife. Some may be fooled
TopLanding:
so it is best to be alert.
  • Hotels and campsites will be hard to come by in the Willamette Valley. Contact your local visitor's center for available lodging or information on viewing parties happening in the area.
  • If you have any health related issues or concerns please refer to these documents for more information:
    •            English
               Japanese
               Spanish
TopPageview: sans-serif; font-size: 12.800000190734863px;\">
MicrositeID:
sans-serif; font-size: 12.800000190734863px;\"> 

More Solar Eclipse Information:
AuditTransferNotes:
sans-serif; font-size: 14px;\">
  • #oreclipse
  • #eclipse2017
column59:
sans-serif; font-size: 10px;\">Find more comprehensive and authoritative pages for the 2017 eclipse:

Eclipse2017.nasa.gov Through the Eyes of NASA. Get more infomation on viewing
column61:
education and events happening across the country.

EclipseWise.com  By Fred Espenak
column62:
retired NASA astrophysicist and the leading expert on eclipse predictions

Eclipse Weather Page. An excellent source for weather prospects for upcoming eclipses by meteorologist Jay Anderson.

Travel Oregon and OMSI Event information

Travel Oregon is producing an eclipse guide book with helpful tips and resources which will also include a pair of eclipse viewing glasses. The guide is set to release in early April and will be available at Oregon Visitor Centers
column63:
State Welcome Centers and online at TravelOregon.com/Getting-Around/Online-Guides/. 

 

Photos and Content sources: nasa.gov

BrowserTitle: Wine + Waterfalls in the Willamette Valley
HeaderText: Trek to waterfalls and sip wine in the mid-valley
ContentText:
Waterfalls + wine tasting in the Cascade foothills

Here’s an idea for a fabulous fall day: pack a picnic lunch and set your GPS for an off-the-beaten-path excursion that includes three waterfalls and beautiful fall foliage, along with a visit to a winery with breathtaking views.  

McDowell Creek Falls Loop Hike  

Tucked into the Cascade foothills north of Sweet Home, Linn County's McDowell Creek Falls is beautiful in every season
PageType: but especially in autumn. The trail is a loop that presents impressive waterfalls as well as a couple of smaller cascades and a popular summer swimming hole. Trekking through the lush mixed woodland here
PageLevel:
visitors feel they’ve entered an island of serenity. Hikers are almost always within earshot of the sound of rushing water. 

The McDowell Creek Falls loop trail is slightly less than two miles in length and naturally links the Lower McDowell Creek
ParentPage: Crystal Pool Falls and Majestic Falls for an invigorating
Status:
easy-to-moderate hike.  The park and the trail are family friendly and dogs on leash are allowed.  There are restrooms and picnic tables near the trailhead.

Marks Ridge Winery

Just five miles from McDowell Creek Park is Marks Ridge Winery
InsertCode: located on a mountain top with spectacular views.  The owner/wine-makers restored a 30-year-old vineyard
IssuuCode: and planted new vines that produce fabulous Pinot noir
DisplayListings: and Gewurztraminer grapes on their property. The warm and inviting tasting room maximizes the view
AccountCatIDForListings: with 60 feet of large windows inside
SortOrder: a lookout patio and a picnic area; all of which entice visitors to sit
FeatureChildPages:
sip and stay awhile. 

Marks Ridge Winery frequently hosts art shows and
DisplayArticles: live music on Friday nights. In the fall
PageLogo:
they celebrate the harvest and welcome visitors on weekends from 12 to 5 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays. Visitors can bring a picnic and wind up a perfect autumn day watching the sun set over the vineyard.

If you want to explore more of the central Willamette Valley’s trails
FeatureBlockTitle2: check out Trails to Linn
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
and the Albany Visitors Association; both are comprehensive guides to miles of outdoor exploration in the mid-Willamette Valley.

Photos: McDowell Creek Falls by Scott van Schoiack; Marks Ridge Harvest by Gary Thurman

"

BrowserTitle: Explore the Territorial Wine Trail
HeaderText: Autumn vineyard views in the South Willamette Valley
ContentText:
Take a scenic drive on the Territorial Wine Trail this fall

It’s time to take in the beautiful colors and crisp air Oregon is known for. One must-stop on a wine-lover’s fall list should be the South Willamette Valley’s Territorial Wine Trail. 

This scenic route is often overlooked by drivers on I-5. The next time you’re on the corridor
PageType: pull off the busy interstate and take this 40-mile drive through scenic wine country. Starting from West Eugene
PageLevel:
visitors can make their way by scenic stops like the West Eugene Wetlands and Fern Ridge Lake as they head south to tackle the trail. 

  • One of the first stops is at Sweet Cheeks winery. Here
PageSectionID: rolling hills wait to greet you along with the winery’s signature Pinot and Riesling selection. If you arrive on a Friday evening
ParentPage:
you might even catch some live music.
  • Next
Status: make a stop at Iris Vineyard
InsertCode: where more sweeping mountain views await your arrival. This winery is a hub for handcrafted Pinot Noir
IssuuCode:
Pinot Gris and Chardonnay. Don’t miss this opportunity to sip while you take in the view from their beautiful porches.
  • Cap off the journey south off with a stop at King Estate
HideFromNav: just west of Cottage Grove. An excellent spot for an elegant dinner and lush views
DisplayListings: this winery is internationally renowned for their Pinot Gris and Pinot Noir. King Estate’s wines can only be matched with the incredible view of the 1
AccountCatIDForListings: 033 acres of organic grapes and the food at their on-site restaurant. When it comes to a scenic dinner
SortOrder:
it’s tough to beat King Estate. 
  • For a nice view on the way back
FeatureChildPages: head east toward Cottage Grove’s covered bridges. This little town is known as the “Covered Bridge Capital of the West
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: ” and visitors often enjoy hitting a select handful of these on a loop. Start near Currin Covered Bridge
PageLogo: then end up at Chambers Bridge
FeatureBlockTitle1: near downtown Cottage Grove. This loop can be done in 30 – 60 minutes
FeatureBlockTitle2:
and is a perfect route by car or bike.

Itching for a longer excursion? Find a list of all the South Willamette Wineries and wine country adventures at: www.eugenecascadescoast.org/wine-country.

 Photos: Autumn at King Estate by Rachell Coe; cyclist at King Estate by Molly Blancett
"

600).

Wine + Cuisine in Salem | In the heart of Oregon’s lush Willamette Valley growing region
ProposedBrowserTitle:
taste the culinary best of Oregon
Taste: Enjoy Sunday brunch
SEOPaidSearch: and wine tasting for 2 people at Eola Hills Winery
SEOPaidSocial: boutique winery located in the heart of Willamette Valley wine country. Enjoy an award-winning brunch paired with Eola Hills’ estate grown wines
ContentType:
plus a private tour and tasting. Reservations required. Please contact the winery at least one month in advance.
Stay: One night for 2 at the Best Western Plus Mill Creek Inn. Spacious rooms complemented with an indoor pool
CreationDate:
hot tub and private sauna make relaxing after a day of exploration a breeze. Stay includes complimentary breakfast.

Wine + Art in Mt. Hood Territory | Learn how Oregon winemakers capture the creative spirit of the Willamette Valley in Oregon’s Mt. Hood Territory
Create: Enjoy a private tour and tasting for two at Beckham Estate Vineyard
Excerpt: featuring handcrafted and limited production wines alongside original ceramic art made by owner
AuthorUserID: Andrew Beckham. Take part in a hands-on ceramic demonstration and wheel throwing experience
PublishDate:
taking home your uniquely crafted ceramic treasures. 
Stay: Overnight for two at the Best Western Wilsonville Inn & Suites.  Includes indoor pool
IncludeInWidgets:
and hot breakfast. Advanced reservations required.

Wine + Cycling in Eugene | Cycle past vineyards
TopLanding:
and forests in the scenic south Willamette Valley
Cycle + Sip: Adventures await with a 24-hour bike rental for two from Paul’s Bicycle Way of Life in Eugene. Explore the city’s many trails or head out of town
TopPageview: where you can ride to wineries
AuditTransferPage: and charming small towns. After a day on the road
AuditRefreshPage: unwind with one Executive Wine Tasting for two at the Oregon Wine Lab
AuditNavChange:
a winemaker and avid outdoor adventurer.
Stay: One overnight for two at the Hilton Eugene
column58: a premier downtown Eugene hotel adjacent to the Hult Center for the Performing Arts in the heart of downtown
column59: and walking distance to the Fifth Street Public Market
column61:
Amtrak and many boutique shops and fine dining

Wine + Heritage in Yamhill Valley | Travel to the birthplace of Oregon’s famous pinot noir in the storied hills of the Yamhill Valley
Taste: 50 years ago
column62: visionary winemakers planted the first Pinot noir vines in Oregon’s Yamhill Valley. Taste the fruit of their labors when you dine at The Painted Lady Restaurant in Newberg
column63:
a restaurant repeatedly honored for having one of the finest wine lists and best dining in the state.
Stay: One night at The Allison Inn & Spa in Newberg
column64:
a luxury hotel and spa in Oregon Wine Country that’s been internationally recognized as one of the Top 10 hotels in the United States.

Wine + Sustainable Agriculture in Corvallis | Explore the fertile lands that ledpioneer farmers to Oregon
column65:
and see how winemakers are conserving the valley for the future
Discover: You will be picked by one of our local guides and taken to historic Tyee Winery
column66: located on a certified Century Farm noted for its sustainable practices and its art gallery. While there savor a taste of their award-winning Pinot under their old apple tree
column67:
from a seedling that made the journey across the Oregon Trail.
Stay: Enjoy an overnight stay for two the newly remodeled Hilton Garden Inn
column68:
located just across the street from Oregon State University.*
*Offer not available OSU Mom's Weekend and Commencement 2016.

Wine + Family Adventure in Albany | Travelers of all ages can enjoy the beautiful countryside and charming small towns of Oregon Wine Country
Explore: Take the kids or kids-at-heart to experience life on a working farm. Springbank Blueberry Farm and winery produces fresh Oregon blueberries and delicious blueberry wine. Tour the farm
column70: and explore the refurbished one-room schoolhouse on site
column71:
then taste their hand-crafted blueberry wine.
Stay: One overnight at the Best Western Plus Prairie Inn in Albany
column72:
known for its charming historic homes and kid-friendly carousel museum. Complimentary breakfast and indoor pool included in the stay.
