PageDesc: Enter to Win a 4 Day Trip to the Willamette Valley
BrowserTitle: Enter to Win a 4 Day Trip to the Willamette Valley
HeaderText: Win a 4-night Adventure Trip in Oregon's Wine Country
ContentText: Oregon Wine Country’s lush green landscapes
PageType: independent craftspeople and inviting small towns await the lucky winner and a guest for a four night adventure in the Willamette Valley. With over 500 wineries nestled in the hills between Portland and Eugene - just two hours apart - the Willamette Valley is revered as one of the world’s premier regions for Pinot Noir and was named Wine Region of the Year by Wine Enthusiast Magazine. Plus
PageLevel:
Oregon Wines fly free on Alaska Airlines!

Your Trip Awaits: 

  • 2 Round trip tickets on Alaska Airlines to Oregon — Fly into Portland or Eugene
  • 4 Nights lodging - Spend 2 nights at a famous Willamette Valley vineyard
PageSectionID:
Youngberg Hill and 2 nights at a brand new Courtyard Marriott.
  • 3 VIP Winemaker Experiences — Meet the producers & enjoy private tastings at award-winning wineries like Willamette Valley Vineyards
ParentPage:
Youngberg Hill and Brigadoon Vineyards. 
  • Sip
Status:
Cycle and Adventure! A half day guided bike tour & an adventure with an outdoor outfitter
  • Custom travel planning by a Willamette Valley guide to ensure a spectacular trip
  • $150 Visa gift card to spend on Oregon’s delicious meals during your stay
  • $200 Voucher for ground transportation/car rental
    •  
    Residents from U.S. and Canada may enter from August 28th 2017- September 24th 2017. See full contest rules and guidelines.
     

    Want more Oregon Wine Country? Start your adventure today. 
     
     
    "
AccountCatIDForListings: Archive
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Summer cycle trips in Salem
ContentText: The Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway —  the first official scenic bikeway in the United States — follows its namesake river as it winds through the Valley
PageLevel: through charming burgs and historic downtowns. The Salem stretch of the Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway offers its own special charm
PageSectionID: taking cyclists past farm markets bursting with berries
ParentPage: hop fields
InsertCode:
wineries and even a wildlife refuge.

The Salem portion of the Bikeway starts at Champoeg State Heritage Area
IssuuCode: where you can park your car or camp overnight in a tent
HideFromNav: cozy cabin or yurt the day before your journey. The 35-mile stretch from Champoeg to the city of Salem meanders along mostly flat
DisplayListings:
scenic country roads. 

As you enter Salem
AccountCatIDForListings: be sure to stop at EZ Orchards Farm Market
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: made with berries fresh from the farm. As you cycle towards downtown
DisplayArticles: you’ll pass the historic Oregon State Capitol grounds
PageLogo: filled with fragrant roses and bright rhododendrons that bloom throughout the summer. For a hearty
FeatureBlockTitle2: try Wild Pear Restaurant or Croissant & Company. To make it a leisurely two-day trip
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
stay overnight at the Century House B&B – a beautifully restored turn-of-the-century home located just a ½ mile off the Bikeway in the heart of town. 

As you leave town heading south
FeaturedActivityTitle2: you’ll find Ankeny Wildlife Refuge
PartnerText: 492-acre wetland and haven for migratory birds and other wildlife. At nearby Ankeny Vineyards
DisplayPartnerColumns: enjoy a glass of estate grown wine and a slice of wood-fired pizza. As you continue along the bikeway to the Independence Bridge
PartnerCityTitle:
take a slight detour over the bridge and head to Rogue Hop Yard — Rogue Ales’ 33-acre working hop farm and tasting room. Enjoy a farmstead ale made with honey and hops grown on the farm and tour the processing facility for a first-hand look at how hops are harvested and prepared before they become a key ingredient in craft brew. 

Pedaling for Pinot

No cycling trip through Oregon Wine Country would be complete without stops at some of the Salem area’s most iconic wineries via Eola Hills’ “Bike Oregon Wine Country” tours. Held every Sunday in August
YoutubeVideoID: these fully-supported rides include stops at three to four wineries in the beautiful Eola Amity Hills AVA
VideoTitle1:
followed by a salmon barbecue and wine tasting on the patio at Eola Hills Wine Cellars in Rickreall.  

For more ideas about what to see and do on a cycling adventure through Salem

PageDesc: Oregon's Cascade Mountains, Waterfalls and Hot Springs
BrowserTitle: Oregon's Cascade Mountains, Waterfalls and Hot Springs
HeaderText: Oregonï¿½s Cascades Mountains, Waterfalls and Hot Springs
ContentText: Known to some as the "Magic Carpet Ride
PageType: ” the Aufderheidi byway is a cycling tour that presents an incredibly unique day trip
PageLevel: connecting Rainbow (McKenzie River) to Oregon’s Oakridge/Westfir area along the Middle Fork of the Willamette River. This is a nearly symmetrical ride
PageSectionID: halfway up and then halfway down
ParentPage:
with nearly 60 miles of scenic beauty to experience.

Even though the route starts with a climb
Status: the majority is comprised of smooth rolling pavement (with a few gravel patches cyclists will have to watch for) that offers a nice ride. With light traffic and ample sunlight filtering through cathedrals of trees
InsertCode:
this is one smooth ride along the mighty McKenzie River.

If you want to explore the McKenzie River via car
IssuuCode:
Hwy 126 let us show you the way!

Venture west on Hwy 126
HideFromNav: where the Aufderheide Byway connects the McKenzie River area to Hwy 58
DisplayListings: for fall-color viewing. This route is also home to Terwilliger Hot Springs and Delta Old Growth Grove Nature Trail. Make note
AccountCatIDForListings:
this route is not maintained during the winter and is generally open May -October.

Follow along the river from the Willamette Valley to land at the breathtaking Sahalie and Koosah Falls
SortOrder:
located between milepost 5 & 6 on Hwy 126. Sahalie Falls plunges 100 feet over a lava dam and then tumbles 40 feet in a series of cascade and Koosah Falls is an 80-120 ft plunge over an abrupt lava cap to the waiting pool below.

From there
FeatureChildPages: head back on Hwy 126 to reward yourself with a soak in a natural hot spring. Belknap Hot Springs is open to the public for an hourly or daily fee and also home to peaceful
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
beautifully tended gardens.

Up for more adventure? This route is also a gateway to two scenic byways
PageLogo: known as Old McKenzie Highway
FeatureBlockTitle1: is home to some of Oregon’s most dramatic views that appear along a narrow and winding road. Following that road
FeatureBlockTitle2: you have access to Dee Wright Observatory and Proxy Falls. As a scenic byway
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
Hwy 242 is typically open to traffic from May-November depending on weather.

Help Travel Tips:

  • Last chance for gas: Blue River
  • Stop for food at Takoda’s Restaurant
  • Grab a day parking permit at the Eugene
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
Cascades & Coast Adventure Center
  • Cell coverage is limited
PartnerTitle:
make sure you have a map
  • Check TripCheck.com
PartnerText:
or call 511 for highway conditions
 Photo: David Putzier

 

"

BrowserTitle: Vineyard bike tours in Oregon Wine Country
HeaderText: Tour vineyards on a summer cycle trip
ContentText:
Guided cycle trips make Willamette Valley wine tours easy

Bike and wine lovers have a new option for touring some great wineries in Oregon’s Mt. Hood Territory on two wheels: The Bike Concierge in Oregon City recently debuted their latest service
PageType:
an assisted tour of up to four wineries around Oregon City. 

Starting in Oregon City
PageLevel: the 25-mile tour quickly heads down the county roads of in the outskirts of Oregon’s first city
PageSectionID: moving with the land as you pass through historic neighborhoods
ParentPage: farms and fields. Stops can include any combination of Villa Catalana Cellars
Status:
Forest Edge Vineyard and King’s Raven Winery.  Christopher Bridge Winery can be easily-added for a fantastic fourth stop. 

Beginning cyclists may wish to take full advantage of the support vehicle that follows the tour during some of the hillier segments of the ride
InsertCode: while those with more experience can choose to tackle the full course head on. Either way
IssuuCode:
the rider is guaranteed a beautiful trip where getting there will be as integral to the whole experience as is tasting at the wineries themselves.

One of the most unique elements of The Bike Concierge is their ability to work with a customer and craft fully customized tour options based on their needs and desires. The trips are easily tailored according to the rider’s skill level and particular taste in wines. Adding another winery to the itinerary or selecting a different route is no problem. The end result will be a unique pedal to pour experience that will be memorable and fun. 

 Photo: Oregon's Mt. Hood Territory
"
AccountCatIDForListings: NULL
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Bike the Seven Wonders of Corvallis
HeaderText: Bike the Seven Wonders of Corvallis
ContentText:
Did you know that Corvallis has more 60 miles of biking trails throughout town and into surrounding countryside? These miles of pathways and roadways are perfect for biking to many of Corvallis’ 7 Wonders.

For an urban ride: Cycle the path at Riverfront Commemorative Park and explore Historic Downtown Corvallis where many restaurants and brew pubs offer bike friendly spots to secure your ride while you step inside for a bite or a brew.

For a scenic road route: There are many roads in the area that offer wide shoulders and light traffic. Depending on the route you choose you can experience rolling hills and local agriculture
PageType: or a challenging climb. If you’re up to it
PageLevel: tackle the hills on Sulpher Springs Road or the impressive climb to Mary Peak- at 4097 foot elevation
PageSectionID: it’s the highest peak in the Oregon Coast Range.  The summit offers panoramic views of the Willamette Valley
ParentPage: the Coast Range
Status:
the Cascades and the Pacific Ocean.

If you want to combine biking with a wildlife viewing
InsertCode: cycle down to William L. Finley Wildlife Refuge
IssuuCode: which offers some of Oregon’s best wildlife observation
HideFromNav:
photography and hiking. 

For mountain bikers: If you really want to test your mountain biking skills
DisplayListings: you may want to head out to Alsea Falls. The trail offers a steep climb from the trailhead
AccountCatIDForListings:
but the site also offers picnicking and camping. Pack a tent and make it into a two-day trip to relax and unwind in the great outdoors. It’s a great place to cool off in the summer! 

For a long Sunday ride: A good Sunday ride includes the Kings Valley Loop via Cardwell Hill. This ride is a hybrid of road and off-road roading
SortOrder: offering a great mix of rural paved highways with some rugged and steep gravel areas that are closed to motor vehicles. (Note: Kings Valley highway is hilly with narrow shoulders
FeatureChildPages: so we recommend a Sunday ride when the road sees fewer cars). The route includes beautiful scenery
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: especially along the Marys River in the gravel section. Another highlight of the ride ise Bald Hill
DisplayArticles:
a nature preserve on the edge of Corvallis.

At one point
PageLogo: the route forks
FeatureBlockTitle1:
but both options include wine and. Harris Bridge Vineyard is located in a picture-perfect setting beside Harris Covered Bridge. Cyclists who take the right-hand turn onto Kings Valley Highway you can stop in at Airlie Winery at Dunn Forest Road and then continue on Airlie Road to Emerson Vineyards. Either place is a good spot for a picnic and sample great wine. 

For the complete Corvallis Sunday route please visit www.rideoregonride.com and search for “Kings Valley Loop.”

For more about touring the Seven Wonders of Corvallis

BrowserTitle: Tour Willamette Valley covered bridges by bike
HeaderText: Experience Scenic Views while Cycling Through Covered Bridges
ContentText:
Explore Oregon history on a two-wheeled tour

Take a cycle trip through Oregon’s historic covered bridges for a picturesque adventure. The eight bridges in Linn County represent a microcosm of the state’s collection of antique covered bridges. Five of the Linn County bridges are clustered near Scio, one of several small farming towns in the area that provides rich links to the county’s history and heritage. Bring a camera along on this incredibly scenic ride.

For a supported ride: Cyclists who want to cycle covered bridges on a supported group ride can join the Covered Bridge Bicycle Tour on Sunday
ParentPage: lunch
Status:
and a variety of route options. Cyclists who would rather explore on their own can ride the covered bridge route any time of year. 

For a leisurely trip: See two covered bridges on a 40-mile route that’s mostly flat and breezy. The 40-mile covered bridge loop takes you past Gilkey and Hoffman bridges and through countryside dotted with U-pick farms and orchards. (Note: aid stations noted on the map links are available only on the Aug. 9 tour)

For more of a challenge: Try a 68-mile or 85-mile route
InsertCode: or do a full 100-mile century ride. < >These long routes include Gilkey
AccountCatIDForListings: and take cyclists up and down hills
FeatureChildPages:
and through scenic farmland. (Note: aid stations noted on the map links are available only on the Aug. 9 tour)

For a multi-day trip: Three more covered bridges lie in the eastern half of Linn County: Crawfordsville
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: Weddle and Short bridges are in and near Sweet Home
DisplayArticles: a friendly small town nestled into the foothills of the Cascade Mountains. For details of the Linn County loop
PageLogo: including the east county bridges
FeatureBlockTitle1:
check out AlbanyVisitors.com.

As you cycle the scenic routes
FeatureBlockTitle2: don’t forget to along the way to sample local products
FeaturedActivityTitle2: or just relax along a river—after all
PartnerTitle: cycling itself is just one part of the adventure. Exploring the countryside
PartnerText: sampling fresh-picked produce at local farms
DisplayPartnerColumns:
and chatting with the friendly folks you meet along the way will create memories that linger long after your ride. 

For details on the history of Oregon’s Covered Bridges
PartnerCityTitle:
visit www.covered-bridges.org and click on Linn County on the map.

For more information on the trails and bikeways in Linn County

BrowserTitle: Enter to win a mountain bike this summer
HeaderText: Ride Corvallis and win a $1,400 mountain bike
ContentText:
Visit Corvallis has teamed up with Peak Sports to give away an awesome mountain bike this summer! 

*Contest details sourced from VisitCorvallis.com

Each one of Seven Wonders of Corvallis offers a different kind of ride
PageType:
and this 2015 Rockhopper Pro EVO 650 would be perfect for enjoying all of them.

Entering this contest is easy! Here’s what you need to do: Take a selfie at a specific spot at one of our Seven Wonders and send it in to us.* That’s it – you’re entered to win! Want more than one entry? Take another selfie at a different Wonder! You can get up to seven chances to win
PageLevel:
one for each of our Seven Wonders.

* Visit Corvallis maintains all rights and ownership of photos submitted for this contest
PageSectionID:
and may use them in promotional publications.

Where to Take Your Selfies

Marys Peak: Take a selfie in front of Conner’s Camp
ParentPage:
East Ridge Trail #1324.

William L. Finley Wildlife Refuge: Take a selfie in front of Cabell Lodge.

Alsea Falls: Take a selfie in front of the Alsea Falls Recreation Site sign.

Historic Downtown Corvallis: Take your selfie in front of the Benton County Courthouse.

Riverfront Commemorative Park: Snap your selfie in front of one of the “Steamboat Gateways” by Miles Pepper
Status: the kinetic sculptures located at First Street and Van Buren Avenue
InsertCode:
First Street and Monroe Avenue and First Street and Madison Avenue. (See a photo here.)

Covered Bridges: Get your selfie in front of one of our Benton County covered bridges: Harris Bridge
IssuuCode:
the Irish Bend Bridge or the Hayden Bridge.

Heart of Willamette Wineries: Get your selfie in front of a tasting room at a Heart of Willamette Winery. You can find a list of them at HeartOfWillamette.com.

Protip: You can get two entries in one stop if you visit Harris Bridge Vineyard! Take a selfie in front of the nearby Harris Bridge and then head on over to Harris Bridge Vineyard and get one in front of their tasting room. They’re open on Saturday and Sundays from 12 to 5pm – don’t miss a chance to try their wines while you’re there.

Once you've snapped your selfies
AccountCatIDForListings: Facebook or any other photo storage site (Flickr
FeatureChildPages:
etc). Remember to make sure your photo is visible to everyone and not set to \"private\" or \"friends-only\" viewing. Then head to VisitCorvallis.com and enter to win.  

Photos must be submitted by August 31
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
2015 at 5pm. 

If you want to submit your photo entry directly
PageLogo: email your entries to us. Include your name
FeatureBlockTitle2: phone number and the location of your photo
FeaturedActivityTitle1: and put “Corvallis Mountain Bike” in your email subject line. This contest begins July 1
DisplayPartnerColumns: at 5pm (PST). Submitted photos may be used on the Visit Corvallis website
YoutubeVideoID: and in promotional materials. <a title=\"Visit Corvallis contest rules\" href=\"http://visitcorvallis.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/VisitCorvallisMountainBikeContestRulesAndRegulations.pdf\" target=\"_blank\">Click here for the contest rules
VideoTitle2: and terms and conditions. Read our privacy policy. For questions
MetaDescription:
email or call Visit Corvallis at 541-757-1544 or 1-800-334-8118.

"

BrowserTitle: Taste Oregon bounty on the farm
HeaderText: Visit farms in the heart of the valley this fall
ContentText:
Taste the harvest on a Corvallis farm tour

Just when you think it can’t possibly be any prettier here it does. Fall is the perfect time to get out and enjoy all the colors and the harvest of the season. The Corvallis area is home to dozens of farmers and gardeners
PageType:
and this is a perfect time of year to connect with unique local growers.  

Highway 20 Farm Route:

Start out
PageLevel: Oregon\" href=\"http://www.visitcorvallis.com\" target=\"_blank\">downtown Corvallis and head up Second Street
PageSectionID:
which becomes Highway 20. You will quickly find yourself surrounded by small farms with tons of opportunity to get of your car and explore.

  • First stop is the Melon Shack
ParentPage: which offers a corn maze in the fall
Status:
along with plenty of pumpkins to bring home and enjoy.
  • Just a bit north
InsertCode: make sure and stop at Davis Family Farms where you will find fruits and veggies throughout the growing season. This time of year
IssuuCode:
visitors can take a pumpkin patch hay ride that just might become your favorite memory from this fall.
  • Further up the road
HideFromNav: stop off at Garland Nursery. Family-owned for four generations
DisplayListings: this nursery is a Willamette Valley destination. They have more than six acres of trees
AccountCatIDForListings: shrubs
FeatureChildPages:
bonsai and garden supplies. Their gift shop is stocked full of unique decorative items and practical accessories making this nursery a top pick year round. 

Philomath Farm Loop:

On the other side of Corvallis lies the charming small town of Philomath
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: home to several not-to-be-missed farm spots
DisplayArticles:
beginning with Gathering Together Farms.

  • Gathering Together is an organic farm growing a wide array of produce
PageLogo: plus a store and a seasonal restaurant. Tip: don’t miss the famous potato donuts
FeatureBlockTitle1:
baked fresh daily and available at the farmstand. 
  • Another gardener’s paradise in Philomath is Shonnard’s Nursery. Also a family-owned and operated garden facility
FeatureBlockTitle2:
Shonnard’s has offered advice to Corvallis gardeners for more than 25 years.    

Alsea Country Farms:

Want more adventure? Then keep on going past Philomath
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
until you reach the fork in the road that leads to Alsea. There you will find two farms sure to make a lasting autumn impression.

  • Thyme Garden is a local grower offering organically grown seeds and plants
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
bulk dried teas and wonderful seasonings. They offer special events such as their Fall Salmon Celebration and Winter Wellness Workshop; check their website for event hours and times.
  • Another uniquely Oregon experience is Leaping Lamb Farm Stay. Located in the Coast range of Oregon
PartnerTitle: Leaping Lamb is a small farm that offers overnights stays in a private farm cottage
PartnerText:
and it’s also a perfect place to have a picnic and pet the animals. 

For more details on what to do and where to stay in the heart of the Willamette Valley
DisplayPartnerColumns:
visit www.visitcorvallis.com.

Photos: Willamette Valley farm scene by Anna Davidson; Corvallis in fall by Lainey Dyer

 
"

BrowserTitle: Explore the bounty of fall in Oregon Wine Country
HeaderText: Delicious food and harvest fun on Salem farms.
ContentText:
Explore the Bounty of Fall in Salem

Since ancient times, people have gathered in the fall to celebrate a successful growing season and share the season’s bounty. Today, this tradition continues as thousands of visitors flock to area farms and agricultural attractions to celebrate the season with food, games and fun. This fall, gather your family and friends and head out to explore the Salem area’s many harvest festivals. 

  • Bauman’s Farm & Garden in Gervais boasts one of the area’s largest and most popular festivals
PageType: with dozens of different activities
PageLevel: plus the famous Giant Pumpkin Weigh Off
PageSectionID: where competitors square off to see who grew the biggest gourd. In 2014
ParentPage: the first place winner weighed in at more than 1
Status:
500 pounds. 
  • At E.Z. Orchards Farm Market
InsertCode: harvest time means delicious seasonal treats such as roasted corn on the cob
IssuuCode: warm apple cider donuts and their award-winning hard cidre. They also offer plenty of activities including a corn maze
AccountCatIDForListings:
duck races and more. 
  • With more than 30 varieties of pumpkin
SortOrder: squash and gourds to choose from
FeatureChildPages: you’re sure to find the perfect – or perfectly unusual – one to complete your fall décor at Airlie Hills Farm in Monmouth.  The farm also offers trike racing
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
farm animals and a special Dark Maze that challenges older kids and adults to find their way out of complete darkness. 
  • At French Prairie Gardens in St. Paul
DisplayArticles: visitors can enjoy the only pig races in Oregon
PageLogo: plus hayrides
FeatureBlockTitle2: an obstacle course and more. In Dayton
FeaturedActivityTitle1: Heiser Farms is open every day in October with lots of fall-themed fun
FeaturedActivityTitle2: including train and fire engine rides
PartnerTitle:
a giant pumpkin patch and a pumpkin cannon derby. 
  • Try your hand at pumpkin bowling or navigating the Living Forest Maze at family-owned Wavra Farms & Nursery in Southeast Salem. Kids can also decorate their pumpkins
PartnerText:
climb the hay tower or see what it’s like to roll around in a life-sized gerbil wheel. 
  • In Woodburn
DisplayPartnerColumns: tulips are traded for tricks and treats in October as the famous Wooden Shoe Tulip Farm is transformed into the Wooden Shoe Pumpkin Fest - complete with a corn maze
PartnerCityTitle: pumpkin cannon and more. On Friday and Saturday evenings
YoutubeVideoID:
the maze takes on a spooky vibe and offers frightful fun for those who dare enter after dark!

For more ideas of places to explore in the Salem area
VideoTitle1:
visit the Travel Salem website or download a free copy of the official Salem area visitors guide. 

 Photos: Salem vineyard in autumn by Ron Cooper: hay slide bv Andrea Johnson.
"

BrowserTitle: Take a geocaching trek in Oregon this fall
HeaderText: Find a cache in the birthplace of the sport
ContentText:
Celebrate the 15th anniversary of geocaching in Mt. Hood Territory, the birthplace of the sport

As the warm summer temps have given away to crisp, fall weather, you may find yourself wanting to explore. Why not find some hidden treasure while you’re at it, and go on Mt. Hood Territory’s Cache the Stash geocaching challenge. 

The challenge was created to celebrate the 15th anniversary of Geocaching. The popular activity was started right here in the Mt. Hood Territory just outside of Estacada. 

Geocaches are hidden in six communities: Canby
ParentPage: Sandy and West Linn. Each community has ten different caches hidden throughout
Status: making it the perfect chance to really experience each city. You’ll visit local scenic spots
InsertCode: museums and attractions on your journey. Since it is autumn
IssuuCode: you will want to keep your eye out for fall foliage
HideFromNav:
local farms’ harvest festivals and wineries for tastings.

  • Canby: Known as “The Garden Spot”
AccountCatIDForListings: farms and great museums that highlight the rich history of the region. Don’t miss St. Josef’s Winery
FeatureChildPages:
a bona-fide pioneer in Oregon’s wine industry. 
  • Damascus: This small town has some pretty big views of Mt. Hood. It’s also home to numerous farms and nurseries
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: including Christmas Tree farms. While it may be fall
DisplayArticles: the smell at those farms will make you yearn for Christmas. Bring your bike and don’t miss the Boring Station Trailhead Park
PageLogo:
the kick-off point for the Springwater Corridor Trail. 
  • Estacada: This is the birthplace of where geocaching
FeatureBlockTitle1: but it’s also so much more. The Clackamas River runs through this former timber town and offers a wide array of recreational opportunities. Don’t miss Fearless Brewing. They say the water from the Clackamas River is the best for making great beer
FeatureBlockTitle2:
here’s a chance for you to determine that yourself.
  • Sandy: The gateway to Mt. Hood
FeaturedActivityTitle1: Sandy also is home to Jonsrud Viewpoint which offers a sweeping panoramic view of the mountain itself. Stroll the downtown and check out the Sandy Area Historic Society. Don’t miss Joe’s Donuts. Seriously
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
don’t miss it. Your taste buds will thank us for this one. 
  • North Clackamas: Why not take a break from your treasure hunt and enjoy some food and of course
PartnerTitle: great sales tax-free shopping. Don’t Miss: Mt. Talbert Nature Park is a beautiful slice of nature in the city. Numerous walking paths carve through this one-time volcanic butte
PartnerText:
giving you the perfect chance to spy some fall colors and numerous bird species.
  • West Linn:  This historic community just bursts with charm. The main street area is filled with local shops and restaurants
DisplayPartnerColumns: while art galleries showcase local artists’ talent and historic sites tell the story of the city’s pioneers. Don’t Miss Allium Bistro
PartnerCityTitle:
a renowned restaurant that features seasonal ingredients sourced from local farms. 

You’re likely to find your own treasures
YoutubeVideoID: in addition to the geocaches. Be sure to share those on social media with our #omht hashtag. We may find some new favorites as well
VideoTitle1:
thanks to you.

 
Photo: Sandy Historical Museum courtesy of Mt. Hood Territory
"

BrowserTitle: Ancient Art Traditions at Oregon Winery
HeaderText: Experience ancient art traditions at an Oregon winery
ContentText:
Wine is a wonderful thing, especially when perfectly paired with something complimentary. Good company, a decadent cheese or of course a delicious meal all enhance the wine tasting experience. Wine also goes exceptionally well with art, and nowhere is this more evident than Beckham Estate Vineyard outside the Mt. Hood Territory community of Wilsonville. 

Dreams Made Real | Beckham Estate Vineyard is the realized vision of Andrew and Annedria Beckham. They originally purchased the property to fulfill Andrew’s dream of creating and showcasing his ceramic art. As often happens
PageType: the path took on unexpected turns. The Beckhams learned that their beautiful property was also ideally situated to grow wine grape. For eight years they focused their efforts on a now thriving Pinot noir vineyard. The first wines were made in 2009
PageLevel:
followed by a tasting room that shows off both Andrew’s wine and art creations in 2012. 

Blending Two Passions | Ever the artist and artisan
PageSectionID:
Andrew has managed to blend his two passions in
a way that is attracting attention worldwide. Instead of aging his wines in oak barrels
ParentPage: some are instead aged in terracotta amphorae handcrafted on his potter’s wheel. Each 40-60 gallon amphora takes two weeks to form
Status:
plus another three months to dry followed by firing for 40 hours in a kiln. 

This technique is actually similar to how ancient winemakers used to age their creations
InsertCode: and combined with new winemaking traditions
IssuuCode:
is gaining traction again thanks in large part to Andrew’s success. 

See it in person | The tasting room is open every Saturday from 11 am to 5 pm
DisplayListings:
Labor Day and Thanksgiving weekends. Guests can schedule special appointments as well. A truly successful trip will see the guest coming away with a new favorite wine in addition to a new favorite work of art for display in their home. Both will leave lasting impressions. 

For more information or to schedule an appointment
AccountCatIDForListings:
contact Beckham Estate.

 

 

 

"
PageLogo: Archive

BrowserTitle: Wine, Carousels and Cinema in Historic Albany, Oregon
HeaderText: Wine, Carousels and Cinema in Historic Albany, Oregon
ContentText:
A historic carousel, an indie theater, and lots of Oregon wine

The Willamette Valley is a fantastic place to taste great wines and experience unique and creative art. Explore the best of each when you visit historic downtown Albany.

The Albany Historic Carousel Carving Museum | Start your visit at The Albany Historic Carousel & Museum. Because of the dream of an imaginative person and the work of many creative volunteers
PageType: the museum and carving studio now buzzes with activity six days a week year-round. Volunteer woodcarvers and painters work on their beautiful creations
PageLevel:
while docents welcome visitors and guests from around the world to watch as the carousel dream comes to fruition.

Each of the 52 animals on the carousel was adopted by a family or individual
PageSectionID: and each animal is treated with special care. Each animal is a fascinating labor of love
ParentPage:
carved with unique details that tell a story. The completed animals are on display while they wait to be placed on the restored antique mechanism and for the carousel’s new building to be constructed. 

Marks Ridge Wine | Wine-loving visitors can enjoy local wines while also supporting the Carousel. The winemakers at Marks Ridge
Status: a boutique winery in Oregon’s Willamette Valley
InsertCode:
have created four varieties of custom-labeled Carousel wine. Every bottle purchased supports the Albany Carousel’s mission of promoting the artistry of carousel-building. Wines are available for purchase at the carousel store.

Albany Pix Theatre | Next
IssuuCode: head to the Albany Pix Theatre
HideFromNav: housed in a Queen Anne building that dates from 1882
DisplayListings: just a few blocks from the Carousel. Your senses will be delighted as soon as you step into this charming theater. The cozy lobby displays vintage movie art
AccountCatIDForListings: and delicious smells greet your nose. The Pix is known for having the best popcorn in the valley
SortOrder:
plus the owners create decadent homemade movie treats and pair them with local wine and beer. 

The Pix shows a variety of first-run films
FeatureChildPages: and every winter it puts on the Pix Oscar Blitz
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
screening the year’s Academy Award nominees and culminating in a red carpet extravaganza on Oscar night. There’s no better place to kick back with a glass of your favorite Oregon-grown craft beverage and enjoy the art of the cinema.

For more information on these two venues and more
DisplayArticles:
call Albany Visitors Association at (541) 928-0911 or visit www.albanyvisitors.com.

 

"
PageLogo: NULL

BrowserTitle: Live Theater and Local Food in Corvallis, Oregon
HeaderText: Live Theater and Local Food in Corvallis, Oregon
ContentText:
Located in the heart of Oregon wine country, Corvallis, Oregon bustles with life year-round. Known for its hiking and biking in the summer, the winter months are the perfect time to sample the city’s booming live theater and excellent locally-grown cuisine.

A Theater Reborn | In August of 2013, The Majestic Theater turned 100 years old. The venerable vaudeville house has seen many incarnations over the decades before being purchased by the City of Corvallis in 1985. The Parks and Recreation Department of the City of Corvallis began managing operations of the Majestic Theater in January of 2015. The organization is enjoying a new surge of energy and success with new programs
PageLevel: all focused on establishing The Majestic as the flagship cultural space for the performing and contemporary arts in Corvallis
PageSectionID:
serving the City and surrounding communities.

Delicious Dining | When you see a show at The Majestic
ParentPage: turn your experience into a memorable night or an entire weekend of exploring downtown Corvallis’ popular restaurant and craft beverage scene. Just steps from the doors of The Majestic
Status: you’ll find creative restaurants
InsertCode:
quirky craft breweries and decadent bakeries. Stay at an upscale hotel or a cozy B&B and enjoy a weekend of live theater and great food.

Upcoming Shows | Beginning on December 11th
HideFromNav: 18th & 19th two performances of The Best Christmas Pageant Ever will be held at 7:30 and 9:30PM. On the 12th
AccountCatIDForListings:
19th and 20th there will also be performances at 2:30 PM. Love in Unexpected Places will have two performances on December 14th and 15th and The Last Romance is scheduled for the 27th. All three performances are set for 7PM. 

January will feature Improv Smackdown: 2 Towns Ciderhouse vs. Calapooia Brewing on January 16th at 7:30 PM. On the 28th
SortOrder:
29th and 30th Santiam Christian High School is due to present Get Smart at 7:30 each evening. January 31st features Skylight by David Hare. It looks like an intriguing story of attempted reconciliation between former lovers.

February ushers in Alice in Wonderland & Through the Looking Glass on the 1st and 2nd at 7PM. February 5th the Majestic Chamber Music program present the Amelia Piano Trio
FeatureChildPages: and on the 6th the Majestic will hold its first two days of the 1st Annual Majestic Community Film Festival featuring films of all genres by local amateur and professionals. Times are to be announced
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
so check in to their website for more details. Love in Unexpected Places is the theme for Valentine’s Weekend followed by other great performances to round out the month. 

For more information please visit www.majestic.org or www.visitcorvallis.com

Photos: Majestic Theater
DisplayArticles:
101 Eat & Drink by Lainey Dyer

 

"

BrowserTitle: Winter Wine + Art in Salem
ContentText:
Warm Up with Wonderful Arts Venues in Salem

Winter is perfect time to experience the Salem area’s thriving arts scene. Whether it’s colorful artwork, musical performances or live theatre, you’ll find a variety of intimate venues and vibrant performances that are sure to warm you up from the inside out.

Live Theater | One of Oregon’s oldest and most magnificent theatres is located in the heart of Salem. First opened in 1926, the Historic Elsinore Theatre was designed to resemble the castle in “Hamlet
PageLevel: this beautifully restored theatre serves as the backdrop for a wide array of performances
PageSectionID:
from well-known singers and A-list comedians to dance troupes and variety shows. You can also take in a classic or silent film at The Elsinore most Wednesday evenings. 

Classic Artwork | Art lovers will definitely want to visit to The Hallie Ford Museum of Art - Oregon’s third largest art museum located in downtown Salem. This gem of a museum features a permanent collection of more than 6
ParentPage:
000 artifacts as well as beautifully curated temporary exhibitions. The museum is open six days a week with free admission on Tuesdays. 

Local Galleries | Many talented artists make their home in the beautiful Mid-Willamette Valley
Status: and their work is proudly displayed at galleries around the region. At the Red Raven Gallery in downtown Salem
InsertCode: you’ll find an eclectic mix of fine art
AccountCatIDForListings: recycled metal creations and more. In nearby Independence
SortOrder: River Gallery has been a destination for art lovers since 1998
FeatureChildPages: particularly in January and February when their locally famous “Wild Women” juried show is on display. In the historic town of Silverton
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: Lunaria Gallery is renowned for its fine art
DisplayArticles:
excellent crafts and friendly atmosphere.

Wineries + Tasting Rooms | As you’re taking in the arts in Salem
PageLogo: don’t forget to stop at one or more of the many wineries and tastings rooms in the area
FeatureBlockTitle1:
where local vintners use their talents in winemaking to craft some liquid artistry of their own. 

For more ideas of what to see and do in the Salem area this winter
FeatureBlockTitle2:
visit TravelSalem.com. 

Photos: Elsinore Theater by Ron Cooper
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
Vineyard in Winter by Cyndi Easterly

 

"

BrowserTitle: Discover South Willamette Valley's Art + Culinary Scene
HeaderText: Discover South Willamette Valley's Art + Culinary Scene
ContentText:
Take a Night Out in the Eugene with the Show Your Ticket & Save Program

Ready for a night on the town? The South Willamette Valley’s arts and culinary scene is waiting for your next outing.

Show Your Ticket + Save | In a new project with resident companies at the Hult Center for the Performing arts and more than 15 local businesses
PageType: Eugene is celebrating the season with the Show Your Ticket & Save program. It all starts with a ticket to a show from one of the resident companies: Ballet Fantastique
ParentPage:
and/or the Eugene Concert Choir. 

There are a handful of great local eateries
Status:
breweries and wine bars that offer plenty of options within walking distance from the Hult Center. Keep in mind that parking is free downtown after 6 PM.

Take that ticket to any of the supporting restaurants
InsertCode: breweries and eateries four days before and four days after the ticket date to find a range of deals around the show. From specials on drinks before a show at spots like The Barn Light
IssuuCode: or a nice coffee the morning after at cozy stops like Theo’s Coffee House
HideFromNav:
there’s something here for everyone!

Upcoming Shows | Here’s a look at some of the upcoming participating shows this season. Time to grab a ticket
DisplayListings:
and have a blast!

  • December 6 – A Dickens of a Christmas from Eugene Concert Choir
  • December 11 – Yo-Yo Ma from Eugene Symphony
  • December 11
SortOrder:
13 – An American Christmas Carol from Ballet Fantastique
  • December 18 – A Christmas Story from Cottage Theatre 
  • December 18
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
20 – The Nutcracker from Eugene Ballet Company
  • January 21 – Giancarlo Conducts Pines of Rome from Eugene Symphony
  • February 13 & 14 – Carmina Burana/White Noise from Eugene Ballet Company 
  • February 18 – Fire and Water from Eugene Symphony
  • February 20
FeatureBlockTitle1:
28 – The Dragon & The Night Queen from Ballet Fantastique
  • February 27 – Burt Bacharach Songbook from Eugene Concert Choir 

    • For more information about what to do and where to find great wine in the South Willamette Valley
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
Cascades & Coast\" href=\"http://www.EugeneCascadesCoast.org\" target=\"_blank\">www.EugeneCascadesCoast.org and www.SouthWillametteWineries.com.

Photos: Eugene Cityscape by Jeff Green

BrowserTitle: Road Rally
ContentText: Looking to spend some more time in the Willamette Valley? Here are the tools you need to learn about things to do and places to go on your trip -- but don't be surprised if you get a bit sidetracked by all there is to see and do. Discover restaurants
PageLevel:
places to stay and more with our map explorer and wineries pages. Select your favorite destinations and build your own customized trip.

When you're not pedaling or pinoting
PageSectionID:
come enjoy all the Willamette Valley has to offer. From art gallery hopping and antique shop browsing to unforgettable outdoor adventures and scenic covered bridges. You'll be sure to find it in the Willamette Valley. Try these ideas and adventures:

Mt. Hood Territory 

The small towns on the west side of Mt. Hood will entice you with their natural beauty
ParentPage:
outdoor recreation and family farms.

Elk at Rosse Posse in Mollalla

Visit all 52 acres of this working elk farm to see elk face-to-face
Status:
not to mention beautiful views of the surrounding countryside and Mt. Hood.

St. Josef’s Estate

A family owned and operated winery & vineyards centrally located between Woodburn
IssuuCode:
and Wilsonville – just 30 minutes south of Portland.

The Kitchen at Middleground Farms

Take a cooking class
HideFromNav: explore fundamental skills in the kitchen and garden
DisplayListings:
and learn about the lost arts of handcrafting and preserving food.

 

Yamhill Valley

Visit the towns of Yamhill Valley
AccountCatIDForListings:
the northernmost section of the Willamette Valley wine country and the birthplace of Oregon Pinot.  

Eyrie Winery

Taste Eyrie’s newest releases
FeatureChildPages:
and limited bottlings from Oregon's most historic winery

Evergreen Aviation

Don't miss the aviation museum
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
themed waterpark and more.  

Red Hills Market

Stop for lunch and enjoy a selection of sandwiches
PageLogo: salads
FeatureBlockTitle1:
soups and seasonally inspired dishes.

Salem 

Enjoy Oregon’s capital city
FeaturedActivityTitle2: golf and a historic downtown offering shopping
PartnerTitle:
dining and activities.

The Oregon Garden & Frank Lloyd Wright House 

Visit the 80-acre botanical garden that features more than 20 themed gardens located adjacent to the Gordon House.

 Cubanisimo Vineyards

Come visit the tasting room anytime to enjoy great wines
PartnerText:
fabulous panoramic views of the vineyards with the gorgeous backdrop of Salem and the Cascade Mountains.

Bentley’s Grill

Located in the Grand Hotel in Salem the menu features the finest in Northwest ingredients.

Albany

Rivers
DisplayPartnerColumns: lake and waterfalls abound near the town of Albany
PartnerCityTitle:
which has more than 700 historic homes and buildings.

Dive into Adventure at Clear Lake

One of Oregon’ most stunningly pristine mountain lakes perfect for kayaking
YoutubeVideoID: canoeing and fishing or bring scuba diving gear and explore the submerged 3
VideoTitle1:
000-year-old forest. 

Willamette Valley Vineyards

Compete in the Oregon Grape Stomp Championship in September
VideoTitle2:
or have a glass of wine anytime. 

Frankie's 

Embrace the Farm to Table experience and find the freshest
MetaDescription:
seasonal and local products by an award winning chef.

Corvallis

Home to Oregon State University
SEOTags:
Corvallis has the charm of a historic downtown and the beauty of national forests.

Cascadia Expeditions in Corvallis

You'll love the rafting
ProposedHeaderText:
backpacking and rock climbing adventures throughout the year. Don't miss Paddling for Pinot – Kayaking & Winery Tour.

Tyee Wine Cellars

Enjoy wine tasting and picnicking on the farm and vineyard in a variety of scenic locations or hikes along Tyee’s Beaver Pond Loop Nature Trail. 

Gathering Together Farm

Feast on the finest from Oregon wine country: locally-grown produce
SEOPaidSearch: Afton Field Farm free range chicken
CreationDate:
Cascades & Coast

The southernmost section of the Willamette Valley is a destination for mountain bikers
Excerpt:
hikers and University of Oregon Duck fans. 

King Estate

Visit Oregon’s largest winery and the largest producer of Pinot gris in the US with 465 acres of organic vineyards
AuthorUserID: as well as 30 acres of fruits
PublishDate:
vegetables and flowers they use in their on-site restaurant.

A. Helfrich Outfitters

Fish or float the scenic McKenzie River with experienced guides with the finest equipment
IncludeInWidgets:
the greatest meals and the most flexible schedules.

Oregon Electric Station

The beloved national historic landmark features antique railroad cars for dining
DataFinds: elegant bar lounge and award winning Chef Michael
TopLanding:
guaranteeing that anything on the menu will please you and your palate.

 

"
column78: Find things to do in the Willamette Valley. Attractions and wineries in Mt. Hood Territory, Yamhill Valley, Salem, Albany, Corvallis, and Eugene.

NavButtonText: Tours Connect Visitors with Salem Agriculture
BrowserTitle: New Tours Connect Visitors with Salemâs Agricultural Bounty and Outdoor Gems
HeaderText: Experience Salemâs world-class wine region, outdoor gems and agricultural bounty via two new tours
ContentText: Experience Salem’s world-class wine region
PageType: outdoor gems and agricultural bounty via two new tours offered by Gray Line Oregon
PageSectionID:
Amtrak Cascades and the Oregon Department of Transportation.

Starting this summer
ParentPage:
visitors can hop aboard one of Grayline’s park coaches – comfortable buses fashioned after the “white jammers” that operated in national parks in the 1930s – and head off for an unforgettable experience in Mid-Willamette Valley wine country!

Wineries of the Valley Tour
The “Wineries of the Valley Tour” includes a visit and tasting flight at three wineries in Salem area. The tour begins with a stop at Cubanisimo Vineyards
IssuuCode: it’s off to Left Coast Cellars – a 300-acre vineyard featuring entirely estate-grown wines. The final stop is Willamette Valley Vineyards
HideFromNav: whose recently redesigned tasting room received a “People’s Choice” award from the Oregon Chapter of the International Interior Design Association.  A trained driver guide will provide narration en route to each winery. The tour will last approximately five hours and includes a no-host lunch stop at Willamette Valley Vineyards. Tours will run every Saturday from June 11 through October 15
DisplayListings:
2016.

Silver Falls & The Oregon Garden Tour
The “Silver Falls & The Oregon Garden Tour
AccountCatIDForListings: ” which kicks off on Sunday
FeatureChildPages: begins with a visit to E.Z. Orchards Farm Market
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: where visitors can enjoy freshly made baked goods
DisplayArticles: hard cider and more while they enjoy exploring the farm store. The next stop is The Oregon Garden
PageLogo: which features 80 acres of plantings and 20 specialty gardens. From The Oregon Garden
FeatureBlockTitle1: visitors will enjoy a drive through historic Silverton and a stop at Silver Falls State Park  – considered the crown jewel of the Oregon State Parks system with its 10 cascading waterfalls. This approximately five-hour tour includes a no-host lunch stop at historic Silver Falls Lodge and is offered every Sunday through October 16
FeatureBlockTitle2:
2016.   

Both Salem area tours are timed to operate in conjunction with Amtrak rail service.  Pickup points include the Salem Amtrak Station
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
Travel Salem’s Visitor Center and the Grand Hotel in Salem.

 

For more tour information or to make reservations
FeaturedActivityTitle2: go to www.graylineoregon.com or www.travelsalem.com. For Amtrak rail reservations

NavButtonText: Mount Hood's Magical Soils Give Life to Dahlias
BrowserTitle: Mount Hood's Magical Soils Give Life to Dazzling Dahlias
HeaderText: Mount Hood's Magical Soils Give Life to Dazzling Dahlias
ContentText: The fertile soil of the Willamette Valley is world-renowned for its wine-growing capabilities. Those same many other wonderful products too
PageType:
including a dazzling selection of flowers at the annual Dahlia Festival in Canby.

Swan Island Dahlias is the largest dahlia grower in the United States. The business has been producing beautiful flowers for more than 90 years
PageLevel: with the Gitts family owning it since 1963. In that time they’ve cultivated numerous new breeds of all colors
PageSectionID:
shapes and sizes.

The 40 acres are opened to the public each blooming season starting August 1
ParentPage:
culminating in the annual Dahlia Festival which is the largest display put on by one grower anywhere in the country. This year’s festival is set for Aug. 27-29 and Sept. 3-5.

The festival features more than 400 floral arrangements of dahlias
InsertCode: 000 cut blooms on display plus the 40 acres of colorful blooms all vying for your attention. Walk up and down the rows to take in the seemingly endless varieties and just try to choose a favorite – every time you think you’ve found it
IssuuCode:
another one will take its place.

As if the beautiful blooms weren’t enough
HideFromNav: there’s plenty of activity going on as well. In addition to various demonstrations taking place each day
DisplayListings: there’s wine tasting from St. Josef’s Winery
AccountCatIDForListings: amazing BBQ from Canby staple Ebner’s Custom Meats plus other food and drink vendors. Come on an empty stomach
SortOrder:
it’s worth it to sample all the deliciousness you’ll find here.

The festival also features live music from noon until 4 p.m. each day of the event. Always family friendly
FeatureChildPages: the Dahlia Festival also has some fun kids’ activities like a balloon artist and face painting. Parking and festival admission are free
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
all you need to do is bring a camera and a love for beautiful flowers for a fun afternoon.

"
PageLogo: NULL

NavButtonText: Explore Southern Wineries with Pinot Bingo
BrowserTitle: Explore Eugeneâs Urban Wineries & Territorial Wine Trail with Pinot Bingo
HeaderText: Explore Eugeneâs Urban Wineries & Territorial Wine Trail with Pinot Bingo
ContentText: When the sun offers longer (and warmer) days
PageType: it’s time to explore the South Willamette Valley. Sip a little different this summer with Pinot Bingo. Modeled after the successful Eugene Ale Trail passport
PageLevel:
Pinot Bingo offers an opportunity to explore the flavors of the valley with fun prizes around every corner. Grab a passport and let’s get started!

Only have an hour to spare? Check out Urban Wineries like Noble Estate Vineyard
ParentPage: Oregon Wine Lab and Territorial Vineyards & Wine Company. With locations dotted across Eugene’s downtown area out to the Westside Warehouse District
Status: each Urban Winery offers a unique twist on the delicious Pinot the Willamette Valley is known for
InsertCode:
and many will surprise with delicious varietals one might not expect to find in the South Willamette Valley.

Getting hungry? Don’t miss out on stops along the way that earn “pairings” stamps at participating restaurants
IssuuCode:
brew pubs and other tasty locations.

When you’re ready to see the countryside head to the Territorial Wine Trail that 17 Southern Willamette wineries call home. From the gorgeous Chateau Lorane that anchors the south end of the trail
HideFromNav: to the beautifully wide open Benton-Lane Winery to the north
AccountCatIDForListings:
crisp Rose and everything in between while gathering stamps for Pinot Bingo prizes.

When you score a BINGO bring your passport to the Adventure Center in Springfield to claim your prize. The adventure specialists are always ready to help plan your next excursion. 

 

"
PageLogo: Archive

BrowserTitle: Summertime at The Thyme Garden
ContentText: Ah the sights
PageType: smells and tastes that all come to life in Corvallis. Summertime is especially sweet; a time to slow down and appreciate the verdant place we call home and share with locals and visitors alike. If you haven’t already
PageLevel: take a day this summer to visit The Thyme Garden
ParentPage:
specializing in collecting new and unusual varieties of herbs and displaying them for all to see and enjoy.

Located four miles east of Alsea
IssuuCode:
Thyme Garden’s largest greenhouse contains a small conservatory equipped with its own stream and a collection of plants they call Angel’s Trumpet. These Brugmansia boast hundreds of 10-inch long trumpet shaped flowers that are so fragrant and intoxicating many guests refer to a visit as an aromatherapy experience.

Using their Edible Flower Garden to help to liven up dishes
DisplayListings: and sisters Emily Stimac and Bethany Schiminsky prepare gourmet herbal dishes for luncheons
AccountCatIDForListings: weddings and special events. Four-course luncheons
SortOrder: that are prepared Tuesdays through Thursdays all summer long
FeatureChildPages:
include herb-infused entrees and drinks like lavender lemonade.

Luncheons also include a walking tour of the property and a visit to the onsite stream restoration project that aims to help threatened Coho Salmon
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: and increase the number of returning native Steelhead to their streams
DisplayArticles:
supporting the sustainability of the region’s ecosystem and preserving salmon populations for generations to come.  Most Corvallis area wineries are certified Sustainable and Salmon Safe. So while you’re sipping your Pinot Noir or Pinot Gris this summer you can feel good knowing you’re supporting growers and producers committed to the preservation of Oregon’s bountiful fare.

On the weekends
PageLogo: nursery visitors are welcome to bring a lunch and spend the afternoon walking the paths and taking in the 92-bed display garden. The Alsea valley makes a great day trip for out of town guests to explore the coast range including Mary’s Peak
FeatureBlockTitle2:
and the beautiful twists and turns of scenic Highway 34.

Come and experience The Thyme Garden for yourself.

Summer Hours: Open to the public: 10 a.m. – 5 p.m. Friday-Monday

Luncheons available by reservation: Tuesday-Thursday
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
June through August 2016

See all the events at Thyme Garden or please visit www.visitcorvallis.com    

"

NavButtonText: Plan Your Trip for the next Solar Eclipse in 2017
BrowserTitle: Plan Your Trip to Salem for the Great American Solar Eclipse 2017
HeaderText: Plan Your Trip to Salem for the Great American Solar Eclipse 2017
ContentText: For the first time in more than 30 years, a total solar eclipse will move diagonally across the United States on August 21, 2017 -- starting on the Oregon Coast and traveling directly through the Willamette Valley. Mid-Willamette Valley towns including McMinnville, Salem, Albany and Corvallis are located directly in the \path of totality
PageType: \" and will go nearly or completely dark for almost two minutes
PageLevel:
starting at 10:17 a.m. Salem and surrounding communities are gearing up by planning viewing parties and events that will make this rare celestial event even more memorable. Start making plans now to be in the Willamette Valley for the Great American Solar Eclipse 2017!

You don't want to miss it -- the next U.S. solar eclipse isn't until 2024!

What is a Total Solar Eclipse?
Total solar eclipses occur when the Moon comes between the Sun and the Earth and casts the darkest part of its shadow (the umbra) on Earth. \"If you're in the path (of totality)
PageSectionID: you will see one of the most phenomenal sights that human eyes can convey to the brain
ParentPage: \" notes Dan McGlune
Status:
a veteran of 12 solar eclipses.

 \"People travel to remote deserts
InsertCode: jungles and islands just to be in the path of a total eclipse. So walk
AccountCatIDForListings:
or cycle to into the path on eclipse day. You will not regret it!\" adds McGlune.

Eclipse Events & Viewing Parties
Arcane Cellars
SortOrder: located on the banks of the Willamette River in Salem
FeatureChildPages: is offering a special eclipse package that includes camping
PageLogo:
wine and a talk led by an astronomy expert. Wine lovers can also view totality among the vines during a special event being held at Willamette Valley Vineyards in Turner.

OMSI (The Oregon Museum of Science & Industry) invites guests for a viewing party to be held at the Oregon State Fairgrounds in Salem
FeatureBlockTitle1:
while The Oregon Garden will be one of the key sites in historic Silverton to host a viewing within its 80-acre botanical garden. Visitors can even experience the eclipse from the very top of the Oregon State Capitol building during an exclusive tower tour.

More eclipse-related events are expected to be added in the coming months. Check Travel Salem's eclipse page for updates.

Lodging
Visitors are encouraged to make lodging arrangements soon as space is expected to fill quickly. Whether you're interested in a hotel
FeaturedActivityTitle1: RV park or Bed and Breakfast
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
there are a number of options in the Mid-Willamette Valley.
Book your hotel room now or check out RV parks and campgrounds in or near Salem.
For more information about eclipse-related events or lodging in the Salem area

NavButtonText: Festivals, Fairs and Farmers Markets in Mt Hood
BrowserTitle: Festivals, Fairs and Farmers Markets in Mt Hood
HeaderText: Festivals, Fairs and Farmers Markets in Mt Hood
PageType: sans-serif;\">Spring is finally here in Oregon’s Mount Hood Territory. The rains and snow over the past winter season have made way for our farms to produce a bounty of delicious fruits
PageLevel: vegetables and award-winning wines. Our agricultural wonderland is impressive
ParentPage: fairs and events are the perfect way to explore what the region has to offer.
Status: sans-serif;\">One annual event that turns spring into more than a season is The Wooden Shoe Tulip Farm’s Annual Tulip Festival. Stroll through 40 acres of stunning beauty in Woodburn
InsertCode: OR. If you stop in on a weekend try the ziplines
DisplayListings: archery tag and paintball. Let the kids loose for the rubber duck races. Adults can sit back and enjoy sweeping views along with wine under the new Wooden Shoe Vineyards label. In addition to well-known Oregon varietals like Pinot noir and Pinot gris
AccountCatIDForListings: Wooden Shoe boasts rare varieties such as a 2014 Marechal Foch.
SortOrder: sans-serif;\">The Tulip Festival is just the start of a whole assortment of great springtime events in the Mt. Hood Territory. Bring a little of the season to your own home by visiting Gardenpalooza at Fir Point Farms in Aurora. The event features over 40 vendors showcasing a diverse selection of plants
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: gardening tools and everything you need to get growing this season.
DisplayArticles: sans-serif;\">The Clackamas County Master Gardeners Spring Garden Fair takes place at the end of April at the Clackamas County Event Center. Enjoy amazing displays and informative sessions that will help you make your garden shine this season.
PageLogo: sans-serif;\">And don’t forget about the bounty of fresh produce available at the wonderful local farmer’s markets
FeatureBlockTitle1: and the annual Memorial Day Weekend Winery Open Houses.
FeatureBlockTitle2: sans-serif; font-size: 7.5pt;\">Spring is an exciting time here in Mt. Hood Territory. Find more agritourism events at
FeaturedActivityTitle1: sans-serif; font-size: 7.5pt;\" title=\"MtHoodTerritory.com\" href=\"https://www.mthoodterritory.com/\" target=\"_self\">MtHoodTerritory.com

BrowserTitle: Spring into Corvallis
PageLevel: that means it’s time to think about your spring garden
ParentPage: of course. But there’s always time for both! For many in and around the Willamette Valley
Status: Garland Nursery is a must-see destination. This fourth generation family-owned business has been offering the highest quality plants and garden supplies for 79 years. Well-known for showcasing the rare and newest varieties available
InsertCode: they also offer over six acres of trees
AccountCatIDForListings: and bonsai as well as a beautiful selection of home décor and gifts. This spring they will also offer a variety of classes
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: a class for our smallest gardeners. Don’t miss their anniversary celebration April 22-24
DisplayArticles: 2016 in conjunction with Earth Day.
PageLogo: sans-serif;\">Another wonderful destination for the green-thumb gardener is The Thyme Garden. Bring mom on May 8- 9
PartnerText: wine and live music.
PartnerCityTitle: dust off your market baskets because the Corvallis Farmer’s Market officially opens their outdoor venue on April 16
YoutubeVideoID: 2016. Choose from variety of fresh fruits and vegetables
ProposedHeaderText: jams and baked goods. Come out and meet the growers and enjoy live music every Wednesday and Saturday from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. on 1st and Jackson on the Riverfront in downtown Corvallis.
ProposedMetaDescription: May is Oregon Wine Month. Every year the Heart of Willamette Wineries celebrate Memorial Day weekend with an open house. It’s a perfect time to get out
SEOPaidBanner: sip fine wine and meet with winemakers and vineyard owners.
ContentType: sans-serif;\">For more information about any of these places or events

NavButtonText: Explore South Willamette Wineries this Spring
BrowserTitle: Explore South Willamette Wineries this Spring
HeaderText: Explore South Willamette Wineries this Spring
PageType: sans-serif;\">The days are growing longer and the valley is once again in full bloom
PageLevel: marking the perfect opportunity to explore Oregon’s South Willamette Wineries. Bring a picnic and toast to the turn of the season by meandering across the rolling countryside of Eugene’s surrounding wine country this Memorial Day.
PageSectionID: sans-serif;\">One of the region’s most anticipated wine weekends of the year
ParentPage: Memorial Day weekend marks the transition to longer tasting room hours and more time to spend in wine country. This event-filled weekend also makes it the perfect time to try both new wines and the old favorites that make the Southern Willamette Valley so special.
Status: sans-serif;\">From small rustic vineyards to full service restaurants
InsertCode: Southern Willamette wineries curate the perfect escape for every type of visitor.Catch live performances and sample mouth-watering menu options at wineries like King Estate and Oregon Wine Lab. You’ll also run into a variety of talented craftsmen and artisan vendors along the way.
IssuuCode: sans-serif;\">Why choose just one winery? With northern
DisplayListings: wine excursions in the South Willamette Valley can keep you exploring through the holiday weekend. Don’t miss this adventure before the warm summer season!

BrowserTitle: Willamette Valley hikes, trails, waterfalls and outdoor adventures
HeaderText: Get Outdoors in the Willamette Valley
ContentText:
Find your Willamette Valley adventure today.

The Willamette Valley is a natural playground for outdoor enthusiasts and adventure-seekers. Just a stone’s throw in any direction lie waterways like the Molalla River Corridor
PageLevel:
the Willamette River and the wild and scenic McKenzie River. 

Whether an ideal voyage includes biking through covered bridges
ParentPage: running the famous routes of track & field stars
Status: skydiving or meandering from tasting room to tasting room
InsertCode:
Oregon Wine Country is ripe with adventure.

 

"
ProposedMetaDescription: Stroll the Mckenzie River Trail. Explore Oregon State Parks. Cycle miles of breathtakingly beautiful trails like the Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway

PageDesc: Oregon's Willamette Valley Wins Wine Enthusiast's 2016 Wine Star Award for Wine Region of the Ye
NavButtonText: The Willamette Valley Wins Wine Region of the Year
BrowserTitle: Willamette Valley Wins Wine Region of the Year
HeaderText: Willamette Valley Wins Wine Region of the Year
ContentText:
Oregon’s Willamette Valley Wins Wine Enthusiast’s 2016 Wine Star Award for Wine Region of the Year.

 

Get a glimpse into this year's Wine Star Awards Gala held in Miami Beach
ParentPage:
height=405'));\">watch David Adelsheim accept the award on the behalf of all Willamette Valley winemakers. 


A little bit about the Wine Star Awards and the Wine Region of the Year

Each year
Status: the editors of Wine Enthusiast honor outstanding achievements and contributions in the wine industry and Oregon’s Willamette Valley earned their prestigious 2016 Wine Region of the Year award.  Fellow nominees include Provence
DisplayListings:
California.

The Willamette Valley
AccountCatIDForListings: Oregon’s leading wine region
SortOrder: has over two-thirds of the state’s wineries and vineyards
FeatureChildPages: and is home to nearly 500 wineries. It is recognized as one of the premier Pinot noir producing areas in the world. Other cool-climate varieties such as Pinot gris
PageLogo:
Riesling and Gewürztraminer are equally at home in the Willamette Valley. 

“Wine lovers worldwide are traveling to Oregon to experience our valley first hand and find our winegrowers as welcoming as our valley is beautiful. The Willamette Valley is indeed a Star."

-Jim Bernau
FeatureBlockTitle1:
Founder of Willamette Valley Vineyards

While the number of wineries continues to grow
FeatureBlockTitle2: Willamette Valley winemakers haven’t lost their personal
FeaturedActivityTitle2: or their desire to do things a little differently. Many winemakers in the Willamette Valley practice sustainable winegrowing techniques based on their respect for the land and desire to see future generations continue the winemaking tradition. Nearly halfof all Willamette Valley vineyards are certified sustainable
PartnerTitle:
making the valley the most sustainable wine region in the world.

"

BrowserTitle: Farms, vineyards, farmers markets and gardens in the Willamette Valley
HeaderText: Confidently rooted in its land, history and good fortune
ContentText: A little over fifty years ago
PageType: a generation of visionaries reclaimed overgrown hillsides to plant Pinot noir and other cool-climate grapes
PageLevel: including America’s first Pinot gris. These fearless pioneers intended to put the Willamette Valley on the international map
PageSectionID:
and they succeeded.

Oregon Wine Country produces award winning wine
ParentPage: and while the number of wineries continues to grow
Status: Willamette Valley winemakers haven’t lost their personal
IssuuCode:
or their desire to do things a little differently.

Most winemakers in the Willamette Valley practice sustainable winegrowing
HideFromNav: a decision rooted in their respect for the land and desire to see future generations continue the winemaking tradition. Nearly half of all Willamette Valley vineyards are certified sustainable
DisplayListings:
making the Willamette Valley one of the most sustainable wine regions in the world.

Learn a little bit about our winemaking history and plan a visit today.




Wine is just the beginning.


Willamette Valley pioneers are not just blazing the wine trail. The Willamette Valley offers one of the finest climates in the world --- not only for Pinot noir
AccountCatIDForListings: but for flowers like roses
SortOrder:
dahlias and tulips. Awe-inspiring display gardens delight visitors of all ages all over the region.

And don’t just stop to smell the flowers
FeatureChildPages: we have a surprising array of wild edibles
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
like berries and luscious truffles that can be found and foraged from field to table. 

Whether you’re looking to pick your own produce at a local farm
DisplayArticles: take a walk through a scenic covered bridge or view Oregon's Wine Country from the basket of a hot air balloon
PageLogo:
this region has something to please everyone. It is truly the valley for all.

Learn more about the Willamette Valley and pick from its bounty.

"
ExpirationDate: From the Eugene or Salem Saturday Market to a quaint winery tour. Immerse yourself in the fertile and bountiful Willamette Valley of Oregon.

NavButtonText: Cider Pressing at Historic Thompsons Mill State Heritage area
ContentText: NULL
ProposedMetaDescription: Historic Thompson's Mills is the last water powered mill in Oregon. Apple pressing happens in late September and again late October.

BrowserTitle: Family fun in Oregon's Willamette Valley
HeaderText: Fun for everyone in the Willamette Valley
ContentText:
Welcome to the Valley for all.

Visit a Willamette Valley vintner and you’ll feel at home from the get-go. The whole family is welcome to sit on cozy tasting room couches to soak up the sweeping views. Yes
PageType: you may be put to work stomping grapes – and you will definitely leave with the resident dog’s hair all over your pants - but hey
PageLevel:
you’re family now. 

If wine isn't at the top of your whole family's wishlist
PageSectionID: not to worry. We've got plenty of events and attractions for everyone in your group. We welcome you to sleep in a giant old-growth tree
ParentPage: ride in a race car at a motor sports museum
Status:
slip and slide down a retired airplane and ride on a hand-carved animal round and round a historic carousel.  

While the wine is wonderful - it's just the beginning in the Willamette Valley.

"
AccountCatIDForListings: Active
ProposedBrowserTitle: It's not all wine tasting and vineyard tours! Visit Oregon State Parks, hike or bike miles of trails, fish the rivers, lakes and streams.

BrowserTitle: Explore the Culture & History behind the Wine of the Willamette Valley
ContentText: Sure Oregon is outdoorsy
PageType:
but we’ve got some great insides too.

Breathtaking views are plentiful in the Willamette Valley
PageLevel:
but we’ve got more than a few cozy nooks and interesting crannies that invite indoor adventure. 

Wind through a few Oregon wineries that feature art collections in Yamhill Valley for a memorable two-for-one experience. Or
PageSectionID: visit the most varied collection of historic buildings in Oregon
ParentPage:
including the Monteith House in Albany.

Check out a few not-to-miss cultural sights and sounds during your visit through the Willamette Valley. 

"
AccountCatIDForListings: NULL
ProposedHeaderText: The Willamette Valley has been cultivating great wine for years. Discover the history of Oregon Wine Country. Home of the 1st Pinot Gris grape in the US.

BrowserTitle: Dusty Test
The Willamette Valley has been cultivating great wine for years. Discover the history of Oregon Wine Country. Home of the 1st Pinot Gris grape in the US.
HeaderText: Indulge Your Palate in Oregon Wine Country
ContentText:
Tasting is what we in the Willamette Valley might do best.

We’re constantly swirling
PageType: sipping and sampling to ensure the best flavor. But that extends to more than Pinot. Willamette Valley’s craft brew scene is a force to be reckoned with
PageLevel:
and cider houses and distilleries continue to delight customers in every corner of wine country. It’s safe to say that you won’t go thirsty here.

Oh
PageSectionID: and we’ve got food too - acres of farms with organic livestock and produce destined for chefs at our countless award winning restaurants
ParentPage:
café’s and diners.

Come hungry because you will find a stellar culinary scene in every corner of the Willamette Valley.

"
AccountCatIDForListings: NULL
ProposedHeaderText: Willamette Valley Pinot Noir plus wine varietals galore,  cider, distilleries and award winning restaurants featuring local, organic products.

BrowserTitle: Local Stories & Insider Tips For Vacationing In The Willamette Valley
HeaderText: Discover The Stories Of The Willamette Valley
MetaDescription: The Willamette Valley is brimming with activities, attractions and events to fill your next vacation. Let our local experts help you start planning with stories and tips on the best wine tours, bike tours and family friendly trips. Discover the stories of Oregon Wine Country now.

BrowserTitle: Wine Events in the Willamette Valley
ContentText: It's Oregon Wine Month
PageType:
which means you've got exactly 31 days to sip and savor the best of Oregon's world-class wine right here in your own backyard.

There's no shortage of parties or pours in Oregon this May. Right here in Oregon's Wine Country you'll find every kind of wine event– from paddle trips to wine walks
PageLevel: sipping seminars to ballet at the bar
PageSectionID: we've got it all! And because we know just how to party
ParentPage: we end the month of May with a three-day wine fest at nearly every winery in the Valley with Memorial Day weekend open houses
Status:
where practically every wine maker pops open the door and the cork for the summer season.

Get a taste of just a few events happening in your area this May!

 

 Albany:

  • Albany Wine Walk - May 5
  • Marks Ridge Winery “Mothers Day at the Winery” - May 14
  • Benton-Lane Winery Open House - May 28

Find other Albany area events in May

Corvallis:

  • Paddle for Pinot - May 13
  • Airlie's Mother Day Special - May 14th
  • Wine Sensory Two-Day Exclusive Course at OSU- May 20-21
  • Heart Of Willamette Winery Associations Memorial Day Open House - May 27-29

Find other Corvallis area events in May

 

Eugene:

  • Ballet Fantastique Open Barre Event at the Oregon Wine Lab - May 3
  • Food Scene Eugene - May 5-6
  • Grapes of Half Marathon - May 21
  • Memorial Day Weekend on the Territorial Wine Trail - May 28-29

Find Memorial Day wine events in and around Eugene

Salem:

  • Arcane Cellars Big Red Release Party - May 7
  • Syttende Mai (Constitution Day) Celebration - May 20
  • Celebrate Memorial Day "Cuban Style" at Cubanisimo Vineyards - May 27-29
  • “Ribs & Red” - May 29

Find more Salem Area Events

Mt. Hood:

  • Cascade Foothills Winegrowers Oregon Wine Month kick off - May 6

 Find more Mt. Hood Territory Events

Yamhill Valley:

  • Taste Dundee - May 6
  • Chardonnay Day at ROCO Winery - May 6
  • Mother's Day at Youngberg Hill - May 14
  • Bells Up Winery – Rosé Release & New Winery Porch - May 21
  • Calamity Hill Memorial Day Open House - May 27-29

Find more Yamhill Valley Events

 
Not in Oregon to celebrate? Not a problem. Our wines have inspired events in other NW cities.

Taste Oregon (in Seattle) - SUN. MAY 21
InsertCode:
2017

The 2nd annual “Taste Oregon” event in Seattle will feature 35 premium wineries from Oregon to be held in the SODO area of Seattle at a new venue called the Metropolist. There will be a private trade/industry tasting followed by a general public tasting with 35 wineries from an array of Oregon’s diverse AVAs.

Metropolist Event Space
2931 1st Ave. S – Seattle WA
1 to 5 pm
Advance $35/ Door $40

 

"

BrowserTitle: Linn-Benton Farm-to-Table Dinner Series
ContentText:
Corvallis & Albany Wine Dinner Events

Join Visit Corvallis and the Albany Visitors Association for a farm-to-table dinner series this summer! Four of the valley's most creative culinary artists and winemakers will delight your senses at scenic locations in the Willamette Valley. Dine in a garden
PageSectionID:
all while doing a bit of good.
Guests will be able to meet local chefs and learn how their meal was prepared and sourced. You’ll also sample fine vintages from local wineries and learn about local wines and vineyards. Don't miss these four intimate gatherings combining a memorable culinary experience at unique Willamette Valley locations. A portion of the proceeds will be donated to charities and nonprofit organizations – great food and wine for a great cause! Must be 21 or over to attend.

Dates and Details:

June 18
ParentPage:
2017 (Father’s Day)

You’ll meet the executive chef from Forks & Corks Catering and learn how he sources local foods. You’ll also drink and learn about Cardwell Hill Cellars‘ wines.

A portion of your ticket will benefit Community Outreach
Status: a non-profit organization dedicated to serving children
InsertCode:
adolescents and families who are working to overcome a severe life crisis or trauma.

Time: 5:30 p.m. – 8:30 p.m.
Price: $90/person
Seating limited to 50 people.

Part of the proceeds will benefit Albany's Regional Museum.

BrowserTitle: Oregon Wine Country Wonders Getaway Sweepstakes Rules
HeaderText: Oregon Wine Country Wonders Getaway Sweepstakes Rules
ContentText:
Win a 5-night Sip and Adventure Trip in Oregon's Wine Country 

Oregon Wine Country’s lush green landscapes, independent craftspeople and inviting small towns await the lucky winner and a guest for a five night adventure in the Willamette Valley. With over 500 wineries nestled in the hills between Portland and Eugene - just two hours apart - the Willamette Valley is revered as one of the world’s premier regions for Pinot Noir and was named Wine Region of the Year by Wine Enthusiast Magazine. Plus
PageType:
Oregon Wines fly free on Alaska Airlines!

Prize includes:

  • 5 nights lodging in two stunning locations
  • 5 VIP Wine Experiences — Enjoy private tastings and tours at award-winning wineries
  • 1 Three Course Chef's table experience
  • Dining at unique Willamette Valley restaurants
  • Oregon Wine Country adventures opportunities
  • $300 prepaid card for transportation/car rental

SPONSOR
Willamette Valley Visitors Association (WVVA)  ("Sponsor")

2019. All entries must be made via manual entry at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. Entries become the property of Sponsor.

Sweepstakes is open only to legal residents of the United States (excluding residents of Puerto Rico)

age verification and agreement that they have read and understand the Official Rules and Privacy Policy.

No mechanical reproductions or facsimiles of entries allowed. All entries become the exclusive property of Sponsor and will not be acknowledged or returned.

SWEEPSTAKES PRIZES

VideoTitle1:
SELECTION OF AN ALTERNATE WINNER.  

One winner will be selected for the grand prize. Sweepstakes prize valid through period of July 1

2020. Prizes are subject to availability.  

DRAWING AND NOTIFICATION
Prize winner will be selected in a random drawing from all entries received throughout the Sweepstakes Period. The drawing will be conducted on or about June 18 2019
SeoNotes:
whose decisions are final and binding in all matters relating to this Sweepstakes. The winner will be contacted via email and/or phone. Odds of winning will depend on the total number of eligible entries received.

One entry per person. No prize transfer
SEOStatus: assignment or substitution by Winners permitted. Sponsor reserves the right to substitute any prize in the case of unavailability

will be awarded.

If a Winner is unable to travel within prize dates (July 1

insurance and all other expenses associated with acceptance and use of the prize not stated herein are the sole responsibility of the Winner and his/her travel companions. All prize details are at Sponsor’s sole discretion.
