BrowserTitle: Privacy Policy
ContentText:
Privacy Policy:

Your privacy is important to us. In this Privacy Policy
PageType: we will share with you the type of information we gather and how we may use that information.  This Privacy Policy applies to Personal Information you provide to us through any means including
ParentPage: via e-mail
Status: and over the telephone.  Any reference to our “Site” includes our website located at www.oregonwinecountry.org
InsertCode: any mobile applications and other software we may offer now or in the future
IssuuCode: and any reference to our “Services” includes our Site
HideFromNav: visitor information phone line and other product or service offered by us.  This Privacy Policy is incorporated into our Website Terms of Use
DisplayListings:
which are available here.

By using our Services
AccountCatIDForListings:
you agree that your use of the Services constitutes your acceptance of and agreement to this Privacy Policy. Capitalized terms not defined in this Privacy Policy have the meaning given them in the Website Terms of Use.

1. Personal Information.

For the purposes of this Privacy Policy
SortOrder: “Personal Information” means any information that by itself or in connection with other information we collect allows us or anyone to identify you. Personal Information includes
PageLogo: addresses
FeatureBlockTitle1:
and email addresses.

2. Privacy and Protection of Children and Teens.

We take protection of the privacy of legal minors very seriously and in order to adhere to the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (“COPPA”) we will not knowingly collect any Personal Information from children under 13 or knowingly allow children under 13 to register for any portions of the Site requiring registration including
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
commenting on our blog. If we learn that we have collected Personal Information from a child under 13 we will immediately remove the information from our systems.

3. Cross-Border Data Transmission.

The Willamette Valley Visitors Association is headquartered in the United States of America (“USA”) and all of our primary data storage and processing facilities are in the USA. If you are accessing the Services from another country
FeaturedActivityTitle2: please note that all data we collect will be transmitted outside of your country and into the USA
PartnerTitle: where it will reside and be processed. In addition
PartnerText: your data may pass through or be temporarily stored or processed in countries beyond your country and the USA. By continuing to access this Site
DisplayPartnerColumns: or by providing your Personal Information
PartnerCityTitle:
you explicitly consent to have your data so transmitted and stored.

4. Information We May Collect Automatically.

Information About Your Computer. When you visit the Site
YoutubeVideoID: we automatically receive and store certain types of information
VideoTitle1: such as the name of the domain and host from which you access the Internet; the IP address of the computer you are using and the browser and operating system you are using; the date and time you access the Sites; the Internet address of the website from which you linked to the Sites; any search terms you used to find the Sites; the device identifiers and mobile and network information
VideoTitle2: and your actions on the Sites. We may retain this information to assist us in analyzing the behavior of visitors to our Site
MetaDescription: to resolve problems with our network and

PageID: <!-- CookiePro Cookies Settings button end --> We may use cookies or similar programs
PageDesc: such as web beacons or web bugs
NavButtonText: to collect the information described above
BrowserTitle: including tracking your device’s browsing habits on the Site. We may also use cookies to maintain session information you provide to us
HeaderText: so that when you leave the Site and return
ContentText: the Site will recognize your device. A cookie is a small text file that is sent to your computer to collect information about your activities on the Sites. The cookie transmits this information back to the applicable Site each time your browser requests a page from the Site. “Web beacons” are small pieces of code placed on websites used to collect advertising metrics
PageSectionID: or advertising responses. We may also use cookies or web beacons to measure aggregate web statistics
ParentPage: including the number of monthly visitors
InsertCode: most popular webpages and other information. We may allow our third-party service providers to use cookies for the same purposes that we can and we may otherwise allow third-parties to use cookies as set out in this Privacy Policy.  Cookies do not generally contain any Personal Information and it is our policy not to track your Internet usage outside of the Site. However
IssuuCode: you always have a choice with regard to cookies. You can modify your browser preferences to allow you to accept or reject all cookies or to notify you when a cookie is set. However
HideFromNav: because information we obtain may be combined
DisplayListings: we may still be able to identify your web browser
AccountCatIDForListings: computer or mobile device when you access our Services even if you disable cookies. If you choose to reject all cookies
SortOrder: you may be unable to use certain areas of the Site. Please consult your browser instructions for information on how to modify your choices about cookies. Finally
FeatureChildPages: you may delete any existing cookies manually from the hard drive of your device. For more information about cookies
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
please visit www.whatarecookies.com 

Log Data. Our web servers may also collect “log data.” Log data provides aggregate information about the number of visits to different pages on the Sites. We use log data for troubleshooting purposes and to track which pages people visit in order to improve the Sites. We do not link log data collected to Personal Information. Third-party vendors may also collect aggregate log data independently from us.

Tracking Images. We may use tracking images (such as GIFs)
DisplayArticles: which are small image files that we embed into our e-mail newsletters
PageLogo:
to learn whether you opened or forwarded the newsletter or clicked on any of the content. This information tells us about our newsletters’ effectiveness and helps us ensure that we’re delivering information that you find interesting.

“Do Not Track“: Some web browsers may transmit “Do-Not-Track” signals to websites with which the browser communicates
FeatureBlockTitle1: Section 22575 of the California Business & Professions Code requires website and online service operators to disclose whether they honor web browser.  Because there is not yet an accepted standard for how to respond to browser Do-Not Track signals
FeatureBlockTitle2: we do not currently respond to them. Other parties may collect Personal Information about your online activities over time and across different web sites when you visit the Site
FeaturedActivityTitle1: for example by using cookies on our Sites. We have no access to or control over other parties’ Personal Information collection practices
FeaturedActivityTitle2: even those with which the Willamette Valley Visitors Association may have an affiliation. You should carefully review the privacy policy and terms of any website you visit. For more information about Do Not Track
PartnerTitle:
please visit allaboutdnt.org.

5. Information You May Provide to Us. 

Generally. We may require you to provide certain Personal Information in order to access or use certain functions
PartnerText: products or services on the Site or otherwise provided as part of our Services
DisplayPartnerColumns: such as requesting information about the Willamette Valley
PartnerCityTitle: commenting on our blog or requesting that your event be added to our event calendar. We may collect Personal Information from you offline
YoutubeVideoID: such as when you visit us at a convention
VideoTitle2: or request information over the phone. You can choose not to provide such Personal Information
MetaDescription: in which case you may not be able to access or use such functions
SEOTags:
products or services.

If you submit any Personal Information relating to other people to us or to our service providers in connection with the Services
SeoNotes:
you represent that you have the authority to do so and to permit us to use the information in accordance with this Privacy Policy.

By Email. If you choose to email the Willamette Valley Visitors Association
SEOStatus: we may retain your email addresses and copies of your email(s)—including whatever content is in such emails—either separately or in the same database. Also
ProposedHeaderText: we (or our third party providers) may use tools to help prevent and block “spam” e- mail
ProposedMetaDescription: and other harmful or unwanted communications and programs that may be attached to or in the text of e-mails. These tools may automatically scan your e-mails
SEOPaidBanner: and other files and communications to help us protect you and the Willamette Valley Visitors Association against these harmful or unwanted communications and programs. However
SEOPaidSocial:
these tools do not collect or disclose Personal Information about you.

6. How We Use and Share Your Personal Information.

Generally. We will use any information that you provide to us to provide you the Services that you have requested. We will share Personal Information as needed to fulfill your request
ContentType:
as discussed below.

We may also use Personal Information for our internal business purposes that include
AuthorUserID: to comply with our own legal obligations
PublishDate: and communicating with you about the Willamette Valley
ExpirationDate: activities and other offerings that we believe may be of interest to you
IncludeInWidgets:
changes to this Privacy Policy or the Terms and other topics related to our business.

Third-Party Service Providers. We may use third-party service providers to perform services on our behalf
MicrositeID:
and emailing.  We will only permit them to access your Personal Information as necessary to allow them to perform their services or the services that you request

We may use Google Analytics to help analyze how users use the Site and we may use other third-party service providers to perform similar functions. Google Analytics uses cookies and other technologies to collect information such as how often users visit the Site
AuditRefreshPage: and what other sites they used prior to coming to the Site. We use the information we get from Google Analytics only to improve our Site and Service. From our Site
AuditTransferNotes: Google Analytics collects only the IP address assigned to you on the date you visit the Site

9. Protection of Your Data.

While we cannot guarantee the security of anyone’s data (including our own)

alteration and destruction.

You should also be aware of how you handle and disclose your own Personal Information and should avoid sending Personal Information through insecure email. Please refer to the Federal Trade Commission’s website at http://www.business.ftc.gov/privacy-and-security/consumer-privacy for information about how to protect yourself against identity theft.

11. Your California Privacy Rights.

column112: and if that business has within the immediately preceding calendar year disclosed such an individual’s Personal Information to a third party and knows or should have known that such third party used the information for its own direct marketing purposes

12. Corrections and Updates.

13. Changes to Our Privacy Policy.

We reserve the right to change or modify this Privacy Policy as we deem necessary or appropriate due to changes in our business practices or changes in the law. If you have provided us with your email address

14. Contact; Complaints.

We take your privacy seriously

and use of your Personal Information:

using the following contact information:

15. Terms Applicable to Data from EU Member Countries.

We are based in the United States.  In most cases

the Personal Information we collect is stored and used in the United States.

use and retention of that information

Basis for Collection:  As set out above

from visitors to the Sites

All such third parties must agree to use such Personal Information we provide to them only for the purposes for which we have engaged them and they must either: (a) comply with the EU-US Privacy Shield Principles or another mechanism permitted by the applicable EU & Swiss data protection law(s) for transfers and processing of Personal Information; or (b) agree to provide adequate protections for the Personal Information that are no less protective than those set out in this Privacy Policy.  Where we have knowledge that an entity to whom we have provided Personal Information is using or disclosing Personal Information in a manner contrary to this Privacy Policy
column154: we will take reasonable and appropriate steps to prevent

remediate or stop the use or disclosure

Authorized Transfer:  We also may disclose Personal Information for other purposes or to other third parties when you have consented to or requested such disclosure. Please be aware that we will disclose Personal Information in response to lawful requests by public authorities

including to meet national security or law enforcement requirements. We are not liable for appropriate onward transfers of Personal Information to third parties

Data Processors:  We may retain third parties to process or analyze Personal Information we collect from the Websites.  For example

and/or products may be fulfilled by a wholesaler.  These suppliers and other third parties who provide services for us are contractually obligated not to use Personal Information about you except as we authorize.

Profiling:  We may analyze Personal Information we have collected about you to create a profile of your interests and preferences so that we can contact you with information that is relevant to you.  We may make use of additional information about you when it is available from external sources to help us do this effectively.  We may also use Personal Information about you to detect and reduce fraud and credit risk.

Your Rights:  Your rights include: (a) a right to withdraw your consent to the processing of Personal Information about you to which you have previously given consent; (b) a right to object to processing of Personal Information about you for the purpose of direct marketing; and (c) a right to have any incorrect part of the Personal Information about you corrected or removed.

If you request to have incorrect Personal Information removed

You also have the right to obtain a copy of the Personal Information we have about you

although we reserve the right to charge a reasonable fee for this depending on the nature and frequency of your request(s) and our cost to provide the information.

Questions and Complaints:  If you have questions or complaints regarding this Privacy Policy or our handing of Personal Information about you

please contact info@oregonwinecountry.org.  We will promptly investigate and attempt to resolve complaints and disputes in a manner that complies with the principles described in this Privacy Policy.

Enforcement and Disputes:  In addition to the above

you may complain to your home data protection authority and can invoke binding arbitration for some residual claims not resolved by other redress mechanisms.  Contact details for the EU data protection authorities can be found at http://ec.europa.eu/justice/data-protection/bodies/authorities/index_en.htm.

PageDesc: Eat and Drink Vegan from Eugene to Portland
NavButtonText: Eat and Drink Vegan from Eugene to Portland
BrowserTitle: Eat and Drink Vegan from Eugene to Portland
HeaderText: Eat and Drink Vegan from Eugene to Portland
ContentText:
Orignially published by Margaux Lushing

 

The lush Willamette Valley is the perfect backdrop for a leisurely road trip of sustainable wine and healthy culinary landmarks. If you are coming from San Jose or San Fransisco like we were
PageType: I recommend touching down in Eugene and ending in Portland
PageLevel:
as direct flights into Eugene allow for the perfect amount of time to explore the gorgeous scenery during the drive north.

Here’s our take on a healthy three-day trip and all the wine and food along the way. Pro tip: don’t forget that Alaska Airlines offers one case of wine checked for free!
ParentPage: https://wvva.objects.liquidweb.services/photos/7.-wildcraft-cider-bottles-1-1000.webp 1000w
AccountCatIDForListings: https://wvva.objects.liquidweb.services/photos/7.-wildcraft-cider-bottles-1-1000.jpg 1000w
DisplayArticles:
https://wvva.objects.liquidweb.services/photos/7.-wildcraft-cider-bottles-1-800.jpg 800w\">Day 1

We flew into Eugene to check out what we heard more than one local refer to as a “miniature Portland.” Best known to us for vibrant breweries and cocktail bars
PageLogo: many walkable from one another
FeatureBlockTitle1: we prepared for a night of imbibing with a caffeine stop at Provisions Market Hall for a cup of Wandering Goat coffee
FeatureBlockTitle2: the best in Eugene (according to the locals we asked). Afterward
FeaturedActivityTitle1: a 60-minute visit to Threshold Fitness was just what to doctor ordered to get the blood flowing and burn a few calories before checking into charming B&B <a href=\"http://ovaldoor.com\">The Oval Door
FeaturedActivityTitle2: which serves a customizable vegan breakfast each morning that for us included brûléed citrus
DisplayPartnerColumns: and tofu scrambles. After a restful afternoon
PartnerCityTitle: we started our night at Oregon Wine LAB for Pinot Bingo featuring trivia and vegan wines (the red ones are vegan). After getting a buzz
YoutubeVideoID: we walked 20 minutes (five minutes if you’re in a cab) to Cornbread Cafe for vegan takes on comfort food classics such as chicken fried seitan and a French dip sandwich. After dinner
VideoTitle1: we tried some of Eugene’s handcrafted cider at Wild Craft Cider Works
VideoTitle2: where flavors range from wild plum and elderberry to cherry and wild rose. All are vegan-friendly
MetaDescription:
and a late-night bar menu always includes a vegan option.

 


Day 2

We hit Oregon Route 99 for a day of wine tasting in scenic Corvallis
SEOStatus: family-owned Tyee Wine Cellars serves sophisticated
ProposedHeaderText: old world -style Pinots and Chardonnay. Our tasting began with a lovely Pinot Gris
ProposedBrowserTitle: followed by an unoaked Chardonnay whose minerality and notes of vanilla and tropical fruit will convert any Chardonnay nay-sayer. As much as we enjoyed the Chardonnay
ProposedMetaDescription: the award-winning 2014 Estate Pinot Noir and its premium cousin Estate Barrel Select were our faves from the visit. We came to taste and take in the sprawling property (and get in a few snuggles with the resident winery dog) and ended up leaving with a case of wine.
SEOPaidBanner:
https://wvva.objects.liquidweb.services/photos/1053-bethelheights_salem-600x400-thumb.jpg 300w\">


A stop in Salem for salad
SEOPaidSocial: kombucha and a hearty veggie burger at Venti’s Cafe is an excellent place to fill up on the road. After lunch
ContentType: we continued onto Bethel Heights Winery for vegan wines in posh digs (Flat Block Pino and rosé are our faves) and to Willamette Valley Vineyards for the most sweeping views of the valley floor… and more Pinot. We were on a Pinot mission
CreationDate: so we skipped the whites and went straight for the 2016 Whole Cluster and 2015 Estate Pinot Noirs. Both were textbook expressions of Willamette Pinot full of bing cherry and baking spice. We ended our day at vegan eatery/music venue The Space Concert Club to soak up all that wine with a burrito bowl and tofu satay. At night
AuthorUserID: a bicycle-themed inn with a vegan-friendly breakfast spread featuring oatmeal with a fixin’s buffet
IncludeInWidgets:
and coffee.

 

 



Day 3

We headed north to Chehalem Valley to sample some award-winning wines that just so happen to be vegan. Domaine Serene offers tastings outdoors with nearly 360-degree views of nearly all of the Willamette appellations. From there
DataFinds: we visited Beaux Frères for amazingly delicate Pinot from a winemaker who utilizes clean fermentation and indigenous yeast. Our last tasting was at Duck Pond Cellars
TopLanding: a winery previously known for more commercial styles
TopPageview: but new winemaker Trevor Chlanda is upending the brand’s status quo by creating a new generation of wines focused on texture and great aromatics to best represent the vineyards from where they come. We needed some food after all that wine
MicrositeID: which is why we stopped at The Allison Inn & Spa
AuditTransferPage: Willamette Valley’s best-known and longest-standing luxury hotel. The on-site fine-dining restaurant JORY serves produce-driven Pacific Northwest fare overlooking the area. The kitchen team is happy to accommodate any dietary restriction with notice
AuditRefreshPage: and for us whipped up a lovely vegan scramble. After lunch
AuditTransferNotes: we drove to Portland for more food (and more wine)
AuditNavChange: stopping at vegan casual hotspot Harlow for the Hawthorne Mac—made with quinoa pasta—on our last night before heading to the airport. Instead of one last glass of vino
column59:
so we paired the Hawthorne Mac with local Soma kombucha.

 

Find more great Vegan travel ideas on Well+Away

"
column86: Find vegan restaurants and wineries from Portland to Eugene. There are numerous vegan options for travelers in Oregon.

PageDesc: Tales on the Northern Willamette Wine Trails
NavButtonText: Tales on the Northern Willamette Wine Trails
BrowserTitle: Tales on the Northern Willamette Wine Trails
HeaderText: Tales on the Northern Willamette Wine Trails
ContentText:
Written by Miki Finnin and Elizabeth Camp of The Vineyard Trail

 

The Willamette Valley is a heavenly place in the Northwest with majestic mountain ranges that frame a valley of rolling green hills and vineyards scattered in all directions. With more than 500 wineries in this AVA (American Viticultural Area)
PageType:
the Valley offers more than enough variety for wine lovers. 

Take a wine trail in the northern portion of the Valley and you will be hard pressed to find a winery that does not have at least one Pinot Noir on its tasting menu. In fact
PageLevel: it may be the only varietal they produce. Still
ParentPage:
but to a smaller volume.

With favorable climate and unique soil types
Status: it is no wonder that Oregon Pinot Noir has reached world-class status. Another grape that does well in this naturally cool climate is Chardonnay. Expressing flavors such as apple
HideFromNav: and with only a modicum of oak aging
DisplayListings: the Willamette Valley is on a good trajectory for making respected and sought-after Chardonnays
AccountCatIDForListings:
as well. 

Like the variety of wines available in the Willamette Valley
SortOrder: where Pinot Noir is considered king
FeatureChildPages:
it’s the variety of stories behind the wineries themselves that might be most surprising.

As co-owners of The Vineyard Trail
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: a company focused on bringing wine lovers and wineries together in the tasting room
DisplayArticles: we were lucky enough to be invited to visit this special wine growing region
PageLogo: and to have the opportunity to sit and talk with the owners
FeatureBlockTitle1:
winemakers and staff at a number of Willamette Valley vineyards and wineries; these are some of their stories.

Photo courtesy of Erin Lynch

Ghost Hill Cellars 12220 NE Bayliss Rd
FeaturedActivityTitle2:
503-852-7347

If you happen to be traveling through the Yamhill-Carlton AVA and you feel the hairs on the back of your neck stand on end
PartnerTitle: it is possible that you may have some unexpected company.  It just might be that you have been joined by the long-time legend of Ghost Hill
PartnerText: a ghostly gold miner from the late 1800's who
YoutubeVideoID:
leaving only their carcasses and an empty bag of gold. Some folks say that he continues to wander the hill searching for his stolen fortune and the men who took his life so long ago. 

Sharing the land are Michael and Drenda Bayliss
VideoTitle1: owners of Ghost Hill Cellars. Their 234 rolling acres have been in Michael's family since 1906 and have been farmed throughout the years with wheat
ProposedBrowserTitle: now grapes. Michael and Drenda now focus on Pinot Noir and produce four different offerings
SEOPaidSocial:
Pinot Noir Blanc. 

Keeping with the ghostly legend
ContentType: they have built a charming and fun open-air tasting room modeled to resemble a miner's shack. While we didn’t see any ghosts ourselves
CreationDate:
we can only imagine that Michael and Drenda are expecting company - company of the ghost-like fashion.

 

 

Alloro Vineyard 22075 SW Lebeau Road
DataFinds: with 33 acres of vines comprising Chardonnay
MicrositeID: the vines are tended to in an Old World style
AuditTransferPage:
employing a holistic approach to farming. 

David Nemarnik
AuditTransferNotes: follows the long-time heritage of sustainability and biodiversity by raising chicken
column59: and very soon to be added
column60: pigs. He grows hay for the livestock and uses their manure for fertilizing the vines. The sheep help manage the growth of the cover crop
column61:
and the multiple kinds of produce farmed on the land are used as sustenance on a daily basis. 

The commitment to this farming philosophy is not completely surprising seeing as David spent much of his youth visiting his relatives in Italy and Croatia surrounded by their old-world style of living
column62: which has continued from generation to generation. David also spent many years working with his family to grow a successful produce company and was taught to enjoy each meal at a respectful pace
column63:
and always indulge in a glass of wine and good conversation.

But David is not completely entrenched in the Old World. He employs New World technology such as electricity generating solar panels that produce 100% of the estate's energy needs and enough surplus to supply the rest of the grid.

And
column65: David and Alloro bring his family’s values to the people with their Whole Farm Dinner
column66: for which they use produce and meat directly from the farm
column67:
prepared by a local chef to celebrate the success of the harvest. This event is highly awaited and sells out quickly each year. 

Now that is a community! And all of this in the name of family and great wine!

 

 

Lenné Estate 18760 NE Laughlin Road
column70:
03-956-2256

Have you ever known a good thing immediately when you saw it? Well
column71: Steve Lutz sure did when he first saw the property that is now home to Lenné Estate. Steve
column73: stumbled across the land – which wasn't even for sale at the time – and within an hour was drawing up a contract for the sale. Steve claims that it is the "worst soil ever" in which to grow grapes and says that
column75: he is the luckiest grape grower in the world. The hill is steep and the soil is nutrient poor
column76: yet somehow his Pinot Noir vines seem to thrive in their new home
column77:
producing small clusters and berries that showcase a hint of mocha flavor. 

In reality
column78: their home is not all that new as the vines were actually planted in 2001. During our sit-down with Steve
column79: he happily retold his story of the vineyard’s trials
column80: tribulations and successes over the past 16 years. With a smile and a chuckle
column81: he started off by saying that you have to be either stupid or have a lot of guts to get into the winery business
column84: that year after year they were “burning through money” because the soil was so difficult to get the vines to grow in. In fact
column86: they lost an entire block of newly planted vines and were very close to calling it quits. But once again
column88:
Steve replanted and tried again.

Holding their breath seemed to be an everyday occurrence for the Lutzes. It wasn’t until Steve tasted his 2004 vintage
column89: the first fruit of his labor
column90:
for the first time that he felt comfortable breathing normally again. He recalled going home to his wife and happily telling her that she need no longer worry because he had just tasted their first vintage and they were going to be just fine. 

“I knew what we had in the site
column91: but when I tasted that first sip and it tasted like a chocolate covered black cherry
column92: I just knew what we had
column94: Steve has come into his own in the Oregon Pinot Noir market. The Lenné Estate tasting menu includes five different examples of this finicky grape
column96:
all of which have scored 91 or better from either Wine Enthusiast or Wine Spectator.

 

 

Adelsheim 16800 NE Calkins Lane
column101: with the fictitious characters of The Ghost of Christmas Past
column105: founder and co-owner of Adelsheim Vineyard
column106: could easily be called "The Father of Wineries Past
column108: and Future".  When it comes to the Oregon wine industry
column109: David is one of the original pioneers. And we were lucky enough to sit and talk with him
column110: over a glass of his own wine
column112:
how it was started and where he sees it in the future.

Back in 1971
column113: at a time when Oregon was not yet proven as a bonafide viticultural area
column116: purchased 19 acres of land in the Chehalem Mountains near Newberg
column117: with the intent of trying their hand at growing grapes and making wine. According to David
column118: it really wasn't about making a living at that point
column119: but more about moving to the country and finding something to do that he was interested in – the typical late 1960's
column121:
attitude of "just being free and being me". 

With advice from Dick Erath
column122: who was also a rebel of the times having just planted his vines 3 years earlier
column123: they began looking for land with a southerly slope and Jory soil. Once found
column124:
in the ground the grape vines went. 

David reflected
column125:
saying that they would collaborate with these other pioneers (there were a total of ten of them at the time) about making "great wine". 

"We talked very idealistically at the time and yet we had no idea what we were talking about!” he said. “We couldn't possibly have known what would come out 30
column128:
was he ever right!

The year 1978 saw the first release of Adelsheim wines
column130: Ginny and the crew have been going strong ever since
column131:
as has the Oregon wine market which they helped to create.

 

 

Vidon Vineyard 17425 NE Hillside Drive • Newberg
column133:
(503)538-4092

Engineer and NASA physicist Don Hagge began his journey into the world of vineyards 16 years ago
column135: at the ripe young age of 69
column136: he purchased his land in the Chehalem Mountains. That land has become Vidon Vineyard
column137:
but Don’s legacy is as much built as it is grown. 

Don
column138: an engineer and physicist turned vineyard owner and inventor
column139: cleared the land and planted 12.5 acres of vines including varietals of Chardonnay
column145:
several clones of Pinot Noir. But he didn’t stop there. 

As he saw the need
column146:
Don went on to improve the processes by which he creates his vino masterpieces. 

Don employs only glass stoppers for his bottles
column147: saying that it makes no sense to use a closure (cork) that has the opportunity to allow spoilage of the wine. With the decision to use only glass stoppers
column148: Don saw the need to improve the inefficient method by which they must be inserted – by hand. Determined
column149: Don designed and manufactured a bottling line specific for his production space that allows for machine insertion
column152: in an effort to improve wine preservation and dispensing
column153:
Don designed and built one such machine that utilizes argon gas to keep the wine fresh for up to two weeks. 

Engineer
column156: "You don't have to be a rocket scientist to make good wine
column157:
but it doesn't hurt if you are!" 

 

Youngberg Hill 10660 SW Youngberg Hill Road
column161: we introduce you to Wayne Bailey
column162: owner and vintner of Youngberg Hill
column163:
whose philosophy and practice is simple – to stay out of Mother Nature’s way and allow her to nurture the grapes naturally so they reflect where they were grown and the weather of the season. 

Wayne takes this philosophy even further
column164: implementing the same simplistic attitude into Youngberg Hill’s on-site bed and breakfast and event center. The property offers breathtaking views of the coastal range and the Willamette Valley
column166:
and freshly hand-crafted breakfasts that are organic in every fashion. 

But the true embodiment of the spirit of Youngberg Hills is Wayne and his wife
column167: Nicolette. They are some of the most down to earth folks we have ever met. They exude this "Welcome to our family" feeling which
column169:
made us feel right at home. We learned during our visit that this is very intentional. 

Wayne and Nicolette are all about family. Wayne
column170: having grown up on a farm in Iowa
column171: was raised with strong family values and a love of the land. Now he and Nicolette are doing the same for their children and strive to leave them the same legacy. They do this by applying organic and biodynamic farming to every aspect of their farm
column172: from the vineyards to the livestock to the landscape
column173:
so that their daughters can enjoy the land for years to come. And their dedication to a "hands off" approach definitely shines through in their wines. 

With a particular focus on Pinot Noir
column174: and now with the addition of Chardonnay added to their vineyards and tasting room
column175: along with one selection of Pinot Gris
column176: Wayne brings the flavors of the different soils of Youngberg Hill to the bottle and the glass. At this tasting room
column177:
make sure to take your glass out on the veranda and enjoy the 360-degree scenery that surrounds you. 

As you can see
column179: you’ll be sure to find something that you fall in love with in the Willamette Valley. When you visit
column180: be sure to take your time
column181: and to be inquisitive of the wine

BrowserTitle: Industry Resources
ContentText:
The Willamette Valley Visitors Association Background and Structure  

WVVA was founded as a collaborative regional organization made up of six sub-regional organizations. WVVA's members have been a successful team for over twenty-seven years
PageType:
and have supported each other’s individual organizations while concurrently working as a cooperative to successfully adopt structural additions like Travel Oregon's Regional Cooperative Tourism Program and the Oregon Wine Country License Plate program. The six entities that comprise WVVA are represented by members of a Board of Directors and Public Relations and Marketing team.







_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________


Each serve in the following capacities:

BrowserTitle: Grant Application
ContentText: The Fall 2018 Willamette Valley Visitors Association (WVVA) grant cycle has been awarded. See the recipients here. The WVVA cycle will occur annually each fall. To be notified of the next grant cycle
PageType:
sign up for our industry newsletter. Travel Oregon's competitive small grant cycle closed in June. Click to find our more about Travel Oregon's competitive grant program.

The competitive grants are funded by the Regional Cooperative Tourism Program created by Travel Oregon due to HB4146 requiring Travel Oregon to invest 20% of the statewide lodging tax in Oregon’s seven designated tourism regions. WVVA serves as the designated marketing organization for the Willamette Valley Region. 


Questions about grant guidelines
PageSectionID: or process can go to Tori Middelstadt
ParentPage:
grants@oregonwinecountry.org.

BrowserTitle: Grant Application Files
ContentText:
How to attach required documents:

  1. Click "Add Files"
  2. Select files to attach to your application
    • (Required for application: budget template, timeline, three letters of support. Signage projects require additional documents which are listed in the grant guidelines.)
  3. Click "Start Upload"
  4. Wait for all files to say 100% in status bar
  5. Click "Submit Application"

NOTE: You cannot return to the previous page. If you hit the back button
PageType:
you will lose all work on the application form.

PageDesc: Find an Ornament in the Willamette National Forest this hiking Season
NavButtonText: Find an Ornament in the Willamette National Forest
BrowserTitle: US Capitol Christmas Tree
HeaderText: Explore the Willamette National Forest and find your Ornament
ContentText:
In celebration of the 2018 U.S. Capitol Christmas tree, we hosted an ornament hunt in the Willamette National Forest to inspire and increase outdoor recreation, and connect you to these beautiful public lands.

Two hundred glass ornaments were hidden along non-wilderness trails on the Willamette National Forest for lucky adventurers like you to find! 

Our official contest is closed, but you can learn more about the Oregon's Capitol Christmas tree here
PageType: and even make your own ornament or attend an event being held for the traveling tree." Learn more about all the events.
PageSectionID: the beautiful Willamette National Forest is home to 8 wilderness areas – including the popular Three Sisters and Mt. Jefferson Wildernesses – and has over 1
ParentPage: 700 miles of trails for hiking
InsertCode: mountain biking and horseback riding. The varied landscapes of the high mountains
HideFromNav: narrow canyons and cascading streams offer visitors excellent opportunities to play and explore. We encourage people to use the #FindYourTrail as they explore trails and other areas of their local National Forest.
DisplayListings:
sans-serif;'>The US Forest Service #ItsAllYours campaign will be used to encourage trail exploration and stewardship


About the Willamette National Forest
AccountCatIDForListings:
Oregon
With more than 1.5 million acres
SortOrder: the beautiful Willamette National Forest is home to eight wilderness areas – including the popular Three Sisters and Mt. Jefferson Wildernesses—and has over 1
DisplayArticles: mountain biking and horseback riding. The varied landscapes of the high mountains
PageLogo: coastal rainforests
FeatureBlockTitle2:
and cascading streams offer visitors excellent opportunities to play and explore. Get out there and explore and use the #FindYourTrail hashtag to document and showcase your journey.

 

Find your Trail #FindYourTrail 

The theme for the 2018 Capitol Christmas Tree is “Find Your Trail!” in recognition of two 2018 anniversaries: the 50th anniversary of the National Trails Systems Act
FeaturedActivityTitle1: and the 175th commemoration of the Oregon Trail. There is a rich history of Oregon’s forests providing for the needs of Oregonians. The Willamette National Forest provides recreational opportunities
MetaDescription:
take only pictures and memories from your adventures on the Willamette National Forest.  

With so many ways to explore the Willamette National Forest this season we want to remind you to always be safe and responsible. If you pack it in
SEOTags:
please pack it out. Know before you go by reading these guidelines to Fire Prevention and Leave No Trace.  Don't forget to share your adventures with us! Use hashtags #FindYourTrail#USCapitolChristmasTree and #ItsAllYours 

 If you would like more information about the Capitol Christmas Tree project please email: capitolchristmastree2018@gmail.com

"

NavButtonText: Visit Oregon Wine Country at the Portland - Over
BrowserTitle: PDX airport
HeaderText: Oregon Wine Country comes to the Eugene Airport
ContentText:
Going somewhere? From May 15th – August 7th 2018 get to PDX a wee bit early so you can stop by Alaskan Airlines Terminal C and check out what Oregon Wine Country has to offer for your next trip. Explore Oregon Wine Country, enter to win a free five-night adventure trip through the Willamette Valley, plus taste a bit of Oregon wine before or after your next flight. 

The Willamette Valley Visitors Association relaunched our award-winning Oregon Wine Country experience
PageLevel: ” at the Portland International Airport on May 15th. The creative and impactful display promises to educate
PageSectionID: inspire and entertain travelers on the go
ParentPage:
and offers a chance to win a five-night adventure package through the Willamette Valley.

A massive Pinot noir wine bottle containing a world of miniatures will entice travelers to take a closer look at what Oregon Wine Country has to offer and inspire their next trip. Peek inside the bottle to become immersed in a world of wine unlike any other. First sown by free-thinkers in the 1960s and 1970s
Status: the finicky Pinot noir grape flourished in the Willamette Valley despite conventional wisdom
InsertCode: and now more than 500 wineries call it home. Wine varietals
IssuuCode: topography and soil types are highlighted in the display
HideFromNav: but travelers will also be delighted by details such as lush landscapes
AccountCatIDForListings: small towns
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
recreation and more.

Willamette Valley wines will be poured at eight locations throughout the airport between 11:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. on Friday
DisplayArticles:
May 18th. Various tastings of Willamette Valley wines will also be offered throughout the 12-week exhibit. 

“We welcome visitors to the Willamette Valley
PageLogo: home to Oregon Wine Country
FeatureBlockTitle1: and hope they savor every minute they are here
FeaturedActivityTitle1: Board President of the Willamette Valley Visitors Association
FeaturedActivityTitle2: a non-profit organization that supports travel and tourism in Oregon Wine Country. “Savor the tastes
PartnerTitle: views and fragrances that make the Willamette Valley a ‘not to miss’ experience. Our ‘Slice of Oregon’ Pinot noir bottle welcomes visitors as soon as they arrive
PartnerText:
showcasing Oregon Wine Country and all it has to offer.”


"

BrowserTitle: Spring 2018 Grant Recipients
PageType: sans-serif;'>The Willamette Valley Visitor Association (WVVA) is excited to announce that 13 projects have been awarded grants through the Regional Cooperative Tourism Program totaling $84
PageLevel: 711. Funded through state-wide transient occupancy lodging tax funds collected in the Willamette Valley
PageSectionID: the matching grants are competitive grants that work to improve local communities with investments in wayfinding signage
ParentPage: marketing collateral and off/shoulder season tourism product. These projects will enhance the visitor experience throughout the valley solidifying the Willamette Valley as a premier year-round travel destination.
InsertCode: sans-serif;'>The grant awardees and their projects are:
IssuuCode: sans-serif;'>
HideFromNav: sans-serif;'>Eola-Amity Hills American Viticultural Area (AVA)
DisplayListings: sans-serif;'> will be producing a promotional video series highlighting the many fun ways visitors can travel to the AVA to taste wine
AccountCatIDForListings: cellar season tasting as well as the other great stops within their AVA’s wine country.
FeatureChildPages: sans-serif;'> (aka North Santiam Canyon Economic Development Corporation) will be hosting an outdoor recreational showcase called River Fusion 22 highlighting the variety of outdoor activities the North Santiam Canyon has to offer along Hwy 22.
DisplayArticles: sans-serif;'> Tourism Committee will be hiring a newly created staff position focused on destination development in the region. This position is a transition from hosting a Resource Assistance for Rural Environments (RARE) temporary person.
PageLogo: sans-serif;'>City of Harrisburg
FeatureBlockTitle1: sans-serif;'> will be the new home for the Pacific Northwest Marathon
FeatureBlockTitle2: half marathon 5k and Health and Fitness expo in September 2018.
FeaturedActivityTitle2: sans-serif;'> will host Hands on Harvest tours to give wine enthusiasts a hands on
PartnerTitle: behind the scenes harvest season experience within their AVA from September to October 2018.
DisplayPartnerColumns: sans-serif;'> will be reinventing the Hops and Heritage festival focusing on a downtown main street block party to celebrate Independence’s hop growing history.
PartnerCityTitle: sans-serif;'>Gilbert House Children’s Museum
YoutubeVideoID: sans-serif;'> will be refreshing their website with SEO analytics and implementing training to increase website traffic.
VideoTitle2: sans-serif;'> will be producing a new brochure
SEOTags: and mailers and an exhibit display for their consumer tradeshow booth.
SEOStatus: sans-serif;'> will be creating and installing a unified brand of wayfinding signage to make navigating the multiple museums on the property easier for visitors.
ProposedBrowserTitle: sans-serif;'> will update their website and incorporating a rebrand for their 100-year celebration.
SEOPaidSearch: sans-serif;'> will be starting a new annual event on its main street to celebrate its rich culture
SEOPaidBanner: nature and history. Playing off the OSU vs UO rivalry
SEOPaidSocial: there will be a rivalry themed 5k ending at the downtown festival.
CreationDate: sans-serif;'> will be reimagining and expanding the current Solar System Trail in Eugene creating unified signage and upkeep of this 3.7-mile trail.
AuthorUserID:
sans-serif;'> will be installing wayfinding signage to encourage visitor and local traffic to get off the highway and explore Canby’s historic and rich downtown.

HeaderText: An In-ciderâ€™s Guide to the Willamette Valley
ContentText: Craft Cider
PageType: once deeply rooted in American tradition
PageLevel: is not only giving Oregon’s wine industry and craft beer scene a run for its money
PageSectionID: it’s also creating new traditions right here in the Willamette Valley. As the leaves change color and the weather grows crisper
ParentPage:
celebrate the season with a glass of handcrafted hard cider at these up-and-coming Willamette Valley cideries.

1859 Cider Co - 249 Liberty St NE #140
InsertCode:
OR

Located in an alleyway in downtown Salem
IssuuCode: you’ll find 1859 Cider Co.’s industrial styled taproom
HideFromNav: where gleaming stainless-steel barrels of fermenting cider sit against the back wall. 1859 pays homage to Oregon tradition in a number of ways
DisplayListings: not only through their name but also by locally sourcing all their ingredients just a stone’s throw from their taproom doors. Their flagship cider
AccountCatIDForListings: aptly named Statehood
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: and an easy drinker for those new to the cider scene. Their Chemeketan Pear is a very tasty semi-sweet pear flavored cider - a perfect choice for those who want to branch away from apples. Also
PageLogo:
made from juicy heirloom cherries grown by 6th generation farmers just outside of Salem.  

2 Towns Cider House - 33930 SE Eastgate Cir
FeatureBlockTitle2:
OR

As one of the most widely distributed ciders hailing from the Willamette Valley
FeaturedActivityTitle1: 2 Towns has grand ambitions but still remains committed to quality with “no shortcuts.” While their flagship Brightcider is more conventional in flavor
FeaturedActivityTitle2: some of their other popular ciders are a bit more adventurous yet just as delicious. Take the Unfiltered Pacific Pineapple
PartnerTitle: or the Ginga Ninja - though these are highly original with very modern flavors
PartnerText:
they are developed with traditional methods.

The taproom is located off Highway 34 just before Corvallis
DisplayPartnerColumns: and is an excellent place to meet with friends for a game of pool or a round of pinball. And don’t forget to check out the quirky vending machine in back
VideoTitle1:
and... well you’ll just have to see for yourself!  

Carlton Cyderworks - 1036 NE Baker St
MetaDescription:
OR

Carlton Cyderworks brings business very close to home as they are a family owned and operated cidery dedicated to making traditional English-style cider from apples grown exclusively in their orchards. Some of their flagships include a whiskey barrel aged cider named Slake
SeoNotes: an easy drinking semi-dry cider made from apples grown in Dundee. They also make batches of Estate Ciders
ProposedHeaderText: which exclusively features the apples of a single orchard by the same name. Their tasting room in McMinnville not only showcases their ciders
ProposedBrowserTitle: but it functions as a tap station with 36 rotating beers
ProposedMetaDescription: soda and kombucha. Carlton Cyderworks also holds on to tradition by their dedication to transparency in their ingredients. While most ciders don’t list on the bottle the specific amount and type of apples used for each batch
SEOPaidSearch: you’ll find just such a list on every bottle
SEOPaidBanner:
so you always know exactly what you’re drinking.  

Wildcraft Cider Works  - 232 Lincoln St
ContentType:
OR 97401

WildCraft Cider Works is devoted to developing innovative
CreationDate: artisanal dry ciders inspired by traditional and wild methodology. Using whole fruit and botanicals grown in Oregon
PublishDate: guaranteeing a uniquely dry cider full of rich
ExpirationDate:
earthy and floral flavors of Oregon.

E.Z. Orchards- 5504 Hazelgreen Rd NE
DataFinds:
OR 

Salem’s E.Z. Orchards has farmed Roman Beauty apples in the center of the Willamette Valley since the 1920s. In 2000
TopLanding: proprietor Kevin Zielinski and his family planted French
TopPageview: English and heritage American apple varieties. Their fruit produces nuanced
MicrositeID: sophisticated French-style cidre as well as American cider. “Like a wine made with great grapes
AuditTransferPage: his products are worth every penny
AuditRefreshPage:
” says McGrath.


Upcoming Cider Events this Fall

Cider Pressing at Thompson’s Mill - September 21st and October 26th
AuditTransferNotes:
11 a.m. to 3:00 p.m.

Learn a bit about the last water powered mill left in Oregon at Thompson’s Mills Oregon Heritage Site. Admission is free; donations accepted per gallon of cider. 

Harvest Fest  -  September 28th - October 31st

October is Harvestfest month at E.Z. Orchards. Started in 1996 as a way to bring people into closer contact with the fields
AuditNavChange: orchards and animals of E.Z. Orchards
column58:
we are still providing that “real contact” with the farm. Through the years we have added more and more features to our farm for you to experience.

McKenzie Beer and Cider Festival -  November 8th - 9th

If you’re a cider lover
column59: be sure to check out the 7th annual McKenzie Cider and Craft Beer Festival in Springfield
column60: Oregon on Friday and Saturday Nov 9-10th 2018. Featuring over 150 ciders and beers to try
column61: all proceeds go towards helping youth within Lane County. Besides drinking delicious cider
column62: there is a packed schedule full of cider-brewing classes
column63:
activities for kids and live music. So bring the family and drink a hard cider for a good cause.


Additional reporting by Autumn Kraxberger

BrowserTitle: The Willamette Valley Celebrates Wine Cellar Season
ContentText: It's the coziest time of year in Oregon Wine Country. Cool
PageType:
misty weather brings us indoors to the warmth of intimate tasting rooms where we can enjoy that first taste of the new vintage. Share the moment with talented winemakers who finally catch their breath and embrace the calm of this special season.

Visitors are treated to open country roads
PageLevel: quiet tasting rooms and casual one-on-one time with winemakers. The holiday rush gives way to irresistible fireplaces and mellow cellars where just-barreled wines come of age. There’s a quiet and contagious energy to the Cellar Season
PageSectionID: from the neatly-pruned vineyard rows and moody sunsets to the newly invigorated winemaking community
ParentPage:
fresh off another outstanding vintage.

Make the most of Cellar Season with a glass of Pinot noir at one of the Valley’s inviting tasting rooms and then stay at one of our cozy B&Bs or boutique hotels. Plan your trip and customize your perfect wine country visit.




Before you go:

  • Call ahead — During winter
Status: many wineries hold different hours of business. It’s often a good idea to call ahead to confirm. With fewer options
IssuuCode:
so advance reservations are key
  • Visit TripCheck.com — With the valley’s varied elevations and topography
HideFromNav: road conditions can change in a single drive. Be sure to check ahead to ensure the route is clear
DisplayListings: and avoid setting out in inclement weather"
PageLogo: NULL
SEOPaidSocial: In the winter the Willamette Valley celebrates by slowing down and embracing the warm and cozy Cellar Season. It is the perfect time to meet the Oregon Wine makers and get the inside scoop on the inner workings of Willamette Valley Wineries. Start planning your winter Oregon Wine Country vacation.

PageDesc: Start a Willamette Valley Tradition this Holiday Season
HeaderText: Start a Willamette Valley Tradition this Holiday Season
ContentText:
We all get the warm-and-fuzzies when thinking about a new way to celebrate the holiday season. If your Northwest holiday could use a little freshening up, look no further than these five indoor and outdoor opportunities in the Willamette Valley. Once you discover the magic of the holidays in Oregon Wine Country you'll be back to celebrate year after year.

Choose the Perfect Tree & Stay at a Tree Farm in Corvallis

Originally a family-owned apple orchard
PageType: The Donovan Tree Farm was converted to a Christmas tree farm. While there's still a small selection of apple trees on the property
PageLevel: you'll likely be picking a Norwegian Spruce
ParentPage: stop into the pottery studio and display room located on the tree farm and discover the collection of porcelain mugs
Status: bowls and vases by artist and owner
InsertCode:
Dale Donovan.

Pre-cut and U-cut trees are available from early November to Christmas Eve. The tree farm is dog friendly and free cocoa and candy canes are available in the pottery studio.

Looking to stay and play a while? Donovan's also offers a farmhouse and a contemporary flat for vacation rentals. A stay during the tree-hunting season includes a free pottery lesson by Dale himself and tree to take home.

Donovan Tree Farm 

Hours: Monday-Friday
AccountCatIDForListings:
OR 97333

Phone: (541) 753-0533



Skate
FeatureChildPages:
a seasonal outdoor ice skating rink

Returning to Salem's Riverfront park for a second season starting mid-November
DisplayArticles: 400 square-foot rink is completely tented and includes a snack shop
PageLogo:
skate rentals (or bring your own) and fun props for picture taking and creating holiday memories. 

The rink will be open daily
FeatureBlockTitle2: from November 17 through January 21. Before or after your skate session
FeaturedActivityTitle1: take a spin on Salem’s Riverfront Carousel or check out the Gilbert House Children’s Museum – both located in the park and within easy walking distance of the ice rink. Just two blocks east of the park
PartnerTitle: locally-sourced dishes at hip downtown Salem spots like Venti’s Café and Basil & Board – a newly opened urban pizzeria featuring a wide array of local beer
PartnerText:
wine and craft cocktails. 

For more Information on Salem on Ice call 503-602-4760
or email SalemOnIce@gmail.com

Book a private skating party this holiday or gift a season pass

Find more holiday tradition ideas in the Salem area. 




Shop and celebrate at Eugene’s Holiday Market 

Looking for the perfect gifts for loved-ones while in the Eugene area? The Holiday Market is home to over 250 vendors of unique hand-crafted goods on weekends from November through Christmas Eve.

Live music and entertainment keep the space filled with cheer as you wander the market. Bring the whole family and enjoy the special entertainment for kids every morning at 10:30 a.m. With many booths and rotating performances
DisplayPartnerColumns:
you might just find yourself here all day. The market also hosts an International food court full of delicious options that will keep you fueled all day long.

Where: Lane Events Center
YoutubeVideoID:
Oregon

Hours: 10am-6pm (closing at 4pm on Dec 24th)

Find more holiday tradition ideas in the Eugene area.
VideoTitle1: sans-serif; font-size: 18px;\">Brighten up your Holiday in Corvallis
VideoTitle2: sans-serif;'>Nothing puts you in the holiday mood like a trip to the
SEOTags: sans-serif;'> in Corvallis. Load the family up in the car on a cold winter evening
SeoNotes: take a quick spin through your favorite local coffee shop (like Dutch Brothers or Coffee Culture) for hot chocolate
SEOStatus: and head out to the Benton County Fairgrounds.
ProposedBrowserTitle: you and your family can enjoy a slow drive through a sea of holiday lights while enjoying Christmas music and more than 250 handcrafted
ProposedMetaDescription: hand-painted figures and festive mechanized scenes.
SEOPaidSocial: sans-serif;'> has been a Christmas tradition in Corvallis since 1981. The Light Display was founded by Mario and Alma Pastega
ContentType: and originally housed at their Pepsi Cola Bottling Plant. After Mario Pastega's passing in 2012
CreationDate:
the Light Display was moved to the Fairgrounds and is now kept up by a small army of enthusiastic volunteers.

Nov. 24th - Dec. 31st
The Benton County Fairgrounds
110 SW 53rd St
PublishDate:
sans-serif;'> 

Admission is free but guests are encouraged to bring along canned food donations for those in need in our local communities


Find more holiday tradition ideas in the Corvallis area.



Experience the magic of the Nutcracker

Grab the family and get to one of the “do-not-miss” events of the holiday season: Newberg
IncludeInWidgets: presented by Chehalem Valley Dance Academy (CVDA). Newberg
DataFinds: known as the "Gateway to Oregon’s Wine Country"
TopLanding: is proud to have an fantastic team of young performers right in their backyard who put on a fantastic Nutcracker performance year after year that supports local charitable efforts right here in the local community. Ticket sales have allowed them to donate $95
TopPageview: 000 to local charities over the last seven years. This year
AuditTransferNotes:
and A Family Place Relief Nursery. 

Performances at the Newberg High School Auditorium







"

family and the completion of harvest.
