BrowserTitle: Willamette Valley Scenic Byways
ContentText:
Hit the Willamette Valley Byways 

Did you know Oregon has more National Scenic Byways
PageType:
All-American Roads and State Tour Routes than any other state in the nation? 

Spanning more than 3
ParentPage:
roads and routes cover six distinct landscapes and include numerous historical and cultural landmarks—so many inspirational story nuggets to experience along the way.

The Willamette Valley designated three new Scenic Byways
Status: all of which are beautiful trips to take year-round
InsertCode:
this year. So get out there and explore one - or all - of these byways this season.

  • McKenzie River Scenic Byway
  • Marys Peak to Pacific Scenic Byway
  • West Cascades Scenic Byway
  • Over the River and Through the Woods

Detroit Lake - photo by Lavi Nair

"
ProposedMetaDescription: Oregon has the most Scenic Byways, All-American Roads and State Tour Routes in the entire country. The Willamette Valley is home to the McKenzie Scenic Byway, Marys Peak to Pacific Scenic Byway, West Cascades Scenic Byway and Over The River and Through the Woods.

BrowserTitle: Fall 2018 Grant Recipients
PageType: sans-serif;'>SALEM OR – The Willamette Valley Visitor Association (WVVA) is excited to announce that nine projects have been awarded grants through the Regional Cooperative Tourism Program totaling $159
PageLevel: 495. Funded through state-wide transient occupancy lodging tax funds in the Willamette Valley
PageSectionID: the matching grants are competitive grants that work to improve local communities with investments in wayfinding signage
ParentPage: marketing collateral and off/shoulder season tourism product. These projects will enhance the visitor experience throughout the valley solidifying the Willamette Valley as a premier year-round travel destination.
Status: sans-serif;'>The grant awardees and their projects are:
IssuuCode: sans-serif;'> will be producing a promotional video and social media campaign for “Wake Up in Wine Country” to encourage visitors to not only visit the Newberg-Dundee area wine country
AccountCatIDForListings: sans-serif;'>Salem Main Street Association
SortOrder: sans-serif;'> will be creating downtown dining and parking maps/guides that can be distributed to visitors to make experiencing downtown Salem easier and more enjoyable.
FeatureChildPages: sans-serif;'>Willamette Valley Sustainable Foods Alliance
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: sans-serif;'> will be creating a marketing campaign in the Eugene airport for Willamette Grown and Crafted brand to build awareness in of the great locally grown food. This will be in addition to marketing the immediate experience visitors can embark on with the South Willamette Valley Food Trail.
DisplayArticles: sans-serif;'>City of Albany Parks and Recreation
PageLogo: sans-serif;'> will purchase portable pitching mounds the city needs to host competitive softball tournaments that would increase occupancy in local hotel rooms. Funds are also held to attend sports conference to market the new amenity to secure more business.
FeatureBlockTitle2: sans-serif;'> will be creating and installing up to four history panels at eight to 12 sites in the McKenzie River Area. Podcasts for each stop on the self-guided tour will also be created to accompany the historical interpretive signs.
FeaturedActivityTitle2: sans-serif;'> will create the 187 Miles of Wonder social media campaign with live social feeds on multi-day paddle trips with paddling influencers to highlight the many amenities along the Willamette Water Trail.
DisplayPartnerColumns: creating new messaging that ties the truffle to the Willamette Valley as a region with a Wine+Truffle messaging theme.
PartnerCityTitle: sans-serif;'>Shelton McMurphey Johnson House
YoutubeVideoID: sans-serif;'> will be producing a new brochure
VideoTitle1: for historic homes around the state of Oregon to allow the ease of cross promotion amongst historic homes in Oregon.
MetaDescription: sans-serif;'> will create a unified wayfinding signage brand for the Northwest Willamette Valley communities of Willimina
column61: The Willamette Valley Visitors Association awarded 9 projects grants totaling nearly 160,000 in fall of 2018.

BrowserTitle: Celebrate Oregon Wine Month In Oregon Wine Country
ContentText: Join us this May in celebrating our official statewide month of wine discovery and development. Oregon Wine Month begins May 1
PageType:
so it's time to start planning! 

You'll have exactly 31 days to sip and savor the best of Oregon's world-class wine right here in the Willamette Valley.


There's no shortage of parties or pours in Oregon this May. Right here in Oregon Wine Country you'll find every kind of wine event– from paddle trips to wine walks
PageLevel: sipping seminars to ballet at the bar. And because we know just how to party
PageSectionID: we end the month of May with a three-day wine fest at nearly every winery in the Valley with Memorial Day weekend open houses
ParentPage:
where practically every wine maker pops open the door and the cork for the summer season.




Did you know that Oregon wines fly free?

When you travel to Oregon Wine Country it's easy to take a taste of Oregon home with you
Status: thanks to the Oregon Wines Fly Free program offered by the Oregon Wine Board
InsertCode:
Travel Oregon and Alaska Airlines. If you’re not an Alaska Airlines mileage plan member you can sign up today for free. 

Learn more about the program and View Participating Wineries



"
PageLogo: x
ProposedMetaDescription: The entire month of May is dedicated to celebrating Oregon Wines. What better place to partake in the festivities that Oregon Wine Country. You will find wine makers and wine enthusiast drinking in the bounty of the Willamette Valley and showing off what Oregon Wine is all about.

BrowserTitle: Your Favorites From Willamette Valley Wine Country
MetaDescription: Build a list of your favorite spots to visit on your next trip to Oregon Wine Country.

HeaderText: Oregon is celebrating 10 years of beautiful bike routes
ContentText:
Since 2009, OPRD has designated 17 Scenic Bikeways throughout Oregon, covering 1,253 miles. The Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway is famous for being the first official Scenic Bikeway in U.S., but it's more than that. The bikeway follows its namesake river as it winds through the Willamette Valley, shaped by the Coast Range to the west and the towering Cascade Mountains to the east. Over its 134 miles you’ll come to know why this valley is one of the most productive agricultural regions in the country, but you’ll also understand the natural beauty that frames and imbues the valley. 

It's also your pathway to foodie heaven, taking you through Oregon Wine Country. As you cycle the route, you can feast at organic farm stands, sip craft beer at farm-based breweries, and dine at James Beard-nominated restaurants.


Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway:
Difficulty: Moderate | Length: 134 Miles

Wind your way through the bounty of Oregon on the Willamette Valley Scenic Bikeway
PageType:
the nation’s first scenic bikeway.

Best season: Year-round


Marche Restaurant
PageLevel: Eugene: Start your trip with a tasty meal in downtown Eugene. Marche offers classic farm-inspired cuisine from award-winning chef Stephanie Pearl Kimmel
PageSectionID:
all sourced from the farms surrounding the city.

Randy's Main Street Coffee
ParentPage: Brownsville: Stop and stretch your legs in historic Brownsville. Randy's is where the locals gather for coffee every morning
InsertCode:
soup and sandwiches until 3 each afternoon. Try the fresh bread baked in-house every morning by Randy himself.

Gathering Together Farm
IssuuCode:
Philomath. Detour slightly from the bikeway route for a totally-worth-it trip through Corvallis and out to Gathering Together Farms. Their on-site farm restaurant features an ever-changing menu based on what's growing in the fields. The daily fresh-baked doughnuts are divine.

Sybaris Bistro
HideFromNav: Albany. Chef Matt Bennett is a two-time James Beard-nominee. His ever-changing menu varies with whatever is fresh and locally available
DisplayListings: including wild-foraged ingredients. A meal at Sybaris is always a unique experience; after Matt has featured a dish once
AccountCatIDForListings:
he never repeats it.

Ankeny Vineyard
SortOrder: Salem. Munch on wood-fired pizza and chat with the winemaker here
FeatureChildPages:
while petting the friendly winery dog and enjoying views out over the Ankeny National Wildlife Refuge.

EZ Orchards
FeaturedOnSectionLanding: Salem. Taste Oregon's cider renaissance with a stop at EZ Orchards farm market. EZ Orchards grows their own apples and produces award-winning hard cider in the French style
DisplayArticles:
plus home-made doughnuts and fresh produce.

Arcane Cellars
PageLogo: Salem. Take the Wheatland Ferry across the Willamette River to Arcane Cellars. Enjoy a bocce court
FeaturedActivityTitle1:
private setting along the Willamette River.

The bikeway officially ends at Champoeg State Park. Cap off your journey at Lady Hill Winery to celebrate your vistory.

Explore all Oregon's Scenic Bikeways and learn more about the program on the Travel Oregon Scenic Bikeways webpage.


Safety Tips
Please be aware that the Bikeway information here is advisory only. You assume all risks as far as the quality and accuracy of the information; in other words
FeaturedActivityTitle2: you’re agreeing to use it at your own risk. Scenic Bikeway routes include roads with car and truck traffic
PartnerTitle: and are for cyclists that are comfortable riding in some amount of traffic. Cyclists must obey the rules of the road. For car-free riding
PartnerText:
check out the Banks-Vernonia State Trail on the Tualatin Valley Bikeway and the Row River Trail section of the Covered Bridges Bikeway.

A must-know: In Oregon
DisplayPartnerColumns:
a bicycle is legally considered a vehicle (and the same laws apply). Riding with the direction of traffic is the law; it’s also the best way to be seen by motorists.

To demonstrate the best riding etiquette and promote good relations with motorists
PartnerCityTitle: please ride single-file. Riding side-by-side is legal
YoutubeVideoID:
but only if doing so does not impede traffic. Be aware that many rural roads are used daily for commerce; there’s a good chance you’ll encounter large trucks carrying oversized loads.

Never forget about drivers’ blind spots — especially when the vehicle is turning right. If you’re going straight at an intersection with stopped vehicles
VideoTitle1: pull in behind the first stopped vehicle in the lane and wait your turn to go
VideoTitle2:
as if you were a motorist.

All bicycle riders in Oregon under 16 must wear a helmet.

For more information on riding safely and legally in Oregon
MetaDescription:
visit the Oregon Department of Transportation.

"

PageDesc: A three-day tour through Oregonâ€™s Cascade Range Mountains
NavButtonText: A three-day tour through Oregonâ€™s Cascade Range
HeaderText: A three-day tour through Oregonâ€™s Cascade Range Mountains
ContentText: Are you ready for a road trip that includes mid-century modern riverside cabins
PageType: three-star feasts and Japanese Gardens - all in Oregon’s Cascade Range Mountains where the state’s best-known rivers spill through timeless fir forests? Yes
PageLevel:
we will wait while you pack your bags.

If you’re traveling from the Portland airport
PageSectionID: take I-5 south to HWY 213/Silverton and you’ll quickly discover as you’re eating
ParentPage: drinking
Status: hiking and biking why this place is referred to as the “Pacific Wonderland”. From the Santiam Canyon to quaint towns like Sweet Home and Lebanon
InsertCode: this Northern Cascade road trip sweeps you under towering Douglas Firs of the Pacific Northwest and is perfect for traveling by car
IssuuCode:
bicycle or motorbike. 

On your way down south
HideFromNav: stop in at Abiqua Wind Vineyard
DisplayListings: owned by Pete and Marcia Buffington. Abiqua is a small estate vineyard and bonded winery located in the cascade foothills in Scotts Mills
AccountCatIDForListings: OR. The wines are vinted entirely in-house and their selection includes wonderful Pinot noirs and white wines including Pinot Gris
DisplayArticles:
Early Muscat and Black Muscat Rose. 

From Scotts Mills
PageLogo: you’ll pass the tempting  Elk Horn Golf Course in Mill City where you could stop in for a quick round before you hit the road on HWY 22 for an hour and a half trip to Detroit Lake. Detroit Lake is a great place to literally go jump in a lake or pitch a tent at the Detroit Lake Campground.. Eat lunch at The Kornerpost Cafe and Steelwheel Lounge
FeatureBlockTitle1:
complete with “motorcycle mania” memorabilia - or enjoy a meal with substantial portions in the vintage Cedars Restaurant & Lounge. 

Load up with snacks and hydration supplies six mile from Detroit at the Idanha General Store and continue on HWY 22 for an afternoon hike to the 5
FeatureBlockTitle2: 770 elevation Coffin Mt. Fire Lookout complete with a helipad. Warning: though scenic
FeaturedActivityTitle1: this trail has a 2.5 mile incline so be prepared for a worthwhile workout. There are ample opportunities to take breaks amidst wildflowers and vine maples
FeaturedActivityTitle2: and once you reach the summit you’ll be handed an incredible 360 view of the Cascade Range mountains
PartnerTitle:
including Mt. Jefferson and the Three Sisters.

Coffin Mountain Directions: 

  • From Detroit
PartnerText:
Oregon travel east on Highway 22 for approximately 19.5 miles to Forest Road 11 (Straight Creek Road).
  • Turn right on Forest Road 11
DisplayPartnerColumns:
travel for approximately 4 miles to Forest Road 1168. (Do not turn at first  Forest Road 1168 junction).
  • Turn right on Forest Road 1168
PartnerCityTitle:
travel for approximately 3.5 miles to the trailhead


Then head up HWY 22 for a half hour drive to Santiam Pass and merge westbound onto Highway 126 to reach Loloma Lodge on the McKenzie River.  At Loloma
VideoTitle1: newly renovated by current owner Wallis Simpson
VideoTitle2: which is available for group rentals and features sleeping lofts
MetaDescription: a reading room and adirondack chairs on the wraparound porch. Then head down to the bank of the river to park at your mid-century modern cabin featuring modern decor
SEOTags:
a full kitchen and ample sounds of the nearby riverside. 

Hungry after the hike? Head to the Mckenzie General Store and Obsidian Grill. What hiker wouldn’t be lured in by their slogan “hearty food that fuels the adventurer”? Their outdoor seating complete with horseshoe pit and live music is reason enough to visit
SeoNotes: the quirky personality of the store is enticing
SEOStatus: especially if you are a Big Lebowski fan. Don’t leave without feasting on McKenzie Burgers
ProposedHeaderText: onion rings and the chickpea salad from the handy grab n’ go section. The kids will enjoy the kombucha bar
ProposedBrowserTitle:
while you take in the vast microbrew selection. 

In the morning your breakfast/brunch eating options are threefold - the charming vintage Vida Cafe
ProposedMetaDescription: Takoda’s or McKenzie Station Restaurant. If you head to Takoda’s you’ll enjoy the handy bonus of a refueling stop at Blue Sky Market & Gas Station. The Market had a spectacular array of outdoor adventure items like an entire wall of fishing gear
SEOPaidBanner: a deli with delicious sandwich options
SEOPaidSocial:
groceries and even a plumbing/hardware tool section for the locals.

After Loloma Lodge
ContentType: it’s time to take HWY 126 North along the Santiam Wagon Trail Road to the pioneer towns of Sweet Home
CreationDate: Brownsville and Lebanon. But first consider a quick stop at Clear Lake where you can hike
AuthorUserID:
fishing tackle and rent row boats hourly at the resort store. 

After a drive down picturesque HWY 20  you’ll reach the town of Sweet Home
PublishDate:
just in time for a sweet treat. The vintage A&W offers rootbeer floats in truly vintage fashion – just pull up to the drive-in kiosk and order from the driver’s seat. If you’re hungry you’ll pass Spoleto’s Pizzeria & Wine Shoppe offering Italian fare and The Point Restaurant that overlooks Foster Reservoir.

Mark’s Ridge Winery is four miles from downtown Sweet Home and a visit is well worth that short distance. Owners of the 58 - acre estate
DataFinds:
Gewurztraminer and both Pommard and Wadenswill clone Pinot noir from their estate vineyard that features stunning views. 

After Mark’s Ridge
TopLanding:
take HWY 228 and 20 minutes later you’ll find yourself in historic Brownsville. Take a quick stroll of this picturesque downtown and you might find yourself having deja vu. Brownsville is well-known and draws tourists globally because it served as the filming site of the 1986 “Stand By Me” by director Rob Reiner. A museum downtown offers information and walking tours of the local sites commemorating the filming. 

Stroll down mainstreet and you’ll also discovered Brownsville’s newest additions
TopPageview: including Harper’s Winehouse. The brick building interior is lined with local and international wines and offered a delectable menu including stuffed mushrooms
AuditTransferPage:
and four flavors of homemade flatbreads to accompany your glass of wine. 

Kirks Ferry Trading Post Restaurant offers amazing smokehouse ribs and rib eye steak with sides of homemade mashed potatoes and fresh asparagus. On the greener side
AuditRefreshPage:
they have four delicious salads including Rogue River Steak and Blue cheese and a Western Cobb with grilled chicken. 

Call it a day by heading to Lebanon’s three-star Best Western Premier Boulder Falls Inn. You’ll get to renew in a room features a deluxe shower stall with four shower heads and a commanding view of the garden. All guest rooms are steps away from the lush one-acre Japanese-inspired garden
column58:
gazebos and a beautiful collection of koi. 

If you could use a nightcap try the Hideaway Distillery owned by the former Linn county sheriff Tim Mueller. Or make a stop at The Growler House
column60:
where local brewer Matt Cower brews the beer onsite and delivers delicious wood-fired pizza to hungry patrons. Try the beer sampler if you can’t decide.


"

PageDesc: Don't miss these 9 Dine-In Willamette Valley Farm Stands
NavButtonText: Don't miss these 9 Dine-In Farm Stands - old builders
HeaderText: Don't miss these 9 Dine-In Willamette Valley Farm Stands
ContentText: The rich
PageType: fertile soil of the Willamette Valley bursts with edible bounty. While wineries get much of the attention
PageLevel: the valley is checkered with acres of orchards and fields. Berries and vegetables thrive here
PageSectionID: nourished by abundant rain and long summer days. The small-scale agriculture paints an attractive landscape: Crops vary from mile to mile
ParentPage: flanked by the Coast Range to the west
Status:
and by the wooded foothills and snow-clad peaks of the Cascades to the east.

Many farm stands offer the delectable fruits of their labor for on-site enjoyment. From Marion berry milkshakes to strawberry shortcakes to peach pie
IssuuCode: handcrafted loaves to pizza topped with tomatoes and peppers from nearby fields
HideFromNav:
the dine-in farm stands of the Willamette Valley are worth a journey for their own sake.

Round up the family
DisplayListings: grab a cooler and a picnic basket and weave the wonderful Willamette Valley on secondary roads. This itinerary offers nine stops
AccountCatIDForListings: listed from north to south. Three hours of drive time takes you to all nine spots with barely any time spent careening down Interstate 5. Each stop lures you to linger over your food and enjoy colorful gardens
FeatureChildPages:
shops or nurseries. Call for hours and to verify what’s on the menu as the season unfolds.


1. Our Table - Sherwood
Our table in Sherwood is a cooperative farm and store on 58 acres
PageLogo: and flowers. The store deli case carries a revolving selection of savory and sweet items made on site
FeatureBlockTitle1: using farm-grown ingredients whenever possible. There’s indoor and outdoor seating
FeatureBlockTitle2: so make a meal of a pastured chicken pot pie
FeaturedActivityTitle2: seasonal kale salads and more. Beer
PartnerTitle: wine and kombucha are available on tap. If the u-pick is in season
PartnerText: take home some blueberries or raspberries. Friday nights 4-8PM
DisplayPartnerColumns: Our Table hosts a happy hour serving a seasonal menu
PartnerCityTitle:
starring brick oven artisan pizza in the summertime. Check their schedule for seasonal farm dinners served at long tables al fresco.

2. Bauman’s Farm & Garden – Gervais

Bauman’s attractions can entertain a family for hours
VideoTitle1: an elaborate playground and a huge nursery. Start at the bakery
SEOTags: donuts and more. Check out their many varieties of private label cider
SeoNotes: available on tap and by the bottle. Fudge
ProposedHeaderText: and ice cream round out the offerings
ProposedBrowserTitle: along with fresh produce and plenty of picnic supplies. Order a flight of cider for mom and dad and Marion berry turnovers for the kids and savor them in a gazebo overlooking a beautifully landscaped goldfish pond. When hunger and thirst are sated
ProposedMetaDescription: take some quarters to the petting zoo
SEOPaidSearch: where gumball machines dispense handfuls of grain to make quick friends with the herd of goats. Kids spend many a happy hour at Bauman’s: petting goats
ContentType:
and romping in the “nut house” – think ball pit with hazelnuts instead. They can even mine for real gemstones in a sluice. 

3. Jones Farm Produce - Salem

Jones Farm Produce is a simple shop with a simple mission: ice cream. Milkshakes
CreationDate: sundaes and shortcakes featuring seasonal fruit and Umpqua ice cream or frozen yogurt can be lapped up in shade or sun in front of the shop. Inside
ExpirationDate:
muffins and cookies and Jones’ own label of jams and syrups.

4. E. Z. Orchards Shortcake Stand – Salem

E.Z. Orchards Shortcake Stand opens in mid- to late-May with strawberries
IncludeInWidgets: then rolls through the season with mixed berries – Marion berries
DataFinds: raspberries and blueberries – in July and peaches in August. Fruit and whipped cream cascade over scoops of vanilla ice cream piled high on a tender split shortcake biscuit. Milkshakes star seasonal fruit or lavender-vanilla
TopLanding: flavored with their own flowers. Sundaes and dairy-free fruit smoothies round out the menu
TopPageview: along with Italian sodas concocted with fruit syrups. Pop into the adjacent store
AuditRefreshPage: fresh apple cider donuts or seasonal berry donuts. Also available: produce
column59: assorted gifts and kitchenware. Grab a bottle of their hard cider
column60: crafted from heirloom E. Z. Orchards apples. October brings families back for a Harvest Festival complete with caramel apples and pumpkin donuts
column63:
and more.

5. Willamette Valley Pie Co - Salem

Pie is the main event at Willamette Valley Pie Company: Two dozen varieties ensure you’ll want to grab a pie
column65: to take home. Their classic double-crust pie is a luscious vegan affair
column66: while other options have a buttery crunch topping. Get a slice a la mode
column67: or try their hand-mixed pie shake: Your choice of pie blended with vanilla ice cream
column68: left a little chunky to appreciate the crusty goodness. Strawberry and pineapple vegan soft serve alternatives satisfy the dairy-free crowd. Try a Marion berry muffin
column69: or a fruit-filled turnover. Feeling savory? Hot dogs are served outdoors in the summertime
column70: while the rest of the year
column71: house-made chicken pot pie and soups satisfy. Kids can run around on a big lawn and a play structure out front
column72:
and there are games and children’s books in the dining area for rainy days.

6. Aspinwall’s Produce and Café 22 West- Salem

Aspinwall’s produce stand
column74: has been offering seasonal fruit ice cream since the late 90’s. They serve soft vanilla and chocolate ice cream all summer
column75: along with rotating seasonal flavors as the summer unfolds. The strawberries and peaches that bookend the season are grown on site
column76: and the blueberries and raspberries come from neighboring farms. Try the waffle cone sundae: a crispy house-made cone filled with your choice of ice cream
column77: laid on a plate and lavishly dressed with fruit and whipped cream — big enough to share. Also available: shortcake with ice cream
column78: fruit and whipped cream; milk shakes; and pints to take home. Ready for a meal? Step next door to Café 22 West
column82: jams and syrups enhance café menu items from PBJs to waffles
column83:
and they’ll bring goodies from next door to your table.

7. Midway Farms  - Albany

Midway Farms has small-scale
column84: homespun charm. The entire farm is completely gluten-free
column85: so the baked goodies from the small farm store are guaranteed safe for sensitive eaters. Their own organic
column86: no-spray produce and home-grown eggs contribute to a perpetually rotating selection of baked goods like berry pie
column89: cookies and coffee cake. Choose a few goodies and some coffee or tea
column90: and enjoy them on the picnic table out front
column91: then stroll the walking paths and wander the gardens
column92: where Midway grows organic flowers for custom floral design. In the summertime
column93:
they offer day camp for kids aged 5-12.

8. Gathering Together Farm - Philomath

Plan on sitting down for a meal at Gathering Together Farm. Lunch
column94: dinner and Saturday breakfast are served during the growing season
column95: featuring Pacific Northwest cuisine influenced by French and Italian culinary traditions. Wood-fired pizza and housemade pasta make a toothsome foundation for grilled farm vegetables and inventive pestos and sauces. Pickled vegetables and handcrafted kraut
column96: crispy salads and soups complement locally produced meats
column99: plant-filled dining room has large windows with inviting views. On Tuesdays
column100: tour the grounds with a chef and a farmer. Check their website for monthly wine dinners and other special events. No time (or appetite) for a full meal? The farmstand has pastries
column101:
breads and potato donuts along with gorgeous certified organic produce from their 60 acres. Reservations recommended.

9. Camas Country Mill Schoolhouse Bakery and Store – Junction City

Camas Country Mill grows wheat
column102: grinds it on their stone-burr mills
column103: and sells the small batch artisan products at their bakery
column104: where they also craft delectable baked goods from their harvest. The menu changes with the seasons
column105: incorporating local crops such as roasted asparagus served with roast beef on 100% spelt bread. A vegetarian sandwich is always on the menu
column106: like their roasted spiced carrot with carrot tops
column107: sunflower seeds and Fern Ridge goat cheese. Summer brings salads and fall brings soups. Eat in the rustic-chic bakery
column108: or step next door to dine in the late 1800s one-room schoolhouse
column109: restored by owners Tom and Sue Hunton as a community asset. If the weather’s fine
column110: dine outside and admire the adjacent garden whose ingredients enliven the seasonal menu. Make sure to save room for a cookie — try the molasses ginger — or hand pie or coffee cake. Take a loaf home: the country loaf is 100% whole grain
column112: rye and einkorn. Harvest a souvenir of u-pick sunflowers in late summer

PageLevel: https://wvva.objects.liquidweb.services/photos/1022-eugene_gallowcoveredbrid_taylorhiggins3-680x300-thumb.jpg 300w\">The long and winding Willamette Valley is known as Oregon's world-class wine region
PageSectionID:
and it offers plenty of sip stops for sure. But it also beckons with easy access to some of the most rewarding cultural experiences and outdoor recreation in Oregon.

A full picture won't come into view until you pull off the main roads and ease your foot off the pedal: cruising along quiet lanes with farms and nurseries
ParentPage: taking in historic city centers on foot
Status:
or hiking or cycling through seemingly endless trails under covered bridges or to misty waterfalls.

If it is a memorable day trip you are looking for
HideFromNav: and scenic waterfalls to fill a month of Sunday drives. This fall we recommend you stay the weekend and attend one of our famous craft brew fests or hit up a hot spring or two - fit the right one for you here. There are plenty of hotels
AccountCatIDForListings: vintage trailers
SortOrder:
farm and vineyard stays to rest and restore.

Discover restaurants
FeaturedOnSectionLanding:
places to stay and more in the itineraries below or in our visitors guide. Use our map explorer and wine pages to find go-to destinations and build your own customized trip.

If you are researching wineries in a specific area view our wine resources page for additional information from our winery partners. 

Once you get to the Willamette Valley
DisplayArticles:
the hard part isn’t finding something to do. It’s finding a reason to tell your friends back home that you aren’t leaving.

NavButtonText: Oregon Cider Week, Art+Science Team Up for Virtual Happy Hour
